We have wet springs and autumns, stopping us from cultivating the soil and increasing fungal diseases and pests, and yet summers that produce wet air but dry ground - just when crops need water in good quantities at the base of the plant. Your roots - a guide to all-weather watering Never let weeds develop, primarily because they rob the growing plants of precious water and therefore upset the balance of the relationship between the water supply and your vegetables' needs. It is particularly mad to water an unweeded crop, as effectively all you are doing is feeding the weeds - which are supremely efficient at grabbing and using all available water. Mulch vegetables just as you mulch the borders. This suppresses weed growth, reduces evaporation and slows down the water supply - useful when we get days of rain. Root crops benefit particularly from a mulch, because the best way to water them is with a good soak about once every 10 days (which, given our weather, is likely to come from rain), but never to let the soil dry out. Even if it is very hot, a thick mulch will hold moisture for a week before you water again. Always water the base of any plant - but not as a general spray or mist of water, most of which will evaporate in hot weather or simply cool the plant rather than irrigate it. My roots The garden is currently riddled through with holes, like a lump of Gruyère cheese. Thousands of them. Voles are the culprit - voles by the thousand. I thought the flooding might have driven them away, but, instead, it seems to have created a subterranean vole ranch. The little sods nibble at the roots of everything, chew up tulip bulbs and, yesterday, I noticed that three-quarters of a quite large pleached lime had had its bark gnawed off just below ground level. Another couple of inches and it would have been killed. The cats catch dozens of them, which they deposit, headless, on the doorstep, but that will hardly dent the population. Voles tend to have population explosions, so I can only hope that this is the big bang and that there will be a few years of vole fall-out as a result. On the basis of know-your-enemy, I was reading everything I could about voles and discovered that an adult vole eats its own weight in dry food every week and, less surprisingly in light of this revelation, that they can pass over 1,000 droppings a day. Because we have had almost a week of frost, the ground is dry for the first time since September. Assuming that the weather will almost certainly be worse, I have been barrowing loads of mushroom compost all over the garden and making piles wherever it is likely to be needed. This is impossible in the wet, as the mess that a full barrow makes creates more harm than the good of the process. I used to belong to the 'mustn't-mulch-unless-the-soil-is-warm-and-wet' school, but have chucked that out. My New Year's resolution is: don't waste time on what you can't do, and do what you can do now. So, the borders get mulched in January frost and I am sure they will be fine, albeit colder for a little longer. Also, by the time that you read this I will have begun a long bout of filming - so I must get ahead of the jobs as and when I can, regardless of weather. I pruned the autumn-fruiting raspberries, which is one of those jobs that measure out January for me, in the same way that summer-pruning the espalier pears belongs to July. With the secateurs warmed up, I went round all the hornbeam hedges fine-pruning them. I did this last January and was surprised how much difference it made. Any deciduous hedge would do, and it means they enter the growing season at the right height and form, and also gives you a chance to give each plant the once-over.

webTitle: Mandelson and Blair go to war over 'lies'

fields.headline: Mandelson and Blair go to war over 'lies'
fields.standfirst:
PM aide casts doubt on ex-minister's state of mind | I should not have quit, says new Labour architect

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: War broke out last night between Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson, the two key architects of the New Labour Project, as the crisis over the passports-for-favours scandal threatened to plunge the government into chaos just months before a general election.
fields.byline: Antony Barnett, Kamal Ahmed, Martin Bright and Gaby Hinsliff
fields.body:
War broke out last night between Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson, the two key architects of the New Labour Project, as the crisis over the passports-for-favours scandal threatened to plunge the government into chaos just months before a general election.

The prime minister's officials and his former close confidant traded bitter attacks with each other as the recriminations between the pair intensified following Mandelson's sacking last week after it was revealed that he had lied about helping two Indian tycoons get British passports

The row erupted after senior Downing Street sources were authorised on Friday to tell The Observer that Mandelson was 'unfocused' and 'detached', suggesting he had a problem with his state of mind in recent weeks and that his 'unusual' behaviour ahead of his sacking last week had been noticed by key figures in Blair's administration.

The Downing Street source said Mandelson had lost his rapier-like attention to detail and his mind often seemed to be elsewhere. He signalled that Mandelson was no longer viewed as a leading thinker in New Labour and that it was time for him to take a break.

'He did not have the normal focus,' the official said. 'He's been a little bit like that for a while. He's fed up with it. He's kind of had enough.'

Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, later added to the controversy when he briefed Sunday lobby journalists. 'Part of the problem, and Peter would accept this, I think, is that there were things that Peter cannot explain, and cannot explain to himself,' Campbell said. 'I think he has been slightly detached.'

Asked if Mandelson's mental condition was similar to that of Ron Davies, who resigned after an encounter on Clapham Common in 1998, Campbell replied: 'I think it was.'

Mandelson, furious about the way he was being portrayed, agreed to write an article for today's Sunday Times, in which he said was not prepared to 'go quietly' and indicated that he felt he had been forced out after being summoned to attend a 'kangaroo court' with Blair last week.

'I am not a liar. I didn't lie,' he said, describing the 'horrible drama' which allowed him to be persuaded that 'I had erred and that I should resign.'

He added: 'What I did do was make the mistake of speaking out before establishing all the facts and rushing into last-minute interviews.

"This relatively trivial error was turned into a huge misjudgment that led to my resignation."

Rattled by the escalating crisis, Downing Street last night attempted to play down Campbell's attacks on Mandelson, insisting it would be a "grotesque misrepresentation" to suggest that there was any implication made that Mr Mandelson had been "detached" over anything other than the Hinduja issue.

A senior spokesman said: "In terms of Northern Ireland, he has been very focused and completely on top of the detail" and added that he did not intend to respond to today's comments by Mandelson.

"The Prime Minister and Peter Mandelson both set out the reasons for his resignation on Wednesday,' the spokesman said. 'We don't intend to give a line-by-line response to this article."

Campbell's comments and Mandelson's bitter retorts could prove costly to Labour in the run-up to a probable May election. By sacking the former Northern Ireland secretary three days after he lied to The Observer about his involvement in a passport application on behalf of the billionaire Hinduja brothers, Downing Street hoped to minimise the damage.

But Campbell's unprecedented briefing could backfire as the row showed no sign of abating. The fresh turmoil came as new revelations emerged about the links between the Hindujas and senior Labour party figures.

The Observer has discovered that Anji Hunter, one of Blair's most senior aides, had a meeting in autumn 1999 with Mandelson and the Hindujas. This came before Mandelson's questions into the citizenship inquiry of a third Hinduja brother, Prakash, in May 2000. At the time the Hindujas were at the centre of a corruption scandal in India. Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker said: 'We need to know who in Downing Street has met members of the Hinduja family, when and what was discussed. If Tony Blair is committed to open government he does not need to wait for the inquiry to provide us with this information.'

An Observer investigation has also discovered that:

 A senior Whitehall source claims Mandelson had other conversations' about the Hindujas' passport application beyond those so far admitted.

 Home Office officials have flatly contradicted the version of events Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz gave to The Observer last weekend about his involvement with the Hindujas.

 Ministers had been preparing a behind-the-scenes operation to deal with inquiries into the 'killer' parliamentary question on the Hindujas since before Christmas.

 The Home Office was fully aware of the bribery scandal surrounding the Hindujas when it approved Srichand's passport application.

 Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain was 'astonished' to find Gopichand Hinduja at a private Foreign Office party on 14 December, weeks after he was charged with corruption in India. Officials confirm he was not on the guest list.

Home Office sources have confirmed that the answer to Baker's parliamentary question, which uncovered the first details of Mandelson's involvement, went through at least six drafts and its wording was carefully agreed by Ministers. Mandelson, Vaz and Immigration Minister Mike O'Brien had been working on the answer for almost a month. Home Secretary Jack Straw was also consulted.

Last weekend Vaz insisted he had only inquired about Gopichand Hinduja, who received a passport in November 1997. But the Home Office has confirmed that Vaz made inquiries about both brothers.

Senior Whitehall sources have told The Observer that Mandelson had 'other conversations' about the Hinduja passport which will emerge in the Hammond inquiry set up to investigate the affair.

Sir Anthony Hammond QC has been appointed to carry out a judicial inquiry into the allegations, though Blair has prompted fury among backbenchers and opposition MPs by stating publicly that he believes Vaz has not done anything demonstrably wrong.

Claims that Ministers were unaware of the Hinduja brothers' business activities, currently at the centre of a massive corruption inquiry in India, were undermined last night when it emerged that British intelligence gave the Bank of England information about the Hindujas when the brothers applied for a banking licence in 1996.

Mandelson yesterday returned to London from his Hartlepool constituency, where he held talks with officials about whether he should stand as a candidate at the forthcoming election. Sources said he was determined to remain in politics.

webTitle: Showdown at White City

fields.headline: Showdown at White City
fields.standfirst:
A secret plan to carry advertising on a new BBC website has divided staff and outraged competitors, says Jamie Doward

MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: A secret plan to carry advertising on a new BBC website has divided staff and outraged competitors, reports Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
The plotters would meet several times a month in different locations across White City. And from tiny acorns huge oak trees grow. Throughout 1999 a small cabal of strategists had been given a simple task by then-Director General, John Birt - to work out how the BBC could turn the plethora of new technologies emerging at the time into cool, hard cash.

BBC insiders knew of the the group, but few were privy to their ideas. The plotters organised a series of clandestine conferences, all code-named 'Hever' and which were attended by some of the brightest brains advising the corporation. Their conclusions were fed back directly to Birt.

Auntie was nervous about what would happen if Hever's results leaked into the public domain. They exposed huge rifts at the heart of the BBC. In one corner was the old guard, opposed to an increasingly commercialised BBC. In the other was the younger contingent, who viewed the corporation as a fusty relic urgently in need of an overhaul.

Numerous plans were dreamt up. A free internet service provider was one option. But by the time the corporation got round to looking at launching a service, electrical retail giant Dixons had blown competitors out of the water with Freeserve. Then there was the proposal to float off the BBC's internet division on the stock market. But by the time Auntie had squared the move with her public service conscience the value of tech stocks had crashed and the move was dropped. 'The BBC has got the right idea but it's always been following the field. It takes a long time for it to make decisions and they all have to be given policy spins,' said one Hever source.

But some Hever plans are now finding their way on to the desk of Greg Dyke, the BBC's commercially savvy new sheriff, who is charged with finding Auntie an extra £400 million to meet the costs of programming between 2002 and 2006.

'John was always trying come up with a theoretical model to explain why we could do something commercial,' a BBC source said. 'Greg is much more, "f *** it, let's see what we can get away with".'

Last week it became clear just how far Dyke thinks he can go. The BBC admitted that it was studying a plan to display advertising on a yet-to-be built international news website, BBCNews.com. The announcement sent shock waves through the media world. Commercial rivals are screaming that what will start out as a bit of banner advertising on a website aimed at overseas internet surfers will quickly spread to all of the corporation's activities.

'This is the thinnest edge of the biggest wedge you could find. It cuts across all the things the BBC stands for,' said Angela Mills, director of the British Internet Publishers Association, the trade body that lobbies on behalf of online firms and which will argue its case at a Department of Culture, Media and Sport select committee meeting later this week.

The BBC's charter bans the corporation from allowing advertising on its television and radio stations but it is not clear about its position regarding new media. 'It's a grey area, and the BBC is exploiting it,' Mills said.

The commercial media's theory is that as the internet is quickly assimilated into all forms of media - chiefly television, mobile phones and radio - the corporation will have its cake and eat it. While it rakes in billions of pounds a year from licence fees, Auntie will also earn lots more from selling advertising on its new media - all the whizzy technologies that will allow viewers to watch favourite episodes of East Enders whenever they want.

This may seem a long way off, but the technology to merge the internet and television, known as broadband, is practically here. And by 2003, 21 per cent of European households will have broadband access, according to international media analyst Screen Digest.

The commercial firms fear that the BBC won't stop at advertising on its news sites. 'What are they going to do next? Sports? Entertainment?' Mills asked.

The commercial radio stations, which have increased their share of total UK advertising spend from 2 per cent to 6 per cent in the past five years, are up in arms at the prospect of seeing their revenues pour into the BBC.

'The BBC benefits from £3 billion of public money every year,' said Paul Brown, chief executive of the Commercial Radio Companies Association. 'It's a rampaging elephant and this could put the commercial sector at a huge disadvantage. There's only a limited amount of advertising to go round.'

The print media too, already angry at the shameless way the BBC has plugged its various magazines on its television channels, fears the consequences if Auntie's plan goes unchecked. 'I'm scandalised,' said Hugo Drayton, managing director of Hollinger Telegraph New Media, a division of Conrad Black's empire. 'It's down to weak government. They haven't done anything.'

The prospect of the Government stepping in to the row soon is seen as bleak. 'Chris Smith has indicated that he's prepared to conduct a review of the BBC's internet strategy,' Mills said. 'But you've got to be realistic. With a general election coming up, the Government doesn't want to take the BBC on. Chris Smith was always saying that he'd reduce the power of the governors, but the White paper did nothing to neuter them.'

BBC insiders argue that it makes sense for the corporation to commercialise its overseas operations. 'At least half the internet server traffic to BBC sites comes from overseas,' one source said. 'It's being subsidised by people in the UK, and that's not fair.'

But this would still hit UK firms. 'Half of Telegraph.co.uk's audience comes from outside the UK. The whole point of new media is that it reaches audiences you can't reach in print,' Drayton said.

Significantly, those who attended the Hever conferences believe that the fledgling plan for BBCNews.com to take ads is a red herring. The source said: 'The plan was for news and education elements to always be free of advertising. But everything else would be commercial outside the UK and take ads. I think this is some of the old guard trying to stop the plan by raising concerns about what it could mean to news, which has always been seen as sacrosanct.'

These plans have frightened everyone in media land - even Auntie herself.

webTitle: The vexed question of throwing bulks around

fields.headline: The vexed question of throwing bulks around
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: January 28: We're back to the problem of 'the incredible bulk' and the quagmire of newspaper circulation statistics. What's real and what's confected, asks Peter Preston?
fields.body:
It is either a holy war or an unholy muddle. We're back, one more time, to the problem of what the Guardian's Roy Greenslade calls 'the incredible bulk'; and thus to the quagmire of newspaper circulation statistics. What's real and what's confected?

Greenslade thinks he knows. Bulks are 'the piles of papers one finds at airports, fast-food outlets or betting shops. They are the papers left outside your hotel room or handed out as you get on to a plane.' These giveaways, he says, should 'not be regarded as real sales and should not form part of the headline total'. His own reporting of ABC monthly circulation totals will henceforth leave the bulks stacked to one side.

Fair enough? Sure, at first glance: sales are sales are sales. But journey a little further into this swamp and ask more basic questions. Who are these circulation figures for? What purpose are they intended to serve? Are they designed to make editors or publishers feel virtuous? To impress readers? Or to tell advertisers what they're getting for their money? There's no doubt, in history or current practice, where the crucial emphasis lies.

These statistics - together with the results of the National Readership Survey - are an advertising tool. Display ad rates, indeed, tend to be pegged to specific targets, so that if the Express or the Telegraph dips definitively below the 1 million mark the rates they can charge dip, too. Hard cash: hard times.

But here's a funny thing. Newspapers' use of bulks can vary hugely - in December the Daily Express churned out 52,000 a day and the Sun just 2,000 - but there is no hint of such discrepancies in the readership figures.

The number of readers per copy for the Telegraph (which is big on bulks) and the Guardian (which is traditionally small) does not seem one jot affected. Maybe a good deal with the right airline can nudge your AB business readership up a tad - marketing departments traditionally think so - but that's because the bulks BA or Virgin dole out have been read and the ads duly scanned.

A wide-awake advertising space buyer, in short, needs the NRS and the ABC together to have any clear take on value for money. Bulks don't affect such clarity. They are just part of the parcel - and ad agencies themselves are pretty used to bargain offers and direct mailings and samples (because customers use them all the time).That would not hold true, of course, if a reliance on bulks showed up on the NRS; but, if it doesn't, without obvious correlation, then there's not much to get steamed up about.

More confusingly still, consider the new growth of Associated's Metro titles, papers with national reach actually given away every morning. Roy Greenslade (like other commentators) admires the progress they've made: a guaranteed 1 million distributed every morning isn't so far away. Yet what, in truth, is the difference between a pile of Metros outside your railway station and a pile of Daily Mails in your hotel lobby? Associated doesn't draw any moral lines: it aims to make profits either way.

There used to a rough rule of thumb that held that something the customer paid for was more valuable than something that cost nothing: thus, that ads in paid-for papers were more valuable than those in the frees. But it's difficult to run that distinction any longer. Take New York this winter (finally catching up on the Metro wave). Is an ad in the Express there (the Daily News ' new afternoon subway freesheet) worth almost nothing, while an ad in Rupert Murdoch's Post has suddenly become worth much more? The Express distributes 125,000 copies a day; the Post , meanwhile, costs 25 cents, just half of what it did before the freesheet competition began.

webTitle: Lastminute stalls as rivals pile in

fields.headline: Lastminute stalls as rivals pile in
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com is feeling the heat from rivals that have attacked its market share over the past 12 months, writes Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, the beleaguered e-tailer, is feeling the heat from the scores of new online competitors that have emerged to attack its market share in the past 12 months.

Figures soon to be released by global internet research firm Jupiter MMXI show that over the crucial Christmas period Lastminute failed to expand what is known in the industry as its 'reach' - the company's share of the total internet population.

The company's website attracted more than 500,000 visitors last December, 200,000 more than in the same month the previous year.

But as more and more consumers have ventured onto the internet over the last year, Lastminute's reach has remained static. Jupiter's research shows that the company's share of the internet population in December was 4.2 per cent, only 0.1 per cent up on its position the previous Christmas.

Alternative figures released by Nielsen/NetRatings show that in June last year Lastminute was attracting more than 485,000 visitors - but this had fallen to 354,000 by December.

Nick Jones, senior analyst with Jupiter, said: 'The good news is it hasn't gone down. That would have been very disappointing. But the question is what group are they targeting?

'It was popular with early adopters but can it go mass market? Maybe it has already reached that segment of the market it will ever reach.'

Jones said Lastminute's failure to expand its market share was a result of fierce competition.

'There are more people online now, but there are also many more purchasing options,' Jones said. 'All the traditional retailers are online now; you don't have to visit Lastminute.'

Earlier this month the company told The Observer it was happy with its Christmas trading figures and would give a fuller update at its next set of results.

However, concerns over whether its business can permeate the mass market, crucial if the company is ever to justify its once-massive £500 million valuation, continue to linger.

The company has seen its share price slide from a year high of 555p to 79p now.

webTitle: Sky Digital 'dumps' ITV

fields.headline: Sky Digital 'dumps' ITV
fields.standfirst: The bitter war between BSkyB and ITV exploded last night after sources said it had gone cold about taking the  network on Sky Digital
fields.trailText: The bitter war between BSkyB and ITV exploded last night after sources said it had gone cold about taking the network on Sky Digital, writes Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
The bitter war between BSkyB and ITV exploded last night after sources close to the satellite broadcaster said it had gone cold about taking the terrestrial network on Sky Digital.

In a dramatic U-turn, industry insiders said BSkyB was 'reassessing the benefit' of having the commercial network on the platform after ITV's recent disappointing viewing figures. Last year ITV commanded a peaktime share of 37.1 per cent of the audience; its target was 38.5 per cent.

The move would shock the media industry because BSkyB has been trying desperately to woo ITV on to its platform for months in order to attract viewers as yet unconvinced about digital television.

In the past the satellite company has expressed outrage that although ITV and ITV2 are on ONdigital, the pay-TV platform jointly owned by Carlton and Granada, the network has so far refused to sign up to Sky Digital.

In recent months senior executives at Carlton and Granada, the two largest ITV franchise holders, have started to make conciliatory noises about doing so as evidence emerged that the network's viewing figures were slipping because of the stand-off. 'It's always been a question of when, not if,' one source said.

But BSkyB now believes it may make more commercial sense to add to the network's woes by dropping plans for it to come on to Sky Digital. This could hurt ITV, now desperate to reverse its declining audience, by restricting its potential market. It could also be an attempt by BSkyB to force it to agree a lower price for putting ITV and ITV2 on Sky Digital.

'BSkyB is now having second thoughts about ITV coming on to Sky Digital. It is reconsidering whether it really will be of benefit to have ITV on the platform before the analogue shutdown,' a BSkyB insider said. The satellite firm's apparent change of mind leaves the future landscape of digital television uncertain.

By law Sky Digital will have to take ITV once analogue services are switched off. But industry experts believe this won't happen until 2006 at the earliest.

'There's no reason why BSkyB should help ITV,' a BSkyB source said. 'OK, it's got to happen at the time of the analogue switch-off, but it now believes there's no need for it to accelerate that.'

webTitle: Comment: Richard Rogers: UK cities victim to gross neglect

fields.headline: Our urban phoenixes
fields.standfirst: Cash needed for cities to rise from the scorched earth of the Tories
fields.trailText: Cash needed for cities to rise from the scorched earth of the Tories.
fields.body:
Ninety per cent of the UK population lives in cities, and these cities should be our power centres. But decades of neglect and under-investment means they are in the hands of local councils which do not have the expertise to champion urban change. Revitalising city centres is a lengthy process (Barcelona's success took 15 years) and unless the Government takes action, our cities will remain pale shadows of their European counterparts. Last year's Urban White Paper promised to make urban renaissance a priority: will the Labour Party Manifesto now deliver?

The good news is that Labour recognises that the built environment has a huge impact on our quality of life. The bad news is that the Conservative's 'scorched earth' urban policy has left a terrible legacy.

Our cities are fragmented, poorly designed and socially divisive. Worse, the wilful destruction of local government by successive Tory governments has decimated planning and architecture departments, resulting in a desperate shortage of analytical skills. Without these skills, councils will be unable to construct coherent plans. In Europe, local government employs three times as many architects and planners as does Britain. With such a severe skills deficit, we run the risk of repeating the misguided post-war social engineering that wreaked havoc throughout Britain.

An important first step is the Government's support for a new urban agenda and Tony Blair's commitment to the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment (CABE), which champions design quality across all areas of government. Equally, John Prescott's Urban White Paper and Gordon Brown's fiscal support have encouraged the transformation of derelict buildings and brownfield sites into vibrant live-work communities - a welcome change. So far so good. But without key analytical skills at local level it will be impossible to transform into reality the Government vision of compact, mixed-use, well sustainable cities.

Not enough time or funds are being fed into the equation. In Sheffield, Manchester, Liverpool and Hull the story is the same. There are initiatives to turn deprived areas into models of sustainable regeneration, but supervising these demands specific experience in the art of managing urban change - which most agencies do not have.

The city is man's most complex artefact, yet most urban regeneration briefs never include serious research of basic social, economic and physical factors. As a result, architects and urban designers are being invited to bid for projects that are consistently under-resourced. Because there is so little understanding of the role of the design professions, the level of resources committed to large-scale projects is usually inadequate. Without financial backing, fee structures will remain low, limiting input from professionals in the private sector who might otherwise raise the calibre of the schemes.

European countries tackle the problem very differently. Many have Cabinet Ministers responsible for cities, while experienced local architecture centres and planning departments collaborate with communities, politicians and developers - which has an impact on all urban projects. In Europe it is the norm for city authorities to commission well-researched briefs from top consultancies and universities before design briefs are handed out.

If the Government wants to avoid a major urban debacle it must look to Europe and start addressing problems of urban decay and deprivation immediately. Later this year, CABE will publish a 'tool-kit' for public agencies and client organisations on how to write a good brief, obtain experienced advice and procure designers with appropriate skills. This is a useful start, but CABE itself is woefully underfunded and the Government must now guarantee three things.

First, a network of Regional Resource Centres for Urban Development attached to universities, as recommended by the Urban Task Force and proposed in the DETR's Urban White Paper. These centres are vital if we are to promote innovation and best practice, coordinate urban development training and encourage community participation in the regeneration process. As yet no action has been taken.

There should be a five-year programme of international secondments offering a minimum of 2,000 professionals exposure to international best practice in urban design.

And finally, there has to be a commitment to provide realistic funds enabling government departments as well as national and regional regeneration companies to deliver the goods. Sufficient fiscal support will allow chief executives of local authorities, urban regeneration companies and community organisations to get advice from professional bodies, universities and specialist consultants before they set out on initiatives for sustainable urban change.

The UK has an urban policy that has been the victim of gross neglect for decades. Unless we harness the proper skills, resources and vision now, it could continue to be a nightmare.

webTitle: Homeless left out in the cold

fields.headline: Homeless left out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Edinburgh's rough sleepers face care crisis despite £10 million boost from government project
fields.trailText: Edinburgh's rough sleepers face care crisis despite £10 million boost from government project.
fields.body:
The decision could not have come at a worse time for Julie. The 17-year-old had managed to find a precious place in a homeless hostel in Edinburgh, the first step to getting her off the streets and away from the life of prostitution and minor drug abuse she was beginning to drift into. Then she was caught using heroin and alcohol in the hostel and the lifeline of a bed indoors was immediately torn away .

Although she pleaded to be allowed to stay in the hostel, although she explained that was the first time she had touched heroin and promised never to touch it again, although she told staff about the prostitution, about being attacked in the street, about her terror at the prospect of being roofless again, Julie was given 48 hours. She had broken the rules once, and that was as many chances as she was going to get.

Julie's experience is just one of many harrowing cases to be revealed this week in a groundbreaking study of Edinburgh's struggle to get to grips with its homelessness problem. The report, which has been seen by The Observer ahead of its publication tomorrow, paints a grim picture: despite a £10m cash injection from the Government's much-trumpeted Rough Sleepers' Initiative, the city's claims of success in tackling the issue are undermined by evidence of woefully inadequate hostel and care provision, spiralling drug abuse and an appalling toll of preventable deaths.

The most disturbing finding of all is that Edinburgh's problems are far from unique; in towns and cities across the UK, those forced to sleep outdoors are facing the same uphill battle for a roof as their counterparts in Edinburgh.

The Government launched its Rough Sleepers' Initiative in 1997 with the aim of getting homeless people into accommodation so that by the end of 2003 rough sleeping would be eradicated. Halfway down the line, the new study, carried out by the Edinburgh Streetwork Project (ESP) with the backing of Shelter Scotland over the course of 12 months, is a graphic illustration of just how much more needs to be achieved before that target is met. 'The findings were not a shock to us in the respect that we are working on these streets every day,' Tam Hendry, the ESP's general manager and one of the report's authors, told The Observer .

'The shock has been how difficult it has been to communicate the scale of the problem and have it taken seriously.

'Edinburgh happened to be the city we looked at, but other places cannot afford to sit back and be complacent. The issues we identify will be repeated across the country. The problem with a national strategy aiming to reduce rough sleeping by a set date is that there is a tendency to go for simplistic, one-size-fits-all solutions. In fact, the situation is far more complex.'

Since being awarded £10m from the Rough Sleepers' Initiative, Edinburgh has managed to cut the number of people sleeping on the streets at any one time by about 100.

But the study, the first in-depth examination of the initiative in practice anywhere in the country, reveals that these gains may be less impressive than they appear at first glance. In fact, the report shows that the number of hostel beds available in the city has gone down by about 130 since 1997. According to the city council, this should be a matter of celebration, proof that fewer people are in need of emergency accommodation. But translate that figure into harsh experience for those trying to get off the street and the full meaning becomes clear.

Between April and October 1999, only 14 per cent of those ESP workers referred to a hostel managed to find a bed. The report found that, over a three-month period between May and July that year, there was only a one-in-four chance of finding a vacancy. For men, there were only eight days per month when a vacancy was available; for women, there was one vacancy every day in May, 15 days in June and only six in July.

'It is unforgivable that Edinburgh has reduced the number of hostel bed spaces,' said Hendry. 'We appreciate that the council is aiming to provide quality accommodation, and that there are problems with property prices and the not-in-my-backyard attitude, but they are going to have to, as a matter of priority, get the number of beds up so people at least have somewhere to go to get off the street.'

So if those sleeping rough cannot get hostel accommodation, how has Edinburgh managed to reduce the numbers? The report shows that this success may, in large part, be accounted for by a similar increase in the numbers of those spending the night in 24-hour centres without sleeping facilities. A considerable number used the Cowgate Centre, in the heart of the Old Town, for example. It has a café, television room and pool table. But no beds.

'It is like something out of Victorian times,' said Hendry. 'People crushed up on chairs or lying on the floor trying to sleep and stay warm. It is progress in that people are not outside, but it is very tenuous progress. They are only a step away from the street, and that is not enough.'

The implications for the homeless of not being unable to find a hostel space are more serious than being forced to spend another freezing night outdoors, according to Liz Nicholson, director of Shelter Scotland.

'Being turned away from hostels or services is a frustrating experience for anyone, but more so if you literally have nowhere else to turn. Except maybe to your "new best friend" who is more interested in developing your drug habit than solving your housing problems.' This fact is confirmed all too conclusively by the report. Workers at ESP received twice as many requests for help in relation to drugs problems between April and October 2000 than they did in the same period in 1999. There was almost a 20 per cent increase in those seeking help for heroin abuse; 65 per cent of whom were from people under 35 and 35 per cent were from those under 25. But as Julie's case proved, many of the hostels are either unwilling or not equipped to cope.

'The problem is that the wrong thinking has been applied to the provision of hostel care, particularly for young people,' Hendry said. 'The attitude is that when people manage to access accommodation, they should take what they are given and they should abide by the rules, otherwise they are out. There is a completely intolerant attitude and that will require a big cultural change.' For those who are left on the streets, especially vulnerable young people with drugs or mental health problems, the outlook remains bleak, despite the £10m investment. Over the course of the last 17 months, 14 homeless people have died in Edinburgh, an appalling death rate of almost one a month.

For Hendry and other drugs workers, this is the evidence that is most difficult to deal with. 'The hardest thing about this job is having people you have been working with, and trying to help, die. You can tell who is going to be next because they are not getting the support they need, but there is nothing you can do about it. That is why the Rough Sleepers' Initiative has to be made to work.'

In fact, the report shows that the number of hostel beds available in the city has gone down by about 130 since 1997. According to the city council, this should be a matter of celebration, proof that fewer people are in need of emergency accommodation. But translate that figure into harsh experience for those trying to get off the street and the full meaning becomes clear. Between April and October 1999, only 14 per cent of those ESP workers referred to a hostel managed to find a bed. The report found that, over a three-month period between May and July that year, there was only a one-in-four chance of finding a vacancy. For men, there were only eight days per month when a vacancy was available; for women, there was one vacancy every day in May, 15 days in June and only six in July. 'It is unforgivable that Edinburgh has reduced the number of hostel bed spaces,' said Hendry. 'We appreciate that the council is aiming to provide quality accommodation, and that there are problems with property prices and the not-in-my-backyard attitude, but they are going to have to, as a matter of priority, get the number of beds up so people at least have somewhere to go to get off the street.' So if those sleeping rough cannot get hostel accommodation, how has Edinburgh managed to reduce the numbers? The report shows that this success may, in large part, be accounted for by a similar increase in the numbers of those spending the night in 24-hour centres without sleeping facilities. A considerable number used the Cowgate Centre, in the heart of the Old Town, for example. It has a café, television room and pool table. But no beds. 'It is like something out of Victorian times,' said Hendry. 'People crushed up on chairs or lying on the floor trying to sleep and stay warm. It is progress in that people are not outside, but it is very tenuous progress. They are only a step away from the street, and that is not enough.' The implications for the homeless of not being unable to find a hostel space are more serious than being forced to spend another freezing night outdoors, according to Liz Nicholson, director of Shelter Scotland. 'Being turned away from hostels or services is a frustrating experience for anyone, but more so if you literally have nowhere else to turn. Except maybe to your "new best friend" who is more interested in developing your drug habit than solving your housing problems.' This fact is confirmed all too conclusively by the report. Workers at ESP received twice as many requests for help in relation to drugs problems between April and October 2000 than they did in the same period in 1999. There was almost a 20 per cent increase in those seeking help for heroin abuse; 65 per cent of whom were from people under 35 and 35 per cent were from those under 25. But as Julie's case proved, many of the hostels are either unwilling or not equipped to cope. 'The problem is that the wrong thinking has been applied to the provision of hostel care, particularly for young people,' Hendry said. 'The attitude is that when people manage to access accommodation, they should take what they are given and they should abide by the rules, otherwise they are out. There is a completely intolerant attitude and that will require a big cultural change.' For those who are left on the streets, especially vulnerable young people with drugs or mental health problems, the outlook remains bleak, despite the £10m investment. Over the course of the last 17 months, 14 homeless people have died in Edinburgh, an appalling death rate of almost one a month. For Hendry and other drugs workers, this is the evidence that is most difficult to deal with. 'The hardest thing about this job is having people you have been working with, and trying to help, die. You can tell who is going to be next because they are not getting the support they need, but there is nothing you can do about it. That is why the Rough Sleepers' Initiative has to be made to work.'

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Boris in a spin
fields.body:
Boris in a spin

Don't bet on Boris Johnson bagging the transport brief as an MP. The Spectator editor's love of automobiles puts Two Jags to shame and he regularly test drives cars for his column in GQ; last Sunday he took a Ferrari 456GT for a spin.

Unfortunately, on the way home he ran out of petrol. In the fast lane of the M40. In the end, the police had to pick him up. Sadly, this has not been the only blot on his copybook at GQ.

His crimes include: 1. Running up £1,100 in parking fines - publisher Condé Nast now refuses to pay. 2. Damaging alloy wheels (£1,000 apiece) on a Nissan Skyline. 3. Scratching a top-of-the-range Alfa Romeo.

Needless to say, the Ferrari also suffered a 'slight' scratch after Boris's big day out.

McEwan's extra-strong expert

Media dons love popping up in print to share their vast experience. And few are more ready to pop up than Professor Yvonne McEwan of Fife University, apparently an expert on counselling. One of her first appearances in print was in the Daily Mail on 1 October 1997, where she claimed: 'Professional counselling is largely a waste of time.' This article was based on a September 1997 piece in the Telegraph , where McEwan opined: 'Counselling does more harm than good.'

In the same month the omnipresent McEwan repeated these views in the Evening Standard; her opinion was recycled in a caustic tirade by Victor Lewis-Smith in the Mirror on 5 August 2000.

The professor turns up in Dr Phil Hammond's Daily Express column for 14 November 2000; Lynda Lee Potter, in the Daily Mail, has repeatedly quoted McEwan - 'Evidently counselling people after a tragedy can do more harm than good' - most recently on 11 January.

Tragically, for those who need a drop of McEwan to pep up their copy, Fife University does not exist.

There is a Fife College. Its controversial director of trauma management recently resigned after being criticised by medical professionals who questioned her qualifications and expertise. McEwan, for it was she, gave no reason for leaving but has been banned from using the titles of professor and doctor. Indeed, the college admitted she had no academic degrees and said the post was non-academic. All very traumatic. Perhaps McEwan could use some counselling.

Express in the management's lap

Smashing to see the management problems at the Express solved. But Media Diary wonders if owner Richard Desmond reads the paper's business section. Last week there was a fascinating report about SFI group, which is flogging off its lap-dancing clubs: 'The company has come under pressure to sell the three clubs as many investors find them ethically unappealing.' Pots? Kettles?

Mixed messages

Solemn leader in the Sunday Times business section last week. It attacked the backers of Huntingdon Life Sciences which pulled the plug because of protests from animal rights campaigners. 'The result is that each of these companies has caved in to terrorism.'

In the same section, the paper was delighted to announce this year's sponsor of the Sunday Times business enterprise awards: the Royal Bank of Scotland which, um, deserted HLS earlier this month.

webTitle: The Observer Profile: Dominic Lawson

fields.headline: A spy who never was
fields.standfirst:
You can accuse the editor of the Sunday Telegraph of many things - being a stickler, hard to please and a demanding boss. But a former MI6 agent? Never

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: You can accuse the editor of the Sunday Telegraph of many things - being a stickler, hard to please and a demanding boss. But a former MI6 agent? Never.
fields.body:
As an 11-year-old boy, Dominic Lawson held a small glass under the bleeding foot of his sister Thomasina who had been cut in an accident. That night, he placed the vessel on the window sill of his bedroom, overlooking a graveyard, in order to see if vampires would pay him a visit. Even for a boy with the initials DRCL - Dracula without the vowels, as detractors point out - the gesture was curious. But it hardly meant the eccentric 11-year-old should inevitably one day graduate to a world of invisible ink, poisoned dart umbrellas and telephone box assignations on the platforms of suburban railway stations.

Lawson, editor of the Sunday Telegraph and former editor of the Spectator, has always attracted attention. Part of a family with a constellation of contacts - his father is politician Nigel and his sister the columnist and cookery writer Nigella - he has already been mythologised as a sharp, demanding Fleet Street operator at just 44. With an eclectic circle of friends and interests, he inspires strong reactions for not always predictable views.

The most vehement reactions this weekend have been from Lawson himself, accused once again of being an assistant to the security services. Lawson is not just another journalist, according to aggrieved ex-MI6 agent Richard Tomlinson. In an improbable memoir, The Big Breach, now published in Russia, Tomlinson elaborates on claims he first made in 1998, that a newspaper editor is 'Smallbrow', provider of cover to MI6 operatives in troublespots abroad. One MI6 officer allegedly posed as a Spectator freelancer when on an undercover mission to Estonia, with the assistance of the Spectator 's then editor. And Tomlinson himself now insists he was given a letter of introduction by Lawson when he too posed as a Spectator contributor, on a covert mission to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

The use of journalistic credentials as a cloak for espionage is hardly a new modus operandi. (Fastidious Observer readers will be the first to point out that half a century ago Kim Philby used his credentials from this paper as cover too.) But the entirely unproven claim deeply damages Lawson, not only because he has built his career on the basis of being one sceptical step apart from the establishment with which he is so well connected. Much more worrying is the fate that might await a reporter carrying a bona fide commission from him in, say, Kabul or Baghdad.

'It is complete rubbish that I gave journalistic cover to an MI6 officer who wanted to go to Tallin,' insisted a furious Lawson. He does admit to some embarrassment that an 'aid worker' in Kosovo penned two pieces for the Spectator in 1994, countering widespread sympathy for the Bosnian Muslims by emphasising that atrocities had occurred 'on all sides', a view the Foreign Office was keen to promote. It turned out that 'Kenneth Roberts' worked for the security services. 'I simply didn't know,' Lawson insists.

But Lawson's most awkward moment came two years ago, when Labour MP Brian Sedgemore named him in Parliament as an MI6 operative. The suggestion, again made without the benefit of any corroborating evidence, was popular at the time - few on the Left forget that it was Lawson who exposed Guardian journalist Richard Gott as on the payroll of the KGB. Sedgemore declined to repeat the claim without Parliamentary privilege.

But in a catalogue of supposition, rumour and innuendo, there appears to be no evidence whatsoever suggesting that Lawson is a spy. Now his most helpful demonstration of support has come from an unlikely source. Tomlinson's book, as is de rigueur with new publications, is spiced with further celebrity 'revelations'. Not only was Lawson an MI6 agent, it claims, Nelson Mandela was too. Yesterday Mr Mandela condemned the work as a 'disgraceful fabrication'.

Lawson remains a prickly enigma, even to those close to him. For the last decade he has been married to Rosa Monckton, the Asprey & Garrard boss whose salary is reported to match that of her partner. The marriage has - according to one friend - been the making of Lawson. 'It was instantaneous. They went off to dinner after a party and never looked back.'

Rosa hosts dinners at which close friends - including the Hagues, Michael Howard and Ruby Wax - are entertained assiduously. 'Rosa is a source of much subtle influence upon him,' says a regular diner. 'You can see her expanding his horizons very determinedly.'

Monckton also introduced Lawson to her friend Diana, Princess of Wales. On one occasion, the high windows of London's Kensington Gardens twinkled with the reflection of opera glasses as Lawson accompanied the Princess for a stroll, appearing to advise and counsel. The relationship will have come more easily to Monckton, whose grandfather counselled Edward VIII during his abdication crisis, keeping the Windsors on side at the same time.

Lawson does play the gentleman, not always to the satisfaction of some more socially demanding acquaintances. He has been spotted in London wearing 'bright straw-coloured corduroys', an unforgivable faux pas in the eyes of some. But while enjoying life in the inside lane, Lawson is undoubtedly an outsider too. There has never been a full explanation of why he left Eton after one term for the more cerebral Westminster. 'He was unhappy, that's that,' says Nigella. But in the political party and society to which he was born, anti-semitism is not unknown.

Personal tragedy may well have hardened him. His mother died early, of cancer, as did his sister, Thomasina. His brother-in-law, John Diamond, is dying of throat cancer.

Lawson is also driven, as are many sons of the successful, by a wish to be not just loved but also admired by his father. 'After some of his greatest scoops, he has rung Nigel just hoping for a word of acknowledgement,' disclosed a friend. 'It's pointless. The irony is that Nigel will tell us happily how proud he is of Dominic.'

Lawson père was once editor of the Spectator too, but his son appeared to set a driven agenda during his tenure in the same job. An interview with Nicholas Ridley, in which Ridley disclosed his view of Germans, led to the Minister's resignation. Disclosure of Lord Denning's view of the Guildford Four and the Birmingham Six - 'easier if they had been hung' - led to humiliation for the former Master of the Rolls. 'These people were hardly innocents abroad,' points out a Lawson admirer, 'but Dominic drew blood.'

Since his appointment to the Sunday Telegraph in 1995, Lawson has shown a firm touch. He has written successfully - although not exploitatively - about the birth of his daughter Domenica, who has Down's Syndrome. But a story count for the last 12 months yields 15 times as many hits for 'prostitution' and 'cocaine' as for 'common agricultural policy', efforts at popularisation which have driven up sales. 'To Dominic, it's all showbusiness,' says a loyal staffer. 'He wants to get his paper right. I'm a great believer that he has tabloid instincts.' If the editorship on a broadsheet does not become vacant in the next five years, perhaps it will be the Daily Mail - or a Daily Express owned by the Telegraph - to which Lawson brings his tabloid skills. Spookier things have happened.

Dominic Lawson

DoB: 17 December 1956

Job: Editor, Sunday Telegraph

Previous jobs: Researcher, BBC; journalist on FT, Sunday Correspondent, Daily Telegraph; editor, Spectator

Married to: Hon Rosamond Mary Monckton (two daughters: Savanah and Domenica)

Recreation: Chess

Clubs: Garrick, MCC

webTitle: Letters to the Editor

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.trailText: I am writing in response to two articles about deep vein thrombosis by your reporter John Sweeney (14 January).  We take issue with Dr Egerton's comments that it is 'grotesquely misleading' to highlight the 'Chest' study.
fields.body:
In-flight health

I am writing in response to two articles about deep vein thrombosis by your reporter John Sweeney.

We take issue with Dr Egerton's comments - reported by Mr Sweeney (14 January) - that it is 'grotesquely misleading' to highlight the 'Chest' study. The justification by Dr Egerton is that 'it was done in Nantes, a provincial city which has no international airport - so no wonder there are so few cases of air-related DVT'. To suggest inhabitants of a provincial town do not travel on long-haul flights is ludicrous.

The claim we are not allowing doctors access to our passengers is misleading. We are in discussion with research institutions in the UK and mainland Europe and, in the case of Dr Patrick Kesteven, have assisted his research and continue to do so.

The claim that BA has 'only just' responded to the issue by advising passengers of the risks of DVT is not true. We support the need to provide accurate health information and advice. For many years BA has provided passengers with just such information, including exercises that can be done while seated. The airline's 'Well Being' programme has been in operation since 1993.
Dr D J C Flower
British Airways
Harmondsworth
Middx

Postal blunder

Does no one in the Post Office worry about the fun our Euro partners could make of our new name for the Post Office? 'Consignia' is close to 'Consigne' (French) and 'Consigna' (Spanish), meaning left luggage office!
Marian Nicholson
London W4

Cash flow

I would like to clarify two points in the otherwise accurate profile of me by Rosalind Golding (Cash, last week). First, I only became financially independent at 18. Until then, I was partly dependent on my elder brother to whom I owe a great debt. Second, I wouldn't want to exaggerate the modesty of my current lifestyle. I earn enough for my needs and live in a three- not one- bedroom flat.
Yasmin Alibhai-Brown
London W5

HLS on film

Your article on Huntingdon Life Sciences (Comment, last week) mentioned the investigation in 1997 which led to the current campaign by anti-visectionists. One important finding of that investigation is that minimally-trained 'technicians' were openly filmed falsifying data for HLS' customers. That HLS knowingly allowed human health to be endangered proves that not only were the animals' deaths worthless, the results may have distorted the true toxicity of the substance involved.
Anne Marie Moynihan
Hove
E Sussex

webTitle: How the two sides traded blows

fields.headline: How the two sides traded blows
fields.standfirst: Mandelson on  Number 10
fields.trailText: In an article in today's Sunday Times, Peter Mandelson claimed that he agreed to quit his Cabinet job in a moment of personal weakness and vowed to clear his name. These are edited extracts of his article:
fields.body:
In an article in today's Sunday Times, Peter Mandelson claimed that he agreed to quit his Cabinet job in a moment of personal weakness and vowed to clear his name. These are edited extracts of his article:

The version of events widely believed about the circumstances leading to my resignation is inaccurate, misleading and untrue. I believe Sir Anthony Hammond's report will dramatically change public perception about those events.

At the time, in 1998, I was working hard to make a success of a very difficult public project, the Millennium Dome. I wasn't dealing with the Hindujas for myself but for this public project. There was no personal gain. I probably saw them at least half a dozen times, some times for 20 minutes or less. I do not remember when they first raised the question of S P Hinduja's desire for British nationality. The contact with the Home Office was fleeting, inconsequential and harmless. I was not asking for any special treatment [for the Hindujas]. I had done nothing wrong. I had nothing to hide.

I was surprised to learn of The Observer's front page story. Alastair Campbell phoned me, and I told him the story amounted to nothing, that I had given a quote, and that Number 10 could use that in response to further press inquiries _

Alastair Campbell had said to journalists earlier [on Monday] that I had had no personal involvement in the naturalisation inquiry; but Mike O'Brien contacted [Campbell] to point out the personal telephone conversation he remembered me having with him that year _ I am sure he acted on the basis of his recollections.

I agreed that a correction must be made at the following morning's lobby briefing of journalists - even though I was aware of the dangers, where journalists are concerned, of appearing to change your story.

At 4.30 [on Tuesday] I was told that the story was really taking off. My original comment to The Observer and the Downing Street story seemed to be at odds. After a very quick discussion with Alastair Campbell, I decided to deal with the story myself by doing interviews there and then _

On Wednesday I awoke with a shrieking media lynch mob, some of them branding me a liar. I am not a liar. I did not lie. What I did do was make the mistake of speaking out before establishing all the facts and rushing into last-minute interviews.

This relatively trivial error was turned into a huge misjudgment that led to my resignation.

When I went in to see the Prime Minister at 10.15am, I was told that an independent inquiry into the original passport application was to be set up immediately. It was our feeling that, in the time it would take to set out the facts, great damage would be done to me and the Government _ the 11 o'clock press lobby was assembling and a decision from me was required. For the first time and I hope the last time in my life, the fight suddenly went out of me _

webTitle: Port in despair as fishermen get hooked on heroin

fields.headline: Port in despair as fishermen get hooked on heroin
fields.standfirst:
The young men in Fraserburgh's fleet blow their wages on smack, making the Scottish town Britain's drug capital

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The young men in Fraserburgh's fleet blow their wages on smack, making the Scottish town Britain's drug capital.
fields.body:
Davie was shivering, drenched from Adidas anorak hood to Reebok trainers with the day-long freezing rain. Standing on the corner at the entrance to some flats, he had been managing to squeeze out the odd word, but the longer we waited, the faster his conversation deteriorated from nervy gibbering to non-existent - as he focused on hissing a stream of expletives.

It was getting on for nine hours since Davie, 21, had had his last injection of heroin and his dealer was 30 minutes late. Another five, painful-to-watch minutes like this, and then the dealer appeared.

Barely older than Davie and dressed almost identically, he started to utter something which might be a greeting, but the client had waited too long for small talk. Inside the dealer's flat, the business was done quickly: £20 for a tin-foil wrap of a tenth of a gramme. Immediately, Davie went to work, cooking up the drug on a spoon over the flame of lighter. Holding the syringe in one trembling hand, he injected into a vein in the other. And the trembling stopped.

We were not sitting in Glasgow, Liverpool or London, and Davie is no deprived no-hope youngster from a sink council estate. Two days after we met, he would be back at his post on a fishing trawler operating out of the North Sea port of Fraserburgh, population 21,000, 40 miles north of Aberdeen and the undisputed drug abuse capital of Britain.

Fraserburgh should reek not just of the sea, but of the affluence it has generated for 400 years. Home to the second-largest fishing fleet in Britain, the harbour is filled with modern trawlers worth up to £200,000 each. Even in these trying days of falling stocks and EU quotas, the men who crew these boats can bring in £30,000 a year, the owners and skippers even more. Look closely around Fraserburgh and the trappings of high income are there: the BMWs and Audis, the gaudy, modern bungalows on the outskirts of town.

'We are in the middle of a bloody disaster,' said Sandy Wisley, a local doctor. 'If this was Glasgow or London, there would be a public outcry, but because we're a tiny place stuck away up here in the top corner, nobody is interested.'

The cold statistics compiled by Wisley at his Finlayson Street surgery are staggering. One in five young men in his practice, which covers 13,000 of the town's population, is a drug addict. About 70 per cent work on the trawlers, or did until they could no longer juggle their habits and their jobs. Wisley is treating more than 230 addicts and claims that two new ones come to him every week. Between February and April 1998, the practice prescribed 3,622 tablets of the opiate substitute dihydrocodeine; in the same period last year, more than 83,000 tablets - known as 'diffs' by users - were prescribed. The current tally is running above 90,000.

In total, there are about 450 heroin users in the town, more than 2 per cent of the population. On average, they consume about £80 of heroin each a day, more than £29,000 a year. Spread over the whole population, from infants to pensioners, that means heroin is costing every single person in Fraserburgh about £800 each a year. Dealers can make £5,000 a week here, but not all of this is profit; a substantial percentage of their income is used by the dealers to feed their own habits. 'It would be a great living if I didn't have to shoot so much up my arm,' said Davie's dealer.

Heroin has taken a heavy toll on Fraserburgh's young population. On 30 December the town achieved the dubious distinction of being home to Scotland's last drugs fatality of 2000. Richard Smith, 24, had been a familiar face in the local drugs scene for years, but on the Saturday before New Year the heroin addict was found dead at a house in the village of St Combs, just outside Fraserburgh. His death was the 140th in the area since 1996, when the scale of the drugs problem began to emerge.

'We first spotted the drugs problem in the early 1990s, but in 1997 it just exploded.' Wisley explains. 'Now, if I walk down the high street and 20 young lads say hello to me, you can bet that 15 of them will be addicts. And the only reason is money. These kids come back off the boats with a few thousand pounds a month in their pockets, and they don't know what else to do with it. In the past it would have been fast cars and drink binges, now it is drugs.'

That is exactly how it was with Davie. He has not reached the stage where he has had to sell off the television, the hi-fi or the PlayStation, but his flat was in chaos, smelling of unwashed clothes and fish.

'You come back after 10 days or whatever at sea and you are ready to party,' he says. 'You've got money in your pocket and a bit of time on your hands, so you go a bit wild. I used to get mad pissed, but all around you your mates are taking pills, doing a bit of blow, and you get sucked into it.'

If there is one thing that Fraserburgh can be grateful for, it is that it has avoided much of the crime that usually follows in the wake of a drug epidemic. 'Kids don't really need to steal around here to finance their habits,' says Davie. 'Most of them make enough on their own, and when they can't earn any more they can con the money from their families.'

But drugs agencies and police are becoming increasingly concerned about the quantity of crack cocaine making its way into the lucrative Fraserburgh drugs market.

More and more addicts are testing positive for it. Doctors like Wisley are treating people whose heart rates are up at 190 beats a minute after crack binges, and some appear to be using the drug in combination with heroin in an attempt to increase the intensity of the fix.

There have even been crack cocaine 'parties' in some of the outlying villages. 'Cocaine used to be practically non-existent around here,' said Wisley. 'Now we are seeing it in urine tests all the time.'

One senior drugs worker said: 'I can't really see these fishermen's cottages being turned into crack houses, but at least the rich kids are reverting to type and going for the expensive stuff.'

At £50 a rock, which provides a hit lasting less than an hour, the financial incentive is enormous. But with crack comes serious violence. One small-time dealer was recently held hostage by the gang which supplies him because they suspected he had given information to the police. For hours, he was held in a room and tortured. A crossbow bolt was shot into his right leg below the knee, and his face was beaten so badly it has taken three weeks for the bruising around his eyes to subside.

Last August police raids in Fraserburgh uncovered a selection of weapons typically associated with inner-city drugs gangs: a samurai sword, a crossbow, knives, substantial quantities of drugs, and thousands of pounds in cash. In all, seven arrests were made.

'It is the dealers who are fuelling the market,' said one local user, who refused to be named. 'They started using it themselves, so they are trying to build up a market so they can bring in the gear and take a cut of it for themselves.'

Back in his flat, Davie was already starting to plan his next hit. Within 48 hours, he would be back at sea, taking dihydrocodeine tablets to control his withdrawal symptoms. 'The day I lose my job will be the day I stop using the smack,' he said. Until then, he has his cravings to attend to.

webTitle: Leader: Mandelson ill-served public interest

fields.headline: A passport to the wilderness
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson ill-served public interest

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: As with so many political downfalls, it was as much Peter Mandelson's duplicity in response to questions as his original offence that precipitated his resignation.
fields.body:
As with so many political downfalls, it was as much Peter Mandelson's duplicity in response to questions as his original offence that precipitated his resignation. Yet as we report today, in the follow-up to our original exposé last weekend of the Mandelson affair, it is already becoming clear that the relationship between the Government and the Hinduja brothers was deeper and much more complicated than just the issue of a successful application for a passport.

The degree to which the relationship with the brothers extends to the Minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, is also still worryingly unclear. The Government's response - on the face of it speedy and legitimate - has been to set up a judicial review. However, the unacceptable consequence of that decision has been to put the control and timing of the release of more information firmly within the Government's control. This is simply inadmissible given the scale of public interest in this matter. It is also poor politics.

Interest in this affair is no longer driven by sensationalist fascination with the controversial figure of Mr Mandelson, whose judgment and suitability for high office were so obviously wanting. The passports-for-favours affair also goes to the heart of a central issue in British politics, namely where the private domain ends and the public domain begins. We live in a culture where politicians have never been less confident about asserting public purpose and the public interest. As they court the private sector, the boundaries between the public good and private interest become blurred and confused. In this territory of mutual favours, the scope for compromise and embarrassment is vast.

If the Dome had been publicly financed and the absurd promise not made that it would not cost a penny of taxpayers' funds, the Government would not have had to abase itself to people like the Hinduja brothers in order to raise sponsorship funds in the first place. The story is repeated many times over - the new Wembley Stadium; the funding of the London Underground; the concessions to inward international investors on taxation and planning. Even by resisting the public funding of political parties, both Conservatives and Labour open themselves up to the charge of offering private favours to the moneyed and powerful.

Every Minister will have learned an important lesson from Mr Mandelson's fate, but the Government should learn a larger lesson. There is a proper place for private partnership and private capital in public affairs, but only within parameters firmly established by those whose job it is to define the public interest.

webTitle: Comment: Mandelson; the Oscar Wilde of modern politics

fields.headline: My friend the political visionary
fields.standfirst:
Charles Leadbeater regrets the departure from the Cabinet of an inspired colleague he knew as a modern Oscar Wilde

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Charles Leadbeater regrets the departure from the Cabinet of an inspired colleague he knew as a modern Oscar Wilde.
fields.body:
British public life is a little poorer this weekend. Peter Mandelson, for all his acknowledged failings, was a rarity. Amid a political class of cautious managerialists, he had the imagination to see big opportunities and the bravery to take big risks.

The greatest example was his vision of what the Labour Party could become when it was down on its knees in the 1980s. When Labour was still a rump party, most comfortable with impotent opposition, Mandelson had a vision of how it could become a majority party that could command the mainstream of politics.

Not only could he think big; he had the stamina, professionalism and attention to detail to push those changes through. He made things happen when many around him simply talked. He was not afraid to take on fights when more cautious and calculating souls cowered. Many of those in government who are dancing on his grave owe him thanks that they are in power. Imagine if John Prescott, who emerged smirking from Cabinet on Thursday, had been put in charge of Labour Party communications in the 1980s. Presumably the Labour Party would today resemble the nation's transport system - a chaotic, unreliable mess.

The Mandelson who made his name as a backroom media manipulator in the 1990s was growing into a more mature, front-rank politician of drive, stature and imagination. He was prepared to enter into big public arguments about Britain's relations with Europe and proportional representation, areas where many of his colleagues feared to tread.

This government has any number of competent administrators, but it lacks people like Mandelson, who know how to innovate and drive change within a civil service machine that is too often low on ambition.

Take his time at the Department of Trade and Industry as an example. A week after his appointment, I wrote him a two-page note arguing that the DTI lacked a clear strategy and rationale. The note argued it needed a radical change of direction to focus on how Britain could become a 'knowledge-driven economy' that traded on its skills and know-how, its ability to innovate in old and new industries alike. Many of Mandelson's colleagues would have put the note to one side and settled for a piecemeal, steady-as-you-go approach.

Peter was prepared to take a risk and back what was then a relatively novel and big idea. I was brought into the DTI to design and draft the White Paper that was published in December 1998. The entire department was given a sense of direction and a new lease of life. It began to punch above its weight, much to the surprise of Treasury officials. DTI officials still talk wistfully about his few months in the job.

This is not to say that Peter Mandelson does not have flaws. I have known him almost 20 years; I am aware of almost every twist and turn of his character. Yet how unique are these flaws?

His head was turned by the rich and famous, but other members of the Cabinet fell in love with their own celebrity status far more conspicuously than he. Mandelson likes the high life, sure, but he does not have Michael Meacher's extensive property portfolio. Roy Hattersley, the born-again man of the people, likes nothing better than to lay into Mandelson after a couple of hours at the Garrick. Mandelson is vain, arrogant and insecure, but in my experience, that is true of most politicians.

Ken Follett accuses him of briefing against colleagues, behind their back. What a dreadful crime! Presumably it was unheard of at Westminster until Mandelson came along. His crime was not to brief the press but to do it so much more effectively than his enemies.

Peter's failings are much more mundane. When he needs people he can animate them with immense charm, only to ignore, disdain or even look right through them later. This is how he treated people who are counted as his friends; one can only imagine how it felt to be an enemy.

Too often he believed he could dazzle and weave his way out of trouble rather than being honest. Owning up to his telephone call to Mike O'Brien about Srichand Hinduja's passport application would have been an admission of defeat, an acknowledgement that he had been caught out in an elaborate game. He likes the attention of the pursuing pack; he made the mistake - twice - of thinking they would never catch him.

No doubt Mandelson's career will yield many lessons, ranging over big issues like the funding of political parties, the role of spin-doctors and the future of Britain's relations with Europe. I would offer two, much more modest lessons.

First, treat your colleagues well on the way up because you will need them on the way down.

Second, dare to be different. That is why I like and support Peter Mandelson. In a political class marked by its limited imagination, Peter had the capacity not just to think big, but to deliver as well. He dared to stand up and stand out. Now he has been hammered back into place. The Oscar Wilde of modern politics, he embraced the establishment and challenged convention in the same movement. Those who were unsettled by his daring are the ones celebrating this weekend.

 Charles Leadbeater's Living on Thin Air is published by Penguin, £6.99

fields.headline: Why he really had to go
fields.standfirst:
