Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: It wasn't just lying to The Observer. Or forcing Chris Smith to mislead the Commons. It was, ultimately, for betraying his master, Tony Blair, and the party that he had been so instrumental in creating.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
By an irony which escaped both men in the emotional fraughtness of the encounter, Tony Blair reached for a phrase minted by Margaret Thatcher to explain to Peter Mandelson why his political career was dead and Alastair Campbell was preparing the burial plot in history's cemetery for ruined talent. As they argued in the Prime Minister's study on Wednesday morning, and an impassioned argument there was, Blair told this oldest and most intimate of political allies and friends that there was 'no alternative' but for him to resign.

The offence - in the eyes of the Prime Minister as well as an infuriated Campbell - was not that of misleading The Observer when our reporters questioned his office last weekend about the Hinduja brothers and passports. Nor was the crime that of putting Chris Smith in the position of misleading the Commons, though the Prime Minister regarded this as serious. No, as the Prime Minister saw it, the real outrage against the codes of New Labour was to breach the trust with him and his press secretary by not telling them the story straight.

Some of the media coverage, portraying Mandelson in terms normally reserved for serial killers, suggested that he was guilty of the most outrageous mendacity ever committed in the annals of politics. Well, we could take every utterance emitted by Blair, Campbell and Gordon Brown over the past few years, or William Hague and his frontbenchers, or even some journalists, and I doubt they would all get a pristine pass through a lie detector.

Whatever he had done, Mandelson's offence did not compare with Jonathan Aitken's, a man who tried to get his daughter to lie on oath for him. Like the mob, New Labour likes to keep - or at least tries to keep - its secrets, scandals and strategems in the family. Among the many nicknames Blair has given him over the years, he would refer to Mandelson as his consiglière. The capital crime was to deceive the Godfather and his Enforcer, Campbell. And by doing so, Mandelson jeopardised the Firm at the most unforgivable of moments, the run-in to an election in which the Tories' only hope is to blacken all government as sleazy. That, ultimately, is why Mandelson had to sleep with the fishes.

He had also transgressed other commandments that he had been so instrumental and successful in ramming into Labour during the transformation from years of unelectability into party of power. He had been indisciplined. The Hinduja affair fitted a pattern of behaviour of treating the rules as if they applied to everyone except himself and being notably casual about the proprieties to be followed when dealing with the rich.

Not for the first time, just as the Government was trying to get its serious arguments and solid achievements across to the voters, a Mandelsonian scandal was screaming out of every media orifice. He had handed ammunition of an especially lethal nature to the tabloids which he, along with Alastair Campbell, had tutored the Prime Minister to treat with a mixture of loathing, supineness and fear. It has long been a regular source of despair to Tony Blair that his dervish of spin, so brilliant at giving counsel, was hopeless at taking advice about the hazards of his own whirling behaviour.

A smarter operator would have been more assiduous about making friends and less careless about leaving his prints on the bodies of his many enemies. I'm told, for instance, that Gordon Brown is averse to putting anything sensitive or potentially inflammatory on official paper, a habit which causes some consternation at Number 10 and the Cabinet Office when important documents arrive from the Treasury without the signature of the Chancellor.

Whether it was vanity, naivety or infatuation with riches - elements of all three, I guess, played their part - Mandelson demonstrated a startling penchant for living dangerously, especially when dealing with wealthy men of, ahem, interesting provenance. A smarter operator would have handled the Indian billionaires with asbestos gloves. To their requests for help, the cunning player would have bumped into the Immigration Minister in the Lobby to drop an unrecorded murmur in his ear while courteously and formally pointing the Hindujas in the direction of their constituency MP.

To place another paradox on top of this teetering tower of ironies, the man so often and so erroneously described as a modern Machiavelli was not political enough. The final and most heinous of offences against the internal laws of this government was to imperil its grip on power. During that conversation with the Prime Minister, the Conservatives were already up and baying with the highly damaging line that nothing Labour said or pledged during the election could be trusted so long as Peter Mandelson was at Tony Blair's shoulder.

Choosing between the man who had done so much to win that massive majority on May Day 1997 and taking any risks with the goal of securing the second term was, in the end, never much of a choice for Tony Blair. The second term came first. The folly of Peter Mandelson was to make himself so vulnerable to the forces he helped to conjure into British politics that he was finished off by the Prime Minister he had done so much to create.

Not without a fight, mind you. It should be recorded that Mandelson hotly argued there was an alternative to his resignation. He pleaded with Blair for a reprieve. He complained that there had been a rush to judgment before the full facts were established and all the relevant officials had been interviewed. He fought with Blair to stay in the Cabinet, at least until after the completion of the inquiry into the Hinduja affair. Mandelson's sympathisers - there are still a few - contend that when the full facts are established, the picture may look more complicated and different.

In the immediate aftermath of his first expulsion from the Cabinet, he was so depressed that some of his closest friends feared that Mandelson might even take his own life. This time, he is wretched, but he is also angry. Furious enough, perhaps, to try and challenge that universal assumption that he is finished. His decision to carry on as an MP, the voters of Hartlepool permitting, caused widespread surprise. It also so alarmed the Government that Geoff Hoon and Stephen Byers were sent out to consign him to a future as a deliverer of leaflets and knocker on doors. The Grand Vizier of New Labour, who might once have broken the careers of Messrs Byers and Hoon with a jagged whisper, is now himself airbrushed into oblivion by the junior cadre of modernisers. Politics is an unforgiving jungle.

Yet no one who knows Peter Mandelson imagines him spending the next 20 years as an obscure backbencher, content to grapple with no greater challenge than helping council tenants to get their drains unblocked. Mandelson has said to friends: 'It hasn't ended yet.'

This is certainly true in the sense that the emotional and political fall-out will continue to rain down for some time, hardest of all on the head of Tony Blair. Another of his sobriquets for Mandelson was 'my alter ego '. In his study on Wednesday, Tony Blair was amputating part of himself and without the benefit of much anaesthetic. High fury was accompanied by a sense of deep loss. Indeed, the depth of the loss sharpened the height of the fury. When they sat on the front bench that afternoon, the Prime Minister looked more pale and pink-eyed than his fallen friend. It is easy to believe those of the Prime Minister's allies who describe Tony Blair as 'devastated' and 'gutted'.

The Prime Minister will be a lonelier man in his own government. He was the only profound mourner around the table at Thursday's first Mandelson-free Cabinet. That tells him how thoroughly his old friend's intrigues had alienated so many colleagues. I doubt there are many brave enough to say it to his face, but the unrestrained delight of so many in the Labour Party is not just because they loathed Peter Mandelson, but also because they were disturbed and bewildered that Mr Blair seemed so over-addicted to his alter ego.

The decision to bring him back after the first disgrace casts an inevitable taint on the Prime Minister's judgment of character. And yet, in crucial respects which explain exactly why he did take the risk of bringing him back, Blair was absolutely right about Mandelson. The gloating thrill that has run up the collective spine of the Conservative Party, and was given rather graceless voice by William Hague, is informed by a relish that the fall of Mandelson weakens and destabilises the Prime Minister. It also springs from the - of course, unspoken - belief among Tories that this is the destruction of a formidable opponent.

Also removed is one of the very few people who actually believed in the modernising programme in its entirety. Peter Mandelson was a Blairite before Blair. He was one of that tiny band who signed up to New Labour from more than ambition, sycophancy or convenience. He was the only big player in the Government apart from Tony Blair who could be called New Labour from absolute conviction. John Prescott, that great scorner of what he derides as nouveau Labour, can't have grinned so much since his honeymoon.

Jack Straw and David Blunkett are, in their guts, traditional Labourish men wearing a modernising gloss. Gordon Brown is not really New Labour, a phrase he never uses these days. The Chancellor embraced the concept as a useful marketing tool with which to distance Labour from the failures of its past. What he never bought into - in the way Tony Blair did - was the Project as meaning an entirely different approach to progressive politics with the ambition of healing the breach between social democrats and liberals which gave so much of the twentieth century to the Conservatives.

The cause of electoral reform within the Labour Party, already sinking, has been further holed. Of its remaining advocates at the level of Cabinet, Mo Mowlam is parked in the departure lounge and Robin Cook, though he will be encouraged by the removal of one predator for his job, will not feel strong enough to become an agitator for reform. One day, when the Tories are again a serious threat, the Labour Party will wake up. By that time, it will almost certainly be too late.

The Cabinet has also lost its most consistent and articulate pro-European. Though commonly despised as an opportunist without two principles to rub together, Peter Mandelson burnt with the conviction that Britain's manifest destiny lies at the heart of Europe. That animated much of the glee with which his self-ignition was greeted by the Euro-hating press.

Gordon Brown's much more agnostic, verging on the sceptical, approach towards early entry to the single currency is more likely to prevail now that the Prime Minister has been deprived of an intimate with clout who was prepared to push the opposing case and stiffen the Blair backbone in confrontations with his tungsten Chancellor. One of the explanations for Blair's dependency on Mandelson was that he prized him as a large personality, one of the few strong enough to help counterbalance Gordon Brown. The smashing of the original New Labour love triangle simplifies the relationship between the neighbours of Downing Street. No longer will Gordon Brown's paranoid streak be inflamed by the thought that when his early morning phone call to Tony is over, the next person on the line to the Prime Minister will be his hated rival for the ear of Blair.

To Mandelson - and often, though not always, rightly - the Brownites attributed the inspiration for every disobliging reference to the Chancellor in the media. After one burst of infighting between the pair early last year, Mandelson told one friend that he should put a notice up on his desk: 'Remember: Gordon is mad.' Much as Tony Blair frequently bemoaned their incessant feuding, much as he pleaded with both men to bury the hatchet, at some deeply subconscious level it seems to have served him. Peter Mandelson's own theory was that Brown's hatred of him was a displacement of his ferocious resentment at Blair for snatching the crown of leadership which the Chancellor believes should have been his. Though evidently a self-serving bit of psychoanalysis, which conveniently neglected his own tendency to aggravate things, this has the ring of some truth.

The removal of the third person in their marriage simplifies the Blair-Brown relationship: for better, so long as it remains relatively calm, perhaps for worse, when their eruptions can no longer be blamed on someone else. Gordon Brown would not be the acute strategist he is if he did not use his now untrammelled command over the election campaign to mark his claim to become Prime Minister. The Chancellor will want his stewardship of the economy and his campaign to receive the lion's credit for securing the second term. Those who try to protect Tony Blair's interests will be anxious that the Prime Minister's contribution is not entirely neglected.

Brownite joy is unconfined not simply because their hate object has been immolated. In the complex balance of power between them, the seesaw has tilted to the Chancellor at the expense of the Prime Minister. As he drains the toxic dregs of the cocktail of ironies that finished him, perhaps it will be this bitter taste that lingers longest on the tongue of Peter Mandelson. Sacked by his old friend Tony Blair, his fall strengthens no one more than his ancient enemy, Gordon Brown.

 Andrew Rawnsley's dissection of the the first three years of New Labour, Servants of the People, is published by Hamish Hamilton at £17.99

webTitle: Crackdown on web baby sites faces instant log-off

fields.headline: Crackdown on web baby sites faces instant log-off
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Rule one: Always assume that politicians know nothing about technology and even less about the net. Then the only surprises you get will be pleasant ones.
fields.body:
Rule one: Always assume that politicians know nothing about technology and even less about the net. Then the only surprises you get will be pleasant ones.

A couple of years ago, Dutch television viewers were treated to the sight of their prime minister sitting in front of a PC. He was seen to stare at the mouse, pick it up with a puzzled expression and wave it about while clicking its buttons. After a time, the penny dropped with his audience: he thought it was a remote control! It was clear that he had never in his life used a computer.

Readers with long memories will recall a similar episode when George Bush Senior was campaigning in a New Hampshire primary and found himself in a supermarket. Photographers and film crews asked him to process a few items though the checkout and were astonished to find the future President staring bemusedly at a barcode scanner which kept beeping. It was clear that he had never seen such a thing before.

Now spool forward a few years and meet one John Hutton, an obscure minister in the Department of Health who happens to be responsible for child protection. Moved by the hoohah about 'internet adoption', Hutton decided to add his own two-pennyworth to the pot by announcing his determination - in the words of the Guardian report - to 'clamp down on adoption over the internet by warning British-based service providers that they face criminal prosecution for relaying material which infringes British adoption law'. It seems the Government is 'keen to be seen acting strongly', and that Hutton believes his stern move against ISPs 'could provide a lead for the EU and G8 to crack down on child-broker websites'.

Note that Hutton is not just calling for UK-based child-brokering sites (if such exist) to be shut down by the ISPs which carry them. He is instructing ISPs to desist from 'relaying material' from such sites, no matter where they are located.

If this is really what he has in mind, he is either certifiable or entirely ignorant of how the internet works, because the only way of achieving it would be to monitor the clickstreams of every single UK user of the net - and not even Jack Straw believes he can do that.

Meanwhile, the unelected president of the US has moved into the White House. A quick inspection of the presidential website on his first day in office suggested that the lights were on but there was nobody home. Links to the text-only pages - designed for visually impaired visitors or wretches with low-bandwidth connections - were broken. And one eagle-eyed US surfer noticed that the left-hand menu bar sported the legend, 'Insert something meaningful here', just below links to biographies of the Pres. and his lady.

All of which would be funny if Bush wasn't accompanied by a bunch of reactionary technophobes who view the net as a sinister haven of freaks, hackers, paedophiles, terrorists and pointy-headed intellectuals, which should be made safe for wholesome corporate pap and Disneyfied values.

In part this is a reflection of their ideological antecedents, but it stems mainly from the fact that nobody in the higher echelons of the new US administration has any experience of information or computing technology. 'If you think the Clinton/Gore crowd struggled with the technology, wait till you get a load of these people,' a Washington Post reporter told Jon Katz of the Slashdot 'news for nerds' website. 'They think the net is another planet.'

Just like our own dear minister of health and his colleague, the minister of the interior. Looks as though New Labour will get on just fine with Bush & Co.


john.naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Phil Hogan: Down to a fine art

fields.headline: Down to a fine art
fields.trailText: I'm in the market for a modest item of chic art for the sitting room, and what better place to wander around in the idle hope of finding one than the ART2001 Fair in fashionable Islington.
fields.body:
I'm in the market for a modest item of chic art for the sitting room, and what better place to wander around in the idle hope of finding one than the ART2001 Fair in fashionable Islington where, who knows, I might find myself spending my £15 on an early Francis Bacon that has perhaps lain undiscovered for years owing to the great man having painted it long before hitting upon the route to greatness that is pretending not to know how to draw faces. Or how about the next Tracey Emin or the whatsit brothers who build those showroom dummies that have genitals sprouting where their heads should be?

Never let it be said that I am not as open to meretricious novelty as the next man, the only aesthetic proviso being that whatever treasure I dash home with mustn't clash with Dulux Natural Bamboo Matt or resemble anything I might be able to do myself and ideally should be large enough to cover the two holes above the sofa where I can't get the old Rawlplugs out. Admittedly, this may seem the criteria of an oaf and a Philistine, but if memory serves it is an approach perfectly attuned to the time-honoured custom and practice of such giants of Renaissance patronage as Lorenzo de' Medici, who would think nothing of ringing Botticelli in the middle of the night to explain how he's got the Duke of Milan coming down Sunday week and needs a nice 30ft x 24ft altarpiece knocking up with plenty of blue in it, blue being at that time as much the new black among the cognoscenti of 15th-century showing off as elephant dung is to today's aspirants to Turner Prize celebrity.

I'm actually whistling as I mount the steps of the design centre, coins jingling in my pocket and packing enough Wrigley's for a lengthy afternoon's rummage. Naturally I'm expecting a sprawling boot- sale-type event mobbed with hugely talented but penniless graduates of St Martin's desperate to swap their first masterpieces for tipped cigarettes or items of used clothing. So it comes as a bit of a surprise to be asked for a £10 entrance fee and then find the place manned by dealers in designer poloneck jumpers with their own mini galleries and proper frames on the pictures and a little desk to look busy at. Maybe I didn't read the poster properly.

Never mind, according to my free map, which is a useful guide - albeit only to local restaurants and dry cleaners - there's a whole section given over to British 'cutting edge' art. Excellent. And it starts well, with an amusing film of an attractive woman in a red dress being followed up and down the road by a large commercial vehicle (He's behind you!), though it could get a bit repetitive after a while and you do find yourself wondering why she can't use the pavement like everybody else. I stroll around and try to take an interest but it quickly occurs to me that for every young artist who has thought of something fresh and new to do with a penis, there are 100 lesser splodgers and spotwelders whose parents I can only imagine must be constantly on the phone trying to coax them into diverting their creative energies into alternative careers as stationery reps or community outreach workers. I try my luck downstairs.

Prints seem to be the thing for the budget-conscious, but every time I see something decent it turns out to be £148,000 and by Matisse. I move on. An enlarged photograph of a meat pie, a picture of a binbag_ There is an impressive lifesize jackal made out of chicken wire, but where would we put the TV? I give in.

But then I'm coming home on the train when I read in the paper that Britart is the new Athena and that buying limited editions on the internet is quite the sophisticated thing to do as an alternative to being Charles Saatchi. I rush home and visit a website. Here I find lots of cool New York artists I've never heard of whose stuff you can buy using your credit card and therefore not have to pay for until it has quintupled in value! I'm particularly keen on a bunch of poppies. I wonder if they have it in my size...

webTitle: Britain set to outsmart Europe

fields.headline: Britain set to outsmart Europe
fields.standfirst:
This country is poised for a wealthy new era as the Venice of the information age, argues Simon Moores

More net news
fields.trailText: This country is poised for a wealthy new era as the Venice of the information age, argues Simon Moores
fields.body:
The year is 2010. In the first decade of the twenty-first century the face of the global economy has been transformed by the internet. This is tomorrow's business, e-business, and it is dominated by a relatively small number of successful service economies, themselves centred on hub or 'smart' cities, such as Singapore or Dubai. They sit astride the vital infrastructure of the communications network in much the same way that ports, such as Venice, once dominated the trade of the Mediterranean.

It is with such predictions in mind that the Government has set itself the task of making Britain an information superpower or, in the words of Tony Blair, 'the best place in the world for e-business'. Is this ambitious policy initiative realistic?

As a nation, we may love to be disappointed but according to a survey of European executives, Britain is viewed as the preferred location to start an internet-related business, with Germany and France in second and third places respectively. A third of European business managers perceive the UK as the leading European information economy, followed closely again by Germany.

Professor Jim Norton, head of e-business at the Institute of Directors and author of government e-commerce policy, would argue that the UK is already the world leader in businesses trading online. However, he advises that the criteria supporting this claim should be viewed with caution for two reasons. First, the definition of trading online is too broad. Second, the quoted percentages of businesses are weighted by employment, so larger companies dominate.

'Where we need to do better in the UK is for many businesses to overcome their instinctive aversion to new technology, looking beyond to the potential impact on their business models.

'This is not a "new economy"; it is a new set of tools and freedoms, which are complementary and can be usefully deployed in almost any "Old Economy" company. Last year's dotcom collapse is now focusing attention on strategies which leverage existing brands, focusing on traditional values, customers, creativity, charging and collaboration.'

The real winners, he believes, will be those companies which deal with their customers consistently and through a 'clicks and mortar' mix of electronic and physical channels.

Oliver Roll, director of enterprise marketing at Microsoft, suggests one area where the UK has advantages because of government efforts. 'This,' he says, 'is visible through its support for universal access, a reduction in bureaucracy and through the creation of a digital framework capable of offering public services and transactional services, such as VAT returns over the internet.

'As a nation of random entrepreneurs, I don't think that Britain has any inherent advantage in turning smart ideas into business successes. The great challenge lies in matching our existing industry and management skills with such new ideas and methods of doing business over the internet.'

A report by Growth Plus Europe, the entrepreneurs' group, and Arthur Andersen illustrates the lead that the UK has over the rest of Europe in the entrepreneur contest. Behind Britain lies Spain, followed by Italy and the Netherlands. The two largest continental economies, Germany and France, rank near the bottom of the 10-nation survey.

In addition, the UK and the US are considered equal in the business environment segment, which includes corporate and individual taxes, new business formation, and capital gains tax rates.

The report concludes that governments in Europe have long tended to award grants and subsidies in an attempt to foster growth and entrepre neurial spirit, but that this is not enough. The authors view the whole environment - legislation and regulation - as fundamental. 'Disregarding the needs or potential of entrepreneurs and growth companies, with their inherent impact on the economy as job creators, could severely limit the development of national economies,' they say.

A rapid public sector acceptance of e-business and 'joined-up government' principles has quickly established the UK as an example that many other countries are starting to follow. More than 40 per cent of UK government services are now available online, and this is set to rise to nearly 75 per cent by 2002. New research has revealed that nearly one in five adults - 18 per cent - who use the internet do so to access web- based Government services or information.

As a nation, the UK is unique in having an e-Envoy, Andrew Pinder, the Government's 'information age evangelist', responsible for coordinating the evolution and the delivery schedule for the many 'joined-up government' services and websites. These include the new citizens' portal, UK-Online, as well as the Government Gateway and UK-Online for Business.

Pinder, who also has a broader responsibility for driving forward the digital revolution, may be encouraged by the December figures from NetValue, which show more than 11.5 million home internet users in the UK. The Government, according to the e-Envoy, has also achieved its 2002 target of a million businesses online a year early, and it is this critical mass of small business use of the internet that makes Britain remarkable.

Pinder believes the key elements for a successful internet economy are found in a strong national infrastructure: 'a good telecoms infrastructure so that people can have access to the Internet through one source or another, whether that be digital television or personal computers at home or at work'.

Bandwidth is, he believes, a critical issue: 'We need to ensure that people have the opportunity to take advantage of the bandwidth. If there is a key point, it is that the country needs to have in place all the infrastructure that allows those who wish to join in the information economy to do so.'

Government is so convinced that websites accelerate the process of change within the public sector, that next week, in London, Lucian Hudson, the Cabinet Office's director of e-communications, will bring together Ministers, senior civil servants and those with frontline responsibility for producing sites and their content.

'The Government,' says Hudson, 'already has a significant web presence. The challenge is to ensure that whatever we do with our websites not only reflects accurately what government can deliver but holds up the promise that government is becoming increasingly more responsive and approachable.'

The Victorians might have recognised the chemistry at work here. Britain has always enjoyed a unique form of public- and private-sector partnership, one which fuelled the commercial and legislative foundation of an entrepreneurial and aggressive merchant economy. Times may change, but the principles and lessons of the past remain much the same, even in this early post-industrial period of our history. Sound policy, deregulation and inward investment offer Britain an advantage and an opportunity to benefit from the new wealth that will come from being the leading 'smart' economy in Europe.

Meanwhile, nations unable or unwilling to respond to the social and political challenges that accompany the information age may discover, to their cost, that equally rapid forces of economic disadvantage can also work at internet speeds.

webTitle: The power behind the US presidency

fields.headline: The power behind the US presidency
fields.standfirst:
With George Bush in the White House, energy firms lobbying for deregulation are pushing at an open door, writes Oliver Morgan

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: With George Bush in the White House, energy firms lobbying for deregulation are pushing at an open door, writes Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
America 2001. While the inflated riches of the new economy are wilting, an older power is stalking the land. As George W. Bush arrives in Washington from Texas he brings with him a coterie of friends from the Lone Star state whose fortunes, in common with his own, have been founded on power - oil, gas, and electricity.

The timing could hardly be more symbolic. Twenty-first century California is plunged into spasms of nineteenth-century darkness because its power system cannot cope with the demands of its internet-fuelled economy. Meanwhile, energy companies are making fortunes as they sell electricity at vastly inflated prices - up to $1,000 a megawatt-hour compared with a $30 norm - into the starved Californian grid. These are swell times for Bush's new oiligocracy.

But there is more. Electricity deregulation, the problem at the heart of the farce in California, promises to be one of the most controversial legislative issues of Bush's term in office.

With a finely balanced Congress, the California humiliation, and a summer of massive energy price volatility in midwest states, there is waning support for further deregulation.

But Bush and his energy industry players want deregulation. They would do. Two California utilities, Southern California Edison (SCE) and Pacific Gas & Electric, may be facing financial ruin because they can't get consumers to pay the price they are having to shell out for wholesale power. But companies supplying power, be they utilities operating Californian power plants they bought under deregulation or energy traders, are cashing in.

This is happening not only in the Golden State, but right across the US - half of which is deregulated - where fortunes can be made from the mismatch between supply and demand.

Some of these big players will be familiar in the UK. Utilities owning California plants include Southern Energy, part of a consortium buying Welsh utility Hyder, AES Corp, which owns the massive Drax power station in Yorkshire, trader Dynegy, Reliant, which held merger talks with PowerGen, and TXU, owner of Eastern Electricity and a pan-European trader. Enron, which trades in California, operates two plants in Britain and trades here. The last four are all Texan.

Reliant, Dynegy, and AES have been branded by California governor Gray Davis as 'pirates and plunderers'. The companies and their shareholders won't care. Last week Enron announced a huge increase in revenues at the end of the fourth quarter, driven by soaring wholesale operations. It refused to split out Californian earnings. Dynegy's fourth quarter saw earnings double to $105.9m.

These companies want further deregulation wherever in the world they operate. In the US they want to negotiate on a state-by-state basis rather than have onerous environmental and consumer protection conditions imposed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).

They will take their message to the heart of the White House.Texas energy companies, including Enron, TXU, Dynegy and Reliant, have long exerted influence with the Bush dynasty. Diane Albaugh, wife of Bush's campaign manager, registered last autumn to lobby on behalf of TXU, Reliant, and Entergy, another Texas-based utility.

The heads of two Texas energy players - Enron's Kenneth Lay and TXU's Earl Nye - are on the energy team of Bush's transitional administration, and both have made hefty donations to Bush: Lay $310,000 in the past two years and Nye $50,000, according to the Washington-based Center for Responsive Politics.

Lay is particularly close to Bush, having served his father and acted as a fundraiser. Since 1999, Enron, which is also an oil and gas operator with an interest in deregulation, has bankrolled George W's election campaign to the tune of $555,275 - his highest single donor.

Both Lay and Nye are arguing that what has happened in California should not taint future plans, despite the fact that deregulation in midwest states such as Illinois and Ohio caused massive price volatility last summer.

Deregulation supporters argue that California is a one-off, caused partly by environmental blocks to new power stations. Only 700mwh have been built since 1995, compared with 5,700mwh in Bush's Texas. Lay even argues that instead of a federal cap being imposed on wholesale prices, Californian consumers should reduce their electricity consumption.

This desire from the energy giants for deregulation and minimal federal interference was clear from the four-year campaign in Congress run by industry and the Republicans. In 1996 the FERC ordered utilities to open their electricity lines to competitors. Further deregulation has divided Congress, and in the run-up to the 2000 election the main concern was the role of FERC.

Two Congressmen spearheaded the move for state-by-state control: Joe Barton, chairman of the House energy and power subcommittee and a Texas Republican with close links to Bush; and Alaskan senator Frank Murkowski, head of the Senate energy and natural resources committee. According to CRP, of the total $793,064 contributions to Bush's election funds, a massive $256,940 was paid by energy companies.

This included $12,750 from TXU, $10,000 from Reliant, $7,591 from industry lobby group Edison Electric Institute, $5,000 from Ohio utility Cinergy, and $3,000 from Enron. Energy analyst Jerry Oppenheim says it is clear what the companies were paying for: 'Deregulation created volatility, which is what energy traders want. Doing it state by state increases the ability to lobby individual states for favourable deregulation.'

With Bush in the White House, the energy giants are pushing at an open door. In 1997 Bush pushed for a bill that would have deregulated the industry without offering safeguards to consumers or the environment. This 'Bush Bill' failed. In 1999, the Texas legislature passed a deregulation bill, again backed by Bush, this time with some protections in place.

Janee Briesemeister of the South-west region of the US Consumers Union says: 'Bush will argue that California is unique. That's what the energy people want, and access to Bush's team gives them great influence. But there are no consumers' representatives on it, and the 1997 bill shows where his concerns lie.' The question now is, will Republicans be able to drive the plans through a divided Congress?

Some of the lobbying by these US companies will effectively be supported by UK consumers through revenues contributed to parent companies. In the UK itself they could make a great deal of money from the next stage of electricity deregulation here: the introduction of new electricity trading arrangements, (NETA) which will replace the electricity pool.

NETA is intended to make the energy market more competitive by matching supply and demand more accurately than the current pool does. Under the new arrangement, forward contracts between generators and suppliers will become important. For companies that have not contracted successfully and matched demands with their supply, there will be a short-term balancing market.

The prices at this balancing stage, particularly in the first year of NETA, are expected to be very volatile.

David Warwick of KWI, a risk management consultancy, says that while bankrupt utilities and power cuts may not be a feature of NETA, there will be problems that traders can exploit.

'The problem is that many electricity suppliers have not bought forward contracts. They will have to rely a lot on the balancing market, which will become very volatile at times, and very expensive. I would expect some suppliers to see their profits hit. And the traders which get it right will make a lot of money.'

The US companies that have spent so much time lobbying for American deregulation have done so here too, putting in detailed papers to the UK regulator. Four are, coincidentally, from the Lone Star state - Enron, TXU, Entergy and Dynegy. For them, if not for Bush, there will continue to be a special relationship with the UK.

Some of the lobbying by these US companies will effectively be supported by UK consumers through revenues contributed to parent companies. In the UK itself they could make a great deal of money from the next stage of electricity deregulation here: the introduction of new electricity trading arrangements, (NETA) which will replace the electricity pool. NETA is intended to make the energy market more competitive by matching supply and demand more accurately than the current pool does. Under the new arrangement, forward contracts between generators and suppliers will become important. For companies that have not contracted successfully and matched demands with their supply, there will be a short-term balancing market. The prices at this balancing stage, particularly in the first year of NETA, are expected to be very volatile. David Warwick of KWI, a risk management consultancy, says that while bankrupt utilities and power cuts may not be a feature of NETA, there will be problems that traders can exploit. 'The problem is that many electricity suppliers have not bought forward contracts. They will have to rely a lot on the balancing market, which will become very volatile at times, and very expensive. I would expect some suppliers to see their profits hit. And the traders which get it right will make a lot of money.' The US companies that have spent so much time lobbying for American deregulation have done so here too, putting in detailed papers to the UK regulator. Four are, coincidentally, from the Lone Star state - Enron, TXU, Entergy and Dynegy. For them, if not for Bush, there will continue to be a special relationship with the UK.

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Lead us into temptation

fields.headline: Lead us into temptation
fields.trailText: In the modern world, temptation is a tricky business. In an era when the new religion is Instant Gratification, it seems that we are no sooner tempted than we succumb.
fields.body:
In the modern world, temptation is a tricky business. In an era when the new religion is Instant Gratification, it seems that we are no sooner tempted than we succumb. Some of us even manage to succumb before we are tempted. Others might not even have a clear idea what temptation is, we're that busy succumbing.

At the moment, I am being tempted by cigarettes, which I gave up at New Year in a blaze of glory, and never looked back. Sadly, the reason I never looked back is because I'm too busy looking at cigarette machines or other people smoking cigarettes. For me, where ciggies are concerned, temptation seems to be everywhere. Indeed, whatever your 'serpent' of choice - sex, money, drugs - temptation seems to be all around us, gushing away like a jammed tap. Which could explain why one sees so many Colditz Couples these days. Colditz Couples are where one partner (usually the man) is absolutely desperate to escape from the relationship, at least temporarily, while the other partner (invariably the woman) is equally desperate to stop them escaping.

It's a sick dance of ennui and despair deeply ingrained in the human psyche. One person wants to have sex with someone else, while the other person wants to stop them having that sex, even though they don't particularly want to have sex with them themselves. Most of us have been one half of a Colditz Couple, an emotional POW. No matter which side you're on, it's always painful. And because it's a sex thing, and therefore a human thing, of all the temptations it's the most difficult to resist. We've all heard about the devil tempting Jesus on the mountaintop with all the riches of the world, and how JC abstained. What is not so well known is that the devil then tempted Jesus with a photo of Mary Magdalene having a bubble bath, and Jesus was skidding down that mountaintop faster than you could say 'Son of God'.

I just made that up. What I'm not making up is the new American series on Sky television called Temptation Island. Billed as a 'remarkable sociological experiment', its aim seems to be to destabilise loving relationships between happy couples who previously had no difficulties whatsoever. How very sociological, not to mention sweet, of them. The rules seem simple enough: beautiful young couples wearing elegant smiles and beach gear made of dental floss (and that's just their formal look) arrive on Temptation Island, whereupon they are separated from their partners, taken to opposite ends of the island and thrown in among half-naked members of the opposite sex, thereby putting their relationship to the (fanfare of ratings trumpets) 'ultimate test!' Everyone predicts tears by barbie-time, and of course we can hardly wait.

One doesn't wish to be too Daily Mail, but honestly, how did it come to this - infidelity as first prize in a television game show? The producers of Temptation Island have been at pains to point out that none of the couples are married, nor do they have any children. They're clearly saving the thrills and spills of the complete breakdown of the family unit for the forthcoming ratings busters Temptation Wedding Reception and Temptation School Run. For now, we just have to put up with blonde lovelies in bikinis snivelling through a mist of mascara when they are shown footage of their hero being tempted by another blonde lovely in a bikini, or a guy clenching his six-pack in angst as he observes his beloved succumbing to an unscrupulous Lothario.

The obvious question is: why would any self-respecting couple agree to go on a show like this in the first place? - but that seems a bit harsh. Wannabe TV presenters have feelings, too, not to mention relationships they need to 'test', even if this does conjure up images of scientists filling condoms with 10 gallons of water and then looking surprised when they burst. However 'real' the relationships on Temptation Island are or not, the 'temptation' can't be, unless that temptation is to pout lusciously to the camera in the hope that the person who makes Baywatch might be watching.

Other than that, the contestants are surely less likely to succumb to temptation in these exposed conditions than if they were let loose on a night out with their friends. For temptation, in its truest form, isn't a controlled thing, a game show, which can be manufactured at will. Real temptation happens when you least expect it, when you're not looking, and when you'd really rather it wouldn't. Temptation is where the wild things are. In this way, everywhere, every day, is Temptation Island, and a show of the same name could only ever be watched for laughs.

webTitle: Anger as strategic rail plan shunted to sidings

fields.headline: Anger as strategic rail plan shunted to sidings
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail industry is set to remain in disarray for at least another six months because strategic plans for its future have been severely delayed.
fields.body:
The rail industry is set to remain in disarray for at least another six months because strategic plans for its future have been severely delayed.

The Observer has learnt that the 10-year strategic plan being drawn up by the Government's 'rail enforcer', Sir Alastair Morton, will not now be ready until the autumn - more than a year later than originally scheduled.

Morton's Shadow Strategic Rail Authority will be relaunched without its 'shadow' status this Thursday after gaining new powers under the Transport Act.

It had been expected to unveil its 10-year plan, but will not now publish anything until the end of February - and that will be labelled a 'strategic agenda' rather than a comprehensive plan.

Government Ministers and train operating chiefs have been waiting impatiently for Morton to set out both a programme for the network's future and organisation of the passenger franchises.

Gwyneth Dunwoody, who chairs the influential House of Commons Transport Select Committee, told The Observer : 'This is the moment when the SRA must strike hard and effectively to give real leadership.

'It's clear that unless a coherent force shows the way to the rest of the industry, the existing muddle and mess will continue. And the taxpayer is not going to continue funding an industry that has no idea where it is going.'

The industry has been in crisis since the Hatfield crash last October, when Railtrack's admitted failure to mend a cracked rail, which then broke, derailed a Great North Eastern train. Four people died.

The crash has provoked a critical review of the industry and its fragmentation at privatisation - with Railtrack outsourcing maintenance, and being caught up in contractual conflicts with passenger and freight operators.

A senior industry source said: 'The industry is being left to drift. How on earth can operators bid for franchises when they do not know what the strategic issues are - about ticketing, consolidation of passenger services, capacity expansion, specific projects and funding?

'The SRA was meant to be a panacea for the industry but we need more than this so-called agenda, which is just the same as saying a consultation document. We have had two years of consultation and we want action.'

The source said Morton was too ready to trust that 'market forces' would sort out the industry.

webTitle: Quake toll may reach 15,000

fields.headline: Quake toll may reach 15,000
fields.standfirst:
Luke Harding in Bhuj finds darkness, mourning and horror at the epicentre of the disaster
Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Luke Harding in Bhuj finds darkness, mourning and horror at the epicentre of the disaster.
fields.body:
The devastation here, at the epicentre of the earthquake which cut a swath of death across western India, is catastrophically enormous. This old city is a place of darkness, mourning and horror.

A few people trapped under collapsed buildings were still alive as dawn broke - but there was no one to dig them out. No one was even trying.

'We heard a girl's cries to begin with. But by afternoon they stopped. There is nothing we can do,' one officer shrugs.

At least 13,000 and perhaps 15,000 people died, mostly in India and a few in Pakistan. Here at the heart of the horror most buildings are damaged or fissured. Hundreds of people lie in tombs beneath multi-storey blocks. There is no electricity or water and power lines have been wiped out.

The town's two main hospitals are rubble. The streets are littered with the dead, laid out in neat lines, their faces covered with saris or towels. Groups of relatives pushed carts to cremation grounds carrying corpses. The authorities seem paralysed and clueless.

Pravina Abla had been at work when the earthquake struck. She had left her eight-year-old daughter Kushbu at home. And so, when after three deadly minutes the tremors finally subsided, she raced through what was left of Bhuj's old city to try to find her.

But where her house had stood, there was a 30ft pile of rubble. 'There is no rescue team here. No one has come to help me find my daughter,' she said. 'My little girl is under there. I can hear her crying, I can hear her crying. But no one comes.'

In the corner of a municipal garden, Jubilee Grounds, a team of 40 doctors were last night treating patients in a makeshift tent on wooden beds. 'We have had 900 people here,' Dr Mahindra Goswamy said. 'We had one patient today with a fractured spine who was dug out after 24 hours, but no one else.'

Outside, hundreds of patients lay on the ground with drips in their arms awaiting treatment. 'This is my worst day as a doctor,' Dr Goswamy added.

Journeying to Bhuj, across one of India's most sparsely populated areas, the devastation is immediately apparent. The bridge which leads to Kutch, the district worst affected, is crumpled in several places. The fields are littered with dead sheep and goats, feasted on by vultures and kites. Everything has fallen over as if prodded: petrol pumps, toll booths and roadside shrines. Entire villages have been obliterated. In the village of Vondh not a single building was left standing. Those who were out herding their goats when the earthquake struck were busy burning their dead.

The smoke from a dozen cremation fires billowed across the desert. In the opposite direction, streaming away from Bhuj, the homeless trudged to safety carrying on their heads sacks of rice and children.

As well as killing thousands, the earthquake also swept away the local maharaja's 16th-century palace. 'I had taken a bath. I was inside when there was a tremor. Immediately I knew it was an earthquake,' the maharaja's cousin, Ghanshyam Singh, said.

'I ran outside and stood under the door frame. I could hear the sound of the Burmese teak girders crashing above me. It is thanks to God that I survived,' he said.

Singh said Bhuj was hit by three or more aftershocks yesterday and that everyone was too afraid to return to their homes. 'There is no relief operation. We haven't seen a single person here,' he added.

The authorities last night denied accusations of incompetence. 'We have got cranes working in the main city as well as teams with metal-cutting equipment trying to free people from the rubble,' one senior army officersaid.

The job had not started at all yesterday in the old city where dead buffalo, crushed motorbikes and the bodies of elderly women lay in the alleyways. Some 150 army personnel stationed at Bhuj are believed to have died instantly when the earthquake struck. Relief flights are arriving at Bhuj. By road, a trickle of aid has got through. Jeeps from Bombay with boxes of drugs are arriving.

The earthquake also devastated Gujurat's main city, Ahmedabad. Rescuers were last night trying to dig out the bodies of 59 children at Swamy Narayan primary school. The children had come in for lessons on Friday - when the rest of India had a day off to celebrate Republic Day - for a science project. Then the school roof fell on top of them. 'My boy, my boy,' one father said in tears. More than 40 buildings in the city collapsed, killing around 500 people.

Meanwhile, a military plane carrying a 69-strong team from the International Rescue Corps yesterday left for India, taking off from Brize Norton RAF base in Oxfordshire.

Bharat Patel, speaking on behalf of the Bhuj temple in Woolwich, south-east London, said: 'We are concerned that the Government is hugely underestimating the number of British citizens that have been caught in this earthquake. Our temple comes under the same charitable trust as the town of Bhuj.

'There are Bhuj temple communities all over London, in Cardiff and Bolton.

'We want to make the Government realise there are thousands rather than hundreds of British citizens not accounted for, as many go there regularly on holiday or to visit relatives.

'I was there last month. Others have retired there.

'The atmosphere in our community here is quite depressing as a lot of people are distressed because communication lines are down in India and they have been unable to contact friends and relatives.

'We have been praying and there will be a collection of money and possibly clothes to send out there.'

The Foreign Office has set up a hotline for people in Britain who want to find out about relatives in India, or to report that they have been in contact and know they are safe: 020 7839 1010.

Oxfam has launched an appeal to provide blankets, plastic sheeting, tents, cooking utensils and food. To make a donation, please call Oxfam on 01865 313131 or send a cheque, payable to Oxfam Indian Earthquake Appeal, to 274 Banbury road, Oxford 0X2 7DZ.

webTitle: Fallen Minister has a little local difficulty

fields.headline: Fallen Minister has a little local difficulty
fields.standfirst:
Harry Blackwood, editor of the Hartlepool Mail, says the MP must woo his disaffected constituents if he wants to hold his seat

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Harry Blackwood, editor of the Hartlepool Mail, says the MP must woo his disaffected constituents if he wants to hold his seat.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson has every right to feel bruised after last week's events. If the humiliation of having to resign his ministerial position wasn't a big enough blow to his ego, the savaging he took from the nation's press was enough to finish off any man.

The Sun front-page comment on Thursday was as brutal as it was brief. In a withering condemnation, it described the shamed Northern Ireland Secretary as 'a lying, manipulative, oily, two-faced, nasty piece of work'. All they needed to really finish the job off was to add the words... 'and they're his good points'.

As Mandelson steels himself for life as a backbencher, he'd do well to ignore the venom of the national tabloids. Instead he should listen to the people of Hartlepool. The good folk of his constituency have pulled no punches in their condemnation of his recent actions. Indeed, they've been firing warning shots across his bows for many weeks.

There is little doubt that Mandelson was more wounded by a reader's letter in the Hartlepool Mail two weeks ago than anything the Sun managed. Seven words said it all: 'What's Peter Mandelson ever done for Hartlepool?' Mandelson may be able to generalise and point to a significant improvement in the town's jobless figures - the lowest for 30 years. But that won't cut any ice with the disillusioned voters who are more offended that Mandelson has been an absent MP than by any of the lying and cheating that he's been accused of in the past week.

Hartlepudlians could perhaps be accused of being small-minded or even selfish over their discontent with Mandelson's many absences from the town during his period in Northern Ireland. He could argue with justification that the huge task of trying to bring peace to Northern Ireland had to take priority over any of Hartlepool's social and economic problems. They would doubtless counter that, as they had voted him into office to be their MP and represent their interests, he had no right to turn his attentions elsewhere.

Whatever the pros and cons of the argument there is little doubt that Mandelson has a huge challenge ahead of him. Not only must he woo those people who feel he has brought shame on the town, he must also win over those who feel he does not care about Hartlepool. If that isn't enough for him to get his teeth into, he also has to see off prominent local businessman and boxing promoter Gus Robinson who is convinced he can take the seat for the Tories.

Mandelson would be advised to treat his Tory rival with caution and respect because the popular local man is a Conservative candidate like no other. Gus may look every inch the smart Conservative candidate but he thinks more like a socialist, has deep religious convictions and can talk with passion and authority on many of the issues that Hartlepool people feel strongly about. When it comes to sartorial elegance he is more than a match for Mandelson, but beneath the smooth exterior he is as tough as any of the republicans or loyalists that Mandelson had to deal with in his previous political life.

As Labour's master spin doctor tries to rebuild his shattered political career in the run-up to the general election, he will have to keep one eye on his main challenger. The other will need to focus on local issues such as ambulances that fail to turn up, a cash crisis at the council and the threat to 427 steel jobs in the town. It will be a world away from the high political sphere that he has inhabited of late, but it is something he will have to get used to if he is sincere in his wish to continue to represent Hartlepool as a backbench MP.

The people of Hartlepool are honest, decent and hardworking, and they don't ask too much from their MP. What they will be asking for as we head towards the general election is an MP who will work tirelessly for the town and its people. Mandelson has a short time to convince them he is the man for the job. If he can't, the unthinkable could happen.

In a town where it was said that you could pin a Labour rosette on a monkey and people would vote for it, things have changed. Hartlepool voters got rid of the Labour-controlled council in last May's elections after 22 years in charge, and they could turn against Mandelson in the same way.

The people of Hartlepool forgave Mandelson when he was embroiled in the home loan scandal and they may forgive him for his lies in the cash-for-passports affair - but only if they get something in return. They have been loyal to Mandelson when the whole country has turned against him, but now it's payback time.

If he is prepared to forget the high life and become a loyal, dedicated MP who will bring the people of Hartlepool prosperity and rid them of the social problems that have dogged the town for decades, Mandelson will be all right. If he is not prepared to work hard to achieve all that, his 17,000 majority will be safer in the hands of a monkey with a red rosette.

In a withering condemnation, it described the shamed Northern Ireland Secretary as 'a lying, manipulative, oily, two-faced, nasty piece of work'. All they needed to really finish the job off was to add the words... 'and they're his good points'. As Mandelson steels himself for life as a backbencher, he'd do well to ignore the venom of the national tabloids. Instead he should listen to the people of Hartlepool. The good folk of his constituency have pulled no punches in their condemnation of his recent actions. Indeed, they've been firing warning shots across his bows for many weeks. There is little doubt that Mandelson was more wounded by a reader's letter in the Hartlepool Mail two weeks ago than anything the Sun managed. Seven words said it all: 'What's Peter Mandelson ever done for Hartlepool?' Mandelson may be able to generalise and point to a significant improvement in the town's jobless figures - the lowest for 30 years. But that won't cut any ice with the disillusioned voters who are more offended that Mandelson has been an absent MP than by any of the lying and cheating that he's been accused of in the past week. Hartlepudlians could perhaps be accused of being small-minded or even selfish over their discontent with Mandelson's many absences from the town during his period in Northern Ireland. He could argue with justification that the huge task of trying to bring peace to Northern Ireland had to take priority over any of Hartlepool's social and economic problems. They would doubtless counter that, as they had voted him into office to be their MP and represent their interests, he had no right to turn his attentions elsewhere. Whatever the pros and cons of the argument there is little doubt that Mandelson has a huge challenge ahead of him. Not only must he woo those people who feel he has brought shame on the town, he must also win over those who feel he does not care about Hartlepool. If that isn't enough for him to get his teeth into, he also has to see off prominent local businessman and boxing promoter Gus Robinson who is convinced he can take the seat for the Tories. Mandelson would be advised to treat his Tory rival with caution and respect because the popular local man is a Conservative candidate like no other. Gus may look every inch the smart Conservative candidate but he thinks more like a socialist, has deep religious convictions and can talk with passion and authority on many of the issues that Hartlepool people feel strongly about. When it comes to sartorial elegance he is more than a match for Mandelson, but beneath the smooth exterior he is as tough as any of the republicans or loyalists that Mandelson had to deal with in his previous political life. As Labour's master spin doctor tries to rebuild his shattered political career in the run-up to the general election, he will have to keep one eye on his main challenger. The other will need to focus on local issues such as ambulances that fail to turn up, a cash crisis at the council and the threat to 427 steel jobs in the town. It will be a world away from the high political sphere that he has inhabited of late, but it is something he will have to get used to if he is sincere in his wish to continue to represent Hartlepool as a backbench MP. The people of Hartlepool are honest, decent and hardworking, and they don't ask too much from their MP. What they will be asking for as we head towards the general election is an MP who will work tirelessly for the town and its people. Mandelson has a short time to convince them he is the man for the job. If he can't, the unthinkable could happen. In a town where it was said that you could pin a Labour rosette on a monkey and people would vote for it, things have changed. Hartlepool voters got rid of the Labour-controlled council in last May's elections after 22 years in charge, and they could turn against Mandelson in the same way. The people of Hartlepool forgave Mandelson when he was embroiled in the home loan scandal and they may forgive him for his lies in the cash-for-passports affair - but only if they get something in return. They have been loyal to Mandelson when the whole country has turned against him, but now it's payback time. If he is prepared to forget the high life and become a loyal, dedicated MP who will bring the people of Hartlepool prosperity and rid them of the social problems that have dogged the town for decades, Mandelson will be all right. If he is not prepared to work hard to achieve all that, his 17,000 majority will be safer in the hands of a monkey with a red rosette. webTitle: Heather Connon: The marvels - or not - of technology

fields.headline: The marvels - or not - of technology
fields.trailText: Caps, the performance measurement specialist, found that only 11 of the 68 UK equity pension funds it analyses increased in value over the past year; the average fund declined by 5.1 per cent.
fields.body:
How did your investments perform last year? On the face of it, the numbers look dismal. The FTSE All-Share Index fell by 8 per cent. Even including the value of dividends received, the total return was 5.9 per cent - the first time the stock market has produced negative returns since 1994.

It is not surprising, therefore, that fund managers have struggled. Caps, the performance measurement specialist, found that only 11 of the 68 UK equity pension funds it analyses increased in value over the past year; the average fund declined by 5.1 per cent.

Given the state of the market, however, that was not a bad performance - two-thirds of the managers beat the index. Some did sub stantially better: ABN Amro UK Growth, which topped the tables in 2000, increased by 16 per cent; Invesco took second and third places, with returns of 11.4 and 6.7 per cent, respectively. But the bad were very bad: the bottom five all fell by twice as much as the index.

According to Standard & Poor's, the average UK fund rose by more than 2 per cent over the past year, but some - such as Perpetual UK Growth (up more than 26 per cent) - have done spectacularly while others - such as Manek Growth (down almost 20 per cent) suffered.

The reason is simple: technology. Last year, the surge in tech stocks that took the markets by storm in 1999 was spectacularly reversed. So, as those who embraced technology did extremely well in 1999, those who dismissed it as a load of hype did well last year.

The turnaround underlines the rule that buying last year's best performers is usually a sure way to lose money. In 1999, the Manek fund was second in the league table while Perpetual UK Growth (despite the name, an old-fashioned value fund) limped in at 247.

The tech boom and bust has hit other fund managers, although less dramatically. Chief beneficiaries of the return to favour of old-fashioned companies such as retailers and food producers have been managers such as Schroders, Jupiter and Flemings. Those suffer ing from the tech fall-out include Gartmore, Dresdner and Govett.

So where should investors be in 2001? Technology shares have staged a bit of a recovery following the cut in US interest rates, while defensive stocks such as food, drink and tobacco companies have underperformed a little. But that may not continue for the rest of the year. Many observers believe tech stocks are still overvalued and think a US downturn will debunk the theory that they are resilient to economic change. But more bad news from across the Atlantic is likely to send investors back to safe-haven stocks.

There could still be scope for more value-oriented managers to do well. Instead of trying to uncover this year's winner, however - that is a lottery and 12 months is too short a time for equity investment - investors should look for consistency. In Cap's tables, Invesco, ABN Amro and Henderson have performed consistently well over the past 10 years.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Riddle of the 'odd' years and cut payouts

fields.headline: Riddle of the 'odd' years and cut payouts
fields.trailText: We are in the thick of the bonus season; not the one that pays for yachts and country estates for City slickers, but the one that delivers more modest sums to the with-profits investments that underpin homeloans and pensions.
fields.body:
We are in the thick of the bonus season; not the one that pays for yachts and country estates for City slickers, but the one that delivers more modest sums to the with-profits investments that underpin homeloans and pensions.

Among last week's declarants was CGNU, the company formed from General Accident, Commercial Union and Norwich Union. The with-profits funds of each individual company are still run separately, and the payouts have been cut more or less across the board, although their magnitude varies. One eagle-eyed observer, David Carrington of the second-hand endowment company PolicyPlus, noticed that while there has been a relatively small cut in terminal bonuses - those paid on maturity - for 25-year policies with Norwich Union, those maturing after 24 years saw their bonuses cut by 22 per cent.

Fact: independent tables assessing the performance of with-profits endowments and pensions measure performance over 10, 15, 20 and 25 year periods.

Norwich Union denies massaging the figures to flatter its position in the tables. It says investment returns over 24 years have been lower than over 25. And the 24-year endowment investors would have done even worse had NU not cushioned the effect of those poorer investment years by paying more than was actually earned.

Carrington noted a similar phenomenon for 19-year policies versus 20-year ones, and NU says this would almost certainly have been for the same reasons.

Putting all thoughts of creative arithmetic out of our heads, the odd figures for 'odd' year policies underline once again the insurers' huge discretion over the way they distribute returns on these investments.

This discretion, along with the complexity of charging structures and inflexibility of terms, is giving increasing cause for concern among investment advisers who were once happy to sell with- profits policies as a relatively low-risk product.

The agony continues for policyholders with Equitable Life whose attempts to find a buyer depend on finding a way to cap payments on the guaranteed pensions that have been its undoing.

At the end of last week Aegon, the favourite, pulled out. This second auction differs from the first, conducted for Equitable last year, in that it hinges on capping the insurer's liability, but the fact that buyers are already dropping out is not cause for comfort.

Hopefully, a deal can be struck. But if a sale is negotiated, this would poses a new question for the inquiries into the disaster: why could such a deal not have been arranged last year, saving the insurer from having to shut up shop?

webTitle: Liddell widens party split on nursing care

fields.headline: Liddell widens party split on nursing care
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The new Scottish Secretary has weighed into the row over free care for the elderly north of the border with a guarded backing for the Executive's right to pursue a different policy from Westminster.
fields.body:
The new Scottish Secretary has weighed into the row over free care for the elderly north of the border with a guarded backing for the Executive's right to pursue a different policy from Westminster. Amid mounting tensions between the Labour leaderships in Edinburgh and London, Helen Liddell sided with First Minister Henry McLeish, insisting that it was an unavoidable consequence of devolution that there would be policy differences on each side of the border.

Since the Executive was forced on Thursday by the threat of a rebellion among its Liberal Democrat coalition partners to rethink its plans for limited free care, there has been speculation that Scotland will be forced into line with the rest of the country.

The Executive's statement promises only that it will bring forward 'proposals' and costings for free nursing and personal care by August, a move interpreted by opposition parties as a delaying tactic to buy time for Labour until after the UK general election. But Liddell, who became the first woman to hold the job of Scottish Secretary on Thursday after John Reid was moved to succeed Peter Mandelson, said she would not be putting pressure on McLeish and the Executive to toe the London line. 'I would not have campaigned for devolution for so many years if I didn't believe in the right of the Scottish Parliament to make its own decisions,' she said.

Liddell's intervention is unlikely to ease the doubts of opposition politicians and groups representing the elderly, who have warned the Executive of a public outcry if promises of free care are watered down again.

The row has severely strained relations between the two ruling parties at Holyrood. Jim Wallace, Deputy First Minister and leader of the Scottish Lib Dems, upped the ante on Friday when he released an open letter to his backbenchers promising unequivocally that free care would be delivered.

Labour Ministers, by sharp contrast, refused to expand on the promise to bring forward proposals.

webTitle: Ski town becomes 'fortress' as riots spread

fields.headline: Ski town becomes 'fortress' as riots spread
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Protests against globalisation spread across Switzerland last night after police beat back demonstrators at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in the ski resort of Davos.
fields.byline: William Keegan and Peter Capella  in Davos
fields.body:
Protests against globalisation spread across Switzerland last night after police beat back demonstrators at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in the ski resort of Davos.

Four cars were set on fire in Zurich as up to 1,000 people were prevented from getting to the resort by police firing tear gas and rubber bullets.

Earlier, several hundred demonstrators were confronted by riot police firing water cannon in the country's biggest security operation since the Second World War. Inside, behind the barricades, the leaders of the international business community talked of a soft landing for the US economy,

They did their best to convince themselves that collateral damage to the rest of the world from the US slowdown could be contained.

For several days the 'Spirit of Davos' trumpeted by the organisers of the elite international business and political gathering resembled East Germany in the 1980s. A corner of the Alps was turned into a fortress, with roads blocked and train services suspended, while travellers faced repeated identity checks and searches.

At least 140 people were turned back at the Swiss border over the past week, many because they were carrying 'propaganda material'. Hundreds more were turned back on roads to Davos yesterday.

Inside delegates heard the International Monetary Fund's first deputy managing director, Stanley Fischer, assert that 'we are a long way from a global recession'. He added that 'aggressive action by the Fed' in cutting interest rates was welcome.
