webTitle: Comment: Tories' jump on the religious bandwagon

fields.headline: O come all ye faithful
fields.standfirst:
Despite wooing the religious vote, the Tory leader and his moral Right cohorts haven't got a prayer

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Despite wooing the religious vote, the Tory leader and his moral Right cohorts haven't got a prayer.
fields.body:
Hush, hush, whisper who dares, Liam Fox is saying his prayers. The subject of the Shadow Health Secretary's discourses with the Almighty was discovered last week in a Conservative Christian Fellowship booklet containing a list of model political incantations. Fox's offering is a call on Tories to 'pray for a huge restriction, if not abolition, of the current abortion law'. In other words, he wishes the present 24-week limit on terminations to be much shorter. Ideally, he wants abortion outlawed altogether.

God must be gratifyingly deafened with similar pleas. In the United States, Tommy Thompson, the Governor of Wisconsin, has been confirmed as Health Secretary. His view, that terminations should be criminalised, chimes with that of President Bush, whose first move on taking office was to abolish funding for international organisations offering abortion advice. Fox's repellent stance meshes neatly with American redneck social policy and with the Tories' leap aboard the celestial bandwagon.

Some time has passed since William Hague remodelled himself along the lines of John the Baptist, preaching in the Tory wilderness. Naturally, there were some modernising features. For a raiment of camel's hair, substitute a North Face Gore-Tex hiking jacket. Swap locusts and wild honey for a pint or 14 at a local hostelry and Judea for the North York moors, where Hague prefers to commune with his maker during a Sunday ramble.

Hague is a pantheist, who sees God in all places where there are a handful of votes to be garnered. He is also, presumably, a subscriber to the Malcolm Muggeridge view that, to succeed in public life, 'one must conform to the public image of a bookie or a clergyman'. Having sized up the odds on a Tory victory, Hague has deemed the latter course more fruitful. He has guested on Songs of Praise, preached to evangelists, absorbed the ayatollah credo of Pastor Marvin Olasky and ordained that 500,000 free newspapers outlining Tory policy will be shortly distributed to church-goers. At this rate, he may soon, like President Reagan, be evincing 'serious doubts about the theory of evolution'.

This is, of course, the time of the electoral cycle when politicians routinely dust off their religious credentials and serenade the spiritual vote. Before the last election, John Major divulged his habit of 'praying in all circumstances', while Tony Blair disclosed that his beliefs had driven him to join Labour. Then, as now, everyone obsessed over a decline in law and order. Relatives of the murdered (last time, Frances Lawrence, this time, Damilola Taylor's father, Richard) called for the 'moral regeneration' of Britain.

Here we go again, except that Blair, though backed in 1997 by nine out of 10 of the senior clergy, has learned that God and politics are a fissile mixture. His early sermonising was derided, family moralising was unpopular and his former Northern Ireland Secretary might still be in situ but for the Church's bleating that someone must cough up for a Faith Zone at the Dome. Barring Gladstone, no Prime Minister has been more entranced by the purpose of life than Blair. The Christians in his Cabinet include Gordon Brown, Chris Smith, Jack Straw and Michael (blessed are those with too many homes) Meacher. All have drawn a line between private faith and public policy.

Which leaves William Hague a clear field to tilt for the soul of Middle England. On the statistics, he does not have a hope. Forty eight per cent of Church of England members vote Labour, as against 26 per cent for the Tories. Neither Catholics (17 per cent Tory against 48 again for Labour), nor Muslims (22 per cent against 33) seem likely to be impressed by Hague's Damascene conversion.

His Bush-style, faith-based projects - under which the welfare state is bequeathed to the churches - disregards the fact that the vast majority of Americans believe in God, an afterlife and the notion that a guardian angel is clamped to their shoulder like a Trafalgar Square pigeon to Tony Banks's pate. More than a third go to church regularly, compared with 7.5 per cent in Britain, where the faltering Church of England is the doctrinal equivalent of Marks & Spencer. Hague's barmy plan would founder on manpower shortages alone.

His wish to peddle piety like snake oil matters only because religion is gaining an insidious influence on politics. Scientific progress and a strong economy decree, in part, the growth of an ethical agenda which the Christian Right seeks to suborn.

Whenever the abolition of Section 28, or biotechnology, or gay sex at 16 is at issue, a gaggle of apoplectic archbishops proffer brimstone and damnation. Tomorrow, Baroness Young hopes to gather enough support from peers to stop pharmacies selling the morning-after pill. Last week, the Daily Telegraph solemnly exhorted the House of Lords not to endorse embryo cloning because 'Pope John Paul II would be disturbed'.

If his Holiness is truly to be granted such sway over the decisions of the British Parliament, it can only be a matter of time before he is advising on corporation tax and cold weather allowances for pensioners. By an inverse rule, the decline of church popularity has coincided with a disproportionate upsurge of grand standing on policy. That is due partly to the fact that belief is more strident than unbelief. Godless MPs swear their oath of allegiance on the Bible and fail to flaunt their atheism, hedging their bets along with an agnostic public. Of the 65 per cent of adults who say they are Christians while rarely going to church, many will abhor the views of hardliners who purport to speak for them. Others will be scandalised by social reform while holding no religious position.

Moral fundamentalists are not necessarily the same as Christian fundamentalists. Blair, the devout Christian, knows that liberal policies will lose him support in both camps. Hague, the strategic God-botherer, hopes that he can mop up the fall-out and win a few marginals. Tactics, not conviction, seem the issue. Hague gives the impression of someone who has not held a firm article of faith since he ceased to believe in the tooth fairy. That is precisely why his religious posturing is so unthreatening.

So how unlucky for him that Liam Fox, a true adherent to Catholic dogma, should enter the religious debate. If Fox believes in a return to back-street abortion, that is his own affair. To wish to transubstantiate that private view into law is the most stupendous cheek. Even Ann Widdecombe had the grace to admit that her views on abortion would render her an unsuitable Health Secretary. If Fox sees a conflict of interests, he has not mentioned it.

Instead, he has laid out the real agenda of the moral Right - prescriptive, undemocratic, nasty and cold-hearted. It hardly matters that his prayer for abortion reform will never be fulfilled. Already his comment has offered a bogus legitimacy to pro-life protest groups now clamouring for the Tories to fund their work And still, there is some reason to be grateful to Fox, who has offered a salutary cameo of what a Tory government, smiled upon by Bush and God, might seek to do. How lucky that it will not, barring miracles, have its chance. Even the irreligious should count their blessings.

Neither Catholics (17 per cent Tory against 48 again for Labour), nor Muslims (22 per cent against 33) seem likely to be impressed by Hague's Damascene conversion. His Bush-style, faith-based projects - under which the welfare state is bequeathed to the churches - disregards the fact that the vast majority of Americans believe in God, an afterlife and the notion that a guardian angel is clamped to their shoulder like a Trafalgar Square pigeon to Tony Banks's pate. More than a third go to church regularly, compared with 7.5 per cent in Britain, where the faltering Church of England is the doctrinal equivalent of Marks & Spencer. Hague's barmy plan would founder on manpower shortages alone. His wish to peddle piety like snake oil matters only because religion is gaining an insidious influence on politics. Scientific progress and a strong economy decree, in part, the growth of an ethical agenda which the Christian Right seeks to suborn. Whenever the abolition of Section 28, or biotechnology, or gay sex at 16 is at issue, a gaggle of apoplectic archbishops proffer brimstone and damnation. Tomorrow, Baroness Young hopes to gather enough support from peers to stop pharmacies selling the morning-after pill. Last week, the Daily Telegraph solemnly exhorted the House of Lords not to endorse embryo cloning because 'Pope John Paul II would be disturbed'. If his Holiness is truly to be granted such sway over the decisions of the British Parliament, it can only be a matter of time before he is advising on corporation tax and cold weather allowances for pensioners. By an inverse rule, the decline of church popularity has coincided with a disproportionate upsurge of grand standing on policy. That is due partly to the fact that belief is more strident than unbelief. Godless MPs swear their oath of allegiance on the Bible and fail to flaunt their atheism, hedging their bets along with an agnostic public. Of the 65 per cent of adults who say they are Christians while rarely going to church, many will abhor the views of hardliners who purport to speak for them. Others will be scandalised by social reform while holding no religious position. Moral fundamentalists are not necessarily the same as Christian fundamentalists. Blair, the devout Christian, knows that liberal policies will lose him support in both camps. Hague, the strategic God-botherer, hopes that he can mop up the fall-out and win a few marginals. Tactics, not conviction, seem the issue. Hague gives the impression of someone who has not held a firm article of faith since he ceased to believe in the tooth fairy. That is precisely why his religious posturing is so unthreatening. So how unlucky for him that Liam Fox, a true adherent to Catholic dogma, should enter the religious debate. If Fox believes in a return to back-street abortion, that is his own affair. To wish to transubstantiate that private view into law is the most stupendous cheek. Even Ann Widdecombe had the grace to admit that her views on abortion would render her an unsuitable Health Secretary. If Fox sees a conflict of interests, he has not mentioned it. Instead, he has laid out the real agenda of the moral Right - prescriptive, undemocratic, nasty and cold-hearted. It hardly matters that his prayer for abortion reform will never be fulfilled. Already his comment has offered a bogus legitimacy to pro-life protest groups now clamouring for the Tories to fund their work And still, there is some reason to be grateful to Fox, who has offered a salutary cameo of what a Tory government, smiled upon by Bush and God, might seek to do. How lucky that it will not, barring miracles, have its chance. Even the irreligious should count their blessings.

webTitle: Comment: Still ice cool for Alex Salmond

fields.headline: Still ice cool for Alex
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Somewhere at  home I have a collection of tapes of political interviews dating from the early 1990s. I have always meant to listen to them again, not for their substance but for the eccentric extraneous noises.
fields.body:
Somewhere at home I have a collection of tapes of political interviews dating from the early 1990s. I have always meant to listen to them again, not for their substance but for the eccentric extraneous noises.

Interruptions by waiters have a deadly effect on anecdotes; they are always perfectly timed to ruin the punch-line. The chatter and laughter of fellow diners constitute other hazards.

A regular star of the tapes was a man who dined nightly in one of my regular venues. I came to admire his style and courage: he was dandyish - macaronic, the Victorians would have said - and completely disregarded a speech impediment which made his conversation resound like the braying of a donkey.

The memory of those days was revived last week when I had dinner with Alex Salmond, who renounced the SNP leadership last year but has since been persuaded to lead the parliamentary party at Westminster. I could not shake him from his assertion that he had given up the leadership because he had done it for 10 years, quite long enough.

He has naturally been mocked for what was seen as apostasy. He has been accused of turning his back on the Parliament he had helped to found.

Last week he argued that it was practical politics. His continued presence at Holyrood, he felt, would cramp the style of his successor, John Swinney, no matter how he tried to make himself unobtrusive. And the new SNP intake to Westminster would be a fresh generation needing experienced leadership.

I am unable to bring you direct quotation of his remarks. On Friday morning I slipped the tape into the car's cassette player. The playback began with laughter from a nearby table. Then as Alex answered my first question a waiter asked thunderously: 'Who's having the spinach?' At this point the tape jammed and this morning remains stuck fast.

But I left the table convinced that there was no hidden agenda behind his decision. I did detect a certain bitterness about some of the groundless rumours circulated about him during the Holyrood election campaign. He suspected they had been put about by his opponents.

And I also sensed a residue of rancour about the factional squabbling, attributed by commentators to the Sillarsites (though Jim Sillars himself rejects the charge), with which he had to deal towards the end of the leadership.

Another and perhaps even greater source of unhappiness was the vicious treatment he had received from sections of the Scottish press during the Holyrood campaign. Until relatively recently the native newspapers have been largely fair-minded (a tradition maintained by the Herald ). But two factors have changed the landscape. First, the English titles now in the marketplace, notably the Sun and the Daily Mail, freely mix their reporting with prejudice. Among the indigenous titles, the Scotsman has become an opinionated pamphlet under the Barclay Brothers and Andrew Neil, its headlines dripping with attitude, either anti-Labour or Europhobic.

Yet, you might say with Truman, a class politician has to be able to stand the heat. This is no game for pygmies but a gigantomachy, a titanic struggle for supremacy. The SNP is a slightly different case. In major parties, taking time out might have a fatal effect on a career; rivals would simply come jostling through.

By contrast Salmond can afford to stop and smell the flowers along the way. I suspect he has not gone for good. Guile and experience are not exactly in plentiful supply in the SNP and there will inevitably be a dearth of Westminster expertise. But above all I came to the conclusion that Salmond was suffering a little from ennui. And the remedy proposed by his doctor to Buchan's Richard Hannay - steal a horse in a part of the world where to do so is a capital offence - is hardly an option for man who has led the SNP always along the paths of reason.

webTitle: Leader: England should heed Henry McLeish

fields.headline: Follow Scotland
fields.standfirst:
England should heed Henry McLeish

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: England should heed Henry McLeish
fields.body:
The Scottish Executive's promise to bring forward proposals to provide free and universal personal care for the elderly has drawn a predictable response from bilious commentators who see this as yet another example of favoured treatment north of the Border.

This attitude betrays a misunderstanding of devolution. The Scottish Parliament has been given the power to allocate its block grant according to its own priorities. There is something comical, therefore, in the cries of horror at the possibility that it might choose to do so.

There remain genuine worries about whether there is enough money in the pot. The Executive's promise, forced out of Labour at the end of Thursday's debate by its Lib Dem coalition partners and some of its own backbenchers, was opaque.

A study group, surely otiose after the Sutherland Royal Commission, will report in August and proposals will then set out the costs and implications of the change. In plain language, this means that the issue has been kicked into touch until after a general election. It also implies that means-testing will remain part of Labour's preferences and that the coalition will face hard choices. The talk of 'efficiency' savings begins to smack of desperation.

First Minister Henry McLeish has been remarkably determined that the Scottish Parliament should find its own way forward, but even his friends fear he may have been a little too bullish, raising false expectations. He also faces the hostility of his old friend and protector, Gordon Brown, who has set his face against the concession in England. Let's hope Henry's got it right. This is a desirable measure which England and Wales should seek to emulate rather than denounce.

webTitle: Israeli army deserted by soldiers with a conscience

fields.headline: Israeli army deserted by soldiers with a conscience
fields.trailText: The Israeli army has been hit by an unprecedented wave of disobedience as scores of soldiers refuse to serve in areas which have seen the worst violence during the Palestinian uprising.
fields.body:
The Israeli army has been hit by an unprecedented wave of disobedience as scores of soldiers refuse to serve in areas which have seen the worst violence during the Palestinian uprising.

Others have cut short their military service in protest at the Israeli control of Arab territories, against the measures used to tackle the four-month-long revolt, and against what they call the 'militarisation' of Israeli society.

Hundreds more serving soldiers have requested transfers from the West Bank and Gaza Strip or have refused reserve duty. Thousands of other young people are dodging military service - traditionally seen as one of the cornerstones of life in Israel.

At least nine soldiers, including some from combat units and at least one reservist, have been jailed for taking a stand against military authorities since the start of the intifada in September. Campaigners say only one in 40 refusers is being prosecuted. The army says exact figures are unavailable.

Eyal Rozenberg, 20, refused to complete the last of his three years of mandatory service with a prestigious intelligence unit when the most recent violence broke out.

'The army is being used to defend and further a policy I do not agree with but was assisting,' he told The Observer . 'Every morning when I woke up I was torn between what I was doing and what I believed in.'

Many of the refusers are reservists. After their three years of compulsory service, Israeli men can be called up for more than a month each year.

Thousands of reservists have been deployed on the West Bank and in Gaza in recent months. Several have been killed. More than 300 Palestinians have died.

'I don't want to be in a position where I might have to shoot and wound and kill people who are throwing stones and I don't want to die myself. If it was a war for Israel's survival, that would be totally different,' said one 33-year-old reservist, a former fighter in the elite paratroop brigade. Sympathetic commanding officers, aware that Israel's forces are a 'people's army', are often happy to quietly transfer soldiers away from sensitive positions. Others recommend that they seek a medical discharge, he said.

However, the new wave of 'refuseniks' has revealed deep divisions in Israeli society. Young Israelis are increasingly secular and materialistic. Many conservatives see the new trends as undermining the nation's security, damaging its moral fabric, or even as contrary to divine injunctions.

In nine days, Israelis go to the polls to elect a new Prime Minister. Ariel Sharon, the bullish hardliner, has a huge lead over Ehud Barak, whose electoral pledge to bring peace has not been fulfilled.

In the heated pre-election atmosphere, the criticism of conscientious objectors and 'refuseniks' has been severe. Lothan Raz, 20, who spent two months in jail for refusing to serve in the West Bank, said he has received abuse and threats after talking publicly about his decision.

'People said that I wasn't a Jew if I didn't serve in the army. They called me a traitor and a coward,' he said. Raz maintains that he speaks for a huge number of young Israelis whose vision of Israel is very different from that of 'the religious or military establishment'.

But although the violence in the territories has caused a crisis of conscience for some, it has also led to a backlash against the peace process. The army points out that unprecedented numbers of reservists are reporting for duty and says some are requesting a posting on the West Bank or in Gaza.

During the last intifada, from 1987 to 1993, about 200 soldiers were jailed for refusing to serve. Campaigners say current figures do not reflect the extent of the discontent. 'The army don't want to stir things up at a difficult time, so they have a policy of not jailing people. It's the tip of the iceberg,' said Ishai Menuchin, a veteran of Israel's traumatic war in Lebanon who now runs a group supporting conscientious objectors. He says that out of 40 refusers who have contacted him since September only one has been jailed.

Instead of formally objecting, some young Israelis simply opt to avoid military service. Some campaigners claim that a quarter of those called up are dodging the draft. The army says only 1 per cent fails to serve.

Outside a bar in central Jerusalem last week several young Israelis were happy to tell The Observer how they avoided military service.

'It was easy,' said Yoel, a 19-year-old IT student. 'I just told them that I had bad nightmares and sometimes had suicidal thoughts. They don't want to take any risks, so they let me off.' He said he was not ashamed. 'I don't like fighting and I don't want to shoot anyone. I don't see why that should stop me being a good Israeli citizen.'

webTitle: Comment: Lies and statistics cloud the smoking debate

fields.headline: Better off dead?
fields.standfirst:
Lies, damned lies and statistics only serve to cloud the whole debate about smoking

Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Lies, damned lies and statistics only serve to cloud the whole debate about smoking.
fields.body:
I am trying to adopt as many bad habits as possible before it's too late. In that spirit, I recently took up smoking. My teacher was my friend Alexis Trboyevich. It was a while before I got the hang of it. 'You must inhale,' she would insist, 'otherwise you won't enjoy the full benefits of the nicotine'. She had a point

It comes as no surprise that scientists are now discovering that nicotine may not be so bad for you after all. According to a 1994 article in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine, smokers are less likely to get ulcerative colitis - inflammation of the bowels - than non-smokers. Indeed, the article claims, 'the onset of colitis is often associated with the cessation of smoking.' Recently, a Duke University Medical Center study found that nicotine helped Alzheimer's disease patients. Pharmaceutical companies are now trying to develop nicotine medication for use against schizophrenia and depression.

I am not saying that a pack a day will do you as much good as a two-mile run. On the other hand, I don't take the health warnings particularly seriously either. The anti-smoking campaign, a noxious alliance of government and corporations, was always a giant scam to transfer wealth from the poor to the rich. It was not the shareholders of Philip Morris or R.J. Reynolds who were fleeced. They know how to look after themselves and have not gone poor. It was ordinary smokers, many of whom earned very little, who were forced to turn over an ever-larger share of their income to the state. Governments love sales taxes. They are not as readily noticeable as taxes on income. And their targets are usually the poor, who are unlikely to protest as vehemently as the rich.

More sinister has been the role of the corporations. Anxious about the costs of providing their workforce with health care coverage, corporate managers launched a fierce campaign to compel their employees to lead healthy lives. It was not enough that they did not smoke at the workplace. They could not smoke outside the workplace either. They could not drink. And they had to maintain a proper diet. Ted Turner, the founder of CNN, for example, refused to hire smokers. A few years ago, the Florida Supreme Court ruled that it was not a violation of privacy for an employer to ask a job applicant whether or not he had smoked over the previous 12 months. A desire to reduce health insurance costs, the Court argued, constituted reasonable grounds for not hiring someone.

The health care costs are ludicrously exaggerated. And deliberately so, for it provides the corporations with an excuse to intrude into their employees' personal lives. And it provides government with a basis to make a bogus financial claim. Smokers are not a net cost to society. The US academic W. Kip Viscusi argues that smokers will die before non-smokers. Therefore, whatever the health care they may inflict on others during their lifetimes, these would be more than offset by the financial gains that arise from lower nursing home costs, not to mention foregone retirement pensions and social security claims.

The biggest financial burden today is not treatment of the sick but support of the elderly. In Britain the figures are quite startling. Within 30 years Britain is expected to be devoting around 5 per cent of its GNP to long-term care for the elderly - almost the resources the National Health Service as a whole currently commands. Eleven million people receive retirement benefits today, up from £8 million in 1975. In 1999 Britain spent £99 billion on social security benefits, doubling in real terms over 20 years.

Nearly half of this expenditure was on the elderly who, in addition to retirement pensions, may be entitled to income support, housing and council tax benefits. They may also receive home care, day care and meal services. Moreover, if they are sick and disabled, they may be entitled to incapacity benefits, war pensions and statutory sick pay. And that does not even include the amount spent on their medical care. In 1990, there were 3.4 people of working age to every pensioner. By 2031, the ratio may change to 2.7 to one. According to one projection, by the year 2050, 75 per cent of the population will be looking for support from the remaining 25 per cent.

Thus the State's financial claims on the tobacco industry are without foundation. In any case, are smokers really that much more unhealthy than non-smokers? Interestingly, it is hard to get an answer to that question.

The American Center for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 400,000 people die every year from smoking-related diseases. How it arrives at this figure has always been a bit of a mystery. For one thing, what exactly is a smoking-related disease? According to the CDC it is something a smoker is more likely to get than a non-smoker. Thus if a smoker dies of heart disease, say, the CDC will count it as a smoking-related death. This means that other possible causes, such as a family history of heart disease or chronic lack of exercise, are resolutely ignored. Moreover, the CDC does not like to tell us at what age these 400,000 died. The suggestion is they died young. Yet there is no evidence of this.

Everyone dies of something. Dying of lung cancer at 75 is not the same as dying of it at 45. As a Cato Institute study pointed out: 'Almost 255,000 of the smoking-related deaths - nearly 60 percent of the total - occurred at age 70 or above. More than 192,000 deaths - nearly 45 percent of the total - occurred at age 75 or higher. And roughly 72,000 deaths - almost 17 percent of the total - occurred at the age of 85 or above.'

The CDC loves to cite meaningless statistics, such as: 'Men who smoke increase their risk of death from lung cancer by more than 22 times and from bronchitis and emphysema by nearly 10 times.' Well, it all rather depends on what the likelihood of non-smokers dying from lung cancer is. If the chances are very small, then 22 times this figure will still not amount to a huge number. 'On average,' the CDC claims, 'smokers die nearly seven years earlier than nonsmokers'. Seven years is by no means an insignificant number if true. On the other hand, it is a far cry from the doom-laden tales of the anti-smoking zealots. A 1991 RAND study claimed that smoking 'reduces the life expectancy of a 20-year-old by about 4.3 years'. I think I can stand to lose 4.3 years from my life. As Harry Lime explained in The Third Man : 'The dead are happier dead. They don't miss much here, poor devils.'

They may also receive home care, day care and meal services. Moreover, if they are sick and disabled, they may be entitled to incapacity benefits, war pensions and statutory sick pay. And that does not even include the amount spent on their medical care. In 1990, there were 3.4 people of working age to every pensioner. By 2031, the ratio may change to 2.7 to one. According to one projection, by the year 2050, 75 per cent of the population will be looking for support from the remaining 25 per cent. Thus the State's financial claims on the tobacco industry are without foundation. In any case, are smokers really that much more unhealthy than non-smokers? Interestingly, it is hard to get an answer to that question. The American Center for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 400,000 people die every year from smoking-related diseases. How it arrives at this figure has always been a bit of a mystery. For one thing, what exactly is a smoking-related disease? According to the CDC it is something a smoker is more likely to get than a non-smoker. Thus if a smoker dies of heart disease, say, the CDC will count it as a smoking-related death. This means that other possible causes, such as a family history of heart disease or chronic lack of exercise, are resolutely ignored. Moreover, the CDC does not like to tell us at what age these 400,000 died. The suggestion is they died young. Yet there is no evidence of this. Everyone dies of something. Dying of lung cancer at 75 is not the same as dying of it at 45. As a Cato Institute study pointed out: 'Almost 255,000 of the smoking-related deaths - nearly 60 percent of the total - occurred at age 70 or above. More than 192,000 deaths - nearly 45 percent of the total - occurred at age 75 or higher. And roughly 72,000 deaths - almost 17 percent of the total - occurred at the age of 85 or above.' The CDC loves to cite meaningless statistics, such as: 'Men who smoke increase their risk of death from lung cancer by more than 22 times and from bronchitis and emphysema by nearly 10 times.' Well, it all rather depends on what the likelihood of non-smokers dying from lung cancer is. If the chances are very small, then 22 times this figure will still not amount to a huge number. 'On average,' the CDC claims, 'smokers die nearly seven years earlier than nonsmokers'. Seven years is by no means an insignificant number if true. On the other hand, it is a far cry from the doom-laden tales of the anti-smoking zealots. A 1991 RAND study claimed that smoking 'reduces the life expectancy of a 20-year-old by about 4.3 years'. I think I can stand to lose 4.3 years from my life. As Harry Lime explained in The Third Man : 'The dead are happier dead. They don't miss much here, poor devils.'

webTitle: Bill Gates pledges $100m to fight Aids

fields.headline: Bill Gates pledges $100m to fight Aids
fields.standfirst:
Largest boost to vaccine research

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Largest boost to vaccine research
fields.body:
He is already the world's most generous individual benefactor, giving more to charitable causes than the US government. Now Bill Gates, who has committed himself to spreading medical advances to Third World countries, has given the largest single boost to the worldwide search for an Aids vaccine.

The Microsoft founder yesterday pledged $100 million (almost £70m) to the International Aids Vaccine Initiative. He has teamed up with the internet company Yahoo!, which donated an extra $5m.

It is one of the single biggest donations from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, a charitable foundation - the world's richest - with assets of more than $21 billion. Its aim is to share advances in medicine with developing countries.

In the past two months, the foundation, run by Gates's father, has given $25m for Aids prevention in Nigeria, and $15m to develop drugs for African sleeping sickness. It also supports the global effort to eradicate polio from the world. Gates has pledged to donate more than $1bn a year throughout his lifetime to charitable causes, and last year gave away $1.44bn (almost £1bn).

His generosity has been escalating while his wealth plummets. Just over a year ago he was worth almost $100bn, the richest man in history. But the collapse in the Microsoft share price has brought his wealth down to a relatively impoverished $34bn.

Gates made the announcement at the world economic summit at the ski resort of Davos in Switzerland, bringing together the world's political and business leaders. He wanted to spur others into raising the rest of the target of $550m needed by the International Aids Vaccine Initiative. 'A vaccine is the only way to end Aids for all time,' said Gates.

The pledges came as Dr Seth Berkley, the head of the Aids vaccine initiative, announced that the first vaccine designed specifically for Africa - the hardest hit continent - will enter clinical trials in Nairobi after winning approval from the Kenyan government.

webTitle: Letters: We know better than your Barefoot Doctor

fields.headline: We know better
fields.trailText: People over the age of 40 have difficulty reading because the lens of the eye becomes progressively more stiff and so focusing becomes more difficult. It has nothing to do with the eyes being the flowers of the liver, as said by your Barefoot Doctor (Life, last week).
fields.body:
People over the age of 40 have difficulty reading because the lens of the eye becomes progressively more stiff and so focusing becomes more difficult. It has nothing to do with the eyes being the flowers of the liver, as said by your Barefoot Doctor (Life, last week), any more than tinnitus is explained by the ears being the flowers of the kidney, an earlier nonsensical explanation.

We have moved on in understanding of human anatomy and physiology since the Chinese formed their ideas 5,000 years ago.
Dr Neville W Goodman
Consultant Anaesthetist
Southmead Hospital
Bristol

webTitle: Letters: In defence of social workers

fields.headline: Experience is all
fields.trailText: Tell us, Pat Smith (Letters, last week), which army of mothers would you recruit - Judith Kilshaw? Rosemary West? Anna Climbie's aunt? Joan Crawford?
fields.body:
Tell us, Pat Smith (Letters, last week), which army of mothers would you recruit - Judith Kilshaw? Rosemary West? Anna Climbie's aunt? Joan Crawford?

The only 'army' social work needs is of people who are thorough, have experience of life, possess sound judgment, and not given to leaping to conclusions. That army would contain men as well as women, with or without children of their own.

And for readers' reassurance, the average age of social work students is mid-thirties - mature entrants who have relevant life experience. No one fresh out of university with a sociology degree but no relevant experience would get anywhere near a social work course.
Jan Hill
London N17

webTitle: Letters: Don't slam NHS

fields.headline: Don't slam NHS
fields.trailText: I find the article entitled 'How the Doctors have failed my disabled daughter' (News, last week) appalling. It is ridiculous and irresponsible to devote a high-profile article to the damnation of doctors, based on the anecdotes of one individual and those of her friends and family.
fields.body:
I find the article entitled 'How the Doctors have failed my disabled daughter' (News, last week) appalling. It is ridiculous and irresponsible to devote a high-profile article to the damnation of doctors, based on the anecdotes of one individual and those of her friends and family.

There are thousands of NHS workers trying to do their jobs in the face of an understaffed, under resourced and over-burdened system.

Doctors can only offer a service within the confines of the resources allocated to us. These are wholly inadequate. It is therefore no surprise patients and people like Linnet Macintyre feel let down. They are not let down by doctors or their attitudes, but by the system as a whole and by the society that engineers it.
Dr Michael England
Northwick Park Hospital
Harrow, Middx

webTitle: Barthez, the best buy

fields.headline: Barthez, the best buy
fields.standfirst: Master of his area and beyond, United's keeper is the complete package
fields.trailText: The master of his area and beyond, United's keeper is the complete package.
fields.body:
Eight million pounds might be a lot to pay for a goalkeeper, and that record sum doesn't even include the expense incurred in hiring and firing Massimo Taibi and Mark Bosnich. But few would deny Manchester United's Fabien Barthez represents value for money.

If 10 years of football inflation makes the French World Cup winner seem less of a snip than Peter Schmeichel at £550,000, bear in mind there was a degree of risk in bringing the relatively untried Dane to England from Brondby in 1991. Schmeichel only shot to prominence a year later with Denmark's unexpected European Championship success, and gradually came to be regarded as perhaps the best in the world during his eight years at Old Trafford.

There is no perhaps about Barthez. A European Cup winner with Marseille at the tender age of 21, the Monaco goalkeeper was signed as the world's best, with a price tag, World Cup and Euro 2000 winner's medals to prove it. Italy's Francesco Toldo, on the back of an impressive European Championship, was the only other goalkeeper in the reckoning for Fifa World Player 2000, but Barthez was the higher placed. Higher, in fact, than Marcel Desailly, Pavel Nedved, Alessandro del Piero and many more influential outfield players.

Yet some would say an influential outfield player is exactly what Barthez is. 'He's not like other goalkeepers,' said Tony Coton, United's goalkeeping coach. 'He doesn't see his job as just stopping you losing games. He tries his best to help you win games too.'

In this respect, Barthez has been greatly assisted by the rule change that allows goalkeepers to take more than four steps. Such was his readiness at the start of the season to race to the edge of his penalty area and immediately release a team-mate halfway up the pitch it was assumed he had adapted to the new rule quicker than most.

In fact the change could have been made for his benefit, and had United signed him at the start of last season, as they originally wanted to, they would have found his distribution restricted by enforced immobility. 'For once we've got a rule that actually frees goalkeepers,' Barthez said. 'I always want to keep the momentum going and this is a great rule for me, one that really suits my temperament.'

Not that Barthez is only about distribution, or that he does not catch the eye in the traditional goalkeeper's role between the posts. 'France would not have won Euro 2000 but for him,' said Gérard Houllier, who in his time as French coach gave Barthez his international debut.

'He kept them in the final with his saves when Italy were one-up. He is the best in the world in my opinion, and he has given Manchester United added value.'

According to Sir Alex Ferguson, the special quality Barthez brings, apart from his superb athleticism, is authority at the back. He doesn't do it the same way as the hectoring Schmeichel, but he rules his penalty area and beyond, rarely failing to take charge once he has decided to come for a ball. United's defenders are slightly in awe of him - which was never the case when Taibi or Bosnich were playing - and Ferguson clearly prefers it that way.

So assured is Barthez under high crosses that Coton admits he was slightly surprised on meeting him for the first time to discover he was smaller than he had imagined. 'At six feet he's not the tallest of goalkeepers, but he gets up much higher than anyone else,' Coton said. 'He's got a great spring, though I think what really counts is the speed of his decision-making. He starts off while others are still thinking about it. He had me worried once or twice at first, going for balls I thought he'd never reach, but I soon realised I was making judgments based on my standards, not his. He covers the ground much more quickly.'

This brings us to a slightly delicate question, and one which Coton, a modest man, is able to anticipate. 'I know, what can I teach the world's best goalkeeper?' the former Birmingham, Watford and Manchester City stalwart hazarded.

'The answer is nothing. Absolutely sod all, and I told him that on the first day. He knows what he wants, what he needs, and I'm just here to help him get it. All I'm doing is keeping the world's number one ticking over, but between us we must be doing something right.

'Not only is Fabien training and playing very well, but he has complimented the club on treating him like an adult, which apparently was not always the case at Monaco.'

Barthez was pictured with Catherine Deneuve on Wednesday at the Paris launch of Yves Saint Laurent's spring/summer collection, which is not something Jim Leighton used to get up to, though United are relaxed about their goalkeeper's lifestyle as long as he remains focused on his game.

Which so far he clearly has. 'He's laid-back off the field and switched-on during matches,' Coton said. 'That's a good combination. As for all the fuss about swapping Monaco for Manchester, I can honestly say I've never seen any overseas player adapt so easily. He's a footballer responding positively to a footballing environment.

'Even when it's been pouring down with rain in training the only thing I've ever heard him say about Monaco is that there is nobody there in winter and too many people in summer. Restaurants are either shut up or booked up. That's one problem we don't have in Manchester.'

webTitle: MI6 'abused our mentally ill son'

fields.headline: MI6 'abused our mentally ill son'
fields.standfirst: Britain must apologise for cowardly exploitation, say parents of Russian diplomat who became spy
fields.trailText: Britain must apologise for cowardly exploitation, say parents of Russian diplomat who became spy.
fields.body:
The parents of a jailed Russian diplomat have denounced MI6 as a disgrace for the 'cowardly and ugly' way it exploited their son's mental illness in recruiting him as an undercover British agent.

Alexei Obukhov, a former Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, has demanded an apology from Britain for MI6's 'cynical' operation to extract information from his son in the full knowledge he was mentally disturbed.

The allegation in the memoirs of renegade spy Richard Tomlinson that MI6 staff referred to Platon Obukhov as 'completely off his rocker' comes as a new embarrassment to the British secret services, calling into question the ethics of its spy recruitment.

Tomlinson claims that MI6 officials were under such pressure to meet pre-set targets of CX (the MI6 code for secret intelligence) from Russia they were ready to overlook not only the morality of recruiting such an informant, but also the quality of the information he could provide.

Platon Obukhov is held in one of Moscow's harshest prisons, his mental health rapidly deteriorating, with no access to treatment. He was sentenced to 11 years in a top-security jail last year, after a Moscow judge ruled that he was simulating madness to evade a treason conviction. The court rejected arguments by his family and doctors that he had been mentally ill since childhood, suffering from a degenerative form of schizophrenia.This month the Supreme Court granted him the right to an appeal.

In his book The Big Breach , soon to be published in Moscow, and which the British Government tried to ban, Tomlinson writes that an agent named Spencer was given the task of handling Obukhov in the early 1990s. Obukhov had been given the impressive codename Masterwork. It became obvious to Spencer after their first debriefing session, however, that Obukhov was not well. 'Masterwork's a nutter!' he told Tomlinson. MI6's new protégé had arrived at their meeting in a Mickey Mouse hat and clutching the manuscript of the 'manic and twisted book' he was writing. 'The guy should be getting psychiatric help, there's no way we should be running him as an agent.'

Tomlinson writes that Spencer's advice was ignored in contravention of MI6 rules that prohibit recruitment of anyone believed to be mentally ill. In an earlier chapter, Tomlinson suggests that the agency's Moscow operation was under pressure to perform after several expensive schemes failed.

Obukhov's father, a respected diplomat who was deputy to Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze under Mikhail Gorbachev's administration, welcomed the revelations, which he said came as the long-awaited vindication of his own arguments. 'The whole case is a disgrace. This is a very mild word for it,' he said. 'This extract simply proves what we have been saying all along - my son was not well and MI6 used him.'

The family had been mystified by why MI6 chose to work with someone so patently unwell. 'When you recruit someone that you are going to work with for a long time, you build up a careful psychological portrait of them. We have been asking ourselves for years how an experienced security service could recruit a mentally ill informant,' Platon's mother, Olga Obukhova, said. 'We thought it was stupidity or incompetence. Now it appears that they were simply motivated by ignoble intentions.'

She believes MI6 may have aimed to discredit her husband by setting up her son.

Obukhov, now 32, held only a very junior post as a third secretary in Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and would not have had access to any sensitive information, she said. He was using his diplomatic career to provide material for the espionage thrillers that he wrote in his spare time.

This was also the reason for his decision to accept MI6's offer of employment, according to an interview he gave shortly after his arrest in 1996. Before his imprisonment, he successfully published a series of lurid and violent thrillers, with titles like The Sex Demon and In The Embrace of the Spider; a psychiatrist later concluded that these were the works of a disturbed mind.

In the same televised interview, where he spoke incoherently, rolling his eyes and grinning strangely, Obukhov admitted he had been paid $2,000 (£1,330) a month by the British and would occasionally receive an extra $1,000 payment for 'important information'.

Despite his evident eccentricities, Obukhov was treated as a serious spy during his trial last year, with the Russian authorities apparently determined to portray him as a key player in the British spy network, presenting the case as a major counter-intelligence coup. His arrest triggered the worst spy row between London and Moscow, with the Kremlin expelling four British diplomats and London responding with the tit-for-tat expulsion of their Russian counterparts.

'MI6 wanted to show that they had recruited a superspy and the FSB [the post-Soviet successor of the KGB] wanted to show that they had unmasked a superspy. They were trying to justify their work, and officials in both agencies were just after promotion; our son was their victim,' Obukhova said.

'You couldn't imagine someone less suitable for the job. In some areas he was very knowledgeable; in other areas he had the mind of a six-year-old.'

She and her husband had become concerned about his health when he was nine and, later, he began to display symptoms of paranoia, unpredictable and sometimes violent behaviour and epilepsy. Obukhov himself remains unaware of his illness.

'I have no respect for MI6 - they are simply scoundrels who have destroyed my son's life and devastated our family. They exploited him in a cowardly and ugly fashion. The whole affair has been a tragedy for us. The British taxpayers should not stand for the way their money has been wasted,' she said.

Tomlinson's memoirs state that Spencer initially had bi-monthly meetings with Obukhov in the Estonian capital, Tallinn, and allege that Dominic Lawson, editor of the Spectator at the time, agreed to allow Spencer to assume the cover of a journalist working for the magazine. Lawson last week dismissed the claim as 'complete rubbish'.

Tomlinson concludes: 'The Russians were alerted to Masterwork by his rambling boastings that he was a spy, but the real fault lay with MI6, who should never have continued to run an agent who was so manifestly unstable.'

MI6 officials have dismissed Tomlinson's book as a mixture of fact and fiction. But although Obukhov's parents were surprised by some of the detail included about their son, and said they were not aware of any trips to Tallinn, they said the essence of the passage rang true.

'If it is true MI6 knew he was mentally ill, then we expect an apology from the British Government,' his mother said. 'Until now we have heard nothing from them. We would also like them to help him. He needs medical help, but MI6 has never fought for him - they used him and then abandoned him.'

Despite his evident eccentricities, Obukhov was treated as a serious spy during his trial last year, with the Russian authorities apparently determined to portray him as a key player in the British spy network, presenting the case as a major counter-intelligence coup. His arrest triggered the worst spy row between London and Moscow, with the Kremlin expelling four British diplomats and London responding with the tit-for-tat expulsion of their Russian counterparts. 'MI6 wanted to show that they had recruited a superspy and the FSB [the post-Soviet successor of the KGB] wanted to show that they had unmasked a superspy. They were trying to justify their work, and officials in both agencies were just after promotion; our son was their victim,' Obukhova said. 'You couldn't imagine someone less suitable for the job. In some areas he was very knowledgeable; in other areas he had the mind of a six-year-old.' She and her husband had become concerned about his health when he was nine and, later, he began to display symptoms of paranoia, unpredictable and sometimes violent behaviour and epilepsy. Obukhov himself remains unaware of his illness. 'I have no respect for MI6 - they are simply scoundrels who have destroyed my son's life and devastated our family. They exploited him in a cowardly and ugly fashion. The whole affair has been a tragedy for us. The British taxpayers should not stand for the way their money has been wasted,' she said. Lawson last week dismissed the claim as 'complete rubbish'. Tomlinson concludes: 'The Russians were alerted to Masterwork by his rambling boastings that he was a spy, but the real fault lay with MI6, who should never have continued to run an agent who was so manifestly unstable.' MI6 officials have dismissed Tomlinson's book as a mixture of fact and fiction. But although Obukhov's parents were surprised by some of the detail included about their son, and said they were not aware of any trips to Tallinn, they said the essence of the passage rang true. 'If it is true MI6 knew he was mentally ill, then we expect an apology from the British Government,' his mother said. 'Until now we have heard nothing from them. We would also like them to help him. He needs medical help, but MI6 has never fought for him - they used him and then abandoned him.'

webTitle: 'Whore' fights to become a heroine

fields.headline: 'Whore' fights to become a heroine
fields.standfirst: A woman accused of corruption is vowing to clean up France
fields.trailText: A woman accused of corruption is vowing to clean up France
fields.body:
She called herself 'the whore of the republic'. Her former lover called her France's Mata Hari. But in the country's biggest post-war sleaze trial, Christine Deviers-Joncour is trying to show she's a changed woman. The problem is, the court seems to prefer the old version.

Everyone in the packed Paris courtroom was laughing at Deviers-Joncour last week. At one point, she leapt to her feet to say she had worked tirelessly for Elf-Aquitaine, and allegations that she received 64.5 million francs (nearly £7m) from the oil giant for a job involving no real work were false.

But the judge, Sophie Portier, cut her short with a jibe: 'You put your body and soul into the job.' Deviers-Joncour sank back down, her head in her hands as the small wood-panelled room collapsed in roars of laughter.

Two years ago, Deviers-Joncour wrote a book, The Whore of the Republic, in which she admitted she was paid by the then state-owned firm to lobby her lover, Roland Dumas, the late President François Mitterrand's Foreign Minister, to win approval for a colossal arms deal with Taiwan.

What could the judge's jibe mean, other than that the former lingerie model had used her body to woo one of France's leading politicians into a world of corruption and lies to benefit Elf Aquitaine?

It hurt because Deviers-Joncour is portraying herself as a latter-day Mary Magdalene who fell, but who has since found her way again. She is no longer the 'whore of the republic', but the figure of Liberty herself, leading France's honest, brave people out of the rubble of sleaze.

And France needs someone to perform that task. Corruption oozes from its body politic. President Jacques Chirac has still not properly answered accusations that the coffers of his Gaullist RPR party were swollen by covert slush funds in the Eighties.

But no sooner was that scandal revealed than ano-ther stole its thunder. The French press called it 'Angolagate', a huge money-laundering and arms-trafficking scam involving the illicit sale to Angola of £350m-worth of Russian helicopters, tanks, weapons and other military equipment in 1993 and 1994. It embroiled Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, the late President's son, and implicated many senior politicians.

Now this third corruption case is riveting the nation. It is a soap opera, complete with a silver-haired seducer of a politician and a spurned lover, illegal arms sales, lavish parties and lots of cash.

Deviers-Joncour has portrayed herself as the victim of machinations by Elf's second in command, Alfred Sirven. He is charged with corruption along with her, Dumas and four other senior company officials. Unfortunately, Sirven is being tried in absentia. He is believed to be living a high life in the Philippines.

Perhaps not surprisingly, he has been blamed by co-defendants for setting up the slush fund, feathering colleagues' nests and trying to buy off one of France's most senior politicians with the aid of the former model's charms.

In the Whore of the Republic, which brought the whole Elf scandal luridly before the country, Deviers-Joncour claimed the firm hired her in 1989 because of her 'amorous' relationship with Dumas. Although billed as a public relations consultant, she had no office, and conducted all her 'business' - dinners, receptions and introductions - from a £1.7m Left Bank apartment paid for by Sirven.

The book stopped well short of implicating her lover. She claimed he never gave in to her lobbying, received no money from Elf and knew nothing of the £6m commission she took for the deal. Elf also settled her credit card bills of up to £20,000 a month.

In return, she was expected to persuade her lover to serve the company's interests. Deviers-Joncour claimed she represented good value.

On one occasion, Sirven used her to get the itinerary of a presidential tour changed because it excluded a country in which Elf had 'important interests'.

Deviers-Joncour had to fly to New York, where her lover was involved in talks at the United Nations. She dogged his footsteps until Dumas agreed, telling her: 'Well done, little soldier. You've won. Now you can go home.'

Elf won an 'enormous contract' as a consequence, prompting her to claim she deserved a life pension from Elf for that deal alone, 'and there were others'.

Indeed, she claimed to be serving it so assiduously that she risked annoying Dumas, who began calling her Mata Hari and asked: 'Are you here for me or for Elf-Aquitaine?'

Then she changed her story. She confessed to the magazine Paris-Match that she had lied to protect her lover. Was this the revenge of the spurned lover, or just a new desire to tell the truth? Either way, she seemed determined to bring Dumas down with her.

Both were investigated, and he resigned as president of the Constitutional Council, France's senior legal authority.

In court last week she changed her story again, claiming Dumas had not pressurised Elf to appoint her. This was a great fillip for the former Foreign Minister's chances of avoiding prosecution. But this story was contradicted later by one of the Elf officials on trial. He said he had signed Deviers-Joncour's employment contract at Dumas's request.

The nervous, pencil-thin Deviers-Joncour, aged 53, looked tired and drawn throughout the week, and wept several times.

Dumas railed against her when he appeared as a witness last Wednesday. 'She was an emissary,' he said, but not for Le Floch-Prigent (Elf's head in the early Nineties), rather for Sirven.

Deviers-Joncour, on the verge of tears, shouted: 'But I came to your office with M Le Floch-Prigent! Why are you denying it? It drives me crazy!'

Dumas, a former barrister, retained his sang froid throughout. She was less composed in giving her evidence, repeatedly answering questions by saying: 'I don't know'. His case seemed to strengthen, hers to weaken.

Maybe the 'whore of the republic' will take the fall for the man called 'the prince of intrigue in Mitterrand's palace'. There will be three more weeks of courtroom drama before we find out.

webTitle: Baroness buys liberty for slaves

fields.headline: Baroness buys liberty for slaves
fields.standfirst: Baroness Cox has bought and freed 1,500 people. She calls it 'first aid'. Others call it folly
fields.trailText: Baroness Cox has bought and freed 1,500 people. She calls it 'first aid'. Others call it folly.
fields.body:
She sits perched on a pile of bricks, her demure appearance, smart safari jacket and neat Alice band belying the grim nature of her task. To some she is a saint, a liberator. To others she is responsible for encouraging one of the most evil trades practised on the globe.

She is haggling for slaves. In front of her are two masked traders. Between them is a leather suitcase containing $24,000 (£16,000) in banknotes. Under nearby trees 300 slaves, mostly women and children with their wrists tied and confusion etched on their faces, squat while their destiny is bartered over.

She is Baroness Cox, educationalist, writer and a Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords. But now she is thousands of miles away from the cloisters of Westminster, engaged on a perilous mission within range of artillery on the front line in the brutal Sudanese civil war, to rescue a wretched band of Sudanese peasants from a life of captivity.

'We are happy to offer $50 per person. Is that acceptable to the gentlemen?' Cox asks.

The two dealers look down and ease their toes in and out of their plastic flip-flops. They elbow their translator.

'You tell the lady frankly that we have bought every person here from slave owners for one million Sudanese currency, equivalent to $200. Do you have any idea what the price of a camel is?'

One hour later, Cox, fiddling with her jewellery, set tles on $60 a slave if the dealers throw in an extra 53 people. 'Shall we show them the dosh? she asks Stuart Windsor, a Pentecostal preacher carrying the case. The total paid is the equivalent in Sudan of £300,000. The slave traders grab her hands in appreciation. Then Cox turns to her crouching crowd of human purchases and tells them they can go free. They stand, bewildered, before they are untied. They are free.

Caroline Cox, 62, campaigner for Christian values, was made a peer by Margaret Thatcher in 1982, and became Deputy Speaker of the Lords in 1986. In the past three years, she has made five trips to Sudan and bought 1,496 slaves, at around £45 a head, in order to set them free. She calls it 'first aid'.

Detractors, including Anti-Slavery International, the UN children's agency Unicef, and Save the Children call her the 'loony libertarian'. They say paying dealers will only prolong the practice of slave-trading. Cox says she is tired of waiting for the international community to come up with a long-term solution, and while it does not, someone must act.

Sudan, the largest country in Africa, is the only place in the world where political slavery persists. Slaves do not inherit servant status from their parents; they are abducted from villages by militia men and marched across the countryside to herd cattle or wait on families. Anti-Slavery International says the numbers may seem trivial compared to large-scale bonded labour in India, but are still vast. Around 14,000 people in Sudan have been enslaved since the mid-Eighties, casualties of 18 years of continuing civil war between government and rebels, which has killed two million people and displaced five million.

Most slaves sleep with animals, in quarters separate from their master's house. They are disciplined and taught the new language of their owners. Often they are shot, whipped, abused and given new names. Many blank out their pre-slave past, scarred by memories of rape and ransacked villages.

Cox knows the Sudanese government wanted to kill her. 'I try to play tennis to keep fit because one never knows when we are going to have to run for our lives through the bush. Of course, I'm just as likely to be taken out in an accident in Britain,' she says. 'I have fits of fearful dread,' says Cox. 'But then I remember the privilege of being with the kind of people we meet, their courage, their cheerfulness.' She often interviews freed slaves at length.

Among her most recent purchases were Ajok Alwal, 19, abducted by militia with her small child, carried off over a horse, beaten with thorns and forced to walk through towns naked and barefoot. She was taken to her captor's family, forced to work in the kitchen, starved and raped by his son. 'They all mistreated me. I had to sleep on the floor in the kitchen and eat the leftovers. I had to work hard washing clothes and cleaning,' she said.

Ajok escaped and set off to find the traders she knew sold slaves to Cox. She handed herself over and stayed with the traders for one month, huddling with the others in an enclosure while the traders went looking for other slaves for the sale. The crowd of human merchandise travelled by night. She said the traders had guns, but they kept them hidden.

'Once we are free, I will meet my [family]. I have heard they are all right. But according to our Dinka tradition, bad news is kept until a person returns home,' Ajok said.

Cox is president of Christian Solidarity Worldwide, and visits Sudan under its banner. The charity raises £1.3 million a year, mostly from individual Christian donors of all denominations, and part of the money to buy the latest batch of slaves came from donors at a Salvation Army convention in Southport last year. Leading figures in the Salvation Army alone raised £50,000 for the slave redemptions. 'We are a Christian organisation and part of our mandate is to set captives free, whatever their faith,' says Stuart Windsor, director of Christian Solidarity .

Cox is now planning her next trip, adamant that fixing a date with traders before she goes does not create a slave economy. Her missions also include food drops and the provision of medical supplies.

'I find it macabre, grotesque and utterly tragic that I hand money to slave traders. It shouldn't be necessary in 2001. But my arrival in Sudan with a huge wodge of bank notes does not cause slavery to happen. It's not the final solution either, but I can't look a child in the eye and say you must remain a slave until someone finds a political solution to slavery. I can't live in peace believing these women and children should remain slaves if I have the means to release them.'

webTitle: Tape of Wilde reading ballad is a fake, says British Library

fields.headline: Tape of Wilde reading ballad is a fake, says British Library
fields.trailText: It was the most distinctive voice of the Victorian era: a languid drawl mixed with an Irish brogue that enunciated some of the wittiest lines in the language.
fields.body:
It was the most distinctive voice of the Victorian era: a languid drawl mixed with an Irish brogue that enunciated some of the wittiest lines in the language.

But now the only recording of the speech of Oscar Wilde has been exposed as a fake. Experts have discovered that the crackling tones of the man reading the last three stanzas of The Ballad of Reading Gaol did not belong to the writer.

Allegedly made in 1900, the recording - part of the British Library's sound archive - was found last week to have been created in the Sixties. The Library said the tape was a fake.

By studying surface noise and background clicks of the recording - supposedly made on a wax cylinder from which an acetate disc was copied - Library experts Peter Copeland and Jonathan Vickers showed it was created at a speed incompatible with devices of the era.

Such machines operated at 120 revolutions per minute. However, the Wilde recording suggests a 78rpm machine.

The discovery that the barely discernable speech is not that of Wilde may dismay archivists and fans. The writer, however, would probably have felt vindicated. As he once said: 'Nowadays, to be intelligible is to be found out.'

At the time Wilde was supposed to have made the recording he was living in France after serving two years in prison for sodomy.

He was spotted in Paris, it was said, and asked to talk into a speaking machine in one of the stands devoted to Thomas Edison's inventions. According to the story, he then recited Part VI of the ballad. The recording lasts less than two minutes and at the end the name Oscar Wilde is clearly stated.

Wilde's biographer Montgomery Hyde was confident the recording was genuine because Wilde's son Vyvyan Holland said so. But Holland heard those words more than 60 years after seeing his father and later disowned the tape.

webTitle: British men are cleanest in Europe

fields.headline: British men are cleanest in Europe
fields.standfirst: Sales of male beauty products climb to $1bn
fields.trailText: Sales of male beauty products climb to $1bn.
fields.body:
British men have been lampooned for their shabby approach to personal grooming. Liam Gallagher made a career with his lank hair and permanent five o'clock shadow, while Shane MacGowan, the former Pogues lead singer, proudly boasted a mouthful of rotting teeth.

But the male has turned a new leaf, according to a new study which shows the UK now leads Europe in the market for male grooming prod ucts. Sales of fragrances and shampoos are expected to smash the $1 billion barrier for the first time, based on last year's figures.

With exfoliation and facial scrubs the new buzzwords, British men are surging ahead in the European league of male foppery after lagging behind for decades. 'Huge amounts of money have been targeted by manufacturers persuading men to spend more,' said Rhod Jones, an analyst at Datamonitor, which carried out the study.

'They're trading up from supermarket shampoos and not just using their girlfriends' products. But men's fear of being seen using skincare and haircare products has also substantially reduced in the last decade. Some of that appears to be generational.'

British men spent £661 million on grooming products in 1999. In 1995, the market was worth just £492m to companies which tried for decades to promote first 'butch' and then 'unisex' shampoos and fragrances to men previously unwilling to dabble with what was perceived as a female preserve.

'Our latest research suggests clearly that British men are becoming more comfortable about wanting to improve their appearance,' said Nick Peters at Procter and Gamble, who have just spent £3m developing a new range of male hair products. 'Image and packaging is deliberately moving away from the macho, phallic black chrome style of the late 1980s. It is now subtler and gentler. That reflects the preferences of purchasers.'

'Circ', the new range, comes in a light blue 'hip-flask'. Instead of being launched with the help of football stars or topless models - the traditional method of promoting male bathroom products - the range is being introduced to shopping centres around the country with a mobile 'male creche'. webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Motorists were warned to take extra care on the roads as weathermen forecast that the big freeze is set to continue across much of the country. The warning came as one motorist was killed and a police officer injured after they were struck by a car while directing traffic in separate incidents caused by ice on the roads.
fields.body:
Warning to motorists as big freeze sets in

Motorists were warned to take extra care on the roads as weathermen forecast that the big freeze is set to continue across much of the country. The warning came as one motorist was killed and a police officer injured after they were struck by a car while directing traffic in separate incidents caused by ice on the roads.

Wintry showers are predicted across western parts of Scotland while most of the country will wake up to frost.

AA Roadwatch warned motorists in the south and the home counties to be extra vigilant. Surrey, Berkshire, Bedfordshire and Essex are all highlighted as problem areas with Essex , East and West Sussex showing signs of flooding. An AA spokesman said: 'The general rule for drivers is to take care, take a blanket, a mobile phone and a shovel.'

Antarctic mission on ice

A second mission is planned to help clean up pollution left by a Russian research station in the Antarctic despite the death of Philippa Gregory, 26, aboard the yacht 2041 on Thursday.

The expedition, which set off on 16 January, was aborted but another is planned for February.

Crew missing

The St Helier Lifeboat was searching for Paul le Riche, one of its own crewmen, who was aboard the Jersey fishing boat the Saint Paol which disappeared last week.

The body of the skipper, John Roberts, 38, was found on the shore on Friday.

Rock injury

Mary Paul, 48, was seriously injured when a rock thrown up by another vehicle smashed through the windscreen of her car and struck her head near Swindon.

John Inman recovering in London hospital

Actor John Inman, 65, above, star of the sitcom Are You Being Served? , was recovering in St Mary's Hospital, London, after spending three days in intensive care. He had been admitted with severe breathing difficulties. A hospital spokesman said: 'He is in a stable condition.'

Tobacco tax 'justified'

Customs officials have defended the government policy of levying heavy taxes on cigarettes after new figures showed tobacco consumption had risen for the first time in 25 years. Tobacco manufacturers say the taxes encourage cross-Channel smuggling but a Customs and Excise spokesman said 'criminals' should not undermine health policy. He said new resources would slow, and eventually halt, smuggling.

Shoppers clean up

Thousands of bargain hunters descended on a warehouse in Sheffield to buy items people had forgotten to pick up from dry cleaners. They included wedding outfits, designer suits and a set of racing silks.

Student wins

Maths student Aaron Virchis of Southampton has won a £500 bet that he would be offered a place a place at Cambridge University. He placed £100 at 5-1 with William Hill.

Warning over aerosols

Pet lovers were warned not to keep aerosols near animals after a dog bit through a hairspray can, causing a fire which destroyed the house of its owners' at Willenhall, in the West Midlands. A couple and their 21-month-old son and mongrel had to flee the blaze in Short Heath, after alerting fire crews.

Flood-fighters awarded freedom of York

Almost 200 soldiers from 2 Signal Regiment who helped flood relief efforts in York when the Ouse burst its banks last year were awarded the Freedom of the City. The city's Lord Mayor, Shan Braund, presented the Freedom scroll to Lieutenant-Colonel Ian Cameron-Mowat, who said it was an honour of 'which we will be proud for ever'. The soldiers then marched through the city with the scroll to exercise their freedom for the first time.

Police swoop in mass arrest

Thirty-four people have been arrested after a police operation in which drugs, knives, stolen cars and a CS gas canister were recovered. Operation, Alcatraz was carried out by South Yorkshire police in the Doncaster area and all but one of the 30 men and four women - from Doncaster, Sheffield, Goole, Scunthorpe, Manchester, Bradford and Scotland - have been charged with a total of 60 offences and released on police bail.

webTitle: Holocaust Day is one of pride and sadness

fields.headline: Holocaust Day is one of pride and sadness
fields.trailText: Gena Turgel lost eight members of her family in the Holocaust. Her 19-year-old sister, Hela, died as petrol was injected into her veins during one of Josef Mengele's 'medical' experiments. Miriam, another sister, was shot with her husband while trying to smuggle food into Plaszov.
fields.body:
Gena Turgel lost eight members of her family in the Holocaust. Her 19-year-old sister, Hela, died as petrol was injected into her veins during one of Josef Mengele's 'medical' experiments. Miriam, another sister, was shot with her husband while trying to smuggle food into Plaszov.

Janek, one of her three brothers, disappeared while trying to escape through the sewers of the Krakow ghetto, and Hermann, her eldest brother, his wife and their three children were shot in their home early in the Occupation. Lola, their youngest child, was just nine months old.

Turgel herself was 21 when the British liberated the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp at 3pm on 15 April 1945. She fled to England. 'But I could not forget,' she said, describing those in the camp who had been slowly driven mad with grief and fear, murdered on the whim of Nazi commanders.

Britain yesterday held its first Holocaust Memorial Day to remember the victims of the Holocaust and persecuted minorities everywhere.

Turgel, a 78-year-old author and campaigner, spent the day rushing from school to community hall, from television studio to radio station, dismissing the criticisms that have dogged the event and reiterating how important such a day was.

'I speak to Jewish children every day who haven't got the faintest idea what really happened,' she said. 'Their ignorance has ceased to shock me. I've simply accepted that given half the chance, people will ignore what happened, fail to ask or forget to remember. But we must never forget that these were real people with real aspirations, just like you and me, who can now only scream in silence.'

In London the Prince of Wales stood alongside the Prime Minister, Tony Blair, in the Palace of Westminster to listen to speeches from celebrities including Bob Geldof, Ian McKellen and Anthony Sher.

Later the Prime Minister told the Holocaust memorial service at Westminster Central Hall that survivors had come to Britain to rebuild their lives. 'Their memories have become part of our memories, our history. Each step humanity takes is the product of a struggle between good and evil. We know both exist in our nature. The Holocaust was the greatest act of collective evil the world has ever known. The appalling reality of the Holocaust caused a profound crisis in human civilisation.'

webTitle: Letters: Holocaust Memorial Day

fields.headline: Can we ever know how many died?
fields.trailText: Mike Davis's Late Victorian Holocausts would have complemented Will Hutton's article (Comment, last week); in terms of numbers, the Madras Famine competes with the Holocaust.
fields.body:
Mike Davis's Late Victorian Holocausts would have complemented Will Hutton's article (Comment, last week); in terms of numbers, the Madras Famine competes with the Holocaust. And more than a decade after the collapse of communism, the West still cannot acknowledge what went on during the war in Russia, where deaths exceeded those in the rest of the world. While the Holocaust must remain a special depravity, sadly there are many more to be remembered on Holocaust Day.
H N Qood
Sutton Coldfield
West Midlands

Will Hutton needn't be quite so breast-beating about England's treatment of the Jews in medieval times. William Rufus disputed with English Jews in the eleventh century, and even (according to William of Malmesbury) offered to convert if they could win a 'disputation' with the Christian clergy. The same king forbade his clergy and people from going on the First Crusade, which became an orgy of Jewish and Muslim blood, and which turned pacific Christianity into a religion that was violent and half-mad. It was the atmosphere of militant self-righteous bigotry fostered by the Crusades which led 200 years later to Edward III's expulsion of the Jews.
Chris Walker
London W14

Armenian genocide? Massacre? Civil war? Some historical context and a minimum sense of proportion, please? What about the millions of innocent Muslim Turks killed in Gallipoli in 1915 by the Allies, and afterwards in Syria, Iraq, Palestine, Jordan, Yemen, Caucasia, the Balkans and Asia Minor by the then occupying imperial British, French, Russian, Italian and Greek forces? Don't forget that 1915 was in the middle of the bloody First World War. Let's not scratch sore wounds. Leave our dead - Christian or Muslim, Armenian or Turkish - in peace.
Cavli Culfaz
Potters Bar
Herts

For the record, the BBC has complete editorial control over the broadcast of the Holocaust Memorial Day, including the introductory material produced solely for the BBC audience and, of course, John Simpson's commentary on the event itself. The BBC has agreed to use its expertise to help stage the live event, but content of that remains a matter for the Home Office.
Nick Vaughan-Barratt
BBC Factual & Learning
London W12
