webTitle: Matisse's last muse reveals the old master

fields.headline: Matisse's last muse reveals the old master
fields.standfirst: Former nurse stands to gain a fortune from selling sketches by the 80-year-old Modernist
fields.trailText: Former nurse stands to gain a fortune from selling sketches by the 80-year-old Modernist.
fields.body:
A Fench night nurse who posed for Henri Matisse in her youth is about to make a fortune as a result of her labour.

Seven sketches, drawn by the aged artist in the early 1950s while his nurse sat perfectly still, are to be sold at Christie's in London for an estimated £210,000.

The most valuable drawing, which bears a personal message to the young model and is signed in full by the artist, is expected to reach up to £60,000.

The decision taken by Denise Arokas, now a 69-year-old living in Paris, to sell sketches that she has kept with her for almost half a century has revealed an unknown creative episode at the end of the life of one of the world's most popular Modernists.

Matisse and Arokas were unlikely friends. The artist, who along with Picasso was one of the most famous painters of the day, was 60 years her senior when she was first offered the job of caring for him.

Arriving in Paris at the age of 19, the nurse from Aix en Provence got talking to a striking blonde woman with big blue eyes. She was quickly asked if she would like to start work at a home nearby.

Arokas needed the money and it sounded straightforward enough: an old gentleman needed someone to look after him as he coped with growing infirmity.

When she arrived at the house Arokas had no idea who her employer was and she simply began to read and care for him through the night. But the couple felt an immediate bond.

'He was already over 80, but that very first night, as soon as he met her, he decided he wanted to draw this elegant girl's face,' said Jerome Le Blay, a Paris-based art specialist.

Their relationship inspired the artist and changed the girl's life for good, introducing her to an entirely new, bohemian world. 'She agreed to model for him,' said Le Blay. 'It was very instinctive and night after night a real friendship developed. Her life changed for ever.'

The woman who had recruited her in Paris was Matisse's great muse, the Russian refugee Lydia Delectorskaya, who died in 1998. Quickly spotting Arokas's style and poise, 'Madame Lydia', who worked as the artist's secretary and is also believed to have been his mistress, knew that Matisse would approve of her new find.

Back in 1932 Delectorskaya had herself been approached in much the same way by another young woman who worked for Matisse. At 22 she was given the job of a temporary studio assistant and eventually usurped the artist's wife's place in the marital home. Delectorskaya is known to have been the model for the famous paintings 'The Romanian Blouse', 'The Blue Eyes' and 'Le Rêve', among others.

Soon after meeting Arokas, Matisse moved back to his studio in the Hotel Regina in Nice, and took her with him. From days spent working together and nights spent reading the Cantique des Cantiques, a series of drawings were completed.

Speaking in the run-up to the auction at Christie's, Arokas has told art experts that she took her modelling 'very seriously'. Matisse, she recalls, wore glasses and when she modelled for him she had to sit very close so that he could see her. The result was a number of important works such as the painting for the Pavillion de Marsan and large cut-out gouaches, including 'La Tristesse du Roi', now in the Museum of Modern Art in Paris.

Matisse also gave his new muse drawing lessons and one of her best early efforts was a portrait of the artist himself, on the back of which he wrote ' J'aime ce dessin! '

In late 1952 Matisse told her he wanted her to become his 'personal student' - but the lure of Paris was too strong to remain by the side of a man in his eighties and the pair parted. Matisse died two years later of a blood clot on the brain at the age of 85.

In Paris, Arokas adopted the name Rebecca and became a successful fashion model for the designers Jean Patou and Balenciaga, but her memories of Matisse have remained with her. 'He was very harmonious and not demanding. Even when he needed something in the night he would not dare to wake me. He was very charming,' she said.

The artist told her he needed to identify with his model; 'I love you,' he said, 'like a part of myself.'

Arokas has decided to sell her drawings to help fund a foundation for artists in the French countryside. The abstract pencil sketches are part of a Christie's sale of Impressionist and twentieth-century works on paper to be held on 8 February.

webTitle: Olympic heroes on their marks to boost BBC sport

fields.headline: Olympic heroes on their marks to boost BBC sport
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's biggest sports stars are in talks with the BBC about becoming television personalities after they retire.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's biggest sports stars are in talks with the BBC about becoming television personalities after they retire.

Rowing hero Steve Redgrave, his teammate Matthew Pinsent and heptathlete Denise Lewis, who all won gold medals at the Sydney Olympics, and Tanni Grey-Thompson, winner of four golds at the Paralympics, have already held discussions with BBC sports executives.

The corporation is keen to groom the athletes as broadcasters to capitalise on their popularity and rebuild the BBC's battered reputation for sports coverage. The sportspeople would appear on children's programmes and game shows, or present documentaries, as well as fronting sports events.

'These people are heroes and their talents aren't restricted to sport,' said a BBC source.

With veteran commentators such as David Coleman, Harry Carpenter and Peter O'Sullevan all retired or no longer at the BBC, executives want to turn an array of sports stars into a new generation of presenters and commentators.

Although Redgrave retired after winning his fifth gold in successive Olympics, the other three are still competing. They are likely to combine a small number of BBC appearances with their sporting careers and assume a bigger role once they have retired.

Senior figures hope the recuitment of Lewis, who is black, will help portray the BBC - which Director-General Greg Dyke has condemned as 'hideously white' - as more representative of multi-cultural Britain. Hiring wheelchair-bound Grey-Thompson would send a similarly positive signal about commitment to the disabled.

BBC sources say director of sport Peter Salmon, who is the corporation's new race chief, is playing a key role in the negotiations. Audley Harrison, the Olympic heavyweight boxing gold medallist, has signed a career development deal with the BBC, while former Arsenal and England striker Ian Wright has agreed to join the BBC from ITV.

Executives hope Redgrave and the others can emulate the transition made by Gary Lineker, formerly the golden boy of English football who, after taking off his boots for the last time, began his broadcasting career on Radio 5 Live. He now presents Match of the Day and is one of the BBC's biggest names.

Lewis, top woman in British sport, made her debut as a TV presenter last year on a BBC children's programme. Redgrave and Pinsent, with their teammates in the coxless four rowing crew, spent four years filming the Gold Fever video diary series, chronicling their preparations for Sydney. It drew four million viewers.

Hiring high-profile ex-sportspeople is a key part of the BBC's strategy.

Its £150 million sports budget is set to double; it will make bids to regain some of the major sports events it has lost, such as England's home games in rugby's Six Nations championship and golf's Ryder Cup; and it will launch a digital sports channel later this year in partnership with Premium TV.

fields.bodyText: Some of Britain's biggest sports stars are in talks with the BBC about becoming television personalities after they retire. Rowing hero Steve Redgrave, his teammate Matthew Pinsent and heptathlete Denise Lewis, who all won gold medals at the Sydney Olympics, and Tanni Grey-Thompson, winner of four golds at the Paralympics, have already held discussions with BBC sports executives. The corporation is keen to groom the athletes as broadcasters to capitalise on their popularity and rebuild the BBC's battered reputation for sports coverage. The sportspeople would appear on children's programmes and game shows, or present documentaries, as well as fronting sports events. 'These people are heroes and their talents aren't restricted to sport,' said a BBC source. With veteran commentators such as David Coleman, Harry Carpenter and Peter O'Sullevan all retired or no longer at the BBC, executives want to turn an array of sports stars into a new generation of presenters and commentators. Although Redgrave retired after winning his fifth gold in successive Olympics, the other three are still competing. They are likely to combine a small number of BBC appearances with their sporting careers and assume a bigger role once they have retired. Senior figures hope the recuitment of Lewis, who is black, will help portray the BBC - which Director-General Greg Dyke has condemned as 'hideously white' - as more representative of multi-cultural Britain. Hiring wheelchair-bound Grey-Thompson would send a similarly positive signal about commitment to the disabled. BBC sources say director of sport Peter Salmon, who is the corporation's new race chief, is playing a key role in the negotiations. Audley Harrison, the Olympic heavyweight boxing gold medallist, has signed a career development deal with the BBC, while former Arsenal and England striker Ian Wright has agreed to join the BBC from ITV. Executives hope Redgrave and the others can emulate the transition made by Gary Lineker, formerly the golden boy of English football who, after taking off his boots for the last time, began his broadcasting career on Radio 5 Live. He now presents Match of the Day and is one of the BBC's biggest names. Lewis, top woman in British sport, made her debut as a TV presenter last year on a BBC children's programme. Redgrave and Pinsent, with their teammates in the coxless four rowing crew, spent four years filming the Gold Fever video diary series, chronicling their preparations for Sydney. It drew four million viewers. Hiring high-profile ex-sportspeople is a key part of the BBC's strategy. Its £150 million sports budget is set to double; it will make bids to regain some of the major sports events it has lost, such as England's home games in rugby's Six Nations championship and golf's Ryder Cup; and it will launch a digital sports channel later this year in partnership with Premium TV. denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Horses sold for petfood as owners duped

fields.headline: Horses sold for petfood as owners duped
fields.trailText: Hundreds of horses sent into early retirement by their loving owners are being chopped up and sold as dog food by con men.
fields.body:
Hundreds of horses sent into early retirement by their loving owners are being chopped up and sold as dog food by con men.

The owners are being duped into handing over their old horses by criminals who sell them for pet food at £100 each. Police say they know of hundreds of horses that have disappeared, and have uncovered one conspiracy that spans the country.

Hampshire police recently made four arrests after a two-year undercover operation, and are preparing 20 specimen charges. A spokeswoman said: 'We have got a lot of horses missing. We know it's common. The owners are really distraught.'

When a horse is too old to ride, owners who cannot afford to keep it often try to find it a new life as a 'companion horse' in a stables, keeping other horses company. Ann Pritchard's horse, Sally, disappeared after she answered an advert in a horse magazine saying 'companions wanted'. A man came the next morning, showing photographs of where the horse would be kept and of his own horse, which was pining away because it was on its own.

Ann Pritchard trusted the man and handed Sally over. But when she tried to visit her old horse he said she couldn't and became abusive. One of her friends telephoned him a few days later and he said he still needed a companion horse.

'I'm very, very upset - it's very stressful. I didn't sleep for the first fortnight. I can't believe I was taken in by this man,' said Ms Pritchard. 'I thought I had found a good home for Sally, but instead she's almost certainly been sold to the knacker's yard. I haven't told my daughter yet - it would really upset her.'

In another type of scam, old and injured horses are given a strong painkiller, which disguises the fact that they are lame. They are then sold for thousands of pounds. The new owners quickly discover they have been conned and often sell the horses, which end up in abattoirs.

The con men entice owners through classified advertisements but use only mobile phone numbers. One recent advert in Horse magazine said: 'Companion horse wanted - any offers considered.' Another read: 'Wanted on permanent loan. Any height stamp, loving farm awaits.'

The dealers usually make sure that the owner never sees the horse's supposed new home. However, in some cases, dealers have persuaded owners to go to fake locations where there are other horses. When they return to visit their horse, they find the place deserted.

Nichola Gregory of the British Horse Society said: 'It's fairly widespread. There are a lot of people who can't afford to look after their horses and a lot of other people who want to make money out of it.'

Many horse owners feel intimated by the dealers and are afraid to speak out for fear of retribution.

'They are the sort of people who set a hay barn on fire or poison a horse,' one said.

Sometimes the dealers offer a token sum to the owners for the 'companion horse' because it means that they are buying it and so have a legal right to do with it whatever they want. If they simply take the horse without payment, the owners could have some legal redress.

webTitle: Lesbian lover to sue police

fields.headline: Lesbian lover to sue police
fields.standfirst: Alison Lewis was arrested on suspicion of slaying an entire family. After a year-long ordeal, she tells  Tracy McVeigh  exclusively the inside story of  a case that shocked the nation
fields.trailText: Alison Lewis was arrested on suspicion of slaying an entire family. After a year-long ordeal, she tells  Tracy McVeigh  exclusively the inside story of  a case that shocked the nation.
fields.body:
It was a warm night - barbecue weather - and there had been several false alarms for Swansea fire brigade. But the 4.30am call to reports of smoke at 9 Kelvin Road, would stay in the minds of the fire crew forever.

In the semi-detached, three-bedroom house lay the bodies of 34-year-old Amanda Power, a rugby-loving divorcée, her disabled mother Doris Dawson, 80, and her two little girls, Katie, 10, and eight-year-old Emily.

Now, for the first time, Alison Lewis, the woman accused of killing them, has told The Observer of the passion and lies the murders laid bare. It was not flames that killed the Powers: they had each been battered around the head. Amanda had been brutally sexually assaulted. Her mother was beaten so badly that she could only be identified by her rings. South Wales police will not reveal where the children's bodies were, or at what stage of the bloodbath they were killed. But they were not dressed for bed.

The fire started by the killer, or an accomplice, hampered forensic teams and there were signs that somebody had tried to clean up the scene. But neighbours told police that Amanda had a secret love - a woman she had been seeing for six months since meeting her through mutual friends in women's rugby. That woman was Lewis, an international women's rugby player and karate black belt, a former policewoman, mother of twin girls, now aged five, and the wife of Sergeant Stephen Lewis of South Wales police. Sgt Lewis's twin brother, Inspector Stuart Lewis, is still awaiting a Crown Prosecution Service decision on whether he will be charged with perverting the course of justice in connection with the case.

On Wednesday, South Wales police announced that the CPS had decided there is not enough evidence to charge Alison or Stephen Lewis with murder. 'The family of the victims have been informed of this decision,' said Assistant Chief Constable Tony Rogers, who added that the inquiry would continue. But Alison Lewis told The Observer she was considering suing the force for compensation for her ordeal.

'I have not been able to grieve, I could not even attend my lover's funeral. The future holds nothing for me, I have to live with this hanging over my head for the rest of my life,' she said.

'I was in the wrong and Mandy was not my first lesbian lover,' she continued. 'I had affairs and had battled with my sexuality for some time, but I was a coward about admitting it. Mandy was the first woman I'd been with that I didn't feel guilty about being gay.'

When officers arrived at the Lewis home on the morning of the murder, 27 June 1999, Alison says she had already been called by a neighbour and had driven out to the murder scene and back.

'I was distraught, but police told me to take Steve upstairs and tell him the truth about Mandy. I was just hysterical with grief, so I don't really remember much about it, except that he was furious. Apparently I tried to throw myself out of a window, but I don't remember.'

That day she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital where she remained for 10 days. 'When I came out, Steve had gone away with my kids, my house had been boarded up, Mandy was gone and I had nowhere to go.'

Lewis is bitter. 'They had no evidence against me. They said I'd killed them using my martial arts training and showed me a picture of the 4ft bar that had been used. There was blood on it and I kept thinking, "Whose blood was that? Mandy's?".'

Her solicitor, Bernard de Maid, said: 'Alison gave 13 witness statements before her arrest, and then was interviewed extensively over four days after it. I have listened to 23 tapes of those interviews and it is clear that police had no evidence.'

Lewis refuses to accept that her ex-husband could be capable of murder. 'Mandy and the girls had a barbecue at our house on the Friday, we were all drinking together and there was no problem. I don't believe he knew of the affair and suddenly went mad. Steve is a gentleman. That Saturday we had been drinking all day with friends and gone to bed about 11. I got up to see to one of the girls but I don't know what time that was, but Steve was in the bed. Then I got up again and looked at the clock and it was 4.30am. Steve got up at five as normal to start his shift,' she said.

Police estimate the family was killed between 11.50pm, when they returned from visiting relatives, and 4am, when the fire was discovered.

Lewis suspects someone from Power's 'tangled past'. Power had had several relationships since her marriage to her daughters' father ended, though there are conflicting accounts as to whether these involved men or women.

Lewis does admit her relationship with Power involved major rows. 'It was very steamy and we argued a lot, but the week before she died had been the happiest we had ever been, I was ready to tell Steve and move out.'

After 19 months, police face an uphill struggle. An unidentified woman wearing lots of gold jewellery who took a taxi to Kelvin Road on the night of the murders, and a man seen on Power's porch, have never been traced.

There may be another, more damaging factor in this case. In October last year The Observer revealed how the South Wales force was criticised after two decades of allegations that at least 19 people had been wrongfully imprisoned. Nine murders remain unsolved after those originally charged walked free amid accusations of faked police interview notes, false or missing evidence, bribes and intimidation.

The estimated cost to the taxpayer in court costs and compensation payouts of 10 cases is £20 million. Up to 30 officers have been subject to temporary suspensions since 1982.

'The irony is that this time, with these four murders, police and the CPS are under such pressure to ensure watertight cases, so that nothing goes wrong, that it may mean that the killer or killers are never brought to justice because the burden of proof is being set too high,' said one Cardiff lawyer.

But as the murder team lick their wounds after the CPS decision, Lewis has to face up to a community which still views her with suspicion. She now lives with her elderly parents near Cardiff and struggles to maintain a civil relationship with her ex-husband for the sake of their children.

'I have lost everything,' she said. 'You never realise what you have got till it's gone.'

webTitle: Army goes private in NHS crisis

fields.headline: Army goes private in NHS crisis
fields.standfirst: MoD forced to sign contracts with 40 hospitals outside state system to beat long waiting lists
fields.trailText: MoD forced to sign contracts with 40 hospitals outside state system to beat long waiting lists.
fields.body:
Thousands of British soldiers classified as unfit for active service are to be treated at private hospitals in the starkest admission yet that the NHS is in crisis.

The Ministry of Defence has signed contracts with 40 private hospitals to try to get around the long waiting lists in the state system.

The move comes as new figures reveal that fewer people now work in the health service than at the beginning of Margaret Thatcher's first government. In 1982, 874,000 people were employed in the NHS, including consultants, nurses and GPs. The figure for 1999, the latest available, is 873,000.

The Government pointed out that most of the fall in NHS staff was in the last years of John Major's government and that figures have been steadily increasing since 1997. 'We were left with a legacy of decline,' a Department of Health adviser said. 'We have turned that around.'

The MoD contracts with Bupa and Nuffield Hospitals are part of a 'waiting list initiative' to deal with sickness in the ranks. MoD sources said problems with getting people treated in the NHS were so acute that they had to sign the multi-million-pound contracts or face armed forces running 'on half empty'.

'It's not exactly a vote of confidence in our hospitals,' said one official. 'But it was this or leave people who are unfit waiting for months or even years for treatment.'

The MoD took action after it was revealed that nearly 16,000 personnel had been medically downgraded as fit for 'light duties' only. The Army figure was nearly 10,000 or 10 per cent of strength.

Government advisers admit that the use of private hospitals by a Labour government, which said it wanted to build a 'first-class NHS', has caused huge tensions. Last October The Observer revealed that Nigel Crisp, the new chief executive of the NHS, had signed the first 'concordat of understanding' with the private sector to treat 100,000 patients who could not get an NHS bed.

The move was heavily criticised by prominent backbenchers. David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health select committee, said the Government should not do deals with the private sector. Tony Benn said the move was tantamount to privatisation of the NHS.

The Government said it was up to local health authorities to sign the contracts and the Government did not have 'an ideological problem' with the private sector.

The fact that the Government is now signing contracts directly with the private sector brought a fresh wave of criticism.

'I feel very uneasy and very unhappy about such a move,' Hinchliffe said. 'The more work that is given to the private sector, the more consultants and nurses are pulled away from the work they are doing with the NHS.'

Some soldiers and civilians in the armed forces will be allowed to 'queue jump' NHS waiting lists if their condition is urgent and their role cannot be filled by other staff.

Peter Viggers, Conservative vice-chairman of the Commons defence select committee, said the Government's record on armed forces sickness was 'lamentable'. He said the Defence Medical Services operation, responsible for health in the armed forces, was in chaos and that the last military hospital in Britain, the Royal Hospital at Hasler in Gosport, Hampshire, was about to be closed.

'Fifteen or 20 years ago there were eight service hospitals and now we are in this position,' he said. 'It is quite staggering that we have failed to tackle what is such a serious problem.'

Lieutenant-General Tim Granville-Chapman, the Army's adjutant general, said this month that illness in the armed forces was causing serious problems. The Army is 5,000 soldiers under-strength, leading to a high degree of 'overstretch'.

Asked during a hearing before the defence select committee about the high number of soldiers medically downgraded, he said: 'It is a big figure, I would much rather it was not that size. We are looking at fast tracking, putting as many people through the system as we possibly can. It seriously affects getting people from recruiting into the trained Army.'

webTitle: Man's germs wiped out mammoths

fields.headline: Man's germs wiped out mammoths
fields.standfirst: Disease can kill off whole species - including ours
fields.trailText: Disease can kill off whole species - including ours.
fields.body:
They were some of the most remarkable creatures to roam the Earth. For aeons, mammoths, mastodons, giant armadillos, dog-sized rodents, sloths as big as giraffes, and sabre-toothed tigers ruled the plains and forests of North and South America.

Then, 11,000 years ago, they vanished from the face of the Earth, a disappearance that still provokes fierce arguments among scientists.

But now a leading palaeontologist believes he has found the cause of the extinctions: these great animals died because they caught coughs and colds from human beings. And the implications for our planet could be catastrophic. 'Upward of 130 species disappeared in a time period of maybe half a millennium or less,' said Dr Ross MacPhee, of the American Museum of Natural History in New York. 'Disease is the only thing that I know of that could do that.'

The disappearance of the great mammals was originally described by Charles Darwin. 'It is impossible to reflect on the state of the American continent without astonishment,' he noted. 'Formerly, it must have swarmed with great monsters; now we find mere pygmies.'

For the next 100 years, scientists struggled to make sense of the disappearance of the mammoth, mastodon and giant sloth. Then they began to date the bones of these creatures and found they had all been wiped out within a few hundred years of each other.

Crucially, it was at this time that humans first travelled to America, from Asia across a land bridge that joined Siberia and Alaska, leaving signs of their progress in the form of carved stone arrowheads and spearpoints. These early Americans were clearly great hunters, and were quickly fingered as the eradicators of America's mammoths and mastodons.

'Large animals disappeared not because they lost their food supply but because they became one,' says Dr Paul Martin of Arizona University, protagonist of the 'overkill hypothesis'.

But the theory suffers from a major drawback, scientists have realised: there is little evidence to support it. Despite a plethora of fossil remains, only six mammoth bones have been found with spearpoints in them. As for the other 130 species wiped out, not one has been found near an arrow or with a sign of having been butchered.

'People were hunting but not on a scale that could have made any difference to the survival of the species,' says MacPhee. 'You'd have to be killing things all the time and you'd have to be doing it for some purpose. It's unimaginable that the people concerned would be interested merely in killing, especially large, dangerous animals like mammoths.'

Instead MacPhee believes America's great creatures were victims, not of human aggression, but of diseases introduced by us, or possibly by animals such as dogs or rats travelling with us. 'You can imagine a situation, especially for herding animals, where the pathogen could be passed through a population in days,' he argues. 'They would be falling all over the place, without any clear threat at hand.'

MacPhee points to recent epidemics introduced by humans that have wiped out species of toads and frogs in North America, and populations of birds such as the Hawaiian honeycreeper. Similarly, African wild dogs in the Serengeti have been killed off by canine distemper transferred from domestic dogs, while rinderpest - introduced into Africa 100 years ago - eradicated millions of wildebeest, hartebeest and others.

Such outbreaks are trivial compared with those that could have been triggered by humans leaving Africa and Asia and entering America for the first time. 'All kinds of organisms could have been brought to places where humans had never been previously resident,' says MacPhee, whose ideas will be outlined in next month's Scientific American. In a bid to prove this idea, MacPhee is probing tissue of mammoths found in permafrost. He aims to extract the DNA of bacteria, viruses or protozoa, and provide crucial evidence for his theory.

If he succeeds, he believes he will have demonstrated that our planet and all its species, including humans, will always be highly vulnerable to disease. For aeons, mammoths, mastodons, giant armadillos, dog-sized rodents, sloths as big as giraffes, and sabre-toothed tigers ruled the plains and forests of North and South America. Then, 11,000 years ago, they vanished from the face of the Earth, a disappearance that still provokes fierce arguments among scientists. But now a leading palaeontologist believes he has found the cause of the extinctions: these great animals died because they caught coughs and colds from human beings. And the implications for our planet could be catastrophic. 'Upward of 130 species disappeared in a time period of maybe half a millennium or less,' said Dr Ross MacPhee, of the American Museum of Natural History in New York. 'Disease is the only thing that I know of that could do that.' The disappearance of the great mammals was originally described by Charles Darwin. 'It is impossible to reflect on the state of the American continent without astonishment,' he noted. 'Formerly, it must have swarmed with great monsters; now we find mere pygmies.' For the next 100 years, scientists struggled to make sense of the disappearance of the mammoth, mastodon and giant sloth. Then they began to date the bones of these creatures and found they had all been wiped out within a few hundred years of each other. Crucially, it was at this time that humans first travelled to America, from Asia across a land bridge that joined Siberia and Alaska, leaving signs of their progress in the form of carved stone arrowheads and spearpoints. These early Americans were clearly great hunters, and were quickly fingered as the eradicators of America's mammoths and mastodons. 'Large animals disappeared not because they lost their food supply but because they became one,' says Dr Paul Martin of Arizona University, protagonist of the 'overkill hypothesis'. But the theory suffers from a major drawback, scientists have realised: there is little evidence to support it. Despite a plethora of fossil remains, only six mammoth bones have been found with spearpoints in them. As for the other 130 species wiped out, not one has been found near an arrow or with a sign of having been butchered. 'People were hunting but not on a scale that could have made any difference to the survival of the species,' says MacPhee. 'You'd have to be killing things all the time and you'd have to be doing it for some purpose. webTitle: Couch-potato children fall victim to diabetes epidemic

fields.headline: Couch-potato children fall victim to diabetes epidemic
fields.trailText: Anita Ellis became part of Britain's most worrying medical puzzle one night in May last year, when she woke with agonising stomach pains. Her doctor gave her a painkiller. Over the next few days she had a series of tests and was diagnosed as having adult-onset diabetes. The doctors were surprised because Anita was only 15.
fields.body:
Anita Ellis became part of Britain's most worrying medical puzzle one night in May last year, when she woke with agonising stomach pains. Her doctor gave her a painkiller. Over the next few days she had a series of tests and was diagnosed as having adult-onset diabetes. The doctors were surprised because Anita was only 15.

But she is not alone. The Observer has learnt that doctors in other parts of the country have seen nine-year-olds with the same type of diabetes, which is normally seen in people 30 years older.

With more than a million under-16s in the UK classed as overweight or obese - double the number in the mid-Eighties - doctors are becoming convinced a junk food and couch-potato lifestyle is speeding their bodies into a disease of middle age.

In obese diabetics, the cells producing insulin to control blood sugar wear-out, fighting a losing battle to maintain the body's equilibrium. Undiagnosed diabetes can lead to infertility and eye damage, or even fatal kidney or heart disease.

Anita has come to accept that she has a condition that is a symptom of cellular middle-aged burn-out. 'At first I didn't want to tell my friends because they would think I was strange. They were very understanding when it was explained what they would have to do if I had a funny turn. And they understood that I would have to do a blood sugar test four times a day, take tablets and change what I eat,' said Anita, who lives in Romsey, Hampshire.

Since her diagnosis Anita, now 16, has lost over a stone in weight and is taking tablets and regular exercise, which it is hoped will stave off early health problems. 'The doctors were really surprised and at first I was really scared when it was diagnosed.

'I used to love my chips and crisps, but now I only have chips once a week and have cut out crisps and chocolate altogether and take fruit to school. And I do feel a lot healthier and happier since I was diagnosed.'

Doctors Sarah Ehtisham, Nick Shaw and Tim Barrett uncovered the first-ever British cases of type 2 diabetes in eight obese children in Leicester and the West Midlands. The youngest was nine when diagnosed. She had to have eye surgery after developing a cataract - a classic complication of diabetes.

'These are the first cases of type 2 diabetes in children in the UK, although this has become a well-recognised problem in other parts of the world, notably the US,' said Barrett. 'The onset of this form of diabetes at a young age means there will be more time for complications to develop over the lifetime of the individual.'

The World Health Organisation and the charity Diabetes UK estimate that there are a million 'hidden' diabetics in the UK. Doctors fear many are children who will not be diagnosed until serious damage is done. They want to raise awareness among doctors because medical training doesn't recognise type 2 diabetes in children. In Japan, type 2 is now the most common form in children. In the US, where nearly half of child diabetics are type 2, there is routine screening.

Contact Diabetes UK at www.diabetes.org.uk or call 0207 323 1531

webTitle: World in brief

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Papua New Guinea allows independence vote after war
fields.body:
Papua New Guinea allows independence vote after war

Papua New Guinea has agreed to allow the secessionist province of Bougainville to vote for independence in a referendum. The decision follows nine years of civil war and three years of peace talks.

Peace talks hope in the Congo

Joseph Kabila, new president of the Congo, appears ready for talks to end the war, according to EU envoy Aldo Ajello, who added that his father Laurent Kabila, assassinated on 17 January, had been 'an obstacle to peace'.

Writer's jail sentence grows

Egyptian writer Salaheddin Mohsen has been sentenced by the high state security court to three years' jail with hard labour for 'blasphemy against Islam'. It stiffened his original six-month suspended sentence after the intervention of the state prosecutor.

Farmers make BSE cull claim

Thousands of German farmers protested against inadequate compensation for the planned slaughter of around 1,350 cows as a protective measure against mad cow disease.

Fresh fighting in Afghanistan

The heaviest fighting for months has broken out near Kabul, Afghanistan, between Taliban troops and opposition forces led by Ahmad Shah Masood.

Snakehead boss held

Chinese police have arrested the alleged head of a human smuggling ring on suspicion he arranged the passage of 58 Chinese found dead last June in Dover, the government's Xinhua News Agency said yesterday. Chen Xiaokong, a known 'snakehead' boss, was seized on Tuesday night in a disco.

Child labour

More than one million children aged six to 17 work in Turkey, a problem EU chiefs say must be tackled if Turkey is to join the European Union.

Rebels attack

Mujahideen rebels have killed six members of Iran's secret service in clashes in Tehran, according to press reports.

Right to vote

Two women are suing the Kuwaiti government over its refusal to add their names to the electoral roll.

webTitle: Taste revolution hits high street

fields.headline: Taste revolution hits high street
fields.standfirst: As Man at C&A calls it a day, big-spending Britons trade up to the finer things in life
fields.trailText: As Man at C&A calls it a day, big-spending Britons trade up to the finer things in life
fields.body:
A 33-year-old office manager from Woking in Surrey, and a £6.99 wool and polyester ribbed V-neck sweater, last night earned an unlikely place in the history of the world's most famous shopping street.

Shortly before 6pm, Vivian Gray bought the 'Man at C&A' jumper and walked out of the empty store to his Vauxhall Astra parked just off London's Oxford Street. Behind him the doors of what was once Britain's biggest high street clothes retailer closed for the last time. Seventy-eight years after C&A unfurled its rainbow fascia, a banner announced: 'Good Buy & Goodbye'.

Few people will mourn the loss of acrylic 'action slacks', Bri-nylon tunics and 'Rodeo' ski salopettes, but C&A is not alone. In the past week the best-known names on the high street - Marks & Spencer, Boots and Littlewoods - have announced some of their worst ever trading figures. The downturn is not a case of belt tightening. Despite fears of a recession, consumer spending is setting new records and credit card borrowing has doubled in the past year.

Social forecasters say the slump is the result of a revolution that is transforming almost every aspect of our lives. Mr and Mrs Average are chucking out the everyday and trading up to the finer things in life. Consumers are declaring an end to all things ordinary.

The good taste revolution has swept the country with remarkable speed. Just three years ago Marks & Spencer was the nation's favourite with profits of £1 billion a year. Sales have slumped more than 20 per cent since then and were down 5 per cent over Christmas. Littlewoods lost £15.6 million in the last six months of 2000. Boots sales were down by almost 2 per cent last month. Overall, 15 high street retailers have issued profits warnings in recent months.

Yet just 100 yards from the empty aisles in Britain's biggest high street - at the front line of the taste revolution - the story could not be more different. In upmarket Bond Street consumers are going on the biggest luxury spending spree since the 'greed is good' Eighties. Burberry enjoyed a 35 per cent increase in revenues in the last three months of last year. Gucci, the Italian fashion house, saw its sales rise 25 per cent. Armani, its Milan-based rival, reported 20 per cent growth. Demand at Louis Vuitton is so great it is being forced to ration its logo-print bags.

The boom is not confined to the wealthy South-east. Record sales of designer clothes pushed up profits at Selfridges in Manchester by 22 per cent in the final quarter of last year. At Harvey Nichols in Leeds sales rose by 5 per cent, while Porsche car sales were up 25 per cent in almost every region of the country last year.

Economists who have studied the style revolution say Britain has moved from a 'good enough' culture to a 'good taste' culture. Jeremy Baker, senior lecturer at London's Guildhall University, says: 'We live in a world where most products look good, work well, and are competitively priced. That means consumers are looking for something extra. They want products that sell a "lifestyle" they want to be part of - even if they can only afford a T-shirt or a jacket. They want to bask in the image products project. High street goods say "ordinary" and that is an image no one wants.'

On the streets, shoppers agree. Stuart Phillips, 33, who runs his own beauty salon in London's Covent Garden, has 500 designer shirts, 370 suits and 250 pairs of trousers. He has just bought a £32,000 Audi TT and is spending £300,000 installing a bespoke hi-fi and cinema system in his London home. 'High street stores used to be OK but now they make you think of Alan Partridge in a patterned jumper, driving a Rover. No one wants to be that average.'

Almost everywhere you look - from clothes, to food and drink, to cars, to home furnishings, to holidays - Britons are buying into a life less ordinary. Rising wealth is driving the revolution. New research by the Henley Centre shows that the average household is 40 per cent better off than in 1986 and real household disposable income is expected to rise by 3 per cent this year. Last year nearly 3,000 executives were paid a salary of at least £1m, a 500 per cent rise since 1994, and 200 homes in central London were sold for more than £2m. Fifty new millionaires are created every day and more than four million people have more than £50,000 in liquid assets.

'In the past only those with money and time on their hands were able to dedicate energy to the pursuit of tasteful living,' says Martin Hayward, director of consumer consultancy at the Henley Centre. 'But as incomes rise and leisure time increases, the privileged many are living higher-spending, more middle-class lives, developing a greater sense of their own self-image through what they buy.'

The impact of the taste revolution is being felt all over the country. The weak, such as C&A, Vauxhall in Luton, and Ford in Dagenham, are giving up the fight, closing shops and factories. Those who have the resources to struggle on are 'luxing up', offering customers higher quality and better service.

In the high street, Arcadia - the Principles, Top Shop, Burton, Racing Green group - is spending millions launching a new luxury service, Rubshoulders. Debenham's is using top name designers to revamp its stores. After years of disastrous trading, MFI is giving itself a Conran-inspired makeover. Tour operators, such as First Choice, are moving into the cruise market, 'experience' holidays and luxury short breaks. Mid-market restaurants, including Beefeater, are dumping meat and two veg in favour of 'continental cuisine'.

It is a far cry from the rails of lilac tracksuit bottoms that C&A cannot even give away. As staff at the Oxford Street store picked up their P45s last night, they agreed that the days when a high street outfit was good enough for a Saturday night out are gone for good. 'I've bought a load of wool tops and T-shirts in this closing-down sale,' said one former cashier, carrying a bag bulging with last-minute bargains. 'But there is no way I am going to wear any of it on its own. I am going to cut out the labels and wear the tops under jackets I bought in the sales. I saw Martine McCutcheon do it with a Gucci jacket and it looked really classy.'

Good taste may be in the eye of the beholder but these days it is something everyone just has to have.

webTitle: Leader:

fields.headline: Follow our leader
fields.standfirst: Learn to relax like Her Majesty
fields.trailText: New research suggests that more of us than ever are victims of workplace stress. According to the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy, sufferers constantly miss deadlines, make an unusual number of mistakes and pick verbal fights.
fields.body:
New research suggests that more of us than ever are victims of workplace stress. According to the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy, sufferers constantly miss deadlines, make an unusual number of mistakes and pick verbal fights. Just as the research is published, Buckingham Palace confirms that the Queen has still not completed her Christmas break. 'Her Majesty always remains at Sandringham until 6 February, the anniversary of her accession to the throne,' explains a courtier.

While believing that it is time for Britain to become a republic, The Observer has always commended the exemplary professionalism of the Queen as a head of state. She never misses deadlines, she makes few mistakes - and she certainly never picks verbal fights with those she encounters at the opening of hospitals or old people's homes.

After all too many years of anni horribili, how heartening to find the royal family performing its once-quotidian role as an example to us all. With six weeks off at Christmas and, of course, an annual three-month break in the Highlands during the summer, Britain could soon banish workplace stress forever.

webTitle: Leader: Tanker safety must be improved

fields.headline: Peril on the sea
fields.standfirst: Tanker safety must be improved
fields.trailText: Thankfully, the  terrible oil spill off the Galapagos Islands 10 days ago has not turned out - yet - to be an ecological catastrophe, but the lucky winds that have blown the spill out to sea should not stop us from learning lessons.
fields.body:
Thankfully, the terrible oil spill off the Galapagos Islands 10 days ago has not turned out - yet - to be an ecological catastrophe, but the lucky winds that have blown the spill out to sea should not stop us from learning lessons. The stricken Jessica was a 30-year-old, uninsured, rust-bucket tanker with no charts on board, sailing in treacherous currents close to one of the world's most vulnerable and important ecological sites.

Its stranding highlights a frightening lack of regulation. Under the United Nation's Marpol marine pollution convention, the only protection for areas such as the Galapagos is that within a decade all tankers must convert to double hulls, but only if they are of a certain size; smaller tankers are exempt. And there is no requirement for countries or regions to have rescue facilities - Ecuador had to enlist help from as far away as the United States.

One solution is the new international designation of 'particularly sensitive sea areas'. All tankers in those areas will be required to be double-hulled, properly navigated, with radar and regular ship-to-shore communications. But so far, only Australia's Great Barrier Reef and the north coast of Cuba have been designated. It is clear that other areas of the world - the Galapagos, the Andaman islands in the Indian Ocean, parts of the Red Sea and even the west coast of Scotland - should be given similar protection with immediate effect.

A close call in the Galapagos should not blind us to the need for action. With the world's ecological heritage at risk, it should not take another major oil spill such as the Exxon Valdez or Erika disasters to make all tanker companies agree to new safety regulations.

And there is no requirement for countries or regions to have rescue facilities - Ecuador had to enlist help from as far away as the United States. One solution is the new international designation of 'particularly sensitive sea areas'. All tankers in those areas will be required to be double-hulled, properly navigated, with radar and regular ship-to-shore communications. But so far, only Australia's Great Barrier Reef and the north coast of Cuba have been designated. It is clear that other areas of the world - the Galapagos, the Andaman islands in the Indian Ocean, parts of the Red Sea and even the west coast of Scotland - should be given similar protection with immediate effect. A close call in the Galapagos should not blind us to the need for action. With the world's ecological heritage at risk, it should not take another major oil spill such as the Exxon Valdez or Erika disasters to make all tanker companies agree to new safety regulations.

webTitle: Life support

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Boyhood friends Krulik Wilder  and Ben Helfgott were liberated from Nazi death camps to find themselves reunited in the Lake District after the war. Now, more than half a century later, they are still as close as brothers
fields.trailText: Boyhood friends Krulik Wilder  and Ben Helfgott were liberated from Nazi death camps to find themselves reunited in the Lake District after the war. Now, more than half a century later, they are still as close as brothers
fields.body:
Krulik Wilder

I've known Ben since we were 12 years old. We lived in the same ghetto, Piotrkow, in Poland. When the deportations began, my father got me a job in the glass factory, which saved my life. Ben worked there, too. But my mother and sister were deported. After the war I found out they had been murdered at Treblinka. Back then I knew nothing - it was better that way.

At the end of 1944, my father and I were sent to the death camp Buchenwald. A few months later, when he was nearly dying, I was forced to leave him. I was packed in an open cattle truck and for a month the train went backwards and forwards. There was no food, people were dying. By the time the transport arrived at the death camp Theresienstadt, I was barely alive.

In May 1945 the Russians liberated the camp. A few weeks later, I saw Ben; it was wonderful to have a friend who'd survived. In June we were running around with other kids in the field outside Theresienstadt - the freedom was unbelievable.

Ben and I were in the same group of child survivors permitted to enter Britain in 1945. In Windermere, we learnt English, talked about girls and getting a job. I went to Scotland and became a watchmaker. We met up again in 1949 in London at a club set up to assist our rehabilitation. Ben asked me to do weight-lifting with him and I was very impressed when he became British champion and competed at the Olympics. He went to university (to study economics) and I started my own jewellery business.

In 1963 we helped found the '45 Aid Society Holocaust Survivors. Every relative I ever had was killed, but every member of the Society is family, and Ben is like a brother.

Ben and I returned to the glass factory in 1993. When we looked at the register, our names were next to each other, and I saw my father's date of birth, which I'd forgotten. And it was that very same day of our visit. It is hard to talk without getting emotional. But with Ben, I can talk about the past and we can laugh. Now we're closer than ever: sometimes we argue but we never fall out. We speak every day and meet to play cards. Ben is a true and loyal man.

Ben Helfgott

I first remember seeing Krulik on the ghetto streets with a tray over his shoulders, plying his wares: 'Cigarettes, matches, armbands.' The white armbands with a blue star of David were compulsory but you still had to buy them. It was a way to make money to buy a bit of bread. Krulik's face was friendly and instantly familiar. We registered at the glass factory on the same day in August 1942, both aged 12. It was at the height of the deportation and there were rumours that if one had a job assisting the war effort of the Third Reich, one would not be sent away. We did not know where Jews were taken - we heard stories of gas chambers, but who could believe it? It was beyond our comprehension.

In October, the deportations on our ghetto began. There were more than 24,000 Jews in the ghetto and in seven days 22,000 had been taken away to be killed. Two months later, my mother and eight-year-0ld sister, who had returned from hiding outside the ghetto, were rounded up with 560 other Jews and shot in the forest outside our town. I'll never forget that day as long as I live.

I was left with my father and my 11-year-old sister. In November 1944, my father and I were sent to Buchenwald, where we were separated. Krulik and his father were sent there, too. Krulik and I were both liberated in Theresienstadt, the day the war ended. I was delighted to see him alive. He, like I, lost his father towards the end of the war - an agony we have never overcome. My younger sister and I survived, but Krulik was the only survivor of his family.

Together with 732 other Jewish war orphans, Krulik and I arrived in the Lake District. We did everything together. We both married and have three boys each, and both ended up in business: he still works with his two sons and I am a retired clothing manufacturer. We work closely together; presently I am chairman and he is treasurer of the '45 Aid Society. We are part of a past that we lost, and we share it together. Krulik radiates confidence and vitality - he is a positive man. He's as close to me as a brother; he is as large as life.

webTitle: Trail grazer

fields.headline: Trail grazer
fields.standfirst: Part motorbike, part tractor... Suzuki's King Quad is a farmer's best friend
fields.trailText: Part motorbike, part tractor... Suzuki's King Quad is a farmer's best friend.
fields.body:
'Erm... had any experience with one of these?' asks the Suzuki representative nervously, as I clunk on my crash helmet and confidently bounce into the saddle of the King Quad LT300, the big seller of Suzuki's range of ATVs (that's All Terrain Vehicles to you and me). I hesitate momentarily. A huge and friendly looking paddock spreads out ahead of me with no oncoming vehicles, no loose animals or children and no motorway maintenance men to get in my way. As far as I am concerned, I am sitting on a motorbike with stabilisers. How difficult can it be? Hell, Suzuki even manufactures a range of ATVs for six and 12-year-olds. 'I had a go on a moped in Greece once,' I say hopefully. 'So how fast can I go?' I ask, chomping at the bit to open her up and blaze a trail across the field. 'It's the skill, not the race,' I am told sternly.

I set off on the King Quad LT300 and feel as though, if not for the helmet, the wind would be rushing through my hair just like Marianne Faithfull in Girl on a Motorcycle . I look down at the speedo and see that I am in fact hitting a maximum of 5kph with the wind behind me. Time to crank up a gear, I think, and therein lies the problem, in my opinion, with the King Quad manual. To go up a gear, you have to curl your toe under the pedal and flick it up, while at the same time lowering the throttle by releasing pressure on the thumb grip. It was all a bit much for someone with my hopeless hand-eye co-ordination, and I ended up slowing down to a virtual standstill every time I changed gear.

For those who really can't get to grips with the gears, though, Suzuki has just introduced the Quad Master, an automatic version of its most powerful ATV, the 500, with rumours abounding that an automatic 350 will soon also be available. I have to confess, the 500 really was a different ball game. Though the automatic gears do take some of the fun out of driving, particularly on a muddy incline where the gears play a major part in control, the automatic allows you to turn the throttle and get up to speed more quickly. The engine responds beautifully and, throwing caution to the breeze, I went full speed across the paddock and reached 55kph. Any faster and I knew that hitting a tree stump or a large rock would result in one of those accidents which everybody seemed so keen for me to avoid.

The King Quad 300 has three drive options; two-wheel drive, four-wheel drive and front-differential-locked four-wheel drive for difficult conditions. There is also a five-speed subtransmission with high, low and super-low ratios. Turning has a slower response than I expected and there is a fair amount of weight shifting to keep stability on a corner or on a slope, but that all adds to the fun.

Sitting on a powerful engine with little protection means safety features highly on the ATV's list of must dos. A training course is recommended, as is a helmet and sensible and protective clothing. There is also a safety wire attaching you to a cut-off switch which is activated should your body become separated from your vehicle.

All ATVs have a centrifugal clutch system so comparing the quad bike to a scooter gives you some idea what they are all about. The clutch operates automatically and disengages itself when acceleration is low. But be warned, when toiling up a steep hill, the tendency is to open the throttle up in an attempt to get more power. The clutch then engages suddenly and the vehicle transforms itself into a bucking bronco. Although the automatic obviously uses the same clutch system, all the hard work is done for you and there is less potential danger.

Over the past decade, Quad bikes have earned themselves a reputation as sporting vehicles in the US, where big space for outdoor pursuits permits. In the UK, however, the majority of ATV sales are represented by farmers. 'It didn't compute with me at first,' says Nigel Hulme, an entrepreneur and the UK distributor of AGIP oil and who runs his 80-acre estate near Crawley with the help of ATVs. 'A four-wheeled motorbike? What's that going to do for me?' In reality, a quad bike suits his purposes admirably. 'It's incredibly versatile and inherently safe if you treat it properly.'

The popularity of the ATV as a farming vehicle coincided with the agricultural recession. It's much cheaper to run than a tractor in terms of fuel and tyres. 'It's also easier to use than a tractor, especially on a smaller farm,' says Nigel. 'It's compact and makes no mess.' Its low-pressure tyres mean a growing crop recovers from being driven over and weighing in at only 3lb per square inch, it does no more damage than a farmer in his wellies. Also on the practical side, it's quicker to open and close gates as the farmer can remain seated on his ATV.

The quad really comes into its own when it is completed with accessories. There's a whole spectrum of attachments which enable it to mow the grass, transport heavy loads, level the riding school arena, grade dirt tracks and aerate a grass field. All in all, the quad becomes farmer's little helper as well as being a fun and nippy way of getting around the acreage.

Farmers wherever there are hills and animals (that means Wales mostly) are Suzuki's main clients, although they are currently targeting equestrian centres as high ATV users. As farmers' wives and to-the-manor-born ladies are often responsible for the horses, women ATV drivers are on the increase.

According to Nigel, there's a queue in his household to mow the lawn. 'It's a useable tool which can be fun,' he says. 'I never have trouble getting volunteers.' And as a classic-sportscar racing enthusiast with endless trophies to prove his various exploits, Nigel knows all about vehicles as entertainment. And the King Quad is definitely great fun. Suzuki is keen to point out that its ATVs are work vehicles and not sports machines, but combining work with driving around on these chunky bikes almost makes grafting a pleasure.

If I were a farmer, I'd be at the front of the queue to buy a shiny new quad bike. But I'd be even happier if somebody would invent a more flattering crash helmet.

Suzuki LT300 King Quad

Price £5,239
Total rack capacity (back and front) 90kg
Hitch capacity 410kg
Engine size 280cc, 22hp
Ground clearance 210mm
Driven wheels 4

webTitle: The girls are back in town

fields.headline: The girls are back in town
fields.trailText:
Sex and The City C4
Better Sex C4
Jungle Janes C4
Challenger: Go For Launch BBC2
Restaurants From Hell ITV
Changing Rooms BBC1
fields.body:
Sex and The City C4
Better Sex C4
Jungle Janes C4
Challenger: Go For Launch BBC2
Restaurants From Hell ITV
Changing Rooms BBC1

If a man is a bad kisser, is he necessarily bad everywhere else? If a woman lights up a post-prandial snout and he says: 'I don't want to be a jerk, but I can't date a smoker', is this indeed instant and irrefutable proof of a man's jerkiness? If a woman waits too long to sleep with him, does she run the risk of 'missing the window and becoming good friends'? If a man shouts out: 'You whore!' at the moment of orgasm, should a woman take it in her stride or take up tapestry? And if a woman is still serial-dating in her thirties, is it sensible to wonder 'how many men are too many men?' No doubt about it, Sex and The City never fights shy of tackling the Big Stuff.

You think I'm joking? Far from it. Despite the vast, rent-controlled Upper East Side apartments and the expensive heels, sometimes Sex and The City looks like a dirty-realist document strand. I doubt there's an urban single woman in the land who hasn't listened to Sarah Jessica Parker's Carrie Bradshaw without wincing at least once an episode. And, most rarely in the context of American comedy drama, the show never succumbs to schmaltz.

When a man runs Carrie a candlelit bubble-bath, she says: 'Wow, it looks like a Danielle Steele novel in here', which is as it should be, because men who think cheap, quasi-romantic, Cosmo , girlish courtship rituals are the fastest way into a adult woman's bed deserve everything they won't get. Then again, it may just be because last week was such a profoundly dire seven days for TV drama - indeed, the worst I can remember outside of August - that Sex and the City looked so damn good.

More sex in C4's Better Sex, in which we followed Relate's psycho-sexual counsellors and their clients. In a training session for would-be therapists, the group sat down to watch a video featuring a pair of 1970's Californian Joy-of-Socks-and-Sandals types getting it on to a soundtrack of such overwrought cheesiness that it could have been a very early work by TV's King of Strings, W.G. Snuffy Walden.

Afterwards, invited to discuss their reactions, the answer to the question: 'So, what sort of person wants to become a sex therapist anyway?' turned out to be the sort of middle-aged women who kick off their critique by saying: 'Normally when you watch a pornographic film...' Clearly, I must stay in more.

But the heart of the story lay, as it were, with Petula and Chris from Cardiff: 34 years of happy marriage and a clutch of grown-up kids, when, bam!, thanks to press coverage about abuse in children's homes, Petula was reminded of her own long-suppressed memories of childhood sexual abuse and decided she couldn't stand her husband making love to her ever again.

Petula's courage in, first, addressing this issue, then going to Relate and, finally, allowing herself to be filmed was, clearly, above and beyond, but it made for fine, optimistic television. I didn't warm to Gareth, the couple's counsellor - too young, too male, not much of a listener and with far too much Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen hair - but his prescription ('sensate-focus' - basically a massage without hidden extras) seemed to work ('It's like we've started courting again!' admitted Chris, blushingly).

Relate may be justifiably proud of the fact that 20 per cent of clients rekindle their sex lives by the end of their treatment, even if the best way to ensure great sex appears to be to have no sex at all. Can't see this one working for Carrie Bradshaw and friends.

Week Two in Borneo and, for the Jungle Janes, the desire for sex is probably somewhere just above the desire to wear stilettos. Though the narrative is exhaustingly riveting (every time the women took a break and reached for a fag, I'd find myself doing the same), visually this series sucks: Borneo looks like a very unimaginatively designed set for a cheap remake of Tenko , so even when the women complained about one site for a camp being 'too jungly' (cue fits of giggles), we couldn't see how it was any junglier than the jungle they had just heroically negotiated. Still, I'm more than happy to take their word for it.

Though this exercise looks hellish, the women are all shaping up to be a bunch of Lara Crofts, though without the fun of slaying grunting thugs and retrieving a series of fluorescent, wiggly, computer-generated treasures en route . They also take it in turns to cry against the manly chest of their expedition leader, Major Ken Hames (Army, Retd), but who can blame them when Major Ken comes on like a cross between Castaway Ben Fogle and a Relate counsellor? 'Tonight the stars will be shining, the moon will be out and all will be well.' Cut to night-shot of the women sheltering under plastic sheets in the torrential rain.

Unsurprisingly, it's the emotional journeys that makes Jungle Janes such compulsive viewing. All have their coping mechanisms, from Catholicism ('Now I know how Jesus felt carrying the cross') to HRT to near-constant laughter ('If we can keep laughing, especially at ourselves, then we can't go far wrong').

I'm also in awe because I know I'd last a day, at best. None of these women is looking for validation from a man, but it can't hurt that Major Ken is fulsome in his praise of their efforts: 'The UK Special Forces come to Borneo to sort the wheat from the chaff.' Happily, all the women appear to have chaff allergies.

Christa McAuliffe, another envelope-pusher who would have seen the Borneo jungle as a walk in the park, was the star of the doomed Challenger space shuttle mission, but it's easy to forget there was a whole crew whose names aren't as easily recalled. Finally, 15 years after the event we got to find out precisely how doomed the ship was in the excellent Challenger: Go For Launch.

One Nasa employee returned home to his wife and met her 'Nice day at the office, dear?' inquiry with a despairing: 'They're going to launch tomorrow and kill the astronauts, but other than that it was a great day.' Yes, that's how doomed it was. Like the Titanic, a series of cost-cutting cock-ups and management blunders pretty much ensured the shuttle would fail. I'd always consoled myself with the thought that, when it came, the end probably came pretty fast, but no: apparently, the astronauts may have been conscious as the explosion of half-a-million gallons of liquid oxygen and hydrogen propelled them towards the sea at 200mph. Which makes it all the more extraordinary that Barbara, McAuliffe's understudy in the programme gave up teaching and carried on training, qualifying as an astronaut in 1999. She is now preparing to fly shuttles herself and I doubt she loses much sleep over men who are bad kissers.

Bravery is, of course, relative. For Barbara and the Jungle Janes it's about digging deep to discover one's inner Right Stuff, while for the rest of us it might be surviving one of the Restaurants From Hell. Here, I was delighted to see a hideous Aberdeen Angus Steak House - venue for the worst British restaurant meal I have ever eaten (beaten only by something unspeakable I once consumed in Soviet Russia) - being exposed as the House of Vermin Droppings and Bad Sewerage Smells.

It is a mystery how they stay in business but, in the meantime, I guess even a little Health and Safety prosecution helps to undermine a company that still turns over £20 million a year. With its litany of e-coli 0517, salmonella, deep-fried lizards and quarter pounders with mould, I'd have said Restaurants From Hell was the most blackly comedic programme of the week, until I saw Changing Rooms.

Confronted by a demanding, design-conscious bunch of 'performance artists', the designer's (slip) covers were finally blown. Obviously, there's only room for a handful of stars in the show but, as the camp split in two and Carol Smillie consoled Anna Ryder Richardson ('They're wearing me down'; 'Yeah, I feel a bit sorry for you'), it was clear that the stars must never be the contestants - much less those who might know their Barratt from their Bauhaus or recognise that wacky installations made from polystyrene look 's--t'.

It was very funny TV but for all the wrong reasons - so hurry up, Laurence and Linda, let's get busy with those stencils! Surely, for Changing Rooms , the writing's on the wall.
