webTitle: Mission impossible

fields.headline: Mission impossible
fields.standfirst: A third of the world's population carries the TB bacterium. This year it will kill another two million people - more than any other infectious disease. But if anyone can save them it's Paul Farmer, a self-effacing doctor based in rural Haiti (with a little help from George Soros)
fields.trailText: A third of the world's population carries the TB bacterium. This year it will kill another two million people - more than any other infectious disease. But if anyone can save them it's Paul Farmer, a self-effacing doctor based in rural Haiti (with a little help from George Soros)
fields.body:
On maps of Haiti, National Highway 3 looks like a major thoroughfare. And, indeed, it is the gwo wout la , the big- gest road across the Central Plateau, a dirt track on which trucks of various sizes, overfilled with passengers, sway in and out of giant potholes, raising clouds of dust, their engines whining in low gear. A more numerous traffic plods along on donkeys and on foot, including a procession of the sick. They are headed for the village of Cange and the medical complex called Zanmi Lasante, Creole for Partners in Health. In an all-but-treeless landscape, it stands out like a fortress on a hillside, a large collection of concrete buildings half-covered by tropical greenery. Now and then on the road, a bed moves slowly towards it, a bearer at each corner, a patient on the mattress.

Zanmi Lasante is famous on the Central Plateau, in part for its medical director, Dr Paul Farmer, known as Dokte Paul, or Polo, or, occasionally, Blan Paul. The women in Zanmi Lasante's kitchen call him ti blan mwen - 'my little white guy'. Peasant farmers like to remember how, during the violent years of the coup that deposed President Aritide, the unarmed Dokte Paul faced down a soldier who tried to enter the complex carrying a gun. One peasant told me, 'God gives everyone a gift, and his gift is healing.' A former patient once declared, 'I believe he is a god.' It was also said, in whispers, 'He works with both hands' - that is, both with science and with the magic necessary to remove ensorcellments, to many Haitians the deep cause of illnesses. Most of the encomiums seem to embarrass and amuse Farmer. But this last has a painful side. The Haitian belief in illness sent by sorcery thrives on deprivation, on the long absence of effective medicine. Farmer has dozens of voodoo priests among his patients.

On an evening last January, Farmer sat in his office at Zanmi Lasante, dressed in his usual Haiti clothes - black pants and a T-shirt. He was holding aloft a large white plastic bottle. It contained Indinavir, one of the new protease inhibitors for treating Aids - the kind of magic he believes in. A sad-faced young man sat in the chair beside him. Patients never sat on the other side of his desk. He seemed bound to get as close to them as possible.

Farmer is an inch or two over 6ft and thin, unusually long-legged and long-armed, and he has an agile way of folding himself into a chair and arranging himself around a patient he is examining that made me think of a grasshopper. He is about 40. There is a vigorous quality about his thinness. He has a narrow face and a delicate nose, which comes almost to a point. He peered at his patient through the little round lenses of wire-rimmed glasses. The young man had Aids. Farmer had been treating him with antibacterials, but his condition had worsened. The young man said he was ashamed.

'Anybody can catch this. I told you that already,' Farmer said in Creole. He shook the bottle and the pills inside rattled. He asked the young man if he'd heard of this drug and the other new ones for Aids. The man hadn't. Well, Farmer said, the drugs didn't cure Aids, but they would take away his symptoms and, if he was lucky, let him live for many years as if he'd never caught the virus. Farmer would begin treating him soon. He had only to promise that he would never miss a dose. 'My situation is so bad,' the young man said. 'I keep injuring my head, because I'm living in such a crowded house. We have only one bed, and I let my children sleep on it, so I have to sleep under the bed, and I forget, and I hit my head when I sit up.' He went on, 'I don't forget what you did for me, Dokte Paul. When I was sick and no one would touch me, you used to sit on my bed with your hand on my head. I would like to give you a chicken or a pig.'

When Farmer is relaxed, his skin is pale, with a suggestion of freckles underneath. Now it reddened instantly, from the base of his neck to his forehead. 'You've already given me a lot. Stop it!'

The young man was smiling. 'I am going to sleep well tonight.'

'OK, neg pa [my man].'

Farmer put the bottle of pills back in his drawer. No one else is treating impoverished Haitians with the new anti-retroviral drugs. Even some of his allies in the Haitian medical establishment think he's crazy to try. The drugs could cost as much as $18,000 a year per patient. But the fact that the poor are dying of illnesses for which effective treatments exist is, like many global facts of life, unacceptable to Farmer. Indeed, to him it is a sin.

Last autumn, he gave a speech to a group in Massachusetts called Cambridge Cares About Aids and said, 'Cambridge cares about Aids, but not nearly enough.' He wondered if he'd gone too far, but afterwards, at his suggestion, healthcare workers in the audience and people with Aids collected some unused drugs, and he ended up with enough to begin triple therapy for several of his Haitian patients. He is working on grant proposals to obtain a larger, more reliable supply. He doesn't seem to think there is a chance he'll fail. In his experience, when he begs for medicines someone always comes through. Begging of one sort or another is the main way in which he and others managed to create Zanmi Lasante. They didn't borrow, but he did a little stealing - the first microscope in Cange was one he had appropriated from Harvard Medical School.

Farmer has chosen to work in one of Haiti's poorest regions. About 1m peasant farmers rely on the medical complex . About 100,000 live in its catchment area - the area for which the organisation provides community-health workers. On many nights, a hundred people camp out in the courtyard beside the ambulatory clinic; by morning, 300, sometimes more, are waiting for treatment. Unlike almost every other hospital in Haiti, Zanmi Lasante charges only nominal fees, and women and children and the seriously ill pay nothing. Partners in Health pays the bills, which are remarkably small. (Farmer spends about $200 to cure an uncomplicated case of tuberculosis in Haiti. The same cure in the US costs up to $20,000).

Sometimes the pharmacy muddles a prescription or runs out of a drug. Now and then, the lab technicians lose a specimen. Seven doctors work at the complex, not all of them fully competent. But Zanmi Lasante has built schools and communal water systems for most of the villages in its catchment area. A few years back, when Haiti suffered an outbreak of typhoid resistant to the drugs usually used to treat it, Partners in Health imported an effective but expensive antibiotic, cleaned up the water supply, and stopped the outbreak in the Central Plateau. The medical complex has launched programmes in its catchment area for both the prevention and the treatment of Aids, and has reduced the vertical transmission rate (from mothers to babies) to 4 per cent. In Haiti, TB kills more adults than any other disease, but no one from the catchment area has died from it since 1988.

Farmer now has these titles, among others: associate professor in two different departments at Harvard Medical School; member of the senior staff in Infectious Disease at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston; chief consultant on tuberculosis in Russian prisons for the World Bank (unpaid, at his insistence - he deplores some of the World Bank's policies); and founding director of Partners in Health.

In 1993, the MacArthur Foundation gave Farmer one of its so-called genius grants. He had the entire sum sent to Partners in Health - in this case, some $220,000. During his medical-school years, Farmer camped out in Roxbury, in a garret in the rectory of St Mary of the Angels. Later, during sojourns in Boston, he stayed in the basement of Partners in Health headquarters, and he went on staying there after he got married - to Didi Bertrand, the daughter of the schoolmaster in Cange, and 'the most beautiful woman in Cange', people at Zanmi Lasante say. When a daughter was born, two years ago, Farmer saw no reason to change their Boston digs, but his wife did. Now they have an apartment at Harvard. He never sees his paychecks from Harvard and the Brigham. The bookkeeper at Partners in Health cashes them, pays his family's bills, and puts the rest away in the treasury. One day not long ago, Farmer tried to use his credit card and was told he'd reached his limit, so he called the bookkeeper. She told him, 'Honey, you are the hardest-working broke man I know.'

By any standard, Farmer's life is complicated. Didi, who is 31, and their daughter spend the academic year in Paris, where Didi is finishing her own studies in anthropology. Several friends have told Farmer that he should visit his family more often. 'But I don't have any patients in Paris,' he says forlornly. In theory, he works four months in Boston and the rest of the year in Haiti. In fact, those periods are all chopped up. Years ago, he got a letter from American Airlines welcoming him to its million-mile club. He has travelled at least 2m miles since. I spent a month with Farmer: a little more than two weeks in Haiti, with a short trip to South Carolina wedged in; five days in Cuba, at a conference on Aids; and the rest in Moscow, on TB business. He called this 'a light month for travel'. It had a certain roundness. A church group was, in effect, paying for his flight to South Carolina; the Cuban government covered his travel to Havana; and the Soros Foundation financed his trip to Moscow. 'Capitalists, Commies, and Jesus Christers are paying,' he said.

When Paul Farmer goes on a long trip, he carries medicines and carrousels of slides and gifts of Haitian art for his hosts, and ends up with room for only three shirts. He owns one suit, which is black, so that he can, for example, wipe the fuzz off the tip of his pen on his trouser leg while writing up orders at the Brigham, catch a night flight to Lima or Moscow, and still look presentable when he arrives. En route to South Carolina, the zip on his trousers came apart. 'Oh well, I'll button my coat,' he said before his speech.

He addressed a meeting of the Anderson County Medical Society. Some of its members visit Cange every year to treat patients free. Some in this particular audience were also church people - the Episcopal Diocese of Upper South Carolina has been making donations to Zanmi Lasante for almost two decades. It was a jacket-and-tie crowd. Farmer gave them his Haiti talk, a compendium of harsh statistics and cheerful photographs that showed what contributions from places such as South Carolina could do. Here was a photograph of a girl who had come to Zanmi Lasante with extra- pulmonary TB. She was bald, her limbs were wasted. And here was the same girl, with a full head of hair and chubby cheeks, smiling at the camera. Cries of surprise from the crowd, followed by applause. No matter who the audience, that pair of photographs always had the same effect. Farmer had felt jubilant, too, when he treated the girl, but the fact was that the 'before' picture more nearly represented the Haitian norm. When the applause died away, Farmer grinned. 'It's almost as if she had a treatable infectious disease.'

Farmer likes to say that he and his colleagues will make common cause with anyone who is sincerely trying to change the 'political economies' of countries such as Haiti. In the meantime, though, the poor are suffering. They are 'dying like smelt', as Farmer puts it. 'He always kind of holds your feet to the fire,' the MC said when Farmer was done, and, indeed, the applause sounded only slightly more than polite.

Like much of the audience, Farmer is himself religious. He subscribes to the Catholic doctrine called liberation theology, and to its central imperative - to provide 'a preferential option for the poor'. But, he told me, 'I hang on to my Catholicism by a tiny thread. I'm still looking for something in the sacred texts that prohibits using condoms.' Some of his beliefs, ones he hadn't openly expressed that night - for example, 'I think there should be a massive redistribution of wealth to places like Haiti' - would have seemed extreme to this sedate audience. Yet he liked these people a great deal.

Farmer's politics are complex. He has problems with groups that on the surface would seem to be allies. With, for example, what he calls 'WLs' - 'white liberals', some of whose most influential spokespeople are black. 'I love WLs, love 'em to death. They're on our side,' Farmer once said, 'But WLs think all the world's problems can be fixed without any cost to themselves. We don't believe that. There's a lot to be said for sacrifice, remorse, even pity. It's what separates us from roaches.' As often as not, he prefers religious groups and what he calls 'church ladies'.

We stayed at the house of a church lady that night, an impeccably genteel Southerner. She lived in a retirement community. When we arrived, one of her neighbours, a retired dentist, was repainting the movable flags on all the residents' mailboxes. Of our hostess, Farmer had said, 'She is a very good person. I'll take her over a Harvard smart-ass any day. I love her, actually.' I was a little puzzled. This woman wasn't a person you'd suspect of threatening the world order. An hour before dawn the next morning, we climbed into her big new car and she turned on her headlights. They lit up her garage, which was filled to the rafters with boxes and crates - all the equipment Farmer had requested for a new opthalmology clinic in Cange.

As we flew back towards Haiti, via Miami, Farmer worked on thank-you notes to patrons of Partners in Health. During the descent into Miami, Farmer said he had a fantasy that one day he'd look out at the skyline and at the count of 10 all the buildings erected with drug money would collapse. He glanced out the window, disappointed once again. He had other Miami rituals. Depending on its length, a layover at the airport was either 'a Miami day' or 'a Miami day plus,' and included a haircut from his favourite Cuban barber (they'd chat in Spanish) then it was up to the Admirals' Club, which he was in the habit of calling 'Amirales'. There he'd take a hot shower and then stake out a section of lounge (this was 'making a cave' or 'getting cavaceous at Amirales') and answer emails.

He had a message from one of the staff in Cange: 'Dear Polo, we are so glad we will see you in a mere matter of hours. We miss you. We miss you as the cracked, dry earth misses the rain.'

'After 36 hours?' Farmer said to his computer. 'Haitians, man. They're totally over the top. My kind of people.'

Days and nights ran together. He has a small house in Cange, the closest thing in his life to a home, perched on a cliff across the road from the medical complex. It's a modified ti kay , the better sort of peasant house, with a metal roof and concrete floors, and is exceptional in that it has a bathroom, albeit without hot water. Farmer told me that he slept about five hours a night, but, many times, when I looked inside his house, his bed seemed unused. Once, he told me, 'I can't sleep. There's always somebody not getting treatment. I can't stand that.' I suppose he slept some nights. His days usually began around dawn. He'd spend an hour or so among the people who had camped out in the lower courtyard, to make sure the staff hadn't missed someone critically ill, and another hour gobbling breakfast while answering emails. Then he saw patients in his office.

Most of the patients were indeed the poor and the maimed and the lame and the blind. For consolation, there was the man he called Lazarus, who had first arrived on a stretcher, wasted by Aids and TB to about 90lb, and now weighed 150lb. There was a healthy-looking young woman with Aids whose father, only a month before, had been saving for her coffin. But there was also a tiny old woman whose backbone had been eaten by TB bacilli, and who hobbled around with her torso at right angles to her legs. A 16-year-old boy who weighed only 60lb. ('His body has got used to starvation. We're gonna buff him up.') A lovely young woman being treated for drug-resistant TB, now in the midst of a sickle-cell crisis and moaning in pain. ('OK, doudou . OK cheri ,' Farmer cooed. He gave her morphine.) An elderly man with drug-resistant TB who was totally blind. (He'd wanted a pair of glasses anyway; Farmer had found him a pair.) He called the old women 'Mother', and the old men 'Father'. He exchanged quips with most of his patients while he examined them. He turned to me. 'It's so awful you might as well be cheerful.'

Off and on during those two weeks in Cange, he conducted what he called 'a sorcery consult'. A woman had decided that one of her sons had 'sent' the sickness that killed another son. Farmer was trying to make peace in the family. This would probably take months, because, for one thing, it was useless to try to convince any of the parties that sorcery didn't exist.

After office hours, he went on rounds, first to the general hospital and then, with trepidation, to the children's pavilion upstairs, where there always seemed to be a baby with the stick-like limbs, the bloated belly, the reddish hair of kwashiorkor, a form of starvation. Just two weeks earlier, on his first morning back in Cange this year, he'd lost a baby to meningitis, in its ghastly purpura fulminans presentation. And, only days later, another baby, from beyond the catchment area - within it, all children are vaccinated free - had died of tetanus. Farmer saved rounds at the TB hospital for last, because just now everyone there was getting better. Most of the patients were sitting on the beds in one of the rooms watching a soccer game on a wavy, snowy TV screen. 'Look at you bourgeois people watching TV!' Farmer said.

Everyone laughed. One of the young men looked up at him. 'No, Dokte Paul, not bourgeois. If we were bourgeois, we would have an aerial.'

'It cheers me up,' Farmer said on the way out. 'It's not all bad. We're failing on 71 levels, but not on one or two.' Then it was across the road to his ti kay , where he worked with a young American woman from Partners in Health who had been despatched to help him on his thank-you notes and forthcoming speeches and grant proposals. But on many nights Ti Jean, a handyman, would appear out of the dark, with news that would take Farmer back to the hospital.

A 13-year-old girl with meningitis had arrived by donkey ambulance. The young doctors on duty hadn't done a spinal tap, to find out which type of meningitis she had, and thus which drugs to give her. 'Doctors, doctors, what is wrong with you?' Farmer said. Then he did the tap himself. Wild cries from the child: ' Li fe-m mal, mwen grangou .' Farmer looked up from his work and said, 'She's crying, "It hurts, I'm hungry." Can you believe it? Only in Haiti would a child cry out that she's hungry during a spinal tap.'

For a person whose CV makes one think of Albert Schweitzer - the once-popular image of that person, at least - Farmer has an oddly cheerful and irreverent turn of mind. From time to time, colleagues, and even a close friend or two, have subjected him to moral envy, as if his self-abnegation were meant as a reproach to them. It isn't as though he doesn't preach self-sacrifice, but he practises more than he preaches. He has taken only two vacations in the last 12 years - the first after he was run over, in Cambridge in 1988, the second in 1997 while recovering from hepatitis A, contracted in Peru. Yet he thinks that other people ought to have vacations, and the more luxurious the better. He likes a fine meal, a good bottle of wine, a fancy hotel, and a hot shower. But he doesn't seem to need any of those things, or the money to buy others, in order to be happy.

It was impossible to spend any time with Farmer and not wonder why he'd chosen this life. Maybe some partial explanations can be found in the usual place.

One morning, between airplanes, he and I were standing near the side exit of a crowded bus, and he said, 'I feel at home. Our bus had doors like these.' He added, 'Until the bus turned over.' He was about 12. The bus was older. His father had bought it from the State of Alabama, had fashioned it into the Farmer residence, and parked it in a campground in Florida. The Farmers came from western Massachusetts. The whole family - Farmer's father and mother and six children - was heading home from a vacation there when the bus flipped on to its roof. No one was seriously hurt.

'Where did you live after that?' I asked.

'In a tent. Of course. What kind of a question is that?' He was smiling. 'This is before it got crazy, before the boat.'

His father bought a boat, on which he intended the family to achieve full self-sufficiency. But the one time they went to sea they hauled up only a couple of edible fish, and were buffeted all night in a storm. Then his father got lost heading back for port and grazed a rock. After that, the boat stayed moored in a bayou on the Gulf Coast, north of Tampa.

The bus door opened, and Farmer, returning to the present, looked at the door and said, 'My madeleine this morning.'

Farmer's father had a profession - schoolteacher, usually. He was a big, vigorous man and a good athlete. He was strict with his children about manners and schoolwork and chores. But in most other respects he shunned convention, stubbornly pursuing his various schemes. 'You didn't tell him that he couldn't do something, because then he'd have to prove that he could,' Farmer's mother said. 'He was a great risk-taker, and everything always turned out all right. I mean, no one ever got seriously hurt.' He died suddenly, at the age of 49, in apparent good health, while playing basketball.

Farmer, according to his younger sisters, was a scrawny boy, intense in anger and affection, and very smart. He started a herpetology club in fifth grade. No one came to the first meeting, but his father required his siblings to attend the family lectures about plants and animals that Paul delivered at home. He received a scholarship to Duke University. There he discovered wealth. 'How come you put your shirts in plastic?' he asked, watching his roommate unpack. At Duke, he soaked up culture. He was drama critic and art critic for the student paper. The first play he ever saw was one he was sent to review.

But growing up on a bus and a boat, without hot showers, hardly implies a single fate. One of his sisters is a commercial artist, another manages community relations for a hospital's mental-health programme, the third is a motivational speaker. One brother is an electrician, the other a professional wrestler (known to fans as the treacherous New World Order Sting and to his family as the Gentle Giant). A person with Farmer's background might well have yearned for a lucrative suburban practice. He himself doesn't like to make too much of the connections between his present life and his childhood, which, for the most part, he remembers as happy. He did say that it had relieved him of a homing instinct. 'I never had a sense of a home town,' he said. 'It was, "This is my campground." Then I got to the bottom of the barrel, and it was, "This is my home town."' He meant Cange.

Farmer told me, 'It stands to reason that a person who lives the way I do is trying to lessen some psychic discomfort.' He had wanted to avoid 'ambivalence,' he said, and had tried to build his life around 'areas of moral clarity' - 'AMCs' in Partners in Health lingo. These are areas, rare in the world, where what ought to be done seems perfectly clear. But the doing was always complicated, always difficult, in his experience. Thinking of those difficulties, I imagine that most people wouldn't willingly take them on, giving up their comforts. Yet many would like to wake up knowing what they ought to do and that they were doing it. Farmer's life looked hard, but by the time we left Haiti I also thought that it was enviable.

Leaving Haiti, Farmer didn't stare down through the airplane window at that brown and barren third of an island. 'It bothers me even to look at it,' he explained, glancing out. 'It can't support 8m people, and there they are. There they are, kidnapped from West Africa.'

But when we descended toward Havana he gazed out the window intently, making exclamations: 'Only 90 miles from Haiti, and look! Trees! Crops! It's all so verdant. At the height of the dry season! The same ecology as Haiti's, and look!'

Cuba was a great relief to me. Paved roads and old American cars, instead of litters on the gwo wout la . Cuba had food rationing and allotments of coffee adulterated with ground peas, but no starvation, no enforced malnutrition. I noticed groups of prostitutes on one main road, and housing projects in need of repair and paint, like most buildings in the city. But I still had in mind the howling slums of Port-au-Prince, and Cuba looked lovely to me. What looked loveliest to Farmer was its public-health statistics.

Many things affect a public's health, of course - nutrition and transportation, crime and housing, pest control and sanitation, as well as medicine. In Cuba, life expectancies are among the highest in the world. Diseases endemic to Haiti, such a malaria, dengue fever, TB and Aids, are rare. Cuba was training medical students gratis from all over Latin America, and exporting doctors gratis - nearly 1,000 to Haiti, two en route just now to Zanmi Lasante. In the midst of the hard times that came when the Soviet Union dissolved, the government actually increased its spending on health care. 'I can sleep here,' Farmer said when we got to our hotel. 'Everyone here has a doctor.'

Farmer gave two talks at the conference, one on Haiti, the other on 'the noxious synergy' between HIV and TB - an active case of one often makes a latent case of the other active, too. He worked on a grand proposal to get anti-retroviral medicines for Cange, and at the conference met a woman who could help. She was in charge of the United Nations' project on Aids in the Caribbean. He lobbied her over several days. Finally, she said, 'OK, let's make it happen.' ('Can I give you a kiss?' Farmer asked. 'Can I give you two?') And an old friend, Dr Jorge Pérez, arranged a private meeting between Farmer and the secretary of Cuba's Council of State, Dr José Miyar Barruecos. Farmer asked him if he could send two youths from Cange to a Cuban medical school. 'Of course,' the secretary replied.

Again and again during our stay, Farmer marvelled at the warmth with which the Cubans received him. What did I think accounted for this? I said I imagined they liked his connection to Harvard, his published attacks on US foreign policy in Latin America, his admiration of Cuban medicine.

I looked up and found his pale-blue eyes fixed on me. 'I think it's because of Haiti,' he declared. 'I think it's because I serve the poor.'

I had the impression that he was angry, disappointed, and a little hurt. An oddly potent combination. And then I felt I was forgiven. Lying in the bed next to Farmer's in the hotel room took me back to late-night talks in college and in the army. I turned out the light, and he went on talking, his voice growing slurred: 'I had a lovely day. I'm lucky. All my days are good. Not all are lovely, but they're good. I wouldn't trade with anyone.'

A few nights later, we started flying towards Moscow. We stopped off in Paris for 18 hours, so Farmer could attend his daughter Catherine's second birthday party. He'd brought short-acting benzodiazepines to get us through the flights. They have left my memories of Paris all wrapped up in gauze. A small apartment in the Marais district, and Farmer in his black suit, dancing with his daughter, holding her to his chest, swaying from side to side in a loopy, long-limbed waltz. And the little girl's dark eyes, which her face hadn't yet grown into, fixed in serious rapture on some invisible object in the ceiling. Later, Farmer sat on the sofa and watched Catherine play with her stuffed animals. His wife, Didi, tall and stately - she probably was, in fact, the most beautiful woman in Cange - called to him from the kitchen. When did he leave for Moscow? Tomorrow morning, Farmer said. From the kitchen came the sound of something dropping and a deep-throated exclamation.

Farmer was skipping the first meeting in Moscow to make this stop. He'd said he felt guilty about that. Now I looked over at him. He was clasping his knees with his elbows and covering his mouth with both hands. He seemed to be trying, as Haitians say, to make his body very small. I remember thinking, despite my haze, that I'd remember this. It was the first time I'd ever seen him at a loss for words or action.

And, indeed, it is the gwo wout la , the big- gest road across the Central Plateau, a dirt track on which trucks of various sizes, overfilled with passengers, sway in and out of giant potholes, raising clouds of dust, their engines whining in low gear. A more numerous traffic plods along on donkeys and on foot, including a procession of the sick. They are headed for the village of Cange and the medical complex called Zanmi Lasante, Creole for Partners in Health. In an all-but-treeless landscape, it stands out like a fortress on a hillside, a large collection of concrete buildings half-covered by tropical greenery. Now and then on the road, a bed moves slowly towards it, a bearer at each corner, a patient on the mattress. Zanmi Lasante is famous on the Central Plateau, in part for its medical director, Dr Paul Farmer, known as Dokte Paul, or Polo, or, occasionally, Blan Paul. The women in Zanmi Lasante's kitchen call him ti blan mwen - 'my little white guy'. Peasant farmers like to remember how, during the violent years of the coup that deposed President Aritide, the unarmed Dokte Paul faced down a soldier who tried to enter the complex carrying a gun. One peasant told me, 'God gives everyone a gift, and his gift is healing.' A former patient once declared, 'I believe he is a god.' It was also said, in whispers, 'He works with both hands' - that is, both with science and with the magic necessary to remove ensorcellments, to many Haitians the deep cause of illnesses. Most of the encomiums seem to embarrass and amuse Farmer. But this last has a painful side. The Haitian belief in illness sent by sorcery thrives on deprivation, on the long absence of effective medicine. Farmer has dozens of voodoo priests among his patients. On an evening last January, Farmer sat in his office at Zanmi Lasante, dressed in his usual Haiti clothes - black pants and a T-shirt. He was holding aloft a large white plastic bottle. It contained Indinavir, one of the new protease inhibitors for treating Aids - the kind of magic he believes in. A sad-faced young man sat in the chair beside him. Patients never sat on the other side of his desk. He seemed bound to get as close to them as possible. Farmer is an inch or two over 6ft and thin, unusually long-legged and long-armed, and he has an agile way of folding himself into a chair and arranging himself around a patient he is examining that made me think of a grasshopper. He is about 40. There is a vigorous quality about his thinness. He has a narrow face and a delicate nose, which comes almost to a point. He peered at his patient through the little round lenses of wire-rimmed glasses. The young man had Aids. Farmer had been treating him with antibacterials, but his condition had worsened. The young man said he was ashamed. 'Anybody can catch this. I told you that already,' Farmer said in Creole. He shook the bottle and the pills inside rattled. He asked the young man if he'd heard of this drug and the other new ones for Aids. The man hadn't. Well, Farmer said, the drugs didn't cure Aids, but they would take away his symptoms and, if he was lucky, let him live for many years as if he'd never caught the virus. Farmer would begin treating him soon. He had only to promise that he would never miss a dose. 'My situation is so bad,' the young man said. 'I keep injuring my head, because I'm living in such a crowded house. We have only one bed, and I let my children sleep on it, so I have to sleep under the bed, and I forget, and I hit my head when I sit up.' He went on, 'I don't forget what you did for me, Dokte Paul. When I was sick and no one would touch me, you used to sit on my bed with your hand on my head. I would like to give you a chicken or a pig.' He glanced out the window, disappointed once again. He had other Miami rituals. Depending on its length, a layover at the airport was either 'a Miami day' or 'a Miami day plus,' and included a haircut from his favourite Cuban barber (they'd chat in Spanish) then it was up to the Admirals' Club, which he was in the habit of calling 'Amirales'. There he'd take a hot shower and then stake out a section of lounge (this was 'making a cave' or 'getting cavaceous at Amirales') and answer emails. He had a message from one of the staff in Cange: 'Dear Polo, we are so glad we will see you in a mere matter of hours. We miss you. We miss you as the cracked, dry earth misses the rain.' 'After 36 hours?' Farmer said to his computer. 'Haitians, man. They're totally over the top. My kind of people.' Days and nights ran together. He has a small house in Cange, the closest thing in his life to a home, perched on a cliff across the road from the medical complex. It's a modified ti kay , the better sort of peasant house, with a metal roof and concrete floors, and is exceptional in that it has a bathroom, albeit without hot water. Farmer told me that he slept about five hours a night, but, many times, when I looked inside his house, his bed seemed unused. Once, he told me, 'I can't sleep. There's always somebody not getting treatment. I can't stand that.' I suppose he slept some nights. His days usually began around dawn. He'd spend an hour or so among the people who had camped out in the lower courtyard, to make sure the staff hadn't missed someone critically ill, and another hour gobbling breakfast while answering emails. Then he saw patients in his office. Most of the patients were indeed the poor and the maimed and the lame and the blind. For consolation, there was the man he called Lazarus, who had first arrived on a stretcher, wasted by Aids and TB to about 90lb, and now weighed 150lb. There was a healthy-looking young woman with Aids whose father, only a month before, had been saving for her coffin. But there was also a tiny old woman whose backbone had been eaten by TB bacilli, and who hobbled around with her torso at right angles to her legs. A 16-year-old boy who weighed only 60lb. ('His body has got used to starvation. We're gonna buff him up.') A lovely young woman being treated for drug-resistant TB, now in the midst of a sickle-cell crisis and moaning in pain. ('OK, doudou . OK cheri ,' Farmer cooed. He gave her morphine.) An elderly man with drug-resistant TB who was totally blind. (He'd wanted a pair of glasses anyway; Farmer had found him a pair.) He called the old women 'Mother', and the old men 'Father'. He exchanged quips with most of his patients while he examined them. He turned to me. 'It's so awful you might as well be cheerful.' Off and on during those two weeks in Cange, he conducted what he called 'a sorcery consult'. A woman had decided that one of her sons had 'sent' the sickness that killed another son. Farmer was trying to make peace in the family. This would probably take months, because, for one thing, it was useless to try to convince any of the parties that sorcery didn't exist. After office hours, he went on rounds, first to the general hospital and then, with trepidation, to the children's pavilion upstairs, where there always seemed to be a baby with the stick-like limbs, the bloated belly, the reddish hair of kwashiorkor, a form of starvation. Just two weeks earlier, on his first morning back in Cange this year, he'd lost a baby to meningitis, in its ghastly purpura fulminans presentation. And, only days later, another baby, from beyond the catchment area - within it, all children are vaccinated free - had died of tetanus. Farmer saved rounds at the TB hospital for last, because just now everyone there was getting better. Most of the patients were sitting on the beds in one of the rooms watching a soccer game on a wavy, snowy TV screen. 'Look at you bourgeois people watching TV!' Farmer said. Everyone laughed. One of the young men looked up at him. 'No, Dokte Paul, not bourgeois. If we were bourgeois, we would have an aerial.' 'It cheers me up,' Farmer said on the way out. 'It's not all bad. We're failing on 71 levels, but not on one or two.' Then it was across the road to his ti kay , where he worked with a young American woman from Partners in Health who had been despatched to help him on his thank-you notes and forthcoming speeches and grant proposals. But on many nights Ti Jean, a handyman, would appear out of the dark, with news that would take Farmer back to the hospital. A 13-year-old girl with meningitis had arrived by donkey ambulance. The young doctors on duty hadn't done a spinal tap, to find out which type of meningitis she had, and thus which drugs to give her. 'Doctors, doctors, what is wrong with you?' Farmer said. Then he did the tap himself. Wild cries from the child: ' Li fe-m mal, mwen grangou .' Farmer looked up from his work and said, 'She's crying, "It hurts, I'm hungry." Can you believe it? Only in Haiti would a child cry out that she's hungry during a spinal tap.' For a person whose CV makes one think of Albert Schweitzer - the once-popular image of that person, at least - Farmer has an oddly cheerful and irreverent turn of mind. From time to time, colleagues, and even a close friend or two, have subjected him to moral envy, as if his self-abnegation were meant as a reproach to them. It isn't as though he doesn't preach self-sacrifice, but he practises more than he preaches. He has taken only two vacations in the last 12 years - the first after he was run over, in Cambridge in 1988, the second in 1997 while recovering from hepatitis A, contracted in Peru. Yet he thinks that other people ought to have vacations, and the more luxurious the better. He likes a fine meal, a good bottle of wine, a fancy hotel, and a hot shower. But he doesn't seem to need any of those things, or the money to buy others, in order to be happy. It was impossible to spend any time with Farmer and not wonder why he'd chosen this life. Maybe some partial explanations can be found in the usual place. One morning, between airplanes, he and I were standing near the side exit of a crowded bus, and he said, 'I feel at home. Our bus had doors like these.' He added, 'Until the bus turned over.' He was about 12. The bus was older. His father had bought it from the State of Alabama, had fashioned it into the Farmer residence, and parked it in a campground in Florida. The Farmers came from western Massachusetts. The whole family - Farmer's father and mother and six children - was heading home from a vacation there when the bus flipped on to its roof. No one was seriously hurt. 'Where did you live after that?' I asked. 'In a tent. Of course. What kind of a question is that?' He was smiling. 'This is before it got crazy, before the boat.' His father bought a boat, on which he intended the family to achieve full self-sufficiency. But the one time they went to sea they hauled up only a couple of edible fish, and were buffeted all night in a storm. Then his father got lost heading back for port and grazed a rock. After that, the boat stayed moored in a bayou on the Gulf Coast, north of Tampa. The bus door opened, and Farmer, returning to the present, looked at the door and said, 'My madeleine this morning.' Farmer's father had a profession - schoolteacher, usually. He was a big, vigorous man and a good athlete. He was strict with his children about manners and schoolwork and chores. But in most other respects he shunned convention, stubbornly pursuing his various schemes. 'You didn't tell him that he couldn't do something, because then he'd have to prove that he could,' Farmer's mother said. 'He was a great risk-taker, and everything always turned out all right. I mean, no one ever got seriously hurt.' He died suddenly, at the age of 49, in apparent good health, while playing basketball. Farmer, according to his younger sisters, was a scrawny boy, intense in anger and affection, and very smart. He started a herpetology club in fifth grade. No one came to the first meeting, but his father required his siblings to attend the family lectures about plants and animals that Paul delivered at home. He received a scholarship to Duke University. There he discovered wealth. 'How come you put your shirts in plastic?' he asked, watching his roommate unpack. At Duke, he soaked up culture. He was drama critic and art critic for the student paper. The first play he ever saw was one he was sent to review. But growing up on a bus and a boat, without hot showers, hardly implies a single fate. One of his sisters is a commercial artist, another manages community relations for a hospital's mental-health programme, the third is a motivational speaker. One brother is an electrician, the other a professional wrestler (known to fans as the treacherous New World Order Sting and to his family as the Gentle Giant). A person with Farmer's background might well have yearned for a lucrative suburban practice. He himself doesn't like to make too much of the connections between his present life and his childhood, which, for the most part, he remembers as happy. He did say that it had relieved him of a homing instinct. 'I never had a sense of a home town,' he said. 'It was, "This is my campground." Then I got to the bottom of the barrel, and it was, "This is my home town."' He meant Cange. Farmer told me, 'It stands to reason that a person who lives the way I do is trying to lessen some psychic discomfort.' He had wanted to avoid 'ambivalence,' he said, and had tried to build his life around 'areas of moral clarity' - 'AMCs' in Partners in Health lingo. These are areas, rare in the world, where what ought to be done seems perfectly clear. But the doing was always complicated, always difficult, in his experience. Thinking of those difficulties, I imagine that most people wouldn't willingly take them on, giving up their comforts. Yet many would like to wake up knowing what they ought to do and that they were doing it. Farmer's life looked hard, but by the time we left Haiti I also thought that it was enviable. Leaving Haiti, Farmer didn't stare down through the airplane window at that brown and barren third of an island. 'It bothers me even to look at it,' he explained, glancing out. 'It can't support 8m people, and there they are. There they are, kidnapped from West Africa.' But when we descended toward Havana he gazed out the window intently, making exclamations: 'Only 90 miles from Haiti, and look! Trees! Crops! It's all so verdant. At the height of the dry season! The same ecology as Haiti's, and look!' Cuba was a great relief to me. Paved roads and old American cars, instead of litters on the gwo wout la . Cuba had food rationing and allotments of coffee adulterated with ground peas, but no starvation, no enforced malnutrition. I noticed groups of prostitutes on one main road, and housing projects in need of repair and paint, like most buildings in the city. But I still had in mind the howling slums of Port-au-Prince, and Cuba looked lovely to me. What looked loveliest to Farmer was its public-health statistics. Many things affect a public's health, of course - nutrition and transportation, crime and housing, pest control and sanitation, as well as medicine. In Cuba, life expectancies are among the highest in the world. Diseases endemic to Haiti, such a malaria, dengue fever, TB and Aids, are rare. Cuba was training medical students gratis from all over Latin America, and exporting doctors gratis - nearly 1,000 to Haiti, two en route just now to Zanmi Lasante. In the midst of the hard times that came when the Soviet Union dissolved, the government actually increased its spending on health care. 'I can sleep here,' Farmer said when we got to our hotel. 'Everyone here has a doctor.' Farmer gave two talks at the conference, one on Haiti, the other on 'the noxious synergy' between HIV and TB - an active case of one often makes a latent case of the other active, too. He worked on a grand proposal to get anti-retroviral medicines for Cange, and at the conference met a woman who could help. She was in charge of the United Nations' project on Aids in the Caribbean. He lobbied her over several days. Finally, she said, 'OK, let's make it happen.' ('Can I give you a kiss?' Farmer asked. 'Can I give you two?') And an old friend, Dr Jorge Pérez, arranged a private meeting between Farmer and the secretary of Cuba's Council of State, Dr José Miyar Barruecos. Farmer asked him if he could send two youths from Cange to a Cuban medical school. 'Of course,' the secretary replied. Again and again during our stay, Farmer marvelled at the warmth with which the Cubans received him. What did I think accounted for this? I said I imagined they liked his connection to Harvard, his published attacks on US foreign policy in Latin America, his admiration of Cuban medicine. I looked up and found his pale-blue eyes fixed on me. 'I think it's because of Haiti,' he declared. 'I think it's because I serve the poor.' I had the impression that he was angry, disappointed, and a little hurt. An oddly potent combination. And then I felt I was forgiven. Lying in the bed next to Farmer's in the hotel room took me back to late-night talks in college and in the army. I turned out the light, and he went on talking, his voice growing slurred: 'I had a lovely day. I'm lucky. All my days are good. Not all are lovely, but they're good. I wouldn't trade with anyone.' A few nights later, we started flying towards Moscow. We stopped off in Paris for 18 hours, so Farmer could attend his daughter Catherine's second birthday party. He'd brought short-acting benzodiazepines to get us through the flights. They have left my memories of Paris all wrapped up in gauze. A small apartment in the Marais district, and Farmer in his black suit, dancing with his daughter, holding her to his chest, swaying from side to side in a loopy, long-limbed waltz. And the little girl's dark eyes, which her face hadn't yet grown into, fixed in serious rapture on some invisible object in the ceiling. Later, Farmer sat on the sofa and watched Catherine play with her stuffed animals. His wife, Didi, tall and stately - she probably was, in fact, the most beautiful woman in Cange - called to him from the kitchen. When did he leave for Moscow? Tomorrow morning, Farmer said. From the kitchen came the sound of something dropping and a deep-throated exclamation. Farmer was skipping the first meeting in Moscow to make this stop. He'd said he felt guilty about that. Now I looked over at him. He was clasping his knees with his elbows and covering his mouth with both hands. He seemed to be trying, as Haitians say, to make his body very small. I remember thinking, despite my haze, that I'd remember this. It was the first time I'd ever seen him at a loss for words or action. Read the second part of 'Mission Impossible' here

webTitle: The perfect auction

fields.headline: The perfect auction
fields.standfirst: Jussi Pylkkänen, deputy chairman of Christie's United Kingdom, and their international director of 19th- and 20th-century art
fields.trailText: Jussi Pylkkänen, deputy chairman of Christie's United Kingdom, and their international director of 19th- and 20th-century art.
fields.body:
The perfect auction is driven by the need to possess. Collecting pictures is an obsession. Once you start, it's extremely difficult to give up the drug of accumulating beautiful objects.

The ideal scenario would be a group of the world's top collectors in one room. Think of Bill Gates, Madonna, the Rothschilds or Mr Yasuda, who made history when he purchased Van Gogh's Sunflowers for nearly $40m. There would be no phone bidders, no one taking part by digital link, just 20 very wealthy people competing tooth and nail for a great object, such as Manet's Déjeuner Sur l'Herbe.

There's a terrible sort of stillness involved in any perfect auction. It is pure tension. When great collectors have made the trip from LA or Geneva to sit in a room and bid against each other, everybody is waiting to see who comes out on top. The power of silence is enormous. It's the auctioneer's most effective method of putting pressure on someone who is likely to want to bid. It just takes a look, and you can leave the whole room waiting for that individual to give a sign. Great collectors will only buy in person. There's no pleasure in getting an agent to do it; if you're spending such vast sums of money, you want to be the one who raises your finger.

Pace is critical. Two minutes is a long time for one object and 45 seconds is an average time. The Blue Period Picasso we auctioned in New York was valued at $25m, but we sold it for $55m in two minutes flat. If someone is taking three minutes to sell a painting, dragging it out as you sometimes see them do in films, it's far too long and the tension is broken. The excitement can rival any rock concert. Where else can you spend $50m with a nod of your head?

webTitle: Jane Clarke: Sticking with rice

fields.headline: Sticking with rice
fields.standfirst: Why you'll lose more than just pounds when you avoid carbohydrates
fields.trailText: Why you'll lose more than just pounds when you avoid carbohydrates.
fields.body:
At this time of year, members of the dieting industry vie with each other to advertise their new 'wonder diet'. Gone, it seems, are the days when sensible eating habits made the headlines. At the moment, celebrities seem to be falling over each other to trumpet the number of pounds they have shed through following high-protein, low-carbohydrate diets. Some practitioners have even been recommending a potentially dangerous variation on the theme - the protein and citrus-fruit diet, which also includes injections of substances that are thought to contain diuretics and drugs that stimulate the metabolic rate.

I suspect that high-protein diets are so popular because many people find that eating too many concentrated carbohydrates (such as bread, rice and pasta) makes them feel heavy, bloated and lethargic, and that when they cut out such foods their energy levels rise dramatically. But although eating fruit, vegetables and lean-protein foods for a few days may leave you feeling lighter, if you continue to eat less than 100g of carbohydrates a day, your body is likely to enter a state called ketosis. Ketosis causes the body to produce ketones, compounds that can make your breath smell of pear drops (or worse) and your mouth taste metallic. More seriously, it also increases the loss of essential minerals, such as calcium, thereby ultimately resulting in osteoporosis (brittle-bone disease). If you persist in following such a strict diet, your body will suffer metabolic changes that may hinder your ability to maintain your weight in the long run.

It is possible to compromise with a diet that helps you both to lose weight and feel healthier, while also protecting your bones and metabolism. Avoiding carbohydrate-rich foods for a few days may give you rapid results, but I advise incorporating a little carbohydrate into your diet to prevent your body from producing ketones. You can derive your daily requirement of 100g of carbohydrate by eating 200g of baked potato, spaghetti or rice, as well as a few pieces of fruit, such as bananas. Pulses, which contain some carbohydrate as well as protein, along with root vegetables and non-watery fruits such as pineapples, mangoes and dried fruits with no added sulphur dioxide (SO2), are equally good dietary staples.

Nutrition news: The Curcuma cure

Pharmaceutical companies are continually investigating traditional remedies in the hope of finding treatments for illnesses. One of the latest studies focuses on a tonic derived from the oils of the Curcuma shrub, a plant used by the inhabitants of Irian Jaya in Indonesia for digestive ailments that is now thought to play a potential role in the prevention of bowel cancer. Although current research indicates that regular exercise and having a diet rich in vegetables and low in fat, meat and alcohol helps to ward off cancer of both the colon and rectum, watch this space: the Curcuma plant may soon yield some vital information.

Your questions

I have been suffering from increased stress at work and wonder if any foods could help me to deal with it. I should also mention that I smoke.
Alicia Frith, St Albans

A If you have moved up a gear in response to stress, your body starts to use up nutrients at an increased rate. Unless you increase your intake of nutrients, you will soon feel run down and be more likely to succumb to illness. It is therefore vital that you try to maintain healthy eating habits.

Because smoking increases your vitamin C requirement, start by taking a daily dose of 2,000mg, either in one hit or over time. Snack on plenty of vitamin C-packed fresh fruit during the day; bananas are especially nourishing and calming, while even dried fruits (with no added SO2) will provide you with a source of slow-release energy.

Hold off from biscuits, chocolates and other foods that contain rapidly absorbed sugar, as these will send your blood-sugar and energy levels, as well as your emotions, on a stressful roller-coaster ride. If you are highly stressed, eating fatty foods may also prompt your stomach to produce excessive quantities of acid, causing indigestion and heartburn. Opt for lighter foods, such as a pasta or risotto dish, or simply cooked fish.

Because excess caffeine increases the amount of adrenaline that your body generates in response to stress, restrict your coffee, tea or hot chocolate intake to a couple of cups a day, and drink more water and herbal teas instead. This may sound painful (which it literally may be for the first day or so), but so many patients feel far less agitated and aggressive when they can break the caffeine-dependency cycle that it's definitely worth giving it a try.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. If you would like her to answer any questions or address any issues in this column, please write to Jane Clarke c/o Life Magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email her at life@observer.co.uk. webTitle: Loafer's guide

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Botox
fields.trailText: Botox.
fields.body:
What's Botox? Produced by a bacterium called Clostridium botulinum , Botox - or Botulinum toxin, to give it its full name - is a nerve impulse 'blocker', a medication used to temporarily paralyse muscle function. This has been useful in the treatment of illnesses such as MS and cerebral palsy, but more recently has been used to cure that plague of affluent Western civilisation: wrinkles.

But isn't botulism a serious illness? Er, yes. The active ingredient in Botox can, in much larger amounts, cause botulism. Botulism poisoning occurs if you eat food contaminated with Clostridium botulinum . If it paralyses your respiratory system, you can die. The toxin may also be produced in infected cuts and wounds, which is why we have tetanus shots. According to Vogue, the bacteria also formed part of Saddam Hussein's biological-warfare arsenal.

But it's safe for use by doctors? According to the doctors, yes - although it has never been approved safe for cosmetic use by the FDA in the States or the CSM here at home. To have it injected into your forehead to ease frown marks, you therefore have to sign a consent form.

Does it work? There's no surgery involved, very little risk, and just a slight pain while the procedure is being done. Celebrities about to show off their lovely home in Hello! magazine or marry a far younger partner swear by it. Although airbrushing all the pictures can be even more effective in banishing signs of ageing. And that wisdom comes with maturity.

How much will it cost me? £150 to £550. And you'll have to repeat the treatment every three to five months if you want the effect to last.

Are there any other applications? Apparently it's good at curbing excessive sweating in specific areas. Some doctors are also now using Botox injections 'to reduce intractable drooling'. For older actors still trying to play the young love interest, Botox may become the gift that keeps on giving.

webTitle: The cost of...

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: a nuclear bunker
fields.trailText: a nuclear bunker.
fields.body:
He's had time to sharpen his pencils, colour-code his paperclips and appoint bug-eyed, hawkish Cold War relics. What next for Dubya? Well, the Son of Stars Wars for a start, the missile protection programme that won't happen unless we allow our Fylingdales satellite station to be upgraded. (In return for which we get precisely no protective coverage at all.)

It does not take an evil genius, or even a moderately astute terrorist with his grade one in Elementary Terrorism, to work out that if you take Britain (unprotected, remember) out of the equation, the US will be back to square one, with Dubya at the controls. Now, where are those nuclear shelter blueprints?

In the early 80s, the Home Office prepared a guide to domestic nuclear shelters. There were three options: the improvised garden shelter, the manufactured outdoor shelter and the one we are interested in, the underground, reinforced concrete bunker.

Extensive calculations reveal that for a floor area of 10 sq m and walls of 1m thickness, you will need 46m of concrete for the walls and 98m for the floor and ceiling. webTitle: Go see...

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: Antoni + Alison
fields.trailText: Antoni + Alison.
fields.body:
The line between fashion and art is a well-trodden one, the only problem being that people tend to mince along it very seriously. Not so Antonio Burakowski and Alison Roberts, better known as Antoni + Alison. They met when she was studying fine art and he fashion at St Martin's, and for over 10 years they have pooled their talents to create clothes and accessories bearing their witty photographic prints and slogans.

Now these prints are to receive the full exhibition treatment at the Photographers' Gallery. Featuring 70 photographs from 1995 to the current collection, Patterns with Objects involves the photographing of carefully selected objects against patterned backgrounds to create works such as My Lovely Horse (With Cherries) , right, or Potato Polka Dots . 'We like choosing objects - such as, say, glacé cherries - that can be completely dismissed,' comments Alison.

Their talent for cherishing the mundane and making it charming comes through in much of the work, and glacé cherries are not the only objects to receive the pair's attention. 'For us certain things are just absolutely spot on,' says Alison. 'Like a sugar cube. When you shoot it, it could be a monument, a sculpture, a product or a piece of food. I think what we're trying to say is, pay attention, have a good look, don't miss the small things.' Anyone interested in fashion, art or the area in between would do well to follow her advice.

 The Antoni + Alison exhibition runs from 1 February to 1 March at The Photographers' Gallery, 5 Great Newport Street, London WC2; 020 7831 1772. Admission free.

webTitle: Foreplay through the feet to a marimba beat

fields.headline: Foreplay through the feet to a marimba beat
fields.trailText: Henri Oguike Dance Company
fields.body:
Henri Oguike Dance Company

Studio Theatre, North Westminster, London W2

A huge marimba occupies the stage, its polished teeth gleaming as Pedro Carneiro prowls along it, padded sticks poised. He is percussionist and composer for Henri Oguike's Shot Flow, a new duet given its first showing on Thursday. Oguike has just returned to performing after an Achilles tendon injury: Shot Flow is a work-in-progress for himself and Alicia Herrero Simon - and Carneiro, whose slippery, sensual music comments on their relationship.

The dancers obscure and illuminate each other as they move across sources of light. Passion flares up when they come together in a bright square. She extends a hand to keep him at arm's length; he grabs her wrist, pulls her out of her ground; she grapples furiously; they embrace. The light catches her lovely Latin face, his quicksilver contours, the marimba's resonating metal. The concept is simple, the communication multi-layered. In the spartan setting of a studio theatre, Oguike's eloquent programme is a kind of miracle.

He set up his own company 18 months ago, after dancing as a founder member of the Richard Alston Dance Company. His debt to Alston is evident, but he has his own sexy fluency as a choreographer. His promise as a dance-maker has been recognised with awards (the latest from Time Out, for the most outstanding new company), though he is still making his way on a tough touring circuit. Thursday's preview of the upcoming tour might, alas, be the company's only London date. The Place's Spring Loaded festival, in which HODC was scheduled to appear, has been called off. (The re-opening of the new Place Theatre is now postponed until September, leaving pre-booked companies high and dry). The cancellation would be London's loss, for Oguike's work deserves to be seen on a spacious stage, with the musicians who will play in the larger venues, thanks to live music sponsorship from the Hattori Foundation.

It is a special pleasure, however, to catch a young company close up, still flushed with success. In the intimate Westminster Studio, the performers are so near that you intercept every glance, feel every breath. For Oguike's new ensemble piece, Melancholy Thoughts to Piazzolla's bitter-sweet tango music for violin and guitar, the six dancers had to accommodate the players as well as lines of chairs - theirs and ours. Fortunately, instead of sporting stiletto heels, the dancers' feet are bare. Theirs is a contemporary courtship, conducted in the open instead of in a smoky night club.

Encounters are charged with tension. Foreplay is through the feet, arms hanging until a hand is raised in an ambivalent gesture. It could extend an invitation to a new partner, threaten or ward off a blow. Two men circle each other, lock legs then walk away; the women's alliances between the sexes shift with the mood of the music. Their ritual is earthy and fierce, far from the languor of a salon tango. Only once, when Cathy Marston's leg flashes like a blade above her partner's head, is the action acrobatically stylised.

Oguike's ideas tumble out in a torrent, but he has learnt how to exploit stillness and silence. Above all, he enables his young dancers to be exultantly themselves. In a company favourite, Ile Aye to catchy Brazilian songs, they seduce as soloists and as a group. He's the one you want to watch, though - and cleverly, he leaves you wanting more.

 The hint dropped at the end of my piece last week about Teddy Kumakawa and the Ballet Boyz has now been confirmed. Adam Cooper, at present in Tokyo creating a work for K Ballet, is planning his own production for London in the autumn. Based on Les Liaisons Dangereuses , to commissioned music by Philip Feeney, it will have a cast of 12 ballet-trained dancers. Lez Brotherston, the stage designer, is to co-direct with Cooper, who will choreograph and star in the dance-theatre piece. Katherine Doré is producing and managing the project.

webTitle: French pop awards? Surely a contradiction

fields.headline: The Gauls can't help it
fields.standfirst: French pop awards? Surely a contradiction
fields.trailText: French pop awards? Surely a contradiction
fields.body:
Tom Jones knows what he wants. 'When I'm on stage, I don't like to be surrounded by sexy dancers. They take the attention away from me.' He is speaking at a press conference to promote the NRJ awards,the French equivalent of our Brit Awards, a celebration of Gallic and international pop.

The NRJ awards remain defiantly unfashionable. It would hardly be a surprise if Johnny Hallyday walked away with the gong for Most Improved Crooner. Domestic awards go to a succession of airbrushed acts specialising in lachrymose ballads. The recipients of the Best French Group, Les dix commandements, epitomise the type. They are a nine-strong vocal troupe with a hopelessly outdated sound and image.

In this company, Vanessa Paradis emerges as the night's unlikely token 'leftfield' act. Moby, who accepts his Best International Male award looking as if he has just popped into his local, is an anomaly. So are rappers Saian Supa Crew. They explode on to the stage to whoops from the younger members of the audience. They are the only black act to perform on the night, and despite obvious crowd support leave empty-handed.

The international awards are predictable - the Corrs, Madonna and Moby all win. Double winner Madonna fails to attend. Ditto Jennifer Lopez, who was supposed to be on the bill. Ricky Martin performs his latest single 'She Bangs' but everyone is transfixed by his clinging trousers. Anastacia wins two awards on the strength of one single, 'I'm Outta Love', and after exhausting her meagre French on the first visit to the rostrum, gives the evening's most energetic performance.

But most of the nominated international acts, including All Saints and Robbie Williams, haven't made the trip. The soon-to-split All Saints, Williams and Jones are the only Brit nominees. The Brit double act that receives the biggest cheer consists of a pop star with a moribund girl band and her husband, who has never released a record. Posh'n'Becks, dressed in black, get a rapturous reception when they appear to announce an award.

The corporate razzmatazz of the NRJ marks the start of Midem, the giant music industry convention held annually in Cannes. The event is an orgy of business opportunities and good music is often the casualty. Later on in the week, producer David Foster, the man responsible for Celine Dion and Whitney Houston's greatest hits, picked up a lifetime achievement award.

At the black-tie event, the industry's great and good lauded the man who wrote and produced 'I Will Always Love You'. I wonder if he's got Les dix commandements' phone number.

webTitle: For 10 years, City Racing was the gallery to be seen in

fields.headline: An odds-on favourite
fields.standfirst: It was small, shabby and at the wrong end of town, but for 10 years, City Racing was the gallery to be seen in
fields.trailText: It was small, shabby and at the wrong end of town, but for 10 years, City Racing was the gallery to be seen in
fields.body:
City Racing 1988-98: a Partial Account

ICA, London SW1, until 11 March

City racing was once a knackered old betting shop in south London, so close to the Oval that you could hear the crowd applaud on a warm summer day. The shop was in a row of condemned buildings, hard by a gasworks and a bleak corner pub. Even when five artists turned it into a gallery in 1988, it didn't exactly glamorise the area.

For several years, with and without funds, these artists ran intermittent shows. Then along came a Pizza Express, a video shop, even a ritzy French restaurant, by which time City Racing had disappeared. Perhaps you heard of it, perhaps you didn't, but 10-1 you never went there.

This is not intended as any kind of snub, although it's true that City Racing hardly clamoured for attention. Its shows generally ran for days, rather than weeks, and it seemed to be open only at weekends. In this respect, it was very much like all the other short-lived galleries that still come and go in south London, dragonflies to Tate Modern's rock of ages. The point about City Racing was that it showed a lot of young artists before they became famous, along with many who never would, and quite a number of their international counterparts. Moreover, it kept this up for a full 10 artist-run years.

Still, you may say, not much to brag about - the same thing was happening all over Britain. Ever since Damien Hirst curated the Freeze show, also in 1988, empty warehouses, garages, offices and tower blocks were constantly commandeered by artists, who made ever larger and emptier propositions in these concrete acres. It was very much like watching the history of the Edinburgh Fringe all over again, the race to requisition disused ice-rinks and parking-lots, to get some aura from ex-industrial locations, some charge from the context that the performance itself could hardly supply.

City Racing was too small for the big time, it couldn't manage massive installations or videos on cinema-sized screens. Part of the pleasure of City Racing 1988-98 at the ICA, a handy crib of works from a decade of shows, is that it isn't remotely spectacular. It feels quite homely, with its clutter of paintings, drawings, photos and videos on tellies. There's the old shop sign, the old arsenical green paint, the loose wires and the filthy canvases. Unless they've cleaned the place up by the time the show opens - I saw it in the earliest stages - it won't seem at all pristine and ultra-brite, not a bit like the Saatchi Gallery.

Which is where some of these artists fetched up. Sarah Lucas, who had her first solo exhibition at City Racing in 1991, is showing a couple of her customised Sunday Sport covers, which still live as violent tabloid satire. Bryan Cyril Griffiths has his Nasa-like machines, high-tech equipment made, with laborious bathos, out of Blue Peter bottle tops, glue and cardboard. Mark Hosking offers a water pump made from an exercise bike and some tubing, a piece of rudimentary agrarian equipment based, with not much sensitivity, on those UN manuals for drought-stricken countries.

There are early photographs by Gillian Wearing, one of Fiona Banner's outstandingly boring transcriptions of some scenes from Lawrence of Arabia and a video by Mark Wallinger, in which Tommy Cooper tries on a series of funny hats. The tape runs backwards, yet the audience still seems to laugh in all the right places (of course): a running gag on the good old running gags of British humour.

Wallinger recently published a fine diatribe against the 'stunt' art of the warehouse Nineties. 'In hot-wiring straight to the moneyed and influential,' he wrote, 'the need for a discerning public was successfully avoided.' He could hardly have been thinking of the old betting shop, which was scarcely anyone's route to success. Most of those long-ago shows are still in need of an audience, hence the mildly incongruous event of a museum retrospective.

You could take this show as the barometer of a decade, as the curators suggest. There are the cack-handed cartoons, the art about art, the videos that irritate the eye like grit, the arrangements of household garbage. 'You had to be there' is the subtext of far too much, not least the in-jokes about the business and the videos of private views at the gallery.

But there is more and better that you may never have seen. Ross Sinclair's black-and-white flags of the 52 states, paintings arranged like building blocks, mock the stockpiling of electoral votes by media and political machine during the American primaries. There are some elegant plywood sculptures, entirely made to be leant against, if not lounged upon, by Tim Mapstone, who quit the business to become an investment banker.

There are some great jokes - Keith Coventry's games with paintings, Matthew Collings's song lyrics, Paul Noble's pencil drawings, John Burgess's parody pub sign for an imaginary hostelry near City Racing - 'The M16 and Igloo', alternatively 'The Agent and Inuit'.

In fact, as barometers go, this one seems to be quite eccentric - unless there was more humour and less stunt than anyone noticed in the art of that decade.

webTitle: Marilyn Manson - pantomime villain

fields.headline: Look out, he's behind you...
fields.standfirst: He may be a hate figure in America, but in London's East End he seems more like a pantomime villain
fields.trailText: He may be a hate figure in America, but in London's East End he seems more like a pantomime villain
fields.body:
Marilyn Manson

London Arena, E14

To say that, visually, the controversial US superstar Marilyn Manson is a cross between Nosferatu and Gail from Coronation Street is a bit of an insult. To Nosferatu and Gail from Coronation Street. I quite like Marilyn Manson's look - I call it 'Undead Versace' - but you might have other ideas. Ideas which involve screaming, and hugging your edition of the Carpenters' Greatest Hits for comfort.

Indeed, observing Manson (Brian Warner to his mum) wading around the stage on his signature stilts, one is reminded that he is probably one of the first pop stars to endeavour to make the least of himself. On purpose, that is. He's not trying to be controversial or anything. Ugliness - his, yours, everybody's, but in particular that of the society which spawned him - just happens to be Manson's main gig.

Over here, in Britain, Manson is just that strange, trouble-making, devil-worshipping bloke from America, who admits to taking a big girly interest in tarot cards, and should stop wearing make-up and get himself a decent hair cut. He sounds sort of OK (if you like heavy metal done heavier, with a lot of scalded-cat screeching thrown in over the top), and his ideas are entertaining, albeit somewhat Yank-centric (we haven't got a gun culture, but we're happy to pretend we have if it means we can join in) and unsubtly done (not even Manson could pretend his infamous video featuring the JFK motorcade wasn't designed to gratuitously offend). However, it's not like Manson is in danger of usurping Eminem as our favourite controversial musical import.

Over in America things are very different. Manson's white-faced gruesomeness, coupled with his rebellion against religious-political conservatism and sneering contempt for mass media and gun culture, have turned him into a multi-million-selling Bad Boy Incarnate. He is the poster boy for the youthful, alienated American masses, mainly aged between 15 and 15, who really dig those pops he has at God-botherers and trigger-happy right-wingers. In short, in the US, Manson represents everything that is decadent, evil and anti-American. A drug-spiked apple pie smashing straight into Uncle Sam's beloved face.

Which is probably how it came to pass that Manson was blamed for inspiring the Columbine massacre in Colorado, where two boys killed 12 classmates and a teacher. Somebody apart from the government had to take the rap, and Judas Priest were nowhere to be found.

Here in Docklands, the crowd are a bit more mixed than you'd expect - hippie long-hairs and beer boys mingling incongruously with the scrum of painted, pouty Manson faithful, who teeter by on high heels in a stinking cloud of perfume, presumably entitled Eau de Misunderstood. That's just the boys, of course. The girls keep it toned down, wearing only 70 pairs of fishnets at once. On their arms. The chicks also seem to favour those corsets which pinch you in at the waist in so violent a manner that your buttocks become part of your breasts, and you get a nose bleed on escalators. One girl walks around in one of these contraptions, breathing like an old concertina.

Another guy is wearing his studded leather trousers so inappropriately tight that one becomes worried for his future virility. Clearly, a fan doesn't have to go moshing to sustain an injury at a Manson gig - it's enough just to turn up.

Once Manson kicks into his set, the place erupts into a state of mincing frenzy. The set is a well-paced mix of the 1996 crossover album Antichrist Superstar, the 1998 follow-up Mechanical Animals and this year's Holy Wood (In the Shadow of the Valley of Death). The songs, bellicose stews of superannuated goth, headbutt rock and wriggle-bottom metal, sound passable (if you enjoy the sensation of small planets landing on your head and exploding). Sadly, the alienated, impassioned, beautifully fashioned lyrics (a Manson strong point) cannot be heard for love or money. 'WeerrWahhWooo,' he seems to be singing to every song, except for when he's going: 'WooWahhh Werrr!'

Clearly it's going to be a long night. Manson obliges the people who think he is Satan by simulating masturbation and abusing a fan onstage - maybe it's written into his contract that he has to these days - and making rude satanic gestures that nobody who lives outside of Salem could ever understand.

Then, to my delight, he plays 'The Nobodies', his response to the Columbine tragedy. This staggering, passionate poem to America, performed acoustically as an extra track on Holy Wood, convinced me that he might just be a genius waiting for a tune. Tonight, however, Manson turns the drums up loud, launches into the song with all the subtlety of a snowplough, and it's all 'WerrWahhWoo' again. Still, at least everyone gets to feel slightly dangerous.

Which is probably the point. Watching Manson prowling around the stage like some skinny, long-lost cousin of the Tellytubbies, making a big row and attempting to incite the crowd into swearing at the Queen (ooh, careful), it all suddenly seemed very sad, overblown and infantile. And irrefutably American.

After all, Manson has two great strengths - his lyrics and his sense of theatre. Once you can't hear the former, and the latter turns into a cuddly pantomime, the very point of him seems all but lost.
