webTitle: Haydn's enigma variations

fields.headline: Haydn's enigma variations
fields.trailText: Haydn's Orfeo and Musica Secreta
fields.body:
Haydn's Orfeo Symphony Hall, Birmingham

Musica Secreta St Mary's Church, Warwick

Haydn's last opera is an enigma. No one knows why it was cancelled just before rehearsals began, or whether it was ever finished. It ends silently and shockingly on an empty stage. Orpheus, with all the skill of a Cabinet Minister, has lost Euridice a second time and is about to be torn to shreds by hysterical Bacchae.

This may have disturbed Haydn's promoters at the King's Theatre, Haymarket in 1791. Brutish endings were inimical to eighteenth-century taste, which expected happy couples to ascend on fluffy clouds of joy. Yet little wonder that Haydn, a pioneer in so many other musical forms, should want to break the rules in his operas too. He wasn't the first to end a work in chaos. London audiences had recently enthused over a particularly ferocious opera, Tarchi's Virginia, which ends abruptly mid-rape.

Today, Haydn's stage works still struggle to win support. Orfeo was only heard in its entirety when Maria Callas and Boris Christoff sang the title roles in 1950. Now the spellbinding Italian mezzo, Cecilia Bartoli, has mounted her own campaign.

In her Proms debut two years ago, she caused a storm with the work's most glittering coloratura aria, 'al tuo seno fortunato'. She is now on tour with the piece with Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music (with whom she has recorded it for Decca). The only British date was in Birmingham.

Bartoli has a rare ability to persuade audiences to share her musical curiosity. Haydn needs such advocates. Received opinion, for once not wholly inaccurate, praises glorious moments in his operatic writing, but is at a loss to find overall drama or intensity. In concert, this lack of momentum hardly matters. The score is rich with invention and written for a large orchestra (his great 'London' symphonies date from the same period). Choruses are vivid. The best music falls to the double role of Euridice/Sibyl, but isolated arias stand out, notably Orpheus's, in which a solo harp becomes his lyre.

The Royal Opera House has plans to stage the work next season. There's no reason why it should not work as well as Gluck's famously static version. It gives Bartoli, too, a chance to make her overdue debut there in music which suits her agile, pliant voice, and which she so obviously loves. When singing she grabs our attention with every vocal nuance and facial expression; when not, she listens attentively to fellow musicians as if defying us not to do the same.

A more common pose for soloists is head down in the score until it's time to sing again. The rest of the cast offered expert, if lacklustre, support. Hogwood and his players, whose sound tends towards dryness, were dextrous and clean-edged.

If Haydn's operas are little known, Cozzolani's 1650 Vespers are almost boastfully obscure. A top line up of early music singers, including Catherine King, Tessa Bonne and Deborah Roberts has formed an all-female group known as Musica Secreta. Their aim is to sing some of the unknown polyphonic works written by women courtiers, courtesans and nuns in the baroque period. Cozzolani, a Milanese noblewoman and nun, wrote numerous sacred works for double choir, or various combinations of voices, which loosely resemble the style of Monteverdi.

The initial surprise is that without men, women had to provide low notes as well as high. Female tenors are more associated today with barbershop singing than Italian convent music. The eight voices of Musica Secreta, performing in Warwick's distinguished monthly Early Music Series, produced a potent, robust sound, relishing the long, interweaving lines, the explosive outbursts of rapid counterpoint and the yearning, often chromatic and clashing harmonies. No plans exist to repeat this beguiling concert but the group's Cozzolani CD (on Linn) is due out shortly.

Trying to find any contemporary music this week was worse than seeking water in the desert. Even the monthly bulletin of events produced by SPNM (Society for the Promotion of New Music) had no oases of the new.

Things may get worse. The news that performance royalties, imposed by the Performing Rights Society, are to rise steeply will make it harder than ever for promoters to programme new works. This comes on top of the recent reduction in the Classical Music Subsidy.

Large festivals like the Proms might just manage to absorb these costs. Smaller ones, the nerve centres of new music in Britain, will be driven to the wall. The usual suspects will benefit at the expense of their younger would be successors. Reports of the demise of the classical music business tend to be wildly exaggerated. But this is not music as business. It is music itself.

webTitle: Theatre round-up

fields.headline: Suits you, madame
fields.standfirst: Peter Brook returns to London with a South African fable performed in French by a cast of unknowns - and audiences are going wild about it
fields.trailText: Peter Brook returns to London with a South African fable performed in French by a cast of unknowns - and audiences are going wild about it
fields.body:
Le Costume

Young Vic, London SE1

The Tempest

Macclesfield Leisure Centre

Entertaining Mr Sloane

Arts Theatre, London WC2

No British theatre director has so powerful an effect on audiences as Peter Brook. Before Le Costume arrived from Paris - carried to London on the wings of LIFT - all the seats had been sold. Five minutes before it began on the first night, a hush settled on the auditorium, as if a holy ritual were being prepared. At the end, people were on their feet cheering - at a cast which includes not one actor famous in this country, and at a play performed in French. It was as if a sacred act had been performed.

Reverence clouds things. Brook is Britain's most original (perhaps, therefore, expatriate) director, but Le Costume is not one of his major productions: it's a beautifully staged sliver. It compellingly projects Brook's belief in distillation, but in doing so runs the risk of patronising its characters as luminously simple folk.

Adapted from a short story by the South African writer Can Themba, it offers a cruel fable. A cuckolded husband punishes his wife by making her treat her lover's discarded suit as if it were a human being, feeding it, walking with it, abasing herself in front of it. The punishment, ruthlessly exacted, ends up by killing the wife, and leaving her husband bereft.

You could - though the drama is mercifully free of allegorical pointers - decipher in this a parable about South African revenge and forgiveness. But more urgently, the play makes you curious about stories that it skirts. The life of its author, for example: Can Themba was a gifted writer, a drunk - too busy clutching his bottle to take the ANC seriously when they tried to recruit him - and a brave apartheid critic, whose life was transformed when he submitted a short story to Drum magazine. A prolific journalist and fiction-writer, he chronicled the life of the Johannesburg township Sophiatown - the South African equivalent of Twenties Harlem. You want to hear more about this explosive raconteur, and about the indigenous music on which the narrative floats.

What you are given is a sample of Brook's theatrical techniques. The design is bare: a rug, a bed and clothes-racks which are propelled around the stage to serve as windows and wardrobes and cages. A sinuous cast of four mime, sing and dance their way through bus and shabeen. Tanya Moodie is outstanding as the wife who transforms the suit into a lover, slipping its empty arms around her. Everything is direct, stripped down, and intense.

In contrast, James Macdonald's production of The Tempest is a blizzard of wheezes. There's the plausible interpretation of Ariel as a semi-automaton, whose words, cleverly delivered by Gilz Terera with a light twang which seems made for the spirit's ding-dong rhyme, and for Orlando Gough's eerie, whale-like music. There's the wonky idea of making Prospero's island a piece of pale wood descending in billows over the stage, like a minimalist's sofa, down which characters slide into prominence.

And there's Jeremy Herbert's video, running at the back of the action. Waves slosh violently, seeming - delightfully - to cast shipwrecked noblemen up from their depths. Giant ears of corn sprout when Ceres appears. Many of these images are pleasing, but they're effects rather than ideas: they illustrate what's being said. The video film makes the human flesh in front of it look clumsy, as if cellulite were a staging-post on the way to celluloid. And when the video isn't operating, the stage looks dead. None of the acting is sufficiently forceful to overcome this.

The most original stroke is one which requires no advanced technology. The play opens to the sound of a long whoosh of air. Is this inspiration - Prospero's genius and his human breath? Or is it the sound of wind on water? The ideas are fused here - as they are in Shakespeare's play, which ends with a plea to the audience to blow away a fleet with their sighs. Never was there a play in which inner and outer climate so permeated each other.

At the Arts Theatre a play considered excitingly dark when first staged in 1964, now looks torpid. Entertaining Mr Sloane features a young murderer who lodges - quaint word - with an apparently staid middle-aged brother and sister. He goes to bed with both of them, kills their father (who's cottoned onto his murderous history), and gets off scot-free, protected by his lovers, who decide to share him.

There may once have been a thrill in the revelation that a play which seems set to expose one psychopath - Mr Sloane is gloating, gorgeous and guilt-free - eventually shows that his supposed dupes are no less dead-eyed and nonchalantly calculating. It's not a thrill that survives. Orton has helped audiences to regard gentility as code for exploitative nastiness: his revelation no longer surprises. His dialogue - a glorious mixture of the arcane and the obvious - should still carry a charge, but it doesn't do so in Terry Johnson's static production, where the grinding misogyny - female lust is treated as self-evident perversion - is dully displayed.

The only way of making the play register is to play it straight: which is to say, as both tense and hilarious. No one would think of setting a Pinter play in inverted commas - turning its design and its actors into ironic exercises. Why should they do this to Pinter's darker twin? But this is what happens here. William Dudley's design - a sitting-room starring a bright red pouffe - is knowingly, ironically blasted apart, overlooked by a frieze of leaping naked bodies and enormous gas-holders. Alison Steadman switches mechanically from prim to crude.

Hoping to join in a jolly ticket-selling clamour of repugnance, Joe Orton wrote to the Daily Telegraph under one of his pseudonyms, Edna Welthorpe (Mrs): 'I myself was nauseated by this endless parade of mental and physical perversion.' No one's going to feel queasy today.

webTitle: We're all in bed with the ad men

fields.headline: We're all in bed with the ad men
fields.standfirst: Advertising has to work harder than ever - that means appealing to our conscience as well as our libido
fields.trailText: Advertising has to work harder than ever - that means appealing to our conscience as well as our libido
fields.body:
Advertising now is among the most important media of the advanced world. One of its best theorists, the Australian Paulie Boutlis, calls it 'the very public conscience of the new society', and says that any residual guilt felt by admen and women over their profession should be cast aside, because both the creators of advertising and its audience are complicit in an 'open, diffuse and indeterminate' universe. One of its most successful practitioners, Al Young, the senior creative director at the St Luke's agency, says that advertising is 'social messages', that he and his colleagues are 'trying to give a purpose to the brands' they advertise. Both agree, however, that the prime purpose is to grab attention; it is simply that attention-grabbing techniques have changed significantly. They have done so in two particular ways: first, in enlisting pornography; second, in enlisting social conscience.

Over the past year, billboards have carried a number of campaigns showing women, naked or barely clothed, with their legs spread, apparently about to masturbate, or waiting for a man to lick them or enter them. One of the ads, for Gossard, showed a woman in hazy mid-shot, on a bed, her head flung back as if in ecstasy, with the line 'Put him on his knees'. The single entendre was that she was enjoying cunnilingus. A campaign for Versace - which appears even in magazines such as Time - shows a blonde woman in a bedroom, wearing little more than a (presumably Versace) black suspender belt and stockings - the classic outfit for soft porn. In one ad, she lies, as in post-coital sleep, next to a fully clothed man. In another, she lies on a bed, her hand poised pre-masturbatorily above her crotch, just covered by a robe.

On London buses, Folke, the clothing company, features women with their legs open, looking expectantly towards the viewer in the car behind. Anna Friel, a TV star in a low-cut gown, invites customers to 'come to bed' on a reclining seat of Virgin Atlantic's Upper Class service. A magazine ad for Total Spectrum ('creative packaging solutions') shows a large penis encased in white underpants, with the line: 'So you've got a great product'. Then everyone is happy - the uncools, who get something banned; the media people, who get far more space than they paid for; and the client, who gets the product excitingly identified with bad-girl or bad-boy-ness.

Over the past two decades, Toscani - whose father, a news photographer, took the famous shot of the murdered Mussolini and his mistress, hanging by their feet like trussed chickens - has blasted Benetton to fame.

His 'good message' shots were of young people of all colours in Benetton clothes. His 'talk about' shots included a sexy nun, a black stallion mounting a white mare, and a family wailing over an Aids victim. Boutlis writes: 'Like the tabloids or the movies, Benetton ads are sensationalism, entertainment values ironically masquerading as social conscience.'

No wonder - Benetton just sold colourful jumpers, but the 'United Colours' campaign, in Al Young's phrase, gave 'the brand a purpose'. But Toscani wanted to go further. Access to thousands of poster sites and millions of magazine and newspaper pages was, he says, a responsibility as well as a contract - a responsibility to say something. And what he wanted to say, last year, was that the death penalty in the US was wrong.

He gained access to death rows in a number of US prisons - in at least one case, according to the prison authorities, fraudulently. He shot poignant pictures of men and women about to die. The campaign, carefully prepared, went up all over the US - just at the time when Benetton's US executive vice-president, Carlo Tunioli, had signed a deal with Sears to incorporate Benetton in its superstores, giving the company a promise of 800 more outlets where previously it had fewer than 200. By the middle of last year, 400 had already been opened. Then the 'Sentenced to Death' campaign began.

In Louisville, Kentucky, Donata and Emery Nelson saw, on a billboard, a picture of the man who had abducted, sodomised, tortured and then killed their teenage son. They were furious that Toscani had turned him into a martyr.

They began a campaign, picketing Sears wherever they could get a pro-death sentence group together. Sears cancelled the Benetton contract. Toscani's reaction was 'to make me want to laugh, it's so stupid... I am proud, really proud of what I did". Benetton, however, fired Toscani; the great commercial-radical partnership was over.

But it may be more of a temporary retreat than a strategic defeat. Toscani went too far in advertising terms - the acres of publicity were outweighed by the damage he did his client in the lost deal with Sears. But he established a precedent: the overt and committed linking of advertising to social or civil libertarian causes.

The ad world, able to produce images, understand trends and catch attention, is now central to our lives, our imaginations and - its best minds now think - our consciences.

webTitle: If we really care about pop, let's assassinate Westlife

fields.headline: If we really care about pop, let's assassinate Westlife
fields.trailText: Like the Queen Mother, pop music has been obituarised almost to death over the past 10 years
fields.body:
Like the Queen Mother, pop music has been obituarised almost to death over the past 10 years. Yet the decadent old renegade keeps clinging to life. And while the list of her would-be assassins (home taping, stand-up comedy, video games, the internet, Pokémon) stretches ever on, the real culprit is silently gassing her to death at home.

Whodunit? Several overpaid record executives. The motive? Pursuit of short-term profit. And the weapon? The anaesthetic poison known as the boyband.

The recent history of pop has been one of slow defeat for artists and fans and vampiric victory for the shareholders. They're sucking the blood from the most energetic art form of the last half-century and we're standing by, watching them do it. The only remaining heirs of Presley, the Beatles and the Pistols will soon be herds of Westlife clones, and anyone with any intelligence and taste will simply stop listening. Pop won't be dead commercially, but it will be artistically lifeless.

Manufactured groups are nothing new, be it Monkees, Rollers or Spice Girls. Fakeness has its place. But today we are fed an unchanging diet of genetically modified pop groups: Backstreet Boys, Boyzone, Westlife, NSync, A1. Nobody wants these products; they have no nutritional value, no taste. Yet we all consume them because we're too lazy not to. You can't blame the groups for this - they're just following the new national curriculum. You can't blame kids either - they're not being offered any alternatives. So who is to blame? Let's name names, or rather acronyms: EMI, WEA, BMG, RCA. Type these letters into the Enigma machine and the decoded message reads: POP RIP.

The major record companies are the reason why no one over 12 can bear to listen to Radio 1 anymore. They are the reason parents fret that their kids are turning into celibate, drug-free conservatives. They are the reason why every other group you see on Top of the Pops or the National Lottery Show looks like a five-man audition for the next Blue Peter presenter: gelled, streaked hair, smiley faces, inflatable muscles, plasticine brains.

So is there any hope? Well, maybe just a little. Ronan Keating predicted last summer that the age of the boyband - in which he played a major role as singer for Boyzone and manager of Westlife - was coming to an end.

And there have been a few good omens lately. Last week, Virgin Radio - one of several 'real music' radio stations to have capitulated to boyband culture over the last two years - announced it was returning to its original remit of 'classic rock'. This does suggest the boyband market has peaked. This theory is backed up by 'disappointing' sales for the latest albums by NSync and Backstreet Boys.

Now something bold and dramatic must be done. If the Government and the ITC can intervene to demand other forms of 'quality broadcasting', they can do the same for pop. We need strictly enforced quotas: no more than 15 per cent of songs broadcast may be cover versions; no songwriter, manager or producer may have more than a 3 per cent share of daily airplay; no more than two wannabe Blue Peter presenters per band; a minimum requirement of eight GCSEs for anyone wishing to appear in public without trousers.

If this doesn't happen, I wouldn't give pop much longer than the dear old Queen Mum.

webTitle: Euan Ferguson meets Ian Craft

fields.headline: A master of life and death
fields.standfirst: 'You're choosing to give life to one person and not another, whether it's a me or a not-me that comes out. This means having to decide which one won't exist and that hurts' :  The pioneer of IVF is fierce in his belief that it's OK for a woman of 56 to be a new mum. If that means playing God, so be it
fields.trailText: 'You're choosing to give life to one person and not another, whether it's a me or a not-me that comes out. This means having to decide which one won't exist and that hurts' :  The pioneer of IVF is fierce in his belief that it's OK for a woman of 56 to be a new mum. If that means playing God, so be it.
fields.body:
The bringer of life has just, rather reluctantly, become its destroyer. The killing was difficult and took up his Friday afternoon, and on a sunny Saturday morning he was up at dawn to get fresh flowers from Covent Garden to spruce the clinic up a bit. It's a very odd feeling, listening to the chatty ease with which he can sit in his comfy jumper and discuss the massive amount of life he has given, and the masses he has taken away: it's like God smiting the world and then, having smit, deciding to cheer himself up with a new haircut.

But that is modern medicine, and he makes no apologies for it. 'The whole basis of modern medicine is indeed to interfere with nature. Yes, my job is interfering with predetermination, with Fate, but if it brings happiness then I'm really sorry but I can't see anything wrong with it.'

Dr Ian Craft, pioneer of a host of British advances in assisted conception and head of the private London Gynaecology and Fertility Centre, spent his Friday involved in 'selective reduction', reducing the number of fertilised eggs growing inside a female patient from three to two to lower the risk of complications to children and mother; effectively, he had to choose to kill off one of the blobs. 'You really don't want to be doing it, but you have to lower the risk. But that means having to decide which one won't exist, and that hurts.

'Your heart beats very fast. People think you're an automaton, but you're not. You're a person as well as a scientist, and you're choosing to give life to one person and not another; you're determining whether it's a me or a not-me that comes out, a Euan or a not-Euan.' He also hosted last week a heated press conference at which he insisted he and his colleagues were not 'clowns' for implanting eggs which will soon make Lynne Bezant Britain's oldest mother of twins at the age of 56. The story reopened a debate which has gathered force with every new assisted-conception development in the past quarter-century: when babies can be produced against the ways of nature, where do you draw the line, and should it be anyone's right to have a baby?

'It shouldn't be anyone's inviolable right,' he says, as he swallows his words - for he speaks, this fiercely friendly soul, at the frantic pace he would seem to work - 'but it should be everyone's right to try. Actually, I'm pretty sure the right to reproduce is enshrined in the American constitution.

'I don't think we as a nation fully understand the degree of depression, anxiety and alienation that childlessness brings.' Lynne Bezant, however, isn't childless; she already has a family, but this, he argues, should act in her favour. 'If an 80-year-old man fathers a baby no one questions it. But most older mothers who come here have considered it all very carefully - wills, guardianship and the rest, we always go into that. And here there are brothers and sisters, children who have children; they've given thought to who the child will have to kick a ball about with. What I find more worrying is when you get children born to older parents who didn't want them, and let them know. That's a perverse situation.'

He is a fascinating mix of cold, highly persuasive science and arch sentimentality. He is infuriated, for instance, by aspects of the current stem-cell research debate, arguing that scientists do not have the right to experiment on the 'spare' embryos which have been taken from a childless couple engaged in IVF treatment. He is deeply worried by the Bush stance on abortion and Hague's threat to copy it: 'I remember the days of back-street abortions; young girls arriving dead in casualty. Do we want to go back to that, where women are pushing knitting needles through the top of their vagina? I'm not in favour of destroying life, but I do believe in the rights of the individual, and in what is for the best.'

He worries about our prurience, and our press. 'It would be a fine idea, for instance, to have a preventative national campaign to test boys' sperm counts between 16 and 18; there's an association between cancer of the testes and low sperm counts. But for certain the right-wing would say: "How dare you ask my son to produce a semen sample by masturbating at that age"?'

More than anything he is exercised by our refusal to sanction surrogacy. He cannot understand the squeamishness, especially not if, as he suggests, a national body was set up to oversee this and regulate, at last, the provision of sperm and eggs. He is rigorous in his defence of the right to introduce three rather than two fertilised embryos if the individual situation suggests, a stance which has brought him into conflict with professional bodies.

But these are all as much scientific as moral arguments. Where, I wonder, does he stand on the wider ethics of what he is doing, on spirituality, on the giving and taking of life?

He pauses. 'My father, a man for whom I had terrific respect - probably the most honest person I've known other than my ex-wife, with whom I'm still friends - was an ardent Methodist. My brothers and I had a wonderful upbringing, and I went to Sunday school, and my parents wanted me to be a believer, but I came to the reluctant conclusion that it's beyond me. We come in alone and we go out alone.

'I see myself as a creative person, I suppose. There's no medical background in my family; I was the first, and perhaps in a way that lets me speak out, and care, in the way I do. I see my life has been about creating. My twin sister was born dead, and it could have been me. But, whatever I'm doing here, while I'm here I want to create.

'I've destroyed a lot of lives, after the Abortion Act, because I felt strongly that people had the right to make that decision. But I've spent the last 25 years creating life instead, thousands and thousands of lives. I feel much more... comfortable... since I've stopped doing terminations.'

He talks about other creations... about his love of art, opera, the poetry and music he has had commissioned. He talks of the little plot near Wells-next-the-Sea, washed with the bleak beauty of north Norfolk and the cry of Russian geese, where he plans to be buried. He talks of keeping his father's spectacles by his bed; 'the spectacles he saw his whole life out of'.

He has moved from clinician to romantic within seconds, and, in a way, it's no paradox; he seems driven by the need to make things better in a world he loves, and if he's sorted out his own morals on an empirical, scientific basis then so should you. 'Yes, I am very sentimental. And you could see a paradox, yes. But there are paradoxes everywhere; even when operating, you're inflicting injury in order to be constructive.

'But I know what you mean. Recently, strangely, I've almost wanted to write to cemetery authorities and ask which grave my sister's remains are in. Here I am, a scientist, not religious, and yet I want to put flowers on a grave I've not visited for 63 years... why? I can't explain it. It's extraordinary.'

The story reopened a debate which has gathered force with every new assisted-conception development in the past quarter-century: when babies can be produced against the ways of nature, where do you draw the line, and should it be anyone's right to have a baby? 'It shouldn't be anyone's inviolable right,' he says, as he swallows his words - for he speaks, this fiercely friendly soul, at the frantic pace he would seem to work - 'but it should be everyone's right to try. Actually, I'm pretty sure the right to reproduce is enshrined in the American constitution. 'I don't think we as a nation fully understand the degree of depression, anxiety and alienation that childlessness brings.' Lynne Bezant, however, isn't childless; she already has a family, but this, he argues, should act in her favour. 'If an 80-year-old man fathers a baby no one questions it. But most older mothers who come here have considered it all very carefully - wills, guardianship and the rest, we always go into that. And here there are brothers and sisters, children who have children; they've given thought to who the child will have to kick a ball about with. What I find more worrying is when you get children born to older parents who didn't want them, and let them know. That's a perverse situation.' He is a fascinating mix of cold, highly persuasive science and arch sentimentality. He is infuriated, for instance, by aspects of the current stem-cell research debate, arguing that scientists do not have the right to experiment on the 'spare' embryos which have been taken from a childless couple engaged in IVF treatment. He is deeply worried by the Bush stance on abortion and Hague's threat to copy it: 'I remember the days of back-street abortions; young girls arriving dead in casualty. Do we want to go back to that, where women are pushing knitting needles through the top of their vagina? I'm not in favour of destroying life, but I do believe in the rights of the individual, and in what is for the best.' He worries about our prurience, and our press. 'It would be a fine idea, for instance, to have a preventative national campaign to test boys' sperm counts between 16 and 18; there's an association between cancer of the testes and low sperm counts. But for certain the right-wing would say: "How dare you ask my son to produce a semen sample by masturbating at that age"?' More than anything he is exercised by our refusal to sanction surrogacy. He cannot understand the squeamishness, especially not if, as he suggests, a national body was set up to oversee this and regulate, at last, the provision of sperm and eggs. He is rigorous in his defence of the right to introduce three rather than two fertilised embryos if the individual situation suggests, a stance which has brought him into conflict with professional bodies. But these are all as much scientific as moral arguments. Where, I wonder, does he stand on the wider ethics of what he is doing, on spirituality, on the giving and taking of life? He pauses. 'My father, a man for whom I had terrific respect - probably the most honest person I've known other than my ex-wife, with whom I'm still friends - was an ardent Methodist. My brothers and I had a wonderful upbringing, and I went to Sunday school, and my parents wanted me to be a believer, but I came to the reluctant conclusion that it's beyond me. We come in alone and we go out alone. 'I see myself as a creative person, I suppose. There's no medical background in my family; I was the first, and perhaps in a way that lets me speak out, and care, in the way I do. I see my life has been about creating. My twin sister was born dead, and it could have been me. But, whatever I'm doing here, while I'm here I want to create. 'I've destroyed a lot of lives, after the Abortion Act, because I felt strongly that people had the right to make that decision. But I've spent the last 25 years creating life instead, thousands and thousands of lives. I feel much more... comfortable... since I've stopped doing terminations.' He talks about other creations... about his love of art, opera, the poetry and music he has had commissioned. He talks of the little plot near Wells-next-the-Sea, washed with the bleak beauty of north Norfolk and the cry of Russian geese, where he plans to be buried. He talks of keeping his father's spectacles by his bed; 'the spectacles he saw his whole life out of'. He has moved from clinician to romantic within seconds, and, in a way, it's no paradox; he seems driven by the need to make things better in a world he loves, and if he's sorted out his own morals on an empirical, scientific basis then so should you. 'Yes, I am very sentimental. And you could see a paradox, yes. But there are paradoxes everywhere; even when operating, you're inflicting injury in order to be constructive. 'But I know what you mean. Recently, strangely, I've almost wanted to write to cemetery authorities and ask which grave my sister's remains are in. Here I am, a scientist, not religious, and yet I want to put flowers on a grave I've not visited for 63 years... why? I can't explain it. It's extraordinary.'

webTitle: Email row hits Sellafield

fields.headline: Email row hits Sellafield
fields.trailText: The controversy over bosses prying on employees' private emails took a new twist last night with the disclosure that workers at the Sellafield atomic energy complex have been suspended for sending 'offensive' material.
fields.body:
The controversy over bosses prying on employees' private emails took a new twist last night with the disclosure that workers at the Sellafield atomic energy complex have been suspended for sending 'offensive' material.

The 'sexually explicit' messages were discovered by British Nuclear Fuels management last week and traced to the staff, who now face disciplinary action.

The offending emails are thought to be ones involving TV cartoon character Bart Simpson and a donkey, which resulted in the sacking of 10 insurance workers and the suspension of a further 90 at Royal Sun Alliance in Liverpool earlier this month.

Four lawyers at the City of London firm Norton Rose were suspended last month for circulating an email about oral sex. This later found its way to millions of computer screens around the world.

BNFL has suspended three of its staff and six agency and contract workers for sending and opening the messages.

However, unions claim the company has overreacted, threatening the already sour relations between managers and workers.

Sellafield has had serious morale and industrial relations problems since three workers were sacked for falsifying data about fuel rods to be shipped to Japan.

In March last year police were called in after a saboteur - believed to be a worker at the complex - damaged a robot and forced a plant treating nuclear waste to be shut down. There have been a series of other incidents involving safety at the plant which have led to disciplinary action against workers.

A source in the GMB union, which represents three of the suspended workers, confirmed the action taken against them.

'There have been serious attempts to get industrial relations back on track at Sellafield, but BNFL is threatening to undermine all progress by doing this,' the source said. 'It will seriously damage relations at the plant, which we find concerning.

'We would never condone sending offensive material or internet porn, but these are emails involving cartoon characters, and we think this does not merit suspension.'

A BNFL spokesman confirmed that the emails had been traced and the workers suspended. However, he was not prepared to discuss the contents of the message.

'I have not seen it, and I have no wish to,' he said.

However, he added: 'We categorise this as offensive material, not pornographic. It is not something you would find acceptable being pinned up on the office wall. We found it unacceptable, and so the workers have been suspended.'

The GMB said it would represent its members at any disciplinary hearing.

webTitle: Sadness and pride mark Holocaust memorial day

fields.headline: Sadness and pride mark Holocaust memorial day
fields.trailText: Gena Turgel lost eight members of her family in the Holocaust. Her 19-year-old sister, Hela, died as petrol was injected into her veins during one of Jospeh Mengele's 'medical' experiments while Miriam, another sister, was shot with her husband trying   to smuggle food into Plaszov.
fields.body:
Gena Turgel lost eight members of her family in the Holocaust. Her 19-year-old sister, Hela, died as petrol was injected into her veins during one of Jospeh Mengele's 'medical' experiments while Miriam, another sister, was shot with her husband trying to smuggle food into Plaszov.

Janek, one of her three brothers, disappeared trying to escape through the sewers of the Krakow ghetto, and Hermann, her eldest brother, his wife and their three children were shot in their home early in the occupation. Lola, their youngest child, was just nine months old.

Turgel herself was 21 when the British liberated the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp at 3pm on 15 April 1945. She fled to England to escape the memories. 'But I could not forget,' she said, describing those in the camp who had been slowly driven mad with grief and fear, murdered on the whim of Nazi commanders or forced to load their screaming children into open trucks, never to see them again.

Britain yesterday held its first Holocaust Memorial Day to remember the victims of the Holocaust and persecuted minorities everywhere.

Tugel, a 78-year-old author and campaigner, spent the day rushing from school to community hall, from television studio to radio station, dismissing the criticisms that have dogged the event and reiterating how important such a day was.

'I speak to Jewish children and teenagers every day who haven't got the faintest idea what really happened during the Holocaust,' she said. 'Their ignorance has ceased to shock me. I've simply accepted that given half the chance, people will ignore what happened, fail to ask or forget to remember. But we must never forget that these were real people with real aspirations, just like you and me, who can now only scream in silence.'

In London, Prince Charles stood alongside Prime Minister Tony Blair in the Palace of Westminster to listen to speeches from celebrities including Bob Geldof, Ian McKellen and Anthony Sher.

Later, the Prime Minister told the Holocaust memorial service at Westminster Central Hall that survivors had come to Britain to rebuild their lives. 'Their memories have become part of our memories, our history. Each step humanity takes is the product of a struggle between good and evil. We know both exist in our nature. The Holocaust was the greatest act of collective evil the world has ever known. The appalling reality of the Holocaust caused a profound crisis in human civilisation.'

Lord Janner, chairman of the Holocaust Educational Trust, which has played a key role in organising the event, said: 'It's a fantastic achievement for the country and a day when we're reminded of what happened in the past and what could still happen in the present and future.'

Janner denied that by focusing on the Jewish Holocaust, victims of other genocides were being sidelined.

webTitle: Sixties hero revealed as kindergarten sex author

fields.headline: Sixties hero revealed as kindergarten sex author
fields.standfirst: Leading Green MEP insists erotic descriptions in magazine were pure fantasy, reports  Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Leading Green MEP insists erotic descriptions in magazine were pure fantasy, reports  Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
A respected Green MEP and leading figure of the Sixties protest movement has admitted to The Observer that he wrote an article claiming he had sexual contact with very young children.

Daniel Cohn-Bendit, MEP for the French Greens, wrote about how flirtatious encounters in the early Seventies with children in his care as young as five had taken on 'erotic characteristics' and soon developed into more intimate contact from which he did not walk away.

When confronted last week with the article, which appeared in the August 1976 edition of the racy, now defunct cultural-political magazine das da, Cohn-Bendit said what he had written was 'unacceptable and unbearable'. He claimed his descriptions of sexual activity with the children were based on fantasy. No disclaimer to this effect appears in the article.

The article was a spin-off from a best-selling book, The Big Madness, that Cohn-Bendit wrote in 1975 about child education. The book drew on his two-year experience working in a Frankfurt kindergarten with children aged from two to five. In the article, he wrote: 'My constant flirt with all the children soon took on erotic characteristics. I could really feel how from the age of five the small girls had already learnt to make passes at me. It's hardly believable. Most of the time I was fairly defenceless.'

Later he added: 'It has happened to me several times that a few children opened the flies of my trousers and started to stroke me. I reacted differently each time according to the circumstances, but their desire confronted me with problems. I asked them: "Why don't you play with each other, why have you chosen me and not other children?" But when they insisted on it, I then stroked them. For that reason I was accused of perverted behaviour.'

Speaking by phone from his Frankfurt home, where he lives with his wife and daughter, Cohn-Bendit said on Friday that the damning paragraphs had been written as 'verbal provocation'. 'It was meant to illustrate the difficulty of the educator in bringing up children: how does one accept that children have a sexuality, and also to recognise the resistance against which educators have to work. It was written in an autobiographical way and wasn't scientific - it was a literary exaggeration.'

But he added: 'I admit that what I wrote is unacceptable nowadays. When I look at those sentences today, I say to myself, "Hey Danni, that's impossible!" It's quite legitimate that personalities should be forced to confront their pasts.'

The revelations are expected to cause a storm in the European Parliament, where Cohn-Bendit led the French Greens to their best showing in June 1999. Now regarded as a passionate Europhile, and viewed by some as the pan-European politician, Cohn-Bendit, 55, first came to prominence when as a flaming red-haired student he led the May 1968 demonstrations in Paris, earning the nickname 'Danni the Red'.

When he was expelled from France as a result he joined the pacifist German Green movement, entering mainstream politics in 1971 as Frankfurt's deputy mayor. He shared a flat in Frankfurt with Germany's current Foreign Minister, Joschka Fischer, still a close friend who himself has been embroiled in recent controversy after revelations about his militant past came to light following publication of photographs showing him beating up a policeman.

Speaking two weeks ago at the murder trial of a former protester friend, where he was a character witness, Fischer said Cohn-Bendit had kept him on the straight and narrow. 'I'm not sure how the young Joschka Fischer would have developed if it hadn't been for Danni Cohn-Bendit,' he told the court.

In Frankfurt Cohn-Bendit became involved in debates about child education, and the kinderladen or child shop - an anti-authoritarian kindergarten born out of the protest movement and financed and run by its members.

In 1972 Cohn-Bendit, who was born in the south of France and has dual French-German nationality, applied for a position as carer at Frankfurt University's kinderladen, motivated, he wrote in das da, by a strong conviction that 'the needs of the children of the left-wing radicals were always neglected'. He describes his two years working there as a 'fantastic experience'.

But after starting the job 'full of energy' he met his first feelings of ambiguity about the role. 'I realised I had the need to be accepted by them at all costs. I wanted the children to like me and I did everything to make sure they became dependent on me.'

He told The Observer that the aim of the kinderladen was to allow the children to be themselves. 'Our idea was to let them realise their personalities through expression of their needs. Paedophilia was not what got me going.'

But Cohn-Bendit's former stance on the kinderladen movement opens up many unanswered questions about the social and sexual mores of the post-war generation. 'This was a time of very far-reaching educational experimentation,' said Gerd Koenen, a former Seventies revolutionary and author of a book about the period, The Red Decade, which is due out in the spring.

The movement's two main aims were to solve the fixation of children towards their parents and the establishment of a children's solidarity 'battle group' to fight imperialism. 'It was normal to find Mao pictures hung on the walls of the kinderladen,' says Koenen. 'The children were taken out on to the streets to demonstrate, and in the more radical kinderladen sexual games became part of their play.

The protest movement was largely motivated by a desire to break free from the 'contaminated' post-war generation when many Nazis - the parents of the protesters - had remained unpunished. 'They were attempting to make a total break with their parents,' says Koenen. 'But in turn many subconsciously also made the break with their own children.'

The urban guerrilla RAF group, which stemmed from the Baader-Meinhof gang, were strong supporters of the kinderladen but took its theories to extremes. Many believed it was necessary to give up their children when they went underground.

'They saw it as part of the higher purpose of their terrorist activities,' says Koenen. 'They could then say "I'm autonomous, my children are autonomous, we're all stronger because of the separation." In a certain way the children were human guinea-pigs in this social experiment, and today there's a generation of children who suffered from being abandoned and unprotected.'

In 1968 Andreas Baader left his baby daughter in Berlin, and his lover and fellow RAF terrorist Gudrun Ensslin gave up her son Felix to foster parents. The most dramatic of them all was Ulrike Meinhof, who first sent her twin daughters Bettina and Regine to an orphans terrorist training camp in Palestine, and in 1976 committed suicide in prison. Baader and Ensslin committed suicide in prison a year later.

Cohn-Bendit, who was not linked to the RAF, said the damning paragraphs he wrote were bound to be misunderstood if they were taken out of context. 'The desire for change then was so great that sometimes the resulting changes were far too radical and sometimes contradicted themselves when anti-authoritarianism was enforced in some kinderladen.'

He says he maintains contact with some of the children who were in his care in Frankfurt. 'They say the experience was very positive for them. They are independent and confident people who have done well - one is a film producer, the other is a well known musician.'

webTitle: Rugby was his first love

fields.headline: Rugby was his first love
fields.trailText: Keeper Fabien Barthez honed his skills while handling the oval ball in his youth.
fields.body:
No one quite remembers when Fabien Barthez broke with family tradition in his home village of La Roque d'Olmes at the foot of the Pyrenees and started playing with a round ball.

But what they do know is that Barthez, at eight, was a registered rugby player on 4 May, 1979, the date of his first licence. And that, in the months ahead, he had to go a few miles up the road to nearby Lavelanet to find a football club. There simply wasn't one where he lived.

For the roots of Barthez are set deep in the French heartland of rugby where grandad Vincent was a well-known fly-half, and father Alain a top-class full-back who played for his country.

The No 16 jersey Barthez wore to win the World Cup for France now lies in the coffin of the rugby-playing grandfather he adored. It is a moving and eloquent testimony to the family tradition that seemed to earmark Manchester United star Barthez for the game with no place for a goalkeeper.

According to folks in La Roque d'Olmes, Barthez had just as much potential to contest the Six Nations tournament that opens this week as the closing stages of the Champions League. Felix Picon, who oversees the local club's rugby school, said : 'I saw Fabien playing for us from the ages of eight to 13. He was a lively boy who was quick, skilful and extremely brave.

'I am quite sure that, with his background, he would have gone all the way if he had stuck with rugby because he had all the gifts. He would have developed into a top-class fly-half.'

Though Barthez chose to abandon the first organised sport he ever played in favour of football, the family inheritance has not gone to waste.

Even Pierre Berbizier, the former France player and coach, says : 'Fabien's made from other stuff than the classic footballer. He has everything that goes to make a rugby man, the mind, the essential touch of madness - afraid of nothing, ready at all times to throw himself into the fires.'

United fans have noted that Barthez, a Footballer of the Year candidate in his first Premiership season, is a compelling mix of courage and audacity. Eric Bauzou, a hospital administrator who played rugby with Barthez as a kid, said: 'When I see Fabien playing for United, he is just as fearless as he was when tackling lads twice his size.Yes, he would have been a famous rugby star if he'd wanted. We played on the grounds of all the big clubs. He'd certainly have been picked up.'

Joel Bats, a 50-cap France goalkeeper, and Philippe Bergeroo, their World Cup goalkeeping coach, both believe rugby helped make Barthez the player he is. Bats said: 'Fabien has such dexterity in his hands and I think it is almost inborn. It comes from having to handle the oval ball, which is more difficult to gather than a round one. He is self-taught.'

And Bergeroo, recently sacked as Paris St Germain's coach, explained: 'I've never seen a keeper with such co-ordination. In Fabien's native department of Ariège, kids play football, rugby, pelota, basketball and handball. He has learned hugely from other disciplines.

'You can see that in the way he acts on visual information. His sense of anticipation is extremely developed. And there are many of the biggest rugby clubs in the country who would love to have that left foot of his.'
fields.bodyText: No one quite remembers when Fabien Barthez broke with family tradition in his home village of La Roque d'Olmes at the foot of the Pyrenees and started playing with a round ball. But what they do know is that Barthez, at eight, was a registered rugby player on 4 May, 1979, the date of his first licence. And that, in the months ahead, he had to go a few miles up the road to nearby Lavelanet to find a football club. There simply wasn't one where he lived. For the roots of Barthez are set deep in the French heartland of rugby where grandad Vincent was a well-known fly-half, and father Alain a top-class full-back who played for his country. The No 16 jersey Barthez wore to win the World Cup for France now lies in the coffin of the rugby-playing grandfather he adored. It is a moving and eloquent testimony to the family tradition that seemed to earmark Manchester United star Barthez for the game with no place for a goalkeeper. According to folks in La Roque d'Olmes, Barthez had just as much potential to contest the Six Nations tournament that opens this week as the closing stages of the Champions League. Felix Picon, who oversees the local club's rugby school, said : 'I saw Fabien playing for us from the ages of eight to 13. He was a lively boy who was quick, skilful and extremely brave. webTitle: Arsenal boss? I could be

fields.headline: Arsenal boss? I could be
fields.standfirst: A week after quitting England, Tony Adams talks about managing his club - and even his country - one day. But first he wants to fire up 'under-achieving' Gunners
fields.trailText: Tony Adams on managing his club and country. But first he wants to fire up 'under-achieving' Gunners.
fields.body:
It looked like a sudden announcement last weekend that you were retiring from international football. When did you reach the decision?

Like most decisions in my life, I try not to make them impulsively. I do sit with them for a great deal of time. I suppose I first thought about it after France 98 and since then I've taken it like I take my life, one day or one game at a time. If I felt I could do it, I went and played to the best of my ability, proud to play for my country, and every time I enjoyed it. I was 31 at France 98 and at the time I had played 550 games. Now I'm coming up to 640 games so the thought has been there for a while. It felt like the time was right.

Can you confirm the reasons why you are retiring?

I love playing for my country but when I come back injured, it's not very fair on Arsenal. They pay my wages, I've made a commitment to them with a new contract and I don't feel I am giving them what they are paying for. My father always said 'a fair day's pay for a fair day's work' and that's always stuck with me. But at no stage did Arsène Wenger or the club put any pressure on me. I've only played 16 club games this year out of 33. Last year it was 33 in the season, before that 40 so there's been a degeneration. After the France game in September, I was out for three weeks. Now I don't think that's very fair on Arsenal.

Some people will say you jumped before you were pushed.

(Adams laughs). I could maybe say something flippant like I don't care what people say, but I do. It hurts. But jump before I was pushed? Who knows what Sven-Göran Eriksson will go for? I would love to have given him a 24-year-old Tony Adams but it's not possible. If he didn't select me, that's fine as well. But other people's decisions are out of my control.

And it is said that you quit because you knew David Beckham would be captain.

Captaincy is a complete honour and I thought I did really well as captain. But I also played under David Platt and Alan Shearer, when I thought I should have been captain - but that's cool, that's the manager's decision. I tried to get on with my job to the best of my ability. I don't know who Mr Eriksson is going to make captain, it was just an honour being talked about for it. I was out of the England squad for three years, never mind being captain.

Does having a foreign coach for the first time have any bearing on your decision?

None. I play for a French manager now. Mr Eriksson might be the best manager in the world. I'm an Englishman and I want a successful England team. And I'm going to be a fan. I'll probably travel to watch games and cheer the country on. I'd like to go to a World Cup or European Championship as a spectator. That would be lovely.

What have been the highlights of your England career?

The major competitions, a World Cup and two European Championships, particularly '96 when we were fairly successful and enormously unlucky. Just a penalty away from going on to win that, but that was the way it was meant to be. The first cap was special, against Spain in Madrid, alongside Terry Butcher, Kenny Sansom and Viv Anderson, with Gary Lineker scoring four at the other end. It was a fantastic stadium and I was playing with and against people at the top of their trade. Then I brought the shirt home for my mother and father and we had a party.

There have been loads of special memories, including recently playing the World and European champions in Paris and drawing 1-1, and leading out my country in what will now be my last international, against Germany at Wembley. And I thought I played pretty well that day.

What do you consider your best performance?

Against the Germans in the '96 semi-final. I was really in the zone around that time, in jazz terms really swinging. Terry Venables asked me to play a very demanding role. I was marking Andy Möller, as well as being a sweeper and moving into midfield at times. I had to be at my peak to fulfil what he wanted. And I felt I got it all together.

What were the low points?

I had a tough time at Euro 2000 with injury. It was frustrating because if we had got through I was ready to play against Italy in the quarter-finals. Being powerless was hard to take. Then there was Euro 88. But they were all learning curves. I grew enormously from them, though they were painful at the time. I wouldn't swap any bad game for a good one. It was all part of the process, how you deal with things, and they were instrumental in my career. I saw David Beckham coming back from France 98 and winning the treble. It can work like that if you learn from adversity. After Euro 88 I came back and won the title with Arsenal in '89.

This new contract takes you to the summer of 2002. Do you think then you will retire from club football?

I think so, although ending my international career may open things up. I may find that with the amount of time I have to recover I'll be able to go on for longer.

And what do you think you can achieve with Arsenal over the next 18 months?

It's one of the best squads I have ever played in but at the moment it is under-achieving and it will be a challenge to get the full potential out of it. I don't want to be in my armchair when I finish, or going on TV, saying, 'Look at the state of Arsenal'. I want to walk away with dignity and give them some continuity. I'd like to win more things - I haven't given up on that. I don't see myself fading out, I've never been a fading-out kind of guy. There are people at the club who can take it forward.

Like Patrick Vieira, whom you are grooming to be captain?

He's a different guy, a different personality. But I feel he has the capacity to lead by the power of example. He has a wonderful desire and will to win that you need and that other men look up to. A man who has had a lot of success but is hungry for more. And he is learning from his mistakes. I always had the big picture of the team. I had that gift. Patrick hasn't got it, though he has other things I haven't got and he can learn. I think he just needs a little more player-management skills, needs to be a bit more observant about what makes people tick. That will come with experience through verbalising. But he needs to verbalise with his own team, not the other team.

Why do you think Arsenal are under-achieving?

There's been a change of personnel and it's taking time for some players to get settled in this country. It's an issue, but one we can address. I think we're turning a corner. We're getting the desire back, then the confidence comes.

Training has been encouraging and people have got the bit between their teeth. Last Monday, we played basketball and there was an edge to it, a desire to win. On Tuesday, Patrick and I played two v two with Robert Pires and Sylvain Wiltord and I won again. You learn from exercises like that that you can't let your mate down. That if you don't put in the effort, you get shown up. You have to carry that on to the pitch on a Saturday. That desire goes hand in hand with talent, and with the talent we have will bring success again.

Are you banging heads together again?

That's happened and will continue, because I've been able to get into training and get out on the pitch. You can't do it from a medical room. You have to be out there with them. That's another reason why I wanted to finish the international career.

What will you do when you retire next year?

First, spend some time with my family. I discussed my international retirement with my children, Oliver, Amber and Clare and they were in favour of seeing their dad more, having him pick them up from school - except perhaps Clare, who is 16! I want to take them skiing. Have a Christmas away, spend a Christmas night with them instead of rushing off to a game. Kids grow up and leave so quickly. I just want to be part of their lives. Then some sun on the bones in January. I'll need a rest when I'm finished, time to think.

Will you go into coaching or management?

I do feel that knowledge is to be passed on and not owned. And I feel I have a lot to offer, though I don't know at what level or capacity. I haven't had time to do my coaching badge yet but they are fast-tracking players and if I find the time I will do it. I've got to balance that with kids, walking the dogs, learning the piano and my French. I don't think I'm not going to be busy. I can't see myself putting my feet up for too long. I get a bit bored if I'm not active. I will think about management at some stage.

How about managing Arsenal one day? Could you do it?

(Long pause) The idea appeals to me and I'm not going to rule that out. But it's easy to say I could do it. I had to learn to be a professional footballer. I served an apprenticeship. There were a lot of mistakes to be made, there was a lot to learn. I'm not going to be egotistical and say I could jump into the Arsenal job. Maybe I need to learn, to get my coaching badge, to have a look around at a few clubs, to manage a small club. A lot goes into it. But yes, I could do it!

What about England?

A lot of things go into the England job. If I felt there was a need for me to educate the media and get into the politics of football, then I would get involved. The problem in this country is a culture of denial and sometimes the reality of things is different from what is reported. Some people in the media should think about retiring themselves. They're still writing the same stuff as years ago and I think the public deserve better. If I could influence the media, the structure and politics of the industry, then you never know, I don't rule it out, either.

Would it worry you that you might go from hero to villain?

A villain in some people's eyes. But as long as I stay true to myself, I'm never going to be a villain. I'm the one I have to live with. It's funny. Since I stopped drinking and have been in therapy, I think people's perception of me has been pretty much spot-on. The feedback is very positive. That's not to say I do it to please them. I do it because it is right for me. I care about the society I live and work in. I care about my children. I try to do my bit. To keep my side of the street clean.

And how is the addiction treatment centre you are planning coming along?

It's called the Sporting Chance Clinic and it's a non-profit-making charity. I may have found a property for a 16-bed facility, so we are getting there. I have people with vast experience working on it at the moment, people who get results. I am not going to put my name to something I don't believe works. It will open when it's right, maybe in June. Before then, possibly from April, I hope to have counselling available to any sportsmen and women who have the courage to seek help, from football or any other sport. The aim is to give a chance to sporting people, retired or active, to get the best available therapy. I think back to that time when for me there seemed nowhere to go. In this country there is still a lot of shame about the illness, people think you are weak-willed. But I know it took enormous courage for me to accept my alcoholism.

Ian Ridley was the co-writer of Tony Adams' autobiography 'Addicted'.

webTitle: Tony is being selfish - and quite right too

fields.headline: Tony is being selfish - and quite right too
fields.standfirst: Gordon Strachan  recalls when he was in a similar position to the Arsenal captain
fields.trailText: I remember when I felt the strain like Tony Adams.
fields.body:
Tony Adams's decision to bring down the curtain on his international career, at 34, is going to be of tremendous benefit to Arsenal. I would not go as far as to say that it will bring Arsenal the Championship again. But, in view of his tremendous influence on their team, and the ways in which his departure from the England scene are likely to galvanise him, there can be no doubt that it will help.

Not everybody feels he has made the right decision. One who has been critical of it is Jack Charlton. In a newspaper article last week, he was quoted as saying that England still needed what Adams had to offer - they probably needed him as much as ever - and that he was being selfish.

Charlton was right on both counts - but, as far as the latter point is concerned, I personally do not see how anyone can reasonably quibble with it. There are situations in which players have to be selfish to be able to keep giving their best. When it comes to players at the top of the ladder - the players who carry the greatest expectations and play the highest number of matches - there comes a point in their careers when something has to give. They have to listen to what their minds and their bodies are telling them, and give themselves more time to rest and relax.

In prioritising their commitments, it is only right that as their clubs pay their wages, it is their clubs who must be put first.

The strain international football imposes on men like Adams has become increasingly pronounced. Quite apart from the fact that you tends to experience more injury problems as you get older, especially with regards to the time they take to heal, other factors that can become increasingly difficult to handle include your responsibilities towards the squad both on and off the field and, as their spokesman, the media demands for interviews.

Most players derive enormous personal satisfaction in representing their countries. I certainly did, and never more than when Andy Roxburgh recalled me to the Scotland team in 1991, and I made seven more appearances to bring my total of caps to 50. But I have to admit that, by my last appearance against Finland in March 1992, when I was 35 and my club Leeds were striving for the Championship, I was beginning to feel the strain.

What particularly got to me was the amount of time I spent travelling and staying in hotels. When on Scotland duty, it had got to the stage where my first thought on waking up at our hotel was: 'Where am I?' Deep down, I knew that if I did not ease up on my commitments, then both the teams I played for would suffer.

Significantly, my departure from the international scene was followed the next season by Leeds performances that earned me the club's Player of the Year award.

It was the same with Gary McAllister, when he was at Coventry and decided to quit playing for Scotland after leading them in Euro 96. Indeed, if any player illustrates the wisdom of Adams's decision it is Gary, who of course took on such a vibrant new lease of life after the end of his Scotland career that he was signed by Liverpool.

As I said, the loss of Adams to England is very much Arsenal's gain. I think they would have been closer to Manchester United in the Championship race but for the number of matches he has missed through injury. I know that statistics can be used to support all manner of arguments, but it interesting to note that only one of Arsenal's five league defeats has come when he has been in the side.

It was perhaps inevitable that Arsenal would have problems this season, as a result of the break-up of the back four and Emmanuel Petit's departure to Barcelona. His central midfield partnership with Patrick Vieira was the only one in the Premiership that could match United's power in that area.

Of the teams who have not lived up to expectations in the title race, the side whose results have been particularly surprising to me are Chelsea. I thought they would be United's strongest challengers, if only because of the signing of striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. In terms of all-round ability, he is as impressive as anyone I have seen in recent seasons.

Chelsea may have failed but the gap between United and the rest can be closed, as Arsenal could underline now that they have Tony Adams all to themselves.

Indeed, if any player illustrates the wisdom of Adams's decision it is Gary, who of course took on such a vibrant new lease of life after the end of his Scotland career that he was signed by Liverpool. As I said, the loss of Adams to England is very much Arsenal's gain. I think they would have been closer to Manchester United in the Championship race but for the number of matches he has missed through injury. I know that statistics can be used to support all manner of arguments, but it interesting to note that only one of Arsenal's five league defeats has come when he has been in the side. It was perhaps inevitable that Arsenal would have problems this season, as a result of the break-up of the back four and Emmanuel Petit's departure to Barcelona. His central midfield partnership with Patrick Vieira was the only one in the Premiership that could match United's power in that area. Of the teams who have not lived up to expectations in the title race, the side whose results have been particularly surprising to me are Chelsea. I thought they would be United's strongest challengers, if only because of the signing of striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. In terms of all-round ability, he is as impressive as anyone I have seen in recent seasons. Chelsea may have failed but the gap between United and the rest can be closed, as Arsenal could underline now that they have Tony Adams all to themselves.

webTitle: Apologetic Kanouté happy to be the Main Man

fields.headline: Apologetic Kanouté happy to be the Main Man
fields.standfirst: Amy Lawrence on a contrite Cup star heading north
fields.trailText: France's new generation: Henry, Trezeguet, Anelka - and now Fréddié Kanouté.
fields.body:
An hour spent loitering in the corridor of West Ham's training ground, watching playing staff of all ages wander through from canteen to showers, from pitches to sauna, the air of friendliness is quite striking. Even journalists are made welcome. Avoiding eye contact with the hacks is a rule of thumb at most Premiership clubs, but not at West Ham, where most offer a greeting and a smile as they pass. 'Who are you here to see?' asked one.

Fréddié Kanouté. 'Ah, the main man.'

The main man? That is an accolade and a half at a club where Paolo Di Canio makes waves virtually on a daily basis.

Kanouté's star is rising fast. Given Di Canio's temperamental outbursts and propensity for catching colds during the winter, the pressure on the French striker to continue his ascent is intensifying. But, as his club prepares to take on Manchester United at Old Trafford in the fourth round of the FA Cup, it doesn't worry him in the slightest: 'I don't know exactly what Paolo's problem is but I do know that now they are expecting more from me, and for me to score the goals.' He has reacted impressively to the challenge.

Despite Kanouté having to issue an apology last week to both West Ham fans and people in the north of England, an area he reportedly described as being, 'cold and wet with small houses', after stories circulated about him wanting to leave for a bigger club, Harry Redknapp is delighted with him.'I think he enjoys the responsibility of playing on his own up front. We played him on his own at Leeds and Southampton and he was absolutely fantastic. Fréddié plays with anybody. He's a bit special, he's strong, he'll run with the ball, he's turning in great performances.'

Having impressed during his loan spell at the tail end of last season, the rangy, 23-year-old Kanouté has developed this season into one of the Premiership's most difficult strikers to defend against. He is blessed with the qualities the French hone so well in their young attackers, a point not lost on his team-mate and compatriot Marc Keller: 'I would say Fréddié is like Thierry Henry, David Trezeguet and Nicolas Anelka. The new generation in France is all about big players with good technique - he is strong, fast, very good at running one against one and has a lot of tricks.'

But mentioning him in the same breath as Anelka could cause alarm. It is as well then, that Keller adds: 'I also think his mentality is OK, which is important. He has his head on his shoulders. I don't think he will become crazy with money or popularity.'

International recognition is the fundamental difference between Kanouté, who has a handful of under-21 caps, and the other three, who have won World Cups and European Championships. He aims to put that right, and in joining West Ham he believes he has taken a crucial step. For the first time in his career he is playing regular football. He feels liberated.

A product of the Olympic Lyonnais academy, his progression had been stunted by an unlucky run of injuries, the club's unwillingness to blood youngsters at the expense of more experienced players, and the fact that Lyon - as a city and a club - is not the most liberal minded place in France. 'A few years ago it was more difficult for black people and Arab people,' he acknowledges. Kanouté is the son of a French mother and a Malian father, and a converted Muslim. He smiles as he says he doesn't exactly look like 'an authentic French Frenchman'.

Redknapp feels lucky to have him, particularly as a clever stroke of wheeler-dealing secured his services in the summer for only £3.5million. West Ham could have made a killing recently as a couple of clubs came sniffing with bids of £8m - hence the transfer rumours. But so highly do they value him they instantly offered Kanouté improved terms and tied him to the club until 2005.

His productive form has been central to West Ham's steady rise up the Premiership after a dismal start. 'We are aiming for the top five and Europe,' says Kanouté. 'It's going to be very tough but it's possible. I enjoy it much more now I have found my rhythm. I enjoy the spectacular game here.'

Keller reckons Kanouté's upsurge, being monitored back home, will eventually propel him into the international frame: 'When you play abroad and play well you become very popular in France because we speak more about the players who are succeeding abroad. In terms of quality he has a big chance to play for the national team - but in Henry, Trezeguet, Anelka and Wiltord we have a lot of young and very skilled players.'

'I'd like to play in the French team but my aim when I came to England was to succeed this season,' he says. 'I do think about the French team but I don't worry about it. I think everything comes at the right moment.'

Another Frenchman, Fabien Barthez, will be barring his path at Old Trafford today. If Kanouté can enhance his finishing skills, the area Redknapp encourages him to work on, perhaps he really could turn into the main man.
