webTitle: Do people who keep diaries secretly hope someone will read them?

fields.headline: It was the best of times...
fields.standfirst: If we really wanted to keep our thoughts private, we wouldn't write anything down. So do people who keep diaries secretly hope someone will read them?
fields.trailText: If we really wanted to keep our thoughts private, we wouldn't write anything down. So do people who keep diaries secretly hope someone will read them?
fields.body:
When I was 13, I won a five-year diary in a Puffin Club competition. I could not have been happier. It had a scarlet and green psychedelic cover and a little lock with a gold key. And on its cover were the words: 'My Secret Life'. I did not have a secret life but it was wonderful to suppose that somehow, through keeping the diary, I would acquire one. For five years, I kept it, never missing a day. There was about an inch of paper available for each entry so it did not take much effort to be faithful to it. I still have it, never look at it and blame it for a habit that I have not been able to break.

It is now 28 January and there will be some who will already have let their resolution to keep a diary lapse into unfilled white pages.

'How many years have I made it to 28 Jan?' Marcia Foreman asks herself. Each year, she starts a diary but has 'usually abandoned it by 12 Jan'. Why? 'I want my diary to be a ruthless record. I resolve not to lie to the diary or to anyone else. But I am disgusted by my own inability to stick to this.' She adds: 'Either nothing happened and I don't know how to elaborate, or too much happened and I don't know what to make of it so can't write.' She suggests that diary keeping is defined by 'shame'. In a recent interview, Joely Richardson also seemed to imply that diary writing was a sign of trouble. Now that her life has picked up (new love with Jamie Theakston), her journal has been put aside.

I keep my diaries on a high shelf. I have only to eye their covers to feel nervous distaste. Re-reading diaries is a melancholy experience: happier times diminish the present; there is no joy in remembered unhappiness. So why keep a diary at all?

Adam Phillips, psychotherapist and writer, suggests that a diary is a way of being a witness to one's own life, something that is harder than you might suppose. It is a way of 'trying to see what you are doing, to hear what you are saying'. A diary makes links. He suggests: 'One's first diarist is one's mother who links facts for one, holds the pieces together.'

Phillips has never kept a diary. He is afraid he might 'submit' to it. What does he mean? He does not want to 'rid' himself of time. A diary makes experience 'historical'. He concedes that a diary may be therapeutic. He sees it as 'the conversation you fear with some one else, the one in which you couldn't hold your own'.

Rebecca Dix, an intermittent diarist agrees: 'It is like the Greek legend about the king who whispered his secrets to the grass. In a diary, you can alleviate a pressure to say the unsayable. It may be something you haven't even said to yourself, revealed through writing.'

All Dix's diaries are ragged notebooks, she says. She is resistant to pretty, 'flowery' diaries, finding there is a 'weird constraint' about them. Like Katherine Mansfield, she sees her diary, at its best, as an intimate, a 'dear companion'.

Jonathan Coe has found something unusual to do with the diary he kept between 1978-9. He has used it as source material for a novel about his schooldays The Rotters' Club (published by Viking in March). At first, he was squeamishly reluctant to re-encounter his 16-year-old self. But he took his diary away to a cottage by the sea - he planned to write there for a week - and was surprised by what he found. For a start, he discovered he had addressed himself to an audience in his diary.

'I'd do suspense things, like describing a nasty thing that happened in the classroom and then saying, "I bet you are all wondering how wondering how that turned out."' He expressed emotions in a 'comic, truncated, rather male way.'

One moment, he would miserably confess to a crush on a girl but would, in the next sentence, record a 'great episode of New Avengers on TV'. Coe was 'embarrassed and impressed' by his adolescent old voice and its 'magisterial eighteenth-century prose' (he was studying Henry Fielding for A-level). The comedy of his diary was in the 'incongruity of the elevated style and the crashing monotony of what I was recording'. It had a 'weird, unearned assurance'.

In this incontinently confessional age, is there still a place for the unpublished diary? On the internet there is a site for diarists, www.diarist.net/registry, where it is possible to write and read indiscriminately. It is visited by thousands of curious people. It is a peculiar admission that what diarists long for is an audience other than themselves.

Who are diaries for? Diary writing often seems airless, it lacks the oxygen of an audience. It can seem solipsistic, bordering on demented - writing to yourself. Jonathan Hall sees his diary as a letter to himself. He only looks at his old diaries when his life changes in 'a frightening or significant way'- as if to find out who he is. He sometimes imagines that, at the end of his life, he may look at his diaries again but admits they may be waiting for a rainy day that never comes. Some people self-consciously keep diaries which they hope will be discovered as literary gems by their grandchildren. Jonathan Hall has no time for such people: 'Keeping a diary should not be a form of vanity publishing.'

A diary is often a way of trying to cheat mortality: self-memorialising, a garrulous epitaph. Rebecca Dix believes: 'It is about leaving yourself behind, it is almost a message in a bottle.' And yet there are diarists - Evelyn Waugh and Philip Larkin - who burnt their diaries and Katherine Mansfield did not want hers published (she was overruled posthumously by John Middleton Murry). And Marcia Foreman's cousin keeps a diary which she says is is incredibly dull but must be burned before she dies.

Who is the audience for a diary? In Bad Blood, Lorna Sage's autobiography, she quotes from her grandfather's journals. He was a philandering vicar who had reason to keep his sins under his surplice. But Sage concludes: 'His secrets [in the diary] are like the secrets of a character delivering a stage soliloquy who "doesn't know" he has an audience. Grandpa was always writing for Grandma in a certain sense, inconvenient though the consequences of her getting her hands on the written "evidence" may have been.'

By writing a diary, you give the private concrete form. As Adam Phillips observes: 'If you really believed in privacy you wouldn't write anything down.' A diary is 'an elaborate project. You have to find the time to write it, hide it - it is almost like a criminal activity'.

Frances Newton suggests that diary keeping is both addictive and a chore. 'It is a peculiarly collusive vice. People leave their diaries around but are morally indignant when they are read.' She bravely admits to having read her lovers' diaries: 'Most of us have. It is totally irresistible, although you never find what you want to find.'

There are only a few good publishable diaries (compared to novels, for example) - Pepys, Boswell, Coleridge, Anne Frank, Virginia Woolf. What do they have in common? Only that they can all write. (Diaries written for publication - Tony Benn's and Alan Bennett's - ought to go by some other name.) But being able to write is not the whole story (or diary). Why is this? Why is it so difficult to produce a great diary? Phillips suggests it is because of the ambivalence already discussed. It may also be because life resists form and has no controllable plot.

I look at today's date - 28 Jan - and looked at some published diaries on my shelves. I found that, with one exception, they had something in common. All were complaints or lamentations. Here is Anne Frank (1944) whose diary was in letter form: 'Dearest Kitty, this morning I was wondering whether you ever felt like a cow, having to chew my stale news over and over again until you're so fed up with the monotonous fare that you yawn and secretly wish Anne would dig up something new.'

Alan Clark, 28 Jan 1991: 'I loathe being in London on Sunday evenings, and last night I had to come up so as to be in time this morning for another of these useless ministerial conferences, scheduled for 8.30, never start until 9... The flat is bleak and shabby, and takes a couple of hours to heat up. There is dust and grime, and crumbs in, not on, in - the carpet.'

Cornelius Stovin, a tenant farmer on a large Lincolnshire farm in the middle of the nineteenth century, complains about his wife's complaints at at the end of January 1872: 'My dear wife still enjoys very poor health. Restless nights and wearisome days appear to be her constant portion. Her Providential path is darkened by the clouds of affliction. She is constantly speaking of her tingling nerves, her weaknesses and exhaustion, her inability for accomplishing life's duties.'

He later describes her cooking as 'perfection'. It is touching. Or did Cornelius suspect his wife of covert diary reading?

Dorothy Wordsworth on 28 Jan 1802, was in poor shape. And so was William: 'A downright rain. A wet night. Wm slept better this morning - he had [written an] epitaph and altered one that he wrote when he was a boy. It cleared up after dinner. We were both in miserable spirits, and very doubtful about keeping our engagement to the Olliffs. We walked first within view of Rydale, then to Lewthwaite's, then we went to Mr Olliff's. We talked a while. William was tired. We then played at cards. Came home in the rain. Very dark. Came with lantern. William out of spirits and tired...'

Virginia Woolf on Monday, 28 Jan 1918, complains about poor conversation. 'I went to have my tooth finished, winding up for tea at the Club, which becomes as Goldie said "quite a family party". You come in to find half a dozen pairs of legs radiating from chairs towards the fire. You hear, or I heard, a case of revolution or evolution and then, if you've heard enough, you seek the Manchester Guardian , and hide yourself for precisely 10 seconds.'

A diary may be the only place where a person may record a truthful version of events, a sense of tedious society. A diary may break every rule of politeness.

Sylvia Plath's on 28 Jan 1959, does not complain at all: 'A clear blue day, a close-clipped furze of white snow crisping all the cockeyed angles of roof and chimney below, and the river white... I don't know the name of it. If I can only write a page, half a page, here every day and keep myself counting blessings and working slowly to come into a better life.' Plath's hope that the diary might bring about self-improvement, drive her towards a better life is common to many a diarist. But I am beginning to see that a resolution to put lids on pens before 12 Jan - or, better still, never to start a diary at all - is right.

I went up to the loft to look for 'My Secret Life' - and found it in a fancy box that had once contained marrons glacés. 28 Jan went like this: 'Went to school. Discussed Points about School Council. Kept feeling on the brink of tears. Roly's [my brother's] room painted a heavenly green colour. I have been very depressed. I cried and cried after a dance round the bed in Roly's room. Cried in the bathroom and in the bath. Eventually soothed however.'

 Some names in this article have been changed

A diary may be the only place where a person may record a truthful version of events, a sense of tedious society. A diary may break every rule of politeness. Sylvia Plath's on 28 Jan 1959, does not complain at all: 'A clear blue day, a close-clipped furze of white snow crisping all the cockeyed angles of roof and chimney below, and the river white... I don't know the name of it. If I can only write a page, half a page, here every day and keep myself counting blessings and working slowly to come into a better life.' Plath's hope that the diary might bring about self-improvement, drive her towards a better life is common to many a diarist. But I am beginning to see that a resolution to put lids on pens before 12 Jan - or, better still, never to start a diary at all - is right. I went up to the loft to look for 'My Secret Life' - and found it in a fancy box that had once contained marrons glacés. 28 Jan went like this: 'Went to school. Discussed Points about School Council. Kept feeling on the brink of tears. Roly's [my brother's] room painted a heavenly green colour. I have been very depressed. I cried and cried after a dance round the bed in Roly's room. Cried in the bathroom and in the bath. Eventually soothed however.'  Some names in this article have been changed

webTitle: Letters: Blair rejects TV debate

fields.headline: Don't blame Blair
fields.trailText: My former colleague Jonathan Dimbleby is upset that he will not be chairing a leaders' debate during the general election campaign (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
My former colleague Jonathan Dimbleby is upset that he will not be chairing a leaders' debate during the general election campaign (Comment, last week).

But he should not let personal disappointment cloud his judgment. Tony Blair regularly subjects himself to scrutiny by journalists. He also conducts frequent question and answer sessions involving ordinary members of the public, something his predecessors rarely, if ever, risked.

But I am glad he will eschew American-style TV debates. They would simply transfer the bear-pit from the Commons to the TV studio, they would be in danger of becoming the campaign focus for a self-obsessed media, and the idea that they would combat apathy is not supported by the American experience.
Ben Bradshaw MP
House of Commons
London SW1

Mr Dimbleby believes 'the price of denying a rival the oxygen of publicity is to stifle public debate'. Fair enough. Why then is he not offering Mr Hague and Mr Kennedy the opportunity he recently awarded Mr Blair, of standing for an hour in front of hundreds of ordinary people and trying to answer their questions on prime-time TV? Some glaring hypocrisy there, surely.
Charlie Rose
Bristol

webTitle: Cherri Gilham on  Confessions of a Sex Maniac

fields.headline: The day Trigger bit my bum
fields.standfirst: Last week, an adult video store was fined £5,000 for selling Confessions of a Sex Maniac under the label hard-core porn. It wasn't.  Cherri Gilham should know - she was in it
fields.trailText: Last week, an adult video store was fined £5,000 for selling Confessions of a Sex Maniac under the label hard-core porn. It wasn't.  Cherri Gilham should know - she was in it
fields.body:
A few weeks ago, Adrian, my local video shop manager, whispered to me out of the corner of his mouth: 'I've got one of your old movies.' My immediate reaction, after turning crimson, was to ask him how awful I was in it: any film I appeared in during the Seventies was bound to be a huge embarrassment today. Sarah Bernhardt I wasn't.

'You were pretty good,' he said, leering, 'in action.'

Oh God. He meant that he had seen me simulating sex in the altogether. Which also meant that most of my neighbourhood had probably now seen me wriggling around in the buff.

The film was Confessions of a Sex Maniac, which last week figured in a court case brought by York Trading Standards Office who considered it too tame to be in the Hard Core section of a video rental store in the city. The shop owner, who'd been charging £50 per tape, was fined £5,000 after customers hoping for something a little more outstanding for the weekend complained that the film wasn't raunchy enough.

Well, there's a relief - for me, at least. I am endlessly trying to explain that Seventies sex comedies were not considered porn at the time. It's been bad enough having to live down the label 'soft-porn actress', which stuck because I appeared in The Benny Hill Show; 'hard porn' would be well below the belt.

From the age of 20 I had wanted to be a serious actress but I was too lazy, after quitting drama school, to do three years' slog in provincial rep. No graft meant no craft - and no serious jobs. I was relegated to bit-parts in television comedies, stints as a game-show hostess and minor roles in Carry On films or even lower down the scale, the Confessions of ... movies.

Confessions of a Sex Maniac was conceived, produced and directed by a young commercials-maker called Alan Birkinshaw, in 1974. 'It was my first film,' says Alan, 'and it was supposed to be a send-up. It was easier at the time to get finance for that kind of movie than anything more serious. It started life as 'The Tit', then became 'Design for Love', then 'Success or Bust' and finally Confessions of a Sex Maniac. It became the longest running British film in the West End in the Seventies.'

Viewing it again at home (Adrian eventually let me rent if for £4), it was lovely to see some of my old mates yanking off their tops to reveal boobs of all dimensions. It would be unfair to name them here, since they may now be living salubrious lives in the suburbs and not want the spotlight of shame shone on them.

The story is about a young architect who dreams of building an office block shaped like a breast, and he spends the entire film in search of that perfect form. 'My wife was away at the time,' says Birkinshaw, 'and without her knowledge, we shot some of the film at our house. We were desperate for locations. When it was finished, everything was care fully cleared away, and my wife returned home none the wiser until she opened a curtain and a gaffer's clamp fell out.'

The film starred a young Roger Lloyd Pack, later to star as Trigger in Only Fools and Horses, and Vicky Hodge, who played an innocent (until the last reel) secretary. Vicky was a famous upper-crust model in the Seventies who blotted her copybook when she sold the story of her Caribbean romance with Prince Andrew to the tabloids. (Why should she care? She retired on the proceeds.)

Because of the paucity of the budget, Birkinshaw got me to play two cameo roles. One was a young girl in a curly wig, prancing around topless and coming on to Milligan the architect (Lloyd Pack). The other was a suburban housewife, Mrs Burrows, who seduces Milligan using high-falutin language and metaphors about Dante and Beatrice.

The blurb on the video jacket describes the film as 'poorly made celluloid cat litter', and whoever wrote it has a point. But there was actually some very funny and clever dialogue (which you might perhaps expect if you knew that Birkinshaw is the younger brother of Fay Weldon). Also on the sleeve is a picture of me, standing naked, head thrust back with Lloyd Pack biting my bum. Could I ever have hoped to be taken seriously?

After I left acting to the actors I became a mother. I wrote a newspaper article recently about the sadness I felt that my son would soon be leaving home. I received a letter from an 'admirer' who said how fascinating it would be for my readers to see a picture he had of me, a 'split-beaver shot'. In the parlance of adult shops that means full frontal, legs akimbo. I have absolutely no recall of when this might have been taken or what film it might have been snatched from. But I wish now that I'd kept my knickers on.

webTitle: Moral muse: Can my emails to an ex-lover kill my marriage?

fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: Can my emails to an ex-lover kill my marriage?
fields.trailText: Can my emails to an ex-lover kill my marriage?
fields.body:
Ten years ago I finished a long-term relationship with a man who meant a lot to me. I am now happily married with two children. However, I recently instigated an email correspondence with my old lover. He is married and lives a long way away so it is unlikely we will meet. The correspondence is nothing more than friendly but I feel as though I am betraying my husband. I enjoy reliving memories with my ex-lover, but should I stop writing?

A.V. of Portsmouth

The acid test would be to ask your husband what he thinks; or alternatively your e-man's wife. But I don't seriously recommend this course of action. You know they wouldn't like it. I suppose there is some danger for you that rose-tinted past memories may be harmful to present contentment and you may be led on to make plans to speak on the phone, to meet for coffee, for dinner, for the night... You should examine your motives and determine where you will draw the line.

But let's keep a sense of proportion here. I would not advocate to any married couple that they insist on knowing each other's hearts and souls without reserve. That may be a romantic ideal for the euphoria of the early days, but is not wise for a long-term relationship. No two people are totally mutually complementary, nor do their needs invariably correspond. Life would be considerably less rich if a man and a woman were precluded from having a non-sexual friendship just because it might lead to intimacy.

If this little admission is the nearest you have (or will) ever come to infidelity, I think your husband has very little to complain of. Did you know that men think of sex on average once every four minutes? It's unlikely that he dwells on this emotive topic in the abstract or invariable in connection with yourself.

Men are readily distracted by youth, and few can resist glancing at a provocatively displayed cleavage. No harm in that, they say; you can study a menu even when you are not dining. But men expect a more exclusive faithfulness from their spouses, which is why it is better he does not know of your correspondence. A woman with a husband, home and family is not a creature of freedom, and you are tied down as much by your essentially yielding and pliant feminine psyche as by your responsibilities. Take your freedom where you can. There are no thought police behind your screen. Enjoy and value your disinterested friendships, for in the ups and downs of life they are among your most valuable possessions.

Reader's replies

No you cannot, for whatever reason, have a contact with your former lover, deluding yourself that it is all 'nostalgic'. It is just that, a delusion; moreover, it is dangerous in the extreme because it is secretive and dishonest. Why? Because sooner or later, no matter what you think or say, you will meet up, probably each of you without telling your present partner, and your furtive letter writing, with its added afterglow, will very quickly lead to a kiss and, at a stroke, you are lost and embroiled in a relationship that you cannot control and one that will lead to deceit, wretchedness and misery all round.

R.C. of Cheltenham

Are you crazy, or bored, or what? Your correspondence with your ex-lover is a kind of long-distance foreplay and, if you're honest with yourself, you know exactly where that leads. You say you feel you are betraying your husband; this is because you are betraying him.

So grow up - before it's too late. Break off this contact, tell him it's over, forever, and change your e-mail address. Otherwise, you risk wrecking not only your own life but the lives of many others. Do it - today.

J.B. via email

Next week's dilemma

I am single and my boss is married with two children but he hinted strongly at a recent work function that he is very interested in me. Since then he has asked me out to dinner two or three times but I've refused: I have always promised myself that I would never get involved in such a situation. However, the attraction is mutual and I'm tempted. My best friend says it's possible to have an office affair that doesn't spill over into your personal or family life and I'd like to believe her, but is she right?

J.R. of London

 Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for 'Woman's Journal'

webTitle: So a fish does need a bicycle

fields.headline: So a fish does need a bicycle
fields.standfirst: According to a new US bestseller out here soon, there's only one way to keep Mr Right - just don't tell him when he's wrong
fields.trailText: According to a new US bestseller out here soon, there's only one way to keep Mr Right - just don't tell him when he's wrong
fields.body:
Do you ever feel superior to your husband? Do you think everything would be fine if only he did what you said? Do you criticise him when he misloads the dishwasher? Do you imitate the way he clears his throat to make your friends laugh? Do you have a hard time remembering why you married him? Do you ever look at him when he's fast asleep and snoring, and wish he were someone else? If you answered yes to any of these questions, Laura Doyle, America's new self-help queen, has some very bad news for you. It's not your husband's fault that he falls so short of your expectations. The person you should be blaming is yourself.

Do you want to know why? If the answer is no, you'd better flee the country, because when her book comes out in Britain in a few weeks' time, it's set to get the full tabloid puff, and there will be no escaping it. So you might as well know now what you've been doing wrong all this time. The biggest mistake you ever made was throwing away your bunny suit. Let's face it, there isn't a man on earth who isn't desperate for a good, old-fashioned, full-service wife. But please, don't panic! Not that long ago, Laura's husband was just as unhappy as your husband is right now. Maybe he was even worse, because she used to do such awful things like yell at him when he didn't pick up his beer cans and roll her eyes when they were on the freeway and he missed their exit. But then she got what was coming to her because he started watching television to avoid talking to her. She went into a terrible panic, but that turned out to be a blessing in disguise.

Because it made her use her eyes. It made her look around her neighbourhood and see that the happiest marriages in her particular corner of Orange County, California, were the ones in which the women willingly bowed down to their men. So she decided to try it out on Mr. Couch Potato, to see if that perked him up at all. The results were spectacular, so then she closed her eyes and handed over the household finances, saying she trusted his judgement utterly. She started keeping her mouth shut, except to tell him everything he thought and did was wonderful, even when it wasn't. He perked up even more, and then she started closing her eyes when he was driving, and hey presto, he started driving better, or at least more manfully.

She still had to struggle to keep her less kind thoughts to herself, though. She had to keep telling herself: 'Don't try to control him'. That was a mouthful, if you had to say it over and over. So she decided to reduce it to a one-word mantra: surrender.

The mantra worked wonders in all the compartments of her life, but never so wonderfully as it did in the bedroom. By now her friends were noticing that she and John were acting like a couple of newlyweds, and they wanted to know what her secret was. So she started running a surrendered wives group in her sitting-room, and when the group got too crowded, she started running seminars. When these started multiplying faster than amoebae, she decided the time had come to spread the word nationally. As usual, her hunch was right.

After publishing The Surrendered Wife herself a year ago, Simon & Schuster picked it up and this month it did a first print run in the United States of 100,000. The American networks have also shown intense interest, and thanks to their generous coverage, women all over the nation are now setting up surrendered wife support groups. Other women are getting together to tear their hair out. They're concerned for all the obvious reasons. But why non-surrendered women see her as a serious threat is another question. Her message is not new - in many ways it's an update of the Seventies bestseller, Marabel Morgan's The Total Woman, which taught us that the 'total woman caters to her husband's special quirks, whether it be in salad, sex, or sports'. It's been echoed more recently in Ellen Fein's The Rules, Wendy Shalit's A Return to Modesty, and Danielle Crittenden's What Our Mothers Didn't Tell Us. And what Laura Doyle says is not nearly as extreme or obnoxious as her namesake, the family values radio personality Dr Laura Schlesinger whose syndicated daily talk show has 18 million listeners. So you have to wonder why non-surrendered women are paying so much attention to her.

It could be her weird mix of self-help styles that non-fans find so exasperating. She doesn't tell women to give up work. Why bother, if you can make the double standard work in your favour? All you have to do is change your attitude, plus a few annoying habits. You have to let go before you can undergo spiritual rebirth. What she's done in essence is to take the total woman and sent her off to a 12-step recovery programme.

This, in fact, is where her ideas about surrender come from. The first steps in Alcoholics Anonymous are one: that I admit that I am powerless over alcohol - that my life has become unmanageable. Two: that I come to believe that a Power greater than myself could restore me to sanity, and make a decision to turn my will and my life over to the care of God as I understand Him and come to believe that a Power greater than myself could restore me to sanity. Three: make a decision to turn my will and my life over to the care of God as I understand Him . What Doyle has done is replace the word marriage for alcohol and 'understand' her Higher Power to be her husband. She then suggests that a wife who surrenders her will and her life to a husband is not just going to help his ego and rejuvenate their marriage, but also help her become a power in her own right. Laura did just this, and it worked.

But she's still only 32, so maybe she shouldn't count her chickens quite yet, her feminist critics suggest unkindly. Boy, does she get angry, though, if you say this to her face. Feminism may have done a lot for the workplace, but what, she splutters, has it done to help women find fulfilment at home?

'It seems to me that these people have simply empowered women to get divorced, become single mothers, get married again, and leave the next man, too, because he's no good. We're empowered to sue for lots of child maintenance, and then live struggling and lonely for the rest of our lives. Just great!'

It's not just 'the feminists' who are refusing her message, though. The therapeutic establishment is pretty appalled, too. One of her fiercest critics is John Gottman, considered by many to be the world's leading expert on marriage. All his own research points to the importance of balanced, sharing caring, open and honest communication. So it is not surprising that he finds the surrendered wife concept 'personally offensive and scientifically unfounded'. He may be doing her a favour. It is partly thanks to denunciations like this that The Surrendered Wife, or TSW , as it's known among the faithful, has become the book everyone's talking about. It's sure to be the same in Britain, where there are already a number of TSW groups in electronic communication with Laura. A storm of denunciations at publication time is sure to help her extend her message to many more. But the most important bits of it are bound to get lost among the Chinese whispers. So please, listen carefully, or you'll get the whole thing back to front as so many others have done already. A surrendered wife as Laura defines it 'is not about returning to the Fifties or rebelling against feminism'. It isn't 'about dumbing down or being rigid. It's certainly not about subservience.' It's about following some 'basic principles' that will restore intimacy to your marriage, and with it, peace and joy and inner growth. The main principle is to relinquish 'inappropriate control' of your husband. But you are also supposed to respect his thinking, express gratitude for all he gives you, tell him what you want but never, ever, ever tell him what to do. You must hand the family finances over to him, even if he is bad with money. And you've got to let him have his way with you, even if you don't want it , at least once a week. Do all this, and you will have more time and energy to practise 'self-care' and focus on your own fulfilments, she assures us. In other words, you can surrender at home and still kick ass at work. 'Whether your desire is to have a more harmonious family, run a top corporation, or both, you'll feel increasing pride as you realise your goals faster than ever before.'

If her overview seems woolly, her style is anything but. She has to be the bossiest surrendered wife that ever was. She'll state a home truth: 'In marriage, as in nature, water seeks its own level: we marry men who match us. Just as you never see lakes with an uneven surface, you never see couples who aren't perfectly balanced'. Then she'll hit the space bar, and say: 'Really.'

Hitting the space bar again, she goes on to tell you to take that man with whom you are perfectly balanced, and put him on a pedestal. Indulge him. Make him feel powerful by making yourself look small. Get on your hands and knees and honour his choice of socks and stocks. Respect what he does even if what he does makes you want to scream. 'Respect means that when he takes the wrong freeway exit you don't correct him by telling him where to turn. It means that if he keeps going in the wrong direction you will go past the state line and still not correct what he's doing. No matter what you husband does, you will not try to teach, improve or correct him.' If that sounds ludicrous to you, she urges you to sit back for a moment and think what happens when you don't keep your mouth shut. 'Disrespecting your husband's choices on a regular basis is like pricking him repeatedly with little pins. Imagine living with a porcupine and you've got the idea of what it's like for him.'

Changing yourself into a more amenable animal is not easy, she admits. 'In some cases, not responding may require putting large quantities of duct tape over your mouth. Do whatever it takes.' Whatever he says to you, your response should be: 'Whatever you say.' You have to mean it, too. You have to go along with any plan he makes unless you are very sure it would endanger your health. Utter compliance may feel strange at first, she warns. But: 'Your husband will adore you for it.' Especially you know where. 'Most men aren't interested in having sex with their mothers and that is who we remind them of when we are forever controlling them and telling them what to do. A surrendered wife always says 'yes' and is always available for sex.'

'The first rule for a great sex life is to be respectful and wear something sheer and lacy.' The benefits last far beyond climax. Once you let him exercise his manhood, he'll open up and let down his guard and then you'll have intimacy. 'He may speak about the values he hopes to impart to the children, what he's imagining the two of your will do when you're old, or tell you about how he lost a dog he loved as a kid. Intimacy is made up of lots of little tender conversations - sometimes silly, sometimes solemn - that he wouldn't have with anyone else in the world.' And all you have to do to achieve this heavenly state is to give up your rights.

But what if you decide you need them again a year or two down the line? Say you wake up one morning and find out that this wonderful man to whom you've decided to enslave yourself is not so wonderful after all? There is a disturbing testimonial from a woman who used the Surrendered Wife method only to find that it almost landed her in bankruptcy court when her husband ran off with all her money. Another says she's giving up on the surrender idea because her husband is a repulsive slob who plops on to the couch when he gets home from work.

None of this fazes the already converted. They carry on regardless, gushing about surrender and exchanging tips about the appropriate response to a man who says: 'Shut the fuck up.' (Most agree that the standard line - 'whatever you think' - may not be appropriate.) They give kind but slightly patronising advice to the men who come on-line to complain about the way their wives talk to them. Every once in a while, a wife will step out of role to lash out at one of the unsurrendered interlopers. One tells a sceptical unmarried mother: 'It's hardly surprising that you are single, as what man would want to marry such an obnoxious, man-hating creature as you?'

The most intriguing thing is how raunchy the surrendered wives are. Oh how my mother and her friends would blush to hear the advice they give poor Kim, who has surrendered but still isn't getting as much sex as she craves. The 'keys to a happy marriage' are as follows, says Karen. 'Don't criticise him, let him make the wrong turn, give him lots of oral sex and be sure to swallow.' This is followed by a flurry of postings offering further refinements.

Even though she now has an 11-month-old with another on the way, she doesn't think of her pregnant body as ugly, 'but pretty and cute'. But her husband finds it 'repulsive, which I think is funny because he has a big jelly belly, a hairy back and other things women would say are a big turn-off'. But still, she wants to make the marriage work. 'I complimented him on his body. I kissed him passionately, I touched his chest, shoulders, etc, all day, hoping it would pay off at some point. My husband disputed all of my compliments. He told me he felt pressured. Like an idiot, I apologised and he started to yell at me for apologising.' Later on, he told her that he hadn't wanted to have to say it, but that he wasn't sexually attracted to her anymore. And how unfair was that? The consensus in the electronic community of surrendered wives is that she should 'reconsider her relationship'. Which is short for: get rid of the guy. This, surprise, surprise, is the central plank of the surrendering philosophy. Surrender is a privilege you should only extend to 'good guys'. Never surrender to a man who is physically abusive to you, or your children, or has an 'active' addiction, or who is chronically unfaithful. It's not worth it, says Laura. Really. You can never achieve intimacy with types like that.

The biggest shock for me was finding out how exacting these surrendered wives were when discussing who was good husband material, and how little it took for them to say: 'Forget this guy. He's history.' A lot of the wives had careers they were proud of. A few admitted they earned more than their husbands. One said that was why it was such a relief to hand the money management over. After a long day barking orders at work, it's such a relief, she says, to come home at the end of the day, and kick off your shoes and your work personality, and 'be a woman'. This is what Laura Doyle is telling them: you can have everything you want, so long as you play by one set of rules at work and a very different set at home. That, of course, is what most people do anyway. Even people like myself who would rather die than admit it. Which is why, I suspect, we wish Laura would show us the same courtesy she shows her husband, and keep her stupid, half-baked, insulting grains of truth to herself.

Do you imitate the way he clears his throat to make your friends laugh? Do you have a hard time remembering why you married him? Do you ever look at him when he's fast asleep and snoring, and wish he were someone else? If you answered yes to any of these questions, Laura Doyle, America's new self-help queen, has some very bad news for you. It's not your husband's fault that he falls so short of your expectations. The person you should be blaming is yourself. Do you want to know why? If the answer is no, you'd better flee the country, because when her book comes out in Britain in a few weeks' time, it's set to get the full tabloid puff, and there will be no escaping it. So you might as well know now what you've been doing wrong all this time. The biggest mistake you ever made was throwing away your bunny suit. Let's face it, there isn't a man on earth who isn't desperate for a good, old-fashioned, full-service wife. But please, don't panic! Not that long ago, Laura's husband was just as unhappy as your husband is right now. Maybe he was even worse, because she used to do such awful things like yell at him when he didn't pick up his beer cans and roll her eyes when they were on the freeway and he missed their exit. But then she got what was coming to her because he started watching television to avoid talking to her. She went into a terrible panic, but that turned out to be a blessing in disguise. Because it made her use her eyes. It made her look around her neighbourhood and see that the happiest marriages in her particular corner of Orange County, California, were the ones in which the women willingly bowed down to their men. So she decided to try it out on Mr. Couch Potato, to see if that perked him up at all. The results were spectacular, so then she closed her eyes and handed over the household finances, saying she trusted his judgement utterly. She started keeping her mouth shut, except to tell him everything he thought and did was wonderful, even when it wasn't. He perked up even more, and then she started closing her eyes when he was driving, and hey presto, he started driving better, or at least more manfully. She still had to struggle to keep her less kind thoughts to herself, though. She had to keep telling herself: 'Don't try to control him'. That was a mouthful, if you had to say it over and over. So she decided to reduce it to a one-word mantra: surrender. The mantra worked wonders in all the compartments of her life, but never so wonderfully as it did in the bedroom. By now her friends were noticing that she and John were acting like a couple of newlyweds, and they wanted to know what her secret was. So she started running a surrendered wives group in her sitting-room, and when the group got too crowded, she started running seminars. When these started multiplying faster than amoebae, she decided the time had come to spread the word nationally. As usual, her hunch was right. After publishing The Surrendered Wife herself a year ago, Simon & Schuster picked it up and this month it did a first print run in the United States of 100,000. The American networks have also shown intense interest, and thanks to their generous coverage, women all over the nation are now setting up surrendered wife support groups. Other women are getting together to tear their hair out. They're concerned for all the obvious reasons. But why non-surrendered women see her as a serious threat is another question. Her message is not new - in many ways it's an update of the Seventies bestseller, Marabel Morgan's The Total Woman, which taught us that the 'total woman caters to her husband's special quirks, whether it be in salad, sex, or sports'. It's been echoed more recently in Ellen Fein's The Rules, Wendy Shalit's A Return to Modesty, and Danielle Crittenden's What Our Mothers Didn't Tell Us. And what Laura Doyle says is not nearly as extreme or obnoxious as her namesake, the family values radio personality Dr Laura Schlesinger whose syndicated daily talk show has 18 million listeners. So you have to wonder why non-surrendered women are paying so much attention to her. It could be her weird mix of self-help styles that non-fans find so exasperating. She doesn't tell women to give up work. Why bother, if you can make the double standard work in your favour? All you have to do is change your attitude, plus a few annoying habits. You have to let go before you can undergo spiritual rebirth. What she's done in essence is to take the total woman and sent her off to a 12-step recovery programme. This, in fact, is where her ideas about surrender come from. The first steps in Alcoholics Anonymous are one: that I admit that I am powerless over alcohol - that my life has become unmanageable. Two: that I come to believe that a Power greater than myself could restore me to sanity, and make a decision to turn my will and my life over to the care of God as I understand Him and come to believe that a Power greater than myself could restore me to sanity. Three: make a decision to turn my will and my life over to the care of God as I understand Him . What Doyle has done is replace the word marriage for alcohol and 'understand' her Higher Power to be her husband. She then suggests that a wife who surrenders her will and her life to a husband is not just going to help his ego and rejuvenate their marriage, but also help her become a power in her own right. Laura did just this, and it worked. But she's still only 32, so maybe she shouldn't count her chickens quite yet, her feminist critics suggest unkindly. Boy, does she get angry, though, if you say this to her face. Feminism may have done a lot for the workplace, but what, she splutters, has it done to help women find fulfilment at home? 'It seems to me that these people have simply empowered women to get divorced, become single mothers, get married again, and leave the next man, too, because he's no good. We're empowered to sue for lots of child maintenance, and then live struggling and lonely for the rest of our lives. Just great!' It's not just 'the feminists' who are refusing her message, though. The therapeutic establishment is pretty appalled, too. One of her fiercest critics is John Gottman, considered by many to be the world's leading expert on marriage. All his own research points to the importance of balanced, sharing caring, open and honest communication. So it is not surprising that he finds the surrendered wife concept 'personally offensive and scientifically unfounded'. He may be doing her a favour. It is partly thanks to denunciations like this that The Surrendered Wife, or TSW , as it's known among the faithful, has become the book everyone's talking about. It's sure to be the same in Britain, where there are already a number of TSW groups in electronic communication with Laura. A storm of denunciations at publication time is sure to help her extend her message to many more. But the most important bits of it are bound to get lost among the Chinese whispers. So please, listen carefully, or you'll get the whole thing back to front as so many others have done already. A surrendered wife as Laura defines it 'is not about returning to the Fifties or rebelling against feminism'. It isn't 'about dumbing down or being rigid. It's certainly not about subservience.' It's about following some 'basic principles' that will restore intimacy to your marriage, and with it, peace and joy and inner growth. The main principle is to relinquish 'inappropriate control' of your husband. But you are also supposed to respect his thinking, express gratitude for all he gives you, tell him what you want but never, ever, ever tell him what to do. You must hand the family finances over to him, even if he is bad with money. And you've got to let him have his way with you, even if you don't want it , at least once a week. Do all this, and you will have more time and energy to practise 'self-care' and focus on your own fulfilments, she assures us. In other words, you can surrender at home and still kick ass at work. 'Whether your desire is to have a more harmonious family, run a top corporation, or both, you'll feel increasing pride as you realise your goals faster than ever before.' If her overview seems woolly, her style is anything but. She has to be the bossiest surrendered wife that ever was. webTitle: Is Stephen Fry finally joining in?

fields.headline: Fry's puckish delight
fields.standfirst: His sex life is good and he's about to front the Baftas. Is Stephen Fry finally joining in?
fields.trailText: His sex life is good and he's about to front the Baftas. Is Stephen Fry finally joining in?
fields.body:
'I so hate having to think about titles,' Stephen Fry is saying. 'Clearly one must have a title, it's unavoidable, one has to. But it's a nightmare.'

Yes, it does seem only a matter of time before Fry is officially garlanded as a Treasure of the British Empire, but for the moment we're talking about the titles of his books - his four bestselling novels, his collection of humorous musings from radio and the press, his brilliant and compelling autobiography, Moab Is My Washpot.

'Do you spend a lot of time thinking about titles?' I ask.

'Um. No.'

I thought not. He laughs. 'No, and it's very important to me that I don't. I can't bear thinking about titles. I get very superstitious about them. I just don't want them to have a title. I can never come up with one and the publishers say, you must come up with one, so I'll say something like, oh...'

'Hippopotamus?' I suggest (by coincidence, the name of his second novel).

'No, actually that one was quite a good title. But Moab was, well... if you knew the quotation, it would make sense - "Moab is my washpot and over Edom will I cast my shoe".'

Oh, that Moab, that washpot.

We're surrounded by the vestiges of breakfast in a cool Holland Park hotel. Fry leans back and puffs on a Marlboro, even though he has a sore throat and has been at the Day Nurse. He doesn't look too well. I don't think it's too unkind to say that he looks like he might have just woken up in the clothes he might have slept in.

But this superstition business. You'd think that anyone who has made so dazzling a success of being a genius in such arcane matters as Moab and washpots and everything else under the sun would have given up having to cross his fingers by now. No need to go through his lustrous CV here; suffice to say, we are long accustomed to commentators thinking they are the first to ask, with mock weariness: 'Is there nothing this man cannot do?'

Of course no one's perfect. Fry enjoyed a less than exemplary youth, lying, cheating, idling, scheming and, notably, thieving his way through three schools (see Moab for full expulsion details), before eventually ending up in prison at 17 with no A-levels after running wild with a pair of stolen credit cards. In more recent years, he famously deserted the West End play Cell Mates, following depression and bad reviews of his performance. He intended to kill himself, only at the last minute commuting his self-imposed sentence to visiting Belgium instead. Today, he is a contented man, having subdued if not slayed his demons. He is happily partnered, he has done good work for the Samaritans, he is chummy with Prince Charles, he is adored by the nation. In short, he is ready to host the Baftas.

I'm surprised to find that when he fronts the ceremony next month it will be his first time. 'I have been asked to do the Baftas before,' he says. 'I've always been rather hesitant because I don't really see myself as a Clive or an Angus sort of person. No disrespect to them - they do what they do and they do it very well. But because it's the film awards, and one of the things I do myself is act in films, one has to be very sure about the way it's done.' He is happy with the way it's done now. Now it's no longer an event based around eating dinner, where there's the risk of people getting drunk and disorderly. The Baftas are not supposed to be the Brits.

This kind of job seems to be made for him. I wonder, given the dispiriting ease with which he can talk in a straight line and be avuncular, funny and brainy at the same time, why we have never seen him doing solo television or a chat show. 'I have been asked to do things like that. But though I may have a facility for chatting, I like to use it for writing, and I like being an actor. I'm never going to get things that Brad Pitt has turned down, but there are a range of things, some of which are highly crunchy cameos and others are more serious parts. If I were to become a "personality", I'd be far less likely to be asked. It's like, if suddenly Clive James were to appear in a film, you'd think, hang on... Angus is a good comic actor, but he's less likely to do any now because he fronts so many things.'

In any case, he points out, there's hardly a shortage of opportunities to perform off the cuff, as it were. 'Almost everything one does has a press officer attached and smart, besuited young men [he waves his cigarette at hovering smart, besuited young men] who arrange newspaper interviews or beg you to appear on Clive Anderson or Michael Parkinson. Sometimes you find yourself doing a lot of these things. But it goes with the territory. I'm one of those people who was told by schoolmasters that he liked the sound of his own voice.'

By his own account in Moab, liking the sound of his own voice was not regarded as a marketable skill at school. Comedians often tell of how they would use humour as a survival tool in the playground and classroom, but Fry seems to have gone straight for provocation. 'It's all part of the same morbid self-disgust that most comedians have. It worked to some extent. The major thought in my head when I woke up was how I was going to get off games that day. And if you knew you were gay in the late Sixties and early Seventies - well, all I had was the library to tell me I wasn't alone. Provocation comes because you feel disgusted with yourself and because you feel a freak, or not one of the gang.'

Being hopeless at games and a desperately secret homosexual were bad enough. But he couldn't sing either - the final pillar of shame at any self-respecting public school. So Fry junior lied, he schemed, he pilfered and he read books, becoming clever with words, a wit, a smart arse, a tormentor of teachers, a breaker of bounds, a model of wilful depravity. 'Not joining in' is how he characterises his adolescence. Inwardly tortured and outwardly self-sufficient, he gradually took up the language and nuances of his heroes - in particular Conan Doyle, Wodehouse and the Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band oddball Vivian Stanshall - as his shield and sword of differentness. I wonder, then, whether the now familiar tweedy manner and scabrous humour and sudden flights of erudition began back then as an effort to construct the Stephen Fry he consciously wanted to be.

'Very much so. But after a while it becomes you. It's like deciding how you're going to sign your name when you're a teenager and you think, shall I do my "y"s straight down or hooked, or I rather fancy a Greek "e" here, and so on. But eventually it is your autograph. It starts as a kind of mask, as a series of poses that you've gone through in your adolescence, but then it becomes absolutely you. It is inseparable. And it's the same with one's behavioural mannerisms and with one's writing style and perhaps one's personality.'

I ask where he gets his brains from. His father - a physicist and inventor - is the quick answer, but this proves merely the signal for an unscheduled excursion round the Greek deity Mnemosyne, mother of the muses, the Battle of Bannockburn, Plato and Nietzsche, before puffing gently into E.M. Forster, who, he says, 'writes about the beast and the monk in us all - "only connect and both will be exalted".' For the young Fry, mankind's inherent dichotomy boiled down to a) those devoted to the life of the mind and b) the jockstrapping neanderthals who played rugby. 'You were an aesthete or athlete, and I knew which side I was on. I didn't like Forster's idea of connecting - I didn't want to connect. I didn't want to have a human body at all.'

He loves all sport now - well, watching it, anyway. So has he come to terms yet with not being able to do it? Surely he'd rather be brainy than play cricket?

'Well I suppose it's the old cliché - things you're not good at are the things you want to be good at. I've fallen asleep at nights dreaming of opening the bowling for England. You'd never fall asleep at night thinking of yourself debating or being the next Themistocles.'

Some people, I suggest, would give their right bowling arm to be on such familiar terms with the first Themistocles. 'Well, of course, the other man's arse is always cleaner,' he says cheerfully.

Fry hardly seems to think before he talks. Unless he does all his thinking when he's dragging on his cigarette, which is quite often.

I ask whether three months behind bars brought him to his senses. It did, but it was eventually Cambridge that proved the emotional turning point. It was here that he met Hugh Laurie, his writing partner and oldest friend. 'It was a relationship untainted by any sort of schoolboy rivalry or any sexual overtones. I wasn't in love with him or anything so there was no kind of complication in that sense but we had an absolute instinct. People would remark very quickly after we'd met that we said exactly the same thing at the same time in response to something. We started writing together and we just never stopped.'

Was it this unexpected affinity which brought him out of his bunker and made him see that, actually, other people did matter? Was this a conscience-finding moment?

'Yes, that's exactly what it was. I'm sure there are all kinds of jargonistic words like "dissociative" or something that a pyschiatrist would use but having a conscience and recognising that other people existed - that is absolutely the key. I had a very marked case of adolescent solipsism. It was like The Truman Show. I got sent the script of The Truman Show to see if I might twiddle with it, and as soon as I read that script I thought, my God, that was my life. For most of my teens I had this pretty strong feeling that everyone else was an extra and that as I rounded a corner people would be saying he's coming, he's coming - pretend to be ordinary, pretend to have real lives.'

So... walking out of Cell Mates - it must have felt terrible letting everyone down. 'It was a very insane and very bizarre time. It's hard to talk about memories. It can be very hard to reconstruct one's emotions. It's as if there was just foul weather going on in my head.'

Was it the disgrace of it that drove him to thoughts of suicide? 'Yes, I think it was partly disgrace. I don't know what goes on in one's mind - it's a whole parade of things, but they don't go through your mind in an ordered way. It's just a big scream inside saying you really just don't want to carry on. You just feel there is absolutely no point. Of course, logically, there is no point. One can be very Beckettian about it and see that there is nothing in store for us really except disappointment and physical pain and degradation and cancer and arthritis and misery.'

His error, he says, was to seek happiness in work. 'It was all I was. I had no relationships. I had it in my head that if I was reasonably respected in a world that I liked, and if I had enough money to go on holiday whenever I liked, buy a house of my own, then of course I would be happy. It took a long time to work out that, while I was very pleased not have to worry where the next penny was coming from and have people stop me in the street saying how nice or funny I was, these were not things in themselves that could make me happy. It all built up into my suddenly realising that I was fundamentally terribly miserable.'

His next turning point - after years of being one of Britain's most notorious celibates - was falling in love, and a relationship that has brought 'richness to my life'. Some might conclude that he seems to be joining in at last - friends in high places, the possession of a sex life, a readiness to wear the Bafta bow-tie, not to mention monopolising Boxing Day with his reading of Harry Potter. Having experienced happiness, does he now believe in it?

'Well, I wouldn't claim that I've found the true path to enlightened bliss. I'm not in a permanent state of happiness. I can still get deeply annoyed if I can't find my car keys but...'

'But not enough to want to flee the country again...'

'No, no, no.' He stubs out his cigarette. 'Well, not to Belgium anyway.'

 The Bafta film awards will be broadcast on Sky TV on 25 February

But Moab was, well... if you knew the quotation, it would make sense - "Moab is my washpot and over Edom will I cast my shoe".' Oh, that Moab, that washpot. We're surrounded by the vestiges of breakfast in a cool Holland Park hotel. Fry leans back and puffs on a Marlboro, even though he has a sore throat and has been at the Day Nurse. He doesn't look too well. I don't think it's too unkind to say that he looks like he might have just woken up in the clothes he might have slept in. But this superstition business. You'd think that anyone who has made so dazzling a success of being a genius in such arcane matters as Moab and washpots and everything else under the sun would have given up having to cross his fingers by now. No need to go through his lustrous CV here; suffice to say, we are long accustomed to commentators thinking they are the first to ask, with mock weariness: 'Is there nothing this man cannot do?' Of course no one's perfect. Fry enjoyed a less than exemplary youth, lying, cheating, idling, scheming and, notably, thieving his way through three schools (see Moab for full expulsion details), before eventually ending up in prison at 17 with no A-levels after running wild with a pair of stolen credit cards. In more recent years, he famously deserted the West End play Cell Mates, following depression and bad reviews of his performance. He intended to kill himself, only at the last minute commuting his self-imposed sentence to visiting Belgium instead. Today, he is a contented man, having subdued if not slayed his demons. He is happily partnered, he has done good work for the Samaritans, he is chummy with Prince Charles, he is adored by the nation. In short, he is ready to host the Baftas. I'm surprised to find that when he fronts the ceremony next month it will be his first time. 'I have been asked to do the Baftas before,' he says. 'I've always been rather hesitant because I don't really see myself as a Clive or an Angus sort of person. No disrespect to them - they do what they do and they do it very well. But because it's the film awards, and one of the things I do myself is act in films, one has to be very sure about the way it's done.' He is happy with the way it's done now. Now it's no longer an event based around eating dinner, where there's the risk of people getting drunk and disorderly. The Baftas are not supposed to be the Brits. This kind of job seems to be made for him. I wonder, given the dispiriting ease with which he can talk in a straight line and be avuncular, funny and brainy at the same time, why we have never seen him doing solo television or a chat show. 'I have been asked to do things like that. But though I may have a facility for chatting, I like to use it for writing, and I like being an actor. I'm never going to get things that Brad Pitt has turned down, but there are a range of things, some of which are highly crunchy cameos and others are more serious parts. If I were to become a "personality", I'd be far less likely to be asked. It's like, if suddenly Clive James were to appear in a film, you'd think, hang on... Angus is a good comic actor, but he's less likely to do any now because he fronts so many things.' In any case, he points out, there's hardly a shortage of opportunities to perform off the cuff, as it were. 'Almost everything one does has a press officer attached and smart, besuited young men [he waves his cigarette at hovering smart, besuited young men] who arrange newspaper interviews or beg you to appear on Clive Anderson or Michael Parkinson. Sometimes you find yourself doing a lot of these things. But it goes with the territory. I'm one of those people who was told by schoolmasters that he liked the sound of his own voice.' By his own account in Moab, liking the sound of his own voice was not regarded as a marketable skill at school. Comedians often tell of how they would use humour as a survival tool in the playground and classroom, but Fry seems to have gone straight for provocation. 'It's all part of the same morbid self-disgust that most comedians have. It worked to some extent. The major thought in my head when I woke up was how I was going to get off games that day. And if you knew you were gay in the late Sixties and early Seventies - well, all I had was the library to tell me I wasn't alone. Provocation comes because you feel disgusted with yourself and because you feel a freak, or not one of the gang.' Being hopeless at games and a desperately secret homosexual were bad enough. But he couldn't sing either - the final pillar of shame at any self-respecting public school. So Fry junior lied, he schemed, he pilfered and he read books, becoming clever with words, a wit, a smart arse, a tormentor of teachers, a breaker of bounds, a model of wilful depravity. 'Not joining in' is how he characterises his adolescence. Inwardly tortured and outwardly self-sufficient, he gradually took up the language and nuances of his heroes - in particular Conan Doyle, Wodehouse and the Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band oddball Vivian Stanshall - as his shield and sword of differentness. I wonder, then, whether the now familiar tweedy manner and scabrous humour and sudden flights of erudition began back then as an effort to construct the Stephen Fry he consciously wanted to be. 'Very much so. But after a while it becomes you. It's like deciding how you're going to sign your name when you're a teenager and you think, shall I do my "y"s straight down or hooked, or I rather fancy a Greek "e" here, and so on. But eventually it is your autograph. It starts as a kind of mask, as a series of poses that you've gone through in your adolescence, but then it becomes absolutely you. It is inseparable. And it's the same with one's behavioural mannerisms and with one's writing style and perhaps one's personality.' I ask where he gets his brains from. His father - a physicist and inventor - is the quick answer, but this proves merely the signal for an unscheduled excursion round the Greek deity Mnemosyne, mother of the muses, the Battle of Bannockburn, Plato and Nietzsche, before puffing gently into E.M. Forster, who, he says, 'writes about the beast and the monk in us all - "only connect and both will be exalted".' For the young Fry, mankind's inherent dichotomy boiled down to a) those devoted to the life of the mind and b) the jockstrapping neanderthals who played rugby. 'You were an aesthete or athlete, and I knew which side I was on. I didn't like Forster's idea of connecting - I didn't want to connect. I didn't want to have a human body at all.' He loves all sport now - well, watching it, anyway. So has he come to terms yet with not being able to do it? Surely he'd rather be brainy than play cricket? 'Well I suppose it's the old cliché - things you're not good at are the things you want to be good at. I've fallen asleep at nights dreaming of opening the bowling for England. You'd never fall asleep at night thinking of yourself debating or being the next Themistocles.' Some people, I suggest, would give their right bowling arm to be on such familiar terms with the first Themistocles. 'Well, of course, the other man's arse is always cleaner,' he says cheerfully. Fry hardly seems to think before he talks. Unless he does all his thinking when he's dragging on his cigarette, which is quite often. I ask whether three months behind bars brought him to his senses. It did, but it was eventually Cambridge that proved the emotional turning point. It was here that he met Hugh Laurie, his writing partner and oldest friend. 'It was a relationship untainted by any sort of schoolboy rivalry or any sexual overtones. I wasn't in love with him or anything so there was no kind of complication in that sense but we had an absolute instinct. People would remark very quickly after we'd met that we said exactly the same thing at the same time in response to something. We started writing together and we just never stopped.' Was it this unexpected affinity which brought him out of his bunker and made him see that, actually, other people did matter? Was this a conscience-finding moment? 'Yes, that's exactly what it was. I'm sure there are all kinds of jargonistic words like "dissociative" or something that a pyschiatrist would use but having a conscience and recognising that other people existed - that is absolutely the key. I had a very marked case of adolescent solipsism. It was like The Truman Show. I got sent the script of The Truman Show to see if I might twiddle with it, and as soon as I read that script I thought, my God, that was my life. For most of my teens I had this pretty strong feeling that everyone else was an extra and that as I rounded a corner people would be saying he's coming, he's coming - pretend to be ordinary, pretend to have real lives.' So... walking out of Cell Mates - it must have felt terrible letting everyone down. 'It was a very insane and very bizarre time. It's hard to talk about memories. It can be very hard to reconstruct one's emotions. It's as if there was just foul weather going on in my head.' Was it the disgrace of it that drove him to thoughts of suicide? 'Yes, I think it was partly disgrace. I don't know what goes on in one's mind - it's a whole parade of things, but they don't go through your mind in an ordered way. It's just a big scream inside saying you really just don't want to carry on. You just feel there is absolutely no point. Of course, logically, there is no point. One can be very Beckettian about it and see that there is nothing in store for us really except disappointment and physical pain and degradation and cancer and arthritis and misery.' His error, he says, was to seek happiness in work. 'It was all I was. I had no relationships. I had it in my head that if I was reasonably respected in a world that I liked, and if I had enough money to go on holiday whenever I liked, buy a house of my own, then of course I would be happy. It took a long time to work out that, while I was very pleased not have to worry where the next penny was coming from and have people stop me in the street saying how nice or funny I was, these were not things in themselves that could make me happy. It all built up into my suddenly realising that I was fundamentally terribly miserable.' His next turning point - after years of being one of Britain's most notorious celibates - was falling in love, and a relationship that has brought 'richness to my life'. Some might conclude that he seems to be joining in at last - friends in high places, the possession of a sex life, a readiness to wear the Bafta bow-tie, not to mention monopolising Boxing Day with his reading of Harry Potter. Having experienced happiness, does he now believe in it? 'Well, I wouldn't claim that I've found the true path to enlightened bliss. I'm not in a permanent state of happiness. I can still get deeply annoyed if I can't find my car keys but...' 'But not enough to want to flee the country again...' 'No, no, no.' He stubs out his cigarette. 'Well, not to Belgium anyway.'  The Bafta film awards will be broadcast on Sky TV on 25 February

webTitle: Butcher's boy with a lot to deliver at Iceland

fields.headline: Butcher's boy with a lot to deliver at Iceland
fields.standfirst: New chief executive's first challenge is to warm up the share price. Profile of  Bill Grimsey  by Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: New chief executive's first challenge is to warm up the share price. Profile of Bill Grimsey by Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
'Don't go away, duck,' beamed a grateful old dear to her Iceland delivery boy just before Christmas. 'Here's 40p: get yourself a cup of tea.'

The recipient of that Yuletide largesse was Bill Grimsey, the genial working class Londoner regarded as one of the country's top retailers.

Only three months earlier, Grimsey scooped more than £2 million in share options for successfully guiding Wickes, the DIY chain, from near bankruptcy to a £290m venture capital buyout. In the New Year he was to take up the reins as chief executive of Iceland.

In the meantime, Grimsey spent a couple of days performing menial supermarket duties in Borehamwood. His driver had to tell the millionaire that it was Iceland company policy not to accept tips. 'What was I supposed to do?' Grimsey asked. 'She would have been gutted.'

Grimsey, 48, is probably one of the most hands-on executives in Britain. Why? Because it pays.

'Often people in our industry, when they get to director level, start wearing suits and divorcing themselves from the real action. You've got to remember that people who create conditions for failure get paid a lot of money, and the people who have to deal with that failure get paid £4 an hour.

'When the guy in charge of marketing gets a price wrong, the customer who complains takes it out on the check-out girl. The guy who makes the mistake is not at the end of that.

'The only place that makes any money is the stores, and therefore we have to do everything we can to support those colleagues out there to do their job properly.'

Mind you, after the week that Iceland has endured, Grimsey had better start getting his hands dirty.

The frozen-food giant with a pioneering reputation last year announced that it would be switching entirely to organic vegetables and buying 40 per cent of the world's supply. Since organic food is more expensive than conventional produce, Iceland ditched its successful 'buy one get one free' offers to protect margins.

Last week it was clear this had been a mistake. In a trading statement released last Monday, the company announced that like-for-like sales were down 1.5 per cent over the six months to Christmas and had crashed by 5.5 per cent in the four weeks to 28 December.

Iceland's core customers - at the lower end of the economic spectrum and eager for bargain offers - voted with their feet. Shares in the company, which earlier this year touched 319p, now stand at 205p.

'What happened last year was that Iceland took its eye off the ball and pursued a strategy which was not totally aligned to our customers,' Grimsey explains.

'You can't dictate to customers what they should buy. No brand in the world is big enough for that - ask Marks & Spencer. You have to offer people a choice and move progressively. That was a disastrous policy.'

Worse still, a huge question mark hangs over Iceland's chairman, Malcolm Walker. Between 14 and 19 December, Walker sold £13m worth of Iceland shares, just as he was giving retail analysts an upbeat briefing at the group's head office in Deeside, north Wales.

The Financial Services Authority may now investigate Walker, who is currently holidaying in the Maldives. The authority's rules are clear on director sharedealing: directors can't buy or sell shares if they are in the possession of unpublished price-sensitive information and board directors fail to approve the deal.

Not surprisingly, Grimsey is keen to avoid controversy. 'Malcolm's decision to sell his shares was his decision. It was ratified by the board before I was a member.'

But Grimsey is poised to 'press the button' on his own litigation. The son of a structural engineer, he claims that Duke Street Capital, the venture capitalists that bought Wickes, owe him the best part of £300,000 for an unpaid one-year contract.

He fears court action may distract him from putting Iceland back on an even keel, but wants 'what's rightfully mine'.

Grimsey's next quarter will mostly be spent formulating a strategic plan to expand a company which last year bought Booker, the wholesale food outfit. He believes the future lies in home shopping, which he says will make sense of that merger.

'We are a convenience store, a frozen-food specialist which offers good deals to people on tight budgets. I'm going to return the business to its grass roots while I look at how to grow the business from the platform we've got.'

Acknowledging that Iceland's core market is probably a diminishing one, Grimsey says: 'I believe that technology and home shopping will offer this group a tremendous opportunity. We have 181 Booker warehouse depots; 95 per cent of the UK population live within a 15-minute drive of a Booker warehouse.

'We can do the same ranges as the big guys, although we'll have to do some work on fresh foods. We can challenge for a wider population.'

Grimsey is something of a retail junkie. As a child, he admits, he loved going shopping with his mother. He reels off the names of the various shopowners of his childhood.

He left school at 15 and became a butcher's boy in a St Albans supermarket. But his father, who helped build many of the high-rise tower blocks currently being pulled down, wanted him to follow in his footsteps, so Grimsey trained as a civil engineer for two years.

He then ditched that and returned to college. There he took A-levels, and went on to became a trainee manager at Bishop's Food Stores. The chain was eventually bought by Booker.

By 30, Grimsey was a director. When Bishop's merged with Budgen's in 1986, Grimsey joined Tesco to work for Lord MacLaurin. This was an important time for him. MacLaurin breathed new life into what was a tired business. The experience taught him 'everything I know'.

After two years, Grimsey was offered the chance of running Hutchison Whampoa's Park n' Shop supermarket chain. In five years, he increased profits twentyfold.

But his next move was disastrous - joining Kingfisher at a time when the senior directors were at war with one another. 'We're all allowed one mistake,' he said. 'I was there five minutes and thought: I'm outta here.'

After Kingfisher, Grimsey moved to Wickes and made his name there. At the time, Wickes was in the midst of an accounting irregularity scandal that saw its share price suspended and the banks foreclosing.

Grimsey saved the company. He got a rights issue away, started an employee share scheme, and communicated his vision to the point where the company was bought by DIY outfit Focus-Do-It-All, backed by Duke Street. Shareholders were £350m up on the deal.

After the buyout, Grimsey became one of Britain's most sought-after executives. But his idea was to spend a few months taking to the road on one of his three Triumph motorbikes. That all changed in December when Malcolm Walker asked him to replace Stuart Rose, the man behind Iceland's organic experiment.

Observers believe Grimsey will eventually become executive chairman of Iceland, taking complete control of a company he believes can become one of the leading home-shopping businesses in Britain.

If he pulls that off, it won't just be old ladies who are giving him a tip.

Profile

Name: Bill Grimsey

Date of birth: 21 January 1952

Birthplace: Pimlico, London

First job: Butcher's boy at local supermarket

Marital status: Married to Jan for 29 years. Two sons

Home: Radlett, Hertfordshire

Hobbies: Motorbikes, golf, tennis, skiiing
