webTitle: Ted Baker - only for those who can lose their shirts

fields.headline: Ted Baker - only for those who can lose their shirts
fields.trailText: Beware retailers who seem to defy gravity. That is the hard lesson that investors learnt first from Matalan but had reinforced last week by Ted Baker.
fields.body:
Beware retailers who seem to defy gravity. That is the hard lesson that investors learnt first from Matalan but had reinforced last week by Ted Baker.

Shares in the shirt-maker plunged by a quarter last week after it announced that its Christmas sales were up by 19 per cent. That is a better performance than most on the high street could dream of but it was below the expectations of management and, more importantly, the City.

As Matalan learnt when it produced a similar statement earlier this month, the City does not like being disappointed by companies that are supposed to exceed expectations.

The plunge in the share price may look harsh, given that sales are actually moving strongly up. However, it makes more sense than the precipitate rise that preceded it.

Ted Baker's shares had soared from 135p when it was floated in the summer of 1997 to a peak of 535p last year. They may not have reached Matalan's dizzy valuation - at its peak it stood on 60 times its forecast earnings - but it was still roughly double the average rating for the general retailing sector.

Such spectacular ratings must be justified by spectacular growth. If the growth seems to be faltering, so too must the rating.

But a slowdown in growth affects more than just the rating. Ted Baker has been expanding rapidly on the assumption that rapid growth will continue.

Take its new head office, the imaginatively named Ugly Brown Building, which includes space to display its collections and a rather grand restaurant which is, according to the finance director 'a bit more than a staff canteen'.

Then there is a spanking new distribution warehouse, which it has yet to expand enough to fill.

Then there is the cost of taking the brand into Europe and the US.

Such costs were already taking their toll in the first half of the year: they wiped out the benefit of a 24 per cent rise in sales and meant that pre-tax profits fell by more than a quarter.

The City was prepared to wear this - provided it looked as though profits were going to resume a growing trend. Ted Baker says that full-year profits will be ahead of last year's, despite a disappointing Christmas, albeit below the £9 million analysts had been forecasting.

Investors, however, are starting to question the growth story.

That is entirely sensible - the wonder is that they did not do it before. Star retailer after star retailer - DFS Furniture, JJB Sports, John David Sports, and Electronics Boutique, not to mention older examples such as Tie Rack and Sock Shop - has demonstrated that gravity does eventually bring soaring sales down to earth.

Buy them only if you are confident you can spot the right time to head for the door.

Small is beautiful

Last year was another good year for small companies. A 2.8 per cent rise in the FTSE All Share index may not sound that exciting - and was well behind 1999, when the index surged by more than 50 per cent. But it was comfortably ahead of the market, as measured by the 8 per cent fall in the FTSE 100.

Much of the difference can be attributed to one key feature of the small cap index: it includes virtually no telecoms stocks.

Just three telecoms stocks - Vodafone, BT and Cable & Wireless - make up 15 per cent of the FTSE 100 index. None of them exactly shone last year.

There may not be many small telecoms companies, but there are plenty of other types of technology businesses in the index. If you include biotechnology stocks, the proportion is close to a fifth, compared with just 5 per cent for the FTSE 100.

That explains the staggering outperformance of small caps in 1999, when tech stocks were all the rage.

It also explains why the small cap index has risen by more than 4 per cent already this year, four times faster than the rest of the market. The cut in US interest rates helped markets generally, but it gave the technology sector in particular a real fillip. The Nasdaq has risen by a quarter since the start of the year.

But technology shares are still not cheap by any conventional definition. And there is still no real evidence to show how a slowdown in the US economy will affect their performance.

There is a real risk that the renewed optimism about the technology sector will prove just as misguided as the frenzy of buying in 1999.

If so, the small cap sector could find it hard to outperform again this year. That does not mean investors should avoid the sector altogether. It does mean they should be careful what they buy.

Baan storming

It is so long since Invensys produced any good news that the mere fact of a statement without a profits warning would have been greeted with relief. The fact that it described a bit of a recovery at Baan, the software engineer whose acquisition seemed to start Invensys' problems, was enough to send the shares soaring by more than 5 per cent.

It would be wrong to get carried away, however. The 37 per cent rise in Baan's revenues in the three months to December compares with the previous quarter, when Baan's fortunes were at an all-time low.

Compared with the same period in 1999, revenues are still around 25 per cent down and, as Invensys admits, 'the challenge remains to return sales to their historic high'.

There are some encouraging signs. Allen Yurko, Invensys's chief executive, was confident that returning Baan to financial stability would be enough to help it win back business.

That seems to be confirmed by the 162 new customers and 12 new contracts it has won since the deal was completed. Baan's performance has also been helped by the promised cost cuts, including the loss of 1,000 jobs.

There is, however, still some way to go before Invensys can restore its credibility. For a start, investors will want to see what profits it can make from the increased revenues at Baan.

Then there is the question of how the rest of the group is performing - an update on that will be given just before its March year-end.

Invensys's shares have risen strongly since they touched 118p immediately following the profits warning last September. They are high enough for now.

Take its new head office, the imaginatively named Ugly Brown Building, which includes space to display its collections and a rather grand restaurant which is, according to the finance director 'a bit more than a staff canteen'. Then there is a spanking new distribution warehouse, which it has yet to expand enough to fill. Then there is the cost of taking the brand into Europe and the US. Such costs were already taking their toll in the first half of the year: they wiped out the benefit of a 24 per cent rise in sales and meant that pre-tax profits fell by more than a quarter. The City was prepared to wear this - provided it looked as though profits were going to resume a growing trend. Ted Baker says that full-year profits will be ahead of last year's, despite a disappointing Christmas, albeit below the £9 million analysts had been forecasting. Investors, however, are starting to question the growth story. That is entirely sensible - the wonder is that they did not do it before. Star retailer after star retailer - DFS Furniture, JJB Sports, John David Sports, and Electronics Boutique, not to mention older examples such as Tie Rack and Sock Shop - has demonstrated that gravity does eventually bring soaring sales down to earth. Buy them only if you are confident you can spot the right time to head for the door. Small is beautiful Last year was another good year for small companies. A 2.8 per cent rise in the FTSE All Share index may not sound that exciting - and was well behind 1999, when the index surged by more than 50 per cent. But it was comfortably ahead of the market, as measured by the 8 per cent fall in the FTSE 100. Much of the difference can be attributed to one key feature of the small cap index: it includes virtually no telecoms stocks. Just three telecoms stocks - Vodafone, BT and Cable & Wireless - make up 15 per cent of the FTSE 100 index. None of them exactly shone last year. There may not be many small telecoms companies, but there are plenty of other types of technology businesses in the index. If you include biotechnology stocks, the proportion is close to a fifth, compared with just 5 per cent for the FTSE 100. That explains the staggering outperformance of small caps in 1999, when tech stocks were all the rage. It also explains why the small cap index has risen by more than 4 per cent already this year, four times faster than the rest of the market. The cut in US interest rates helped markets generally, but it gave the technology sector in particular a real fillip. The Nasdaq has risen by a quarter since the start of the year. But technology shares are still not cheap by any conventional definition. And there is still no real evidence to show how a slowdown in the US economy will affect their performance. There is a real risk that the renewed optimism about the technology sector will prove just as misguided as the frenzy of buying in 1999. If so, the small cap sector could find it hard to outperform again this year. That does not mean investors should avoid the sector altogether. It does mean they should be careful what they buy. Baan storming It is so long since Invensys produced any good news that the mere fact of a statement without a profits warning would have been greeted with relief. The fact that it described a bit of a recovery at Baan, the software engineer whose acquisition seemed to start Invensys' problems, was enough to send the shares soaring by more than 5 per cent. It would be wrong to get carried away, however. The 37 per cent rise in Baan's revenues in the three months to December compares with the previous quarter, when Baan's fortunes were at an all-time low. Compared with the same period in 1999, revenues are still around 25 per cent down and, as Invensys admits, 'the challenge remains to return sales to their historic high'. There are some encouraging signs. Allen Yurko, Invensys's chief executive, was confident that returning Baan to financial stability would be enough to help it win back business. That seems to be confirmed by the 162 new customers and 12 new contracts it has won since the deal was completed. Baan's performance has also been helped by the promised cost cuts, including the loss of 1,000 jobs. There is, however, still some way to go before Invensys can restore its credibility. For a start, investors will want to see what profits it can make from the increased revenues at Baan. Then there is the question of how the rest of the group is performing - an update on that will be given just before its March year-end. Invensys's shares have risen strongly since they touched 118p immediately following the profits warning last September. They are high enough for now.

webTitle: UK catches a cold - waiting on a freezing platform

fields.headline: UK catches a cold - waiting on a freezing platform
fields.trailText: The men from Davos, they say, don't talk up a recession. The danger, they say, is that the world will end up talking itself bust, despite the fact that - actually - things are ticking along quite nicely, thank you very much. Instead the great and the good gathered at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland would rather we caught the Pollyanna bug, the ability to retain a sunny disposition against all the odds.
fields.body:
The men from Davos, they say, don't talk up a recession. The danger, they say, is that the world will end up talking itself bust, despite the fact that - actually - things are ticking along quite nicely, thank you very much. Instead the great and the good gathered at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland would rather we caught the Pollyanna bug, the ability to retain a sunny disposition against all the odds.

Unfortunately, despite their best efforts to convince us of the numerous reasons to be cheerful, the facts don't really fit their case. The news that Alan Greenspan has performed a spectacular U-turn, coming out in favour of US tax cuts in a frantic bid to stimulate the American economy, paints a gloomy picture. The world's most powerful central banker has already cut US interest rates by half a percentage point this year. The fact that the committed monetarist has become an overnight convert to fiscal policy underlines the mounting seriousness of the situation.

This has not escaped the attention of US consumers. According to the University of Michigan's Index of Consumer Sentiment, confidence among US customers is plunging. It dropped five points this month, following a nine-point slide in December.This was the third-largest two-month drop since the survey started in 1978. Significantly, the two steepest drops preceded the US recessions of 1980 and 1990.

Admittedly, economists are divided on whether the US is heading for a full-blown recession or just a slowdown. But this is to miss the point, which is that the good times have stopped rolling. And the danger now is that a US slowdown will hit the fragile Far Eastern economies as they claw their way back from the abyss of two years ago.

Many companies in the Far East, Japanese ones in particular, have failed to learn the lessons of the past. An alarming and growing debt mountain is a terrifying symbol of the region's continued resistance to widespread structural reform.

But what of the UK? When the US sneezes we catch a cold, runs the cliché. But hang on, this time things are different, we are told by the optimists. There are no signs that the US's problems are being exported over here, they say. But unfortunately - again - the facts don't match the line. Britain ran up a record £2.8 billion trade deficit with countries outside the European Union last month. The main reason? A 10 per cent drop in exports to North America.

All right, the US accounts for only 15 per cent of UK exports, but a slowdown across the Atlantic will still affect us - and not only for economic reasons.

We look across the pond for our corporate inspiration, our business models, our entrepreneurial flair, our visions of the future. They may be thousands of miles away, but the tears lachrymose Americans shed into their lattes will be felt from Dover to Dundee. As the men from Davos know, economics is often a case of mind over matter.

Friday's UK growth figures didn't bring much cheer. They showed that gross domestic product grew by only 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter of last year, and 2.4 per cent year-on-year. The City had been predicting figures of 0.5 per cent and 3 per cent respectively, and the pessimists point out that economic growth is now at its slowest for two years.

But the main reasons for the disappointing figures were wet weather and a slowdown in industrial production. The weather banjaxed the already crippled rail network, so the country came grinding to a halt - and UK production dropped. Friday's figures offer a definitive case for the UK benefiting from major infrastructure investment.

When the economy suffers because of an ailing rail network, the fate of thousands of jobs is literally on the line.

webTitle: Lacklustre St Michael keeps its halo polished

fields.headline: Lacklustre St Michael keeps its halo polished
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's clothing sales may have fallen for the third Christmas in a row - and profits have been declining for equally as long - but the retailer is still confident that its recovery is on track. Alan McWalter, strategy director, is clear about what needs to be done: 'We need to get the adult clothing offer right. That is critical, and there has been no deviation.'
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's clothing sales may have fallen for the third Christmas in a row - and profits have been declining for equally as long - but the retailer is still confident that its recovery is on track. Alan McWalter, strategy director, is clear about what needs to be done: 'We need to get the adult clothing offer right. That is critical, and there has been no deviation.'

Chairman Luc Vandevelde is equally clear about how to do that: 'We must offer adult clothing ranges of consistently better design and appeal.'

No surprise there: customers have been telling M&S that for the past three years. But despite repeated promises - then-chief executive Peter Salsbury said a year ago that he had 'started to see improvements emerging'; and in November Vandevelde promised that M&S would have a good Christmas - the retailer has yet to convince that it has a recovery plan.

So far it has resisted temptation to ditch the old strategy, at least on the surface. When Vandevelde arrived a year ago, he threw himself behind the plan drawn up by Salsbury: switch more buying overseas; revamp stores and make them more responsive to local populations; cut head office bureaucracy; and improve the supply chain.

While Vandevelde maintained public support for that plan - about the only thing he has criticised is the speed of its implementation - he has made numerous changes that suggest that, privately, he wants to ditch it. First, and most obvious, he ditched its architect - Salsbury left the group last autumn - and brought in a new UK retailing head, Roger Holmes. There have been numerous other departures, not least the widely respected womenswear head, Sheila Brown.

Consultants, meanwhile, have had a field day. A huge survey of M&S customers - it even asked some of its card holders where they go on holiday - has yielded more detail than anyone could want on exactly who its customers are. But if it knows what they want, M&S has not yet worked out how to provide it.

'We always said it would take time,' says McWalter. 'You can't turn the business around overnight.' But he dismisses suggestions that Vandevelde should have asked for more time - or will need it.

He believes 'the size and scale of the business' and its 'inherent strength' mean M&S will recover where others, such as BhS and Littlewoods - failed. 'We have had a disappointing financial performance; we have also seen an erosion of our standing in customers' eyes. Even so, we are still up there - extremely well perceived as a brand.'

Others are less convinced. There are already whispers that Vandevelde is not up to the job. For M&S, however, a change of chairman could be disastrous. The group has been through more change in the past three years than at any time in its 115-year history. Any more could be fatal.

webTitle: BP joins rush for Alaska's black gold

fields.headline: BP joins rush for Alaska's black gold
fields.trailText: While California fumbles in semi-darkness, George W. Bush has come up with a seemingly simple solution to America's wider energy needs - drill for more oil.
fields.body:
While California fumbles in semi-darkness, George W. Bush has come up with a seemingly simple solution to America's wider energy needs - drill for more oil.

He is in favour of granting licences for drilling in the unspoilt wilderness of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Northern Alaska, home to herds of wild Caribou and Polar bears.

Last week White House spokesman Ari Fleischer said opening up 8 per cent of the 1.5-million-acre coastal plain would form part of a strategy to 'protect America's energy security'.

Environmental groups are gearing up for battle. Athan Manuel of the US Public Interest Research Group (PIRG) says: 'Conservation groups are going to fight this all the way. It will be the biggest environmental issue of the Presidency.'

Alaska may seem far from the UK. However, scrutiny of the companies involved and how they - legitimately - play the Washington game shows that the US-UK special relationship is founded on business as well as politics.

Alaska is synonymous with four oil companies: ExxonMobil, Chevron, Phillips Petroleum - and our very own BP.

Manuel points out that BP dominates the land nearest to the refuge. A licence to drill there would give access to an estimated 3.4 billion barrels of oil at a relatively low investment for BP.

Most of Alaska's 'North Slope', where the refuge lies, has been opened to big oil. But companies which want to exploit the refuge have previously come across opposition at the very top. In 1995, Bill Clinton twice vetoed budget proposals drawn up by congressional Republicans which included revenues from oil in the Arctic refuge.

But the oil companies have lobbied assiduously. Arco - the US company with Alaskan interests which BP bought for $28.6 billion last year - donated $2.3 million to the Republican party, between 1992 and 1999.

Because BP is a dominant Alaskan player, it had to sell Arco's Alaskan assets to Phillips for $7bn to gain regulatory approval. Phillips' interests in Alaska will be pressed strongly in the White House. Bush has appointed two of the company's senior officials - Don Duncan and CJ Silas - as transitional policy advisers.

For its part, BP has played a forceful hand, legitimately lobbying influential Alaskan Republicans. It paid into campaign funds for Alaskan senators Frank Murkowski and Ted Stevens, along with Mississippi senator Trent Lott, known to favour development in the refuge. It also gave $12,000 to Republican representative Don Young and $2,000 to the Bush presidential campaign.

Between 1997 and 1999, BP also contributed $90,000 to an organisation called Arctic Power - a group set up to lobby congress to open up the refuge.

Nevertheless, BP faces opposition. PIRG and other environmental groups are filing a shareholder resolution to try to stop the company drilling. Manuel says: 'The Arctic is one of the last unspoilt places on Earth. We don't think it is worth devastating that for six months of oil.'

webTitle: Retailers all over the shop

fields.headline: Retailers all over the shop
fields.standfirst: As Marks & Spencer struggles with yet another set of shrunken sales figures,  Heather Connon  looks at the history of rescue operations mounted for ailing high street chains, and asks whether the latest one can succeed
fields.trailText: As Marks & Spencer struggles with yet another set of shrunken sales figures, Heather Connon looks at the history of rescue operations mounted for ailing high street chains, and asks whether the latest one can succeed
fields.body:
'The pace of change in retailing today means Littlewoods is in danger of being left behind. Moreover, the return from its stores is woefully inadequate...'

'What [BhS] lacks is a clear sense of direction and the flair for product design which characterises the new retailing generation.'

Either of these comments could have been made yesterday. In fact, the analysis of Littlewoods' problems is from 1986, and the one about BhS from 1985. Fifteen years on, both chains are still trying to solve the most intractable problem in retailing: winning back customers.

Luc Vandevelde, who is struggling to do just that as chairman of Marks & Spencer, will prefer not to think about these precedents. He should. Britain's high streets are littered with stores that tried, and failed, to reinvent themselves.

Successful recoveries, by contrast, are few: Tesco and Asda in food; perhaps Next and Debenhams in clothing. Indeed, some would quibble at the inclusion of the last two. Next, in particular, had never lost touch with what the customer wanted: it simply expanded too fast under George Davies. Its problem, was financial - it had run out of cash - rather than strategic. Selling the mail order business effectively solved it.

It is far easier to name the failures. As well as BhS and Littlewoods, C&A, which has now given up the struggle and closed down, Hamleys, Laura Ashley (although recent figures are more encouraging) and Liberty have lurched from recovery strategy to recovery strategy, with little to show for them.

So why are retailers so hard to turn around? Philip Dorgan, analyst at WestLB Panmure, says the key is the relationship with the consumer. 'It happens over a period. Consumers are unhappy and have changed their perception of you. Recovery depends on changing that perception, and that takes time.'

Vandevelde doubtless thought he was being conservative when he told the City it would take him two years to produce results. One year and a fourth set of falling sales figures later, it is clear he was hopelessly optimistic.

Geoff Mulcahy and the team which took over a faded Woolworths in 1982 asked for seven years. The brand may now be struggling again, but the profits - and more importantly, the cashflow - from its recovery in the Eighties allowed Kingfisher to build the do-it-yourself powerhouse which is B&Q.

Then chief executive John Beckett told shareholders it would take two years to work out what needed to be done, three years to put it right and another two to bring it up to speed. Fortunately, he was allowed that time, partly because he discovered the hidden gem that was B&Q. Its growth pacified shareholders while Woolworths was being turned around.

But the City was less short-termist then: shareholders would be unlikely now to agree to a seven-year recovery plan. Nigel Whittaker, one of the architects of Kingfisher's recovery, thinks investors would accept five years, however.

Bosses who give in to that pressure - or, like Vandevelde, set deadlines which invite it - risk doing their cause more harm than good. Clothing orders have to be placed as much as six months in advance. Indeed, most fashion buyers are already thinking of what will be in their 2002 collections. The risk is that, by setting too short a timetable for recovery, executives will be rushed into making the wrong decisions, simply to produce short-term results. Over the long term, however, the business will be harmed.

Setting too short a timetable increases the risk that the company will fall into the second key pitfall: not giving people a chance to prove themselves. Many of the firms that have struggled to reinvent themselves have had regular management changes. Littlewoods went through 12 chief executives in as many months. Storehouse, which used to own BhS and Mothercare, was run by six bosses in 13 years.

It is no coincidence that Next, the most consistent high street performer, has been run by the same man - David Jones - for 12 years.

About the only thing that every new boss is clear about is what the previous incumbent did wrong and, usually, they waste no time in changing it. In even the best organisations that can be extremely disruptive; in a business where entire strategies are ditched every two years, it can lead to paralysis.

Barry Gibson, who has survived as chief executive of Littlewoods for three years, said the initial reaction to his plans was an air of disbelief: 'We've heard all this before. We've had people coming in, saying they're going to do things, but we'll stop them.'

M&S is in danger of using up too many bosses. Only one of the directors who served with Sir Richard Greenbury survives - finance director Robert Colvill - and there have been sweeping changes both at the top and in senior management. Peter Salsbury, who won the highly public battle to succeed Greenbury as chairman, lasted less than two years in the post and was always dogged by questions - some of them from within the company - about his ability to do the top job.

Similar questions are already dogging Vandevelde - partly because he set himself too short a time for recovery, partly because he seems to keep changing strategy, and partly because he is clearly not improving sales.

Another new boss, Roger Holmes, arrived at the start of the year to head the UK retail business. He is likely to make changes of his own, and will have a hard time selling them to a change-weary workforce.

Retail recoveries seem to need a retailer to make them work. A business which is already running successfully may benefit from bringing in an outsider. One which is in trouble cannot usually afford that luxury. Someone from outside the industry will take time to learn, time which should be spent addressing the urgent problems.

That is shown by the successful recoveries: Archie Norman, who turned Asda around, had already done that for Woolworths; Terry Leahy, credited with rescuing Tesco in the early Nineties, was its marketing director; David Jones at Next was groomed at Great Universal Stores; Carlos Criado-Perez, who has Safeway's sales growing again, was at Wal-Mart.

Keith Edelman and Michael Julien, two of the Storehouse bosses, came from the media and the drinks business respectively. Vandevelde is a retailer, but from a European food chain, not a British clothing one.

'If you have not traded in a country,' said one executive from a rival retailer, 'you do not know the personnel in a country, and you do not know the industry. You have a tough mountain to climb.'

The temptation for outsiders is to turn to consultants. M&S has made full use of them - new boy Holmes has a consultancy background - with little in the way of visible results so far.

Investors, however, do seem to believe M&S will recover. They were buying its shares last week, despite the dismal trading statement, leaving them more highly valued than Next's. But the group has seen poor sales and an avalanche of bad press for more than two years. The longer this goes on, the harder recovery will become.

WestLB's Dorgan says: 'People get very conservative - scared of doing the wrong thing - so they mess it up even more, and more sales are lost. To avoid losing profit, management tries to cut costs by taking out staff or offering poorer goods. The service deteriorates and the customers get even more unhappy. It is a vicious spiral.'

M&S must break out of that spiral if it is to recover. There is no guarantee it will. Thirty years ago, Littlewoods was far more popular than M&S. It has failed to rebound. Can Vandevelde do it for Marks?

The brand may now be struggling again, but the profits - and more importantly, the cashflow - from its recovery in the Eighties allowed Kingfisher to build the do-it-yourself powerhouse which is B&Q. Then chief executive John Beckett told shareholders it would take two years to work out what needed to be done, three years to put it right and another two to bring it up to speed. Fortunately, he was allowed that time, partly because he discovered the hidden gem that was B&Q. Its growth pacified shareholders while Woolworths was being turned around. But the City was less short-termist then: shareholders would be unlikely now to agree to a seven-year recovery plan. Nigel Whittaker, one of the architects of Kingfisher's recovery, thinks investors would accept five years, however. Bosses who give in to that pressure - or, like Vandevelde, set deadlines which invite it - risk doing their cause more harm than good. Clothing orders have to be placed as much as six months in advance. Indeed, most fashion buyers are already thinking of what will be in their 2002 collections. The risk is that, by setting too short a timetable for recovery, executives will be rushed into making the wrong decisions, simply to produce short-term results. Over the long term, however, the business will be harmed. Setting too short a timetable increases the risk that the company will fall into the second key pitfall: not giving people a chance to prove themselves. Many of the firms that have struggled to reinvent themselves have had regular management changes. Littlewoods went through 12 chief executives in as many months. Storehouse, which used to own BhS and Mothercare, was run by six bosses in 13 years. It is no coincidence that Next, the most consistent high street performer, has been run by the same man - David Jones - for 12 years. About the only thing that every new boss is clear about is what the previous incumbent did wrong and, usually, they waste no time in changing it. In even the best organisations that can be extremely disruptive; in a business where entire strategies are ditched every two years, it can lead to paralysis. Barry Gibson, who has survived as chief executive of Littlewoods for three years, said the initial reaction to his plans was an air of disbelief: 'We've heard all this before. We've had people coming in, saying they're going to do things, but we'll stop them.' M&S is in danger of using up too many bosses. Only one of the directors who served with Sir Richard Greenbury survives - finance director Robert Colvill - and there have been sweeping changes both at the top and in senior management. Peter Salsbury, who won the highly public battle to succeed Greenbury as chairman, lasted less than two years in the post and was always dogged by questions - some of them from within the company - about his ability to do the top job. Similar questions are already dogging Vandevelde - partly because he set himself too short a time for recovery, partly because he seems to keep changing strategy, and partly because he is clearly not improving sales. Another new boss, Roger Holmes, arrived at the start of the year to head the UK retail business. He is likely to make changes of his own, and will have a hard time selling them to a change-weary workforce. Retail recoveries seem to need a retailer to make them work. A business which is already running successfully may benefit from bringing in an outsider. One which is in trouble cannot usually afford that luxury. Someone from outside the industry will take time to learn, time which should be spent addressing the urgent problems. That is shown by the successful recoveries: Archie Norman, who turned Asda around, had already done that for Woolworths; Terry Leahy, credited with rescuing Tesco in the early Nineties, was its marketing director; David Jones at Next was groomed at Great Universal Stores; Carlos Criado-Perez, who has Safeway's sales growing again, was at Wal-Mart. Keith Edelman and Michael Julien, two of the Storehouse bosses, came from the media and the drinks business respectively. Vandevelde is a retailer, but from a European food chain, not a British clothing one. 'If you have not traded in a country,' said one executive from a rival retailer, 'you do not know the personnel in a country, and you do not know the industry. You have a tough mountain to climb.' The temptation for outsiders is to turn to consultants. M&S has made full use of them - new boy Holmes has a consultancy background - with little in the way of visible results so far. Investors, however, do seem to believe M&S will recover. They were buying its shares last week, despite the dismal trading statement, leaving them more highly valued than Next's. But the group has seen poor sales and an avalanche of bad press for more than two years. The longer this goes on, the harder recovery will become. WestLB's Dorgan says: 'People get very conservative - scared of doing the wrong thing - so they mess it up even more, and more sales are lost. To avoid losing profit, management tries to cut costs by taking out staff or offering poorer goods. The service deteriorates and the customers get even more unhappy. It is a vicious spiral.' M&S must break out of that spiral if it is to recover. There is no guarantee it will. Thirty years ago, Littlewoods was far more popular than M&S. It has failed to rebound. Can Vandevelde do it for Marks?

webTitle: Public squalor - UK rules

fields.headline: Public squalor - UK rules
fields.trailText: The other day I received two pages torn from the London Evening Standard with an almost indecipherable scrawl at the top of one of them. This seemed to be drawing my attention to a page on which there were three headlines: 'Monika has become a (role) model engineer'; 'Thousands of Londoners set for water bill rebate'; and 'Kidnap woman flees Britain'. I could not quite see their relevance to this column.
fields.body:
The other day I received two pages torn from the London Evening Standard with an almost indecipherable scrawl at the top of one of them. This seemed to be drawing my attention to a page on which there were three headlines: 'Monika has become a (role) model engineer'; 'Thousands of Londoners set for water bill rebate'; and 'Kidnap woman flees Britain'. I could not quite see their relevance to this column.

Then, over the page, I realised there was an article by the psephologist Peter Kellner, based on some very important work by my old friend, Professor Robin Marris. On close inspection the note overleaf had been written by the good professor himself.

At a time when the most desperate Conservative Party for generations is trying to match the Government's spending plans almost on a weekly basis, Marris's recent work constitutes a timely contribution to what has already become the election debate, and the concomitant question, 'What kind of society do we want to live in?'

For a start Marris demonstrates that the British are 'not as well off as we think'. The Blair government has often had trouble with its boasts about the economy, but broadly speaking it tends to argue that all the bad things are attributable to what happened in 1979-1997, and the good life miraculously began on 1 May 1997.

Recently Britain has appeared to climb the league of economic prosperity, to a position where, in the Group of Seven, it comes third after the US and Japan - so it can tell German foreign minister Joshka Fischer and all those Europeans a thing or two.

But Marris, a leading expert in international economic comparisons, points out that such ratings have been distorted by what almost everybody agrees has been the recent unsustainably high exchange rate. When measured in terms of national price levels (or purchasing power parities) the UK comes fifth behind Germany and Italy.

More important to the debate about where we go from here with 'tax and spend' is that, out of annual national income, we in Britain spend more on personal consumption and less on health, education and investment than most other countries. The popular impression that there is less 'public squalor' across the Channel is borne out by the statistics.

When it comes to what economists term 'the distribution of income' Marris finds: 'Well-paid people in Britain have more spending power than their continental counterparts, while people at the low end of the income scale are worse off than all except the Italians.' Marris finds that this is because 'the UK is the least equal of the major European economies', having wider differentials between high- and low-paid workers, a less progressive tax system and a less generous welfare system.

Perhaps the most staggering finding is that, according to Marris's calculations, Britain comes bottom of the G7 in health spending, with Germany and France spending respectively 37 per cent and 64 per cent more per person. The implication is that, despite all the preaching of the Thatcher, Major and Blair governments to the Continentals on how to run an economy, when it comes to quality of life - which is what economics, in the end, is all about - we have a few lessons to learn from them.

The Blair/Brown plans for a massive increase in public sector investment have come none too soon. No wonder the Conservatives are nervous of appearing as the party whose tax cuts would come at the expense of cutting back on current attempts to redress the balance.

As it happens, Marris's calculations reached me shortly after the text of a most interesting lecture by Professor Anthony B Atkinson, one of the world's leading economists on the subject of welfare and the distribution of income. Atkinson challenges the received wisdom that growing inequality is somehow the inevitable result of globalisation or 'market forces', and argues that much depends on government action and what society perceives as the appropriate 'norm'. ( Is Rising Inequality Inevitable? A Critique of the Transatlantic Consensus, published by the World Institute for Development Economics Research.)

Thus, in the UK between 1977 and 1984, inequality of 'market income' increased ('market income' being before taxes and government transfers), but 'the redistributive impact of cash transfers and taxation increased by enough to offset the more unequal market incomes... After 1984, however, the story is quite different, reflecting a major reduction in the progressivity of income taxation and cutbacks in benefit levels and coverage.' Inequality in 'market incomes' continued to rise between 1984 and 1990, but inequality in post-tax income 'increased more sharply'.

Atkinson believes we may not simply have witnessed a phenomenon whereby 'globalisation' hits unskilled workers in industrial countries, but that attitudes too may have changed, with 'a shift away from a redistributive pay norm to one where market forces dominate'. He thinks shifting 'norms' may have affected both variations in pay and the willingness of governments to redistribute.

He concludes: 'The fact that the driving force is social in origin, rather than trade or technology, means more scope for political leadership.'

For most of its brief life, the party we know - or perhaps knew - as 'New Labour' was paralysed by its acceptance of the social norms that evolved under the previous governments it used to criticise. There have recently been signs of a change, and indications that Gordon Brown would like to go a lot further in disavowing the Thatcherite inheritance. And about time, too.

webTitle: Breare brews formal bid for Wolves

fields.headline: Breare brews formal bid for Wolves
fields.trailText: Old Etonian Robert Breare will this week formally launch a bid for Wolverhampton & Dudley, the UK's largest regional pubs and brewing business.
fields.body:
Old Etonian Robert Breare will this week formally launch a bid for Wolverhampton & Dudley, the UK's largest regional pubs and brewing business.

The 47-year-old leisure entrepreneur will offer the Wolves board something under 500p a share, valuing the business at up to £465 million. City sources say Breare hopes to secure a board recommendation imminently.

It is thought that Breare, who is backed by venture capitalist firm Botts, will share out the Wolves pubs with Enterprise Inns, the 2,600-strong leased and tenanted pub estate run by Ted Tuppen. Tuppen could take up to 1,000 Wolves' pubs at the bottom end of the retail estate.

Breare would have the 700 best-managed pubs to add to Noble House Leisure, his restaurant company, which last November bought Oriental Restaurant Group.

He will also keep hold of the best brewing assets owned by W&D, especially the Pedigree brand, which is produced at Burton on Trent. W&D has three other breweries: in Wolverhampton, Mansfield and Hartlepool.

Breare's main competition is a management buyout led by David Thompson, which has secured backing. But that bid is not expected to beat Breare.

If Breare, a Cambridge rowing blue, triumphs, the win will cap a six-month saga of offers, stand-offs and speculation.

Wolves has been forced into a sale, having seen its shares crash from a high of 618.5p in 1999 to a low of 322p last summer. It announced a sale of the business to enhance shareholder value.

Results have subsequently improved. Last December the company reported full-year profits of £65m, up from £50.2m. Turnover rose from £415.5m to £598.8m.

There are already more than 5,000 pubs up for sale in Britain.

Guy Hands' Principal Finance Group is favourite to scoop the 3,000 Whitbread pubs currently on the market. Bass is selling 900 units and Scottish & Newcastle is ditching 740 of its 2,000-strong estate.

Before his interest in Wolves, Breare's experience of the brewing sector amounted to a year spent as chief executive of InnSpired, the beer and pubs arm of Alchemy Partners, run by Jon Moulton, in 1999.

Previously he worked in the publishing, hotel and hospitality sectors.

webTitle: Own goal: FA must find £100m to save Wembley dream

fields.headline: Own goal: FA must find £100m to save Wembley dream
fields.trailText: The Football Association will be told this week to plough £100 million into the Wembley Stadium redevelopment or risk the £660m project collapsing completely, writes Denis Campbell .
fields.body:
The Football Association will be told this week to plough £100 million into the Wembley Stadium redevelopment or risk the £660m project collapsing completely, writes Denis Campbell .

The soccer chiefs will also have to agree to sink up to £50m every year into the stadium to help persuade the City to lend the £300m-£400m that is needed to rebuild the stadium.

Sir Rodney Walker, chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, will tell the FA, WNSL's parent company, that without both guarantees, banks will again refuse to get involved, leaving the showpiece project dead in the water.

The WNSL board meets on Wednesday to work out exactly what the FA's financial commitments need to be. The FA board assembles the next morning to accept or reject the plan.

Banks have told Walker that unless the FA assumes a significant share of the risk involved in the project they will, for a second time, refuse to lend money. Given such a stark choice, the FA is likely to agree both the £100m cash injection and the extra annual payments to WNSL for England and FA Cup games there. If they do, WNSL will go back to the City and try for a second time to raise the money. Insiders say that with ex-WNSL chairman Ken Bates no longer involved, and income from 14,000 expensive seats now much more certain, they are confident of convincing a syndicate of banks to gamble on Wembley's future viability.

'The design of the stadium won't change much, but the way the financial risk will now be shared out should do the trick,' said an insider.

webTitle: My money: Diane Abbott

fields.headline: Tough talker who's scared of being poor
fields.standfirst: I never open the taxman's letters, Labour MP Diane Abbott tells Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: I never open the taxman's letters, Labour MP Diane Abbott tells Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Labour MP Diane Abbott confesses she's terrible at dealing with money. 'I always think that something will turn up,' she says.

'When I was in my twenties and just down from Cambridge I had a relatively large income for my age. (She was a civil servant and then a TV presenter). The lasting effect was that I felt I could spend what I liked and it wouldn't be a problem.'

But running parallel to these feelings is a huge worry over money - something she attributes to 'a deep, abiding fear of being destitute'.

This is hardly surprising, perhaps, for someone whose parents left school at 14, arrived penniless in Britain from Jamaica in the Fifties and struggled to get by on her father's income as a London factory worker.

In public terms, these fears have propelled her to take an open stand on poverty which is not now popular with New Labour. The MP for Hackney North wants the minimum wage increased by 30 per cent and has always argued for the basic state pension to be linked to earnings, rather than retail prices.

'One of my concerns with New Labour is that they are too concerned with Middle England and aren't doing enough for the very poorest.'

In private terms, her fear of money has often made her ostrich-like. 'I don't open letters from the taxman,' says Abbott, a 47-year old divorcée. 'And I used not to open letters from the bank.'

Her relationship with her bank is better since she opened an account with First Direct: she can check it through the internet - 'a less emotional way of dealing with my affairs than opening brown envelopes'.

So how does she cope if she cannot bear to open Inland Revenue letters? 'I cannot praise the Inland Revenue enough. If you make contact with them and are open, they will help you enormously.'

With the 31 January tax deadline looming, she has her return to sort out. A financial new year resolution was to get it in on time. Despite her fear of money matters, she handles the return herself, having given up on accountants, who, she feels are 'quite bad' at dealing with small incomes. 'Since I started handling my affairs myself, things have gone slightly better.'

One part of her parliamentary life has helped her in her financial life. She spent eight years on the Treasury Select Committee where, despite her lack of a financial background, she became something of a star, never shy of taking the Governor of the Bank of England, or anyone else, to task.

'Matters of banking and finance are too important to be left to white men. Being a woman helped me because I wasn't shy about asking basic questions. Quite often, my male colleagues were quite pleased I had asked.'

Her directness means that, despite her obvious talent, she has little hope of becoming a New Labour Minister. She was not much appreciated in 10 Downing Street for supporting London Mayor Ken Livingstone, who was thrown out of the party last year.

She says: 'Honesty in politics does not guarantee you promotion but, coming as I do from an underprivileged immigrant background, it's a tremendous honour to be a backbencher.'

One other factor has had a big effect on her attitude to her finances: the birth of her son nine years ago. 'Having a child focuses you much more on financial matters. It's made me think much more about pensions and Isas, because I need to plan ahead.'

webTitle: Commons probe for BBC web ads

fields.headline: Commons probe for BBC web ads
fields.trailText: The BBC's controversial plans to show advertising on some of its websites will come under fire in parliament this week. Rivals are terrified at the prospect of the corporation showing ads on its BBCNews.com site, which will be aimed at overseas visitors.
fields.body:
The BBC's controversial plans to show advertising on some of its websites will come under fire in parliament this week. Rivals are terrified at the prospect of the corporation showing ads on its BBCNews.com site, which will be aimed at overseas visitors.

On Wednesday the British Internet Publishers Association (Bipa), the body representing the online interests of media companies, will air members' grievances at a hearing of the Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee.

webTitle: Watchdog hobbles Welsh Water plan

fields.headline: Watchdog hobbles Welsh Water plan
fields.trailText: Water regulator Philip Fletcher is expected to agree to controversial proposals for restructuring Welsh Water, formerly owned by multi-utility Hyder - but he is likely to attach onerous conditions to the deal.
fields.body:
Water regulator Philip Fletcher is expected to agree to controversial proposals for restructuring Welsh Water, formerly owned by multi-utility Hyder - but he is likely to attach onerous conditions to the deal.

Industry and regulatory sources say Fletcher is sceptical about the proposals and claim his conditions may make the scheme unviable.

The decision will come after months of lobbying from Welsh MPs and Assembly members, who strongly support the proposals; some Whitehall officials have been opposed to the idea.

Ministers have been split. Fletcher's own attitude to the plans appears to have cooled; he initially appeared to support them.

Under the proposals, Welsh Water will be taken over by Glas Cymru, a non-profit making company owned and controlled by its members, which will finance the company's £1.2 billion investment programme by issuing bonds while contracting out day-to-day operations.

Glas argues that bond finance will lower its cost of capital because it is cheaper than equity. It also claims that it is building up reserves - it bought Welsh Water for less than the value of its assets.

However, sources close to Fletcher indicate that there are three major concerns: the lack of flexibility that debt financing will give Glas to raise capital in future; its ability to control a sub-contractor; and the lack of shareholder incentives to increase efficiency.

There are also concerns that in the long run the regulator may be unable to demand price cuts or allow Welsh Water a lower return on assets without jeopardising its financial position.

One source close to Fletcher said: 'Ofwat went out to consultation on this and there were no problems raised which were insurmountable. He feels he cannot stand in the way. However, whether his proposals will amount to cold water remains to be seen.'

City bond market experts believe the company is financeable, and say it is likely to gain an investment-grade credit rating.
fields.bodyText: Water regulator Philip Fletcher is expected to agree to controversial proposals for restructuring Welsh Water, formerly owned by multi-utility Hyder - but he is likely to attach onerous conditions to the deal. Industry and regulatory sources say Fletcher is sceptical about the proposals and claim his conditions may make the scheme unviable. The decision will come after months of lobbying from Welsh MPs and Assembly members, who strongly support the proposals; some Whitehall officials have been opposed to the idea. Ministers have been split. Fletcher's own attitude to the plans appears to have cooled; he initially appeared to support them. Under the proposals, Welsh Water will be taken over by Glas Cymru, a non-profit making company owned and controlled by its members, which will finance the company's £1.2 billion investment programme by issuing bonds while contracting out day-to-day operations. Glas argues that bond finance will lower its cost of capital because it is cheaper than equity. It also claims that it is building up reserves - it bought Welsh Water for less than the value of its assets. However, sources close to Fletcher indicate that there are three major concerns: the lack of flexibility that debt financing will give Glas to raise capital in future; its ability to control a sub-contractor; and the lack of shareholder incentives to increase efficiency. There are also concerns that in the long run the regulator may be unable to demand price cuts or allow Welsh Water a lower return on assets without jeopardising its financial position. One source close to Fletcher said: 'Ofwat went out to consultation on this and there were no problems raised which were insurmountable. He feels he cannot stand in the way. However, whether his proposals will amount to cold water remains to be seen.' City bond market experts believe the company is financeable, and say it is likely to gain an investment-grade credit rating.

webTitle: Squeeze rules out tax cuts

fields.headline: Squeeze rules out tax cuts
fields.trailText: A pre-election tax cutting bonanza looks to be off the agenda as a softening UK economy and acceleration in spending on public services puts the squeeze on the size of the Treasury's surplus.
fields.body:
A pre-election tax cutting bonanza looks to be off the agenda as a softening UK economy and acceleration in spending on public services puts the squeeze on the size of the Treasury's surplus.

Though final figures will still hand Gordon Brown a surplus of many billions, its size is expected to be far closer to existing Treasury projections of £10 billion than over-optimistic predictions by City analysts at November's pre-Budget report.

Some predicted the Treasury would have an 'excess surplus' of another £10bn, but now many have scaled back their predictions to an excess surplus of as little as £1.75bn.

'We always made it clear that it was premature to make speculative forecasts on the basis of just a few months' data,' said a Treasury spokesman.

This limits the scope for cutting taxes without altering the fiscal stance. And were the Treasury to change the fiscal position, the Bank of England would be less likely to cut interest rates.

Cautious Treasury assumptions about growth, world oil prices, and other external factors look to have been justified by a raft of weaker economic figures.

Corporate profit warnings were up again in the last quarter of 2000, according to Ernst & Young. The IT sector was particularly affected, accounting for 22 per cent of the 77 warnings.

Similarly, Experian, the credit ratings company, will issue a devastating report on the profitability of British companies in the second quarter of last year.

The return on capital employed by British companies fell by 11 per cent year on year, the fifth successive quarterly fall. This is the longest sustained period of declining profitability since the last recession.

Such data means that tax revenues will not be as strong as expected. Matters are further complicated by the early receipt of revenues following a change to quarterly payment of corporate taxes.

Set against a marked acceleration in public expenditure as government departments learn how to spend again, the slowdown reduces room for manoeuvre over any tax cuts.

Along with Friday's unexpectedly low figure for fourth-quarter growth - 0.3 per cent - the developments are expected to tip the balance of the Monetary Policy Committee in favour of a rate cut.

John Butler, UK economist at HSBC, says a rate cut next week is a 'done deal'. He also predicts that the Treasury will have only £1.75bn 'excess' to play with, assuming the adoption of tax cuts on transport that are now under consultation.

'Although the current expectation is for an interest rate cut, the Government is already offering a substantial fiscal stimulus with the increase in public spending,' argues Martin Weale, director of the National Institute for Economic and Social Research. 'To increase this further would create macroeconomic risks.'

webTitle: News: Anger at granny bonds cut

fields.headline: Anger at granny bonds cut
fields.trailText: Elderly people are being advised to shun National Savings bonds after the their savings rates were reduced yet again.
fields.body:
Elderly people are being advised to shun National Savings bonds after the their savings rates were reduced yet again.

Independent financial advisers called the cuts, of as much as 0.4 per cent, a 'disgrace'.

The bonds are targeted at people over 60 with at least £5,000 to invest. In return for tying up their money they get a monthly income with a fixed rate of interest.

The rate on the new National Savings five-year Pensioner Bonds is 4.75 per cent, down 0.3 per cent, while the rate on the one-year bonds is now 4.9 per cent, 0.4 per cent lower.

National Savings says lower inflation is squeezing market yields.

But independent financial adviser Baronworth Investment services says better rates can be obtained by investing in guaranteed monthly income bonds from life insurers and building societies. You 'should not, on any account, invest in National Savings pensioner bonds', says Baronworth's Colin Jackson.

'Once more National Savings have sneaked in a cut in their rates. Unfortunately it is pensioners who bear the brunt. If only they would seek advice or spend some time researching the market they would be far better off.'

For one-year investments, he recommends AIG's guaranteed monthly income bond, which pays a gross equivalent of 5.66 per cent. Returns are net of tax, which cannot be reclaimed, making the bond unsuitable for non-taxpayers.

Rates on National Savings cash mini-Isas, and income bonds are unchanged.

 Contact Baronworth on 0208 518 1218.

webTitle: A rough old time down the club

fields.headline: A rough old time down the club
fields.standfirst: Last year's rollercoaster left many investment groups nursing bruises, writes  Colin Cottell
fields.trailText: Last year's rollercoaster left many investment groups nursing bruises.
fields.body:
It was bound to happen. Never mind. The Brass Monkey Investment Club had a good run for its money. With its shares worth £28,000 in November 1999, the club changed strategy to get in on the technology boom. 'We rode the crest of the wave,' says club treasurer Mark Goodson. And how. On 4 January 2000 the value of the club's fund had risen to £46,000.

Unfortunately, the club was one of many UK investment clubs hit by the shake-out which saw the FTSE 100 end December 10 per cent lower on the year. 'In all the eupho ria, we forgot that the market can go the other way,' admits Goodson. Before Christmas, the value of the club's investments had fallen to £36,000.

Many other clubs forced to sit out the last few months of 2000 were hit hard. Some, however, bucked the trend. Elizabeth Swaloc's Investment Club, based in Toddington, Bedfordshire, began life in 1994. It lost money for the first two years, but since then its fortunes have been transformed. The club's portfolio, for which members paid £43,500, is now worth £62,000, and the FTSE's fall has passed it by almost unnoticed.

'We are just not bothered by the FTSE and never have been,' says Dick Peake, the club's secretary. Last year saw prices of the club's shares in Amey plc rise by 62.4 per cent, those in Centrica by 47.7 per cent, and in Reliance Security by 44.7 per cent. Shares in Chime Communications and WSP were up 24.3 per cent and 23.0 per cent respectively.

Even in the final four weeks of 2000, while stock markets were falling to a backdrop of worldwide dotcom doom and bust, six of the club's nine shares recorded price increases of between 4 and 12 per cent. Of the other three, even the worst performing, WSP, was down only 12 per cent. The only significant loss was £300 on shares in Umeco, bought in October. Peake dismisses it as 'not something we're going to worry about'. Even here the club may have the last laugh: the shares rose by 4.2 per cent in the final four weeks of the year.

As well as seeing the value of their portfolio increase, the club's 20 members have had some fun along the way - even with tech stocks. They made a profit of £4,000 on shares in DCS Group, which they originally bought at £3.32 in February 1997. In March last year the shares' value had rocketed up to £20. As of 15 December DCS was worth 92p. The club sold half at £14.85, and half at £6.90. 'Then we sat and laughed,' says Peake. All the way to the bank.

The club's strategy has served it well. 'We look for growth stocks and prefer the smaller ones that nobody is talking about. Neither highly speculative nor boring blue chips,' says Peake. The club acts like a unit trust or an investment trust, and considers day trading to be totally unsuitable for investment clubs, which meet infrequently. As for new issues: 'We wouldn't touch a new issue - there is no track record.'

The secret of share selection is to do your homework, says Peake. During the club's first two years they 'lost money like mad'. Shares were chosen because friends tipped them or simply because they were the first ones discussed at a meeting.

Now, though mistakes are still made, they are small in relation to the overall portfolio. The club uses a panoply of systems and techniques to monitor the progress of individual shares. For example, a stop-loss mechanism requires members to meet when a price falls by more than 20 per cent so a decision can be made about whether to sell.

'If the triggers are set off, we still need to decide whether it is the share or the market,' Peake says. 'If there is nothing wrong with the share, we will weather it out.'

Trading together

Investment clubs are booming. Around 4,500 were set up last year, bringing the total to about 10,000. Interest was fuelled by last year's dotcom shares bonanza, and appears to have survived their collapse.

The clubs bring together people who pool modest amounts of money to trade on the stock market. The average monthly amount contributed is £40, but some club ask less. Members of a new club usually pay a small lump sum towards the costs of setting up and starting to trade.

Members meet regularly to decide what to buy and sell. ProShare, the group which promotes share ownership, recommends that clubs have a constitution, with rules on contribution levels, notice for withdrawing funds and how investments will be chosen. A Proshare manual on setting up a club, which includes a model constitution, is available for £29.50 (tel: 0870 264 5484).

Ten stockbroking firms offer special dealing rates to clubs; Barclays Stockbrokers offers a free copy of the Proshare manual to ones that use its service.

webTitle: End of the line for smooth operators?

fields.headline: End of the line for smooth operators?
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley on why with-profits aren't equitable
fields.trailText: Jill Insley on why with-profits aren't equitable.
fields.body:
The well-publicised problems of Equitable Life and its with-profits fund could signal the end for a type of investment that has been in use since the Napoleonic Wars.

With-profits investment has appealed to more cautious investors because it offers access to stock market returns while limiting the volatility normally associated with equity investment. The with-profits method of distributing returns - 'smoothing' - has offered more security than other forms of equity investment, making it ideal for pensions and policies designed to repay mortgages. Returns are paid in bonuses and, to protect policyholders from the effects of poor stock market performance, some of the profits earned in good years are held over to boost bonuses in poor years.

But the fact that Equitable's with-profits fund has run into trouble has called this investment style into question. Most commentators believe Equitable is a one-off, a life office with little in reserve to cover the cost of guaranteed annuities promised by its marketing department in past decades. But its situation has highlighted another problem shared by all with-profits funds - lack of clarity.

Equitable policyholders have until now thought that the insurer was able to maintain high payouts and provide adequate security through consistently good investment performance. Now they have realised that Equitable's performance was actuallymiddle of the road, and it was only sustaining high payouts by distributing almost all the profits it generated.

Up to now it has been impossible for an investor to know how much their with-profits fund has actually earned in any given year, what proportion of those returns is being distributed as bonuses or what the charges are. This has made it difficult for investors to judge whether they are investing with a financially secure life office.

Tom McPhail, of independent financial adviser Torquil Clark, says: 'With-profits policies have often been sold as low-risk investments but they're not. At best they are medium-risk, and if you take it to an extreme, you get an Equitable, which delivers all its profits through annual bonuses and leaves itself with no reserves for security.'

McPhail believes this opacity is no longer acceptable: 'People are much more interested in the bottom line, what they're being charged and what they're getting for their money. None of this is clear in with-profits.'

Nick Bamford of Cranleigh independent financial adviser Informed Choice agrees: 'People are better-educated about financial products these days. They are more inclined to go for simple equity products such as unit trusts, Oeics and unit-linked insurance and pension funds.'

Until now insurers have argued that bonuses and the smoothing process are too complicated for ordinary mortals to understand.

But David White, chief executive of Tunbridge Wells Equitable, whose with-profits fund has consistently appeared at the top of payout league tables, says it has always been possible to tell policyholders exactly how much their policy has earned. 'The actuaries' reticence is about managing peoples' expectations,' he says.

This attitude has also enabled insurers to manipulate the figures to suit their own ends, such as inflating bonuses to raise funds' ratings in league tables and attract new business.

However, faced with increasing consumer dissatisfaction, they are finally beginning to provide more information. Britannic Retirement Solutions, a sub sidiary of Britannic Assurance, has just launched a with-profits annuity that will publish annual performance figures. It will provide policyholders with information about charges and how much money is being held over or paid out in the smoothing process each year. The insurer is considering extending this practice to other products.

Norwich Union, which announced bonuses for the old Norwich Union, CGU (formerly General Accident) and CU with-profits funds last week, is intending to provide most of its with-profits policyholders with similar information this year.

Is this new glasnost enough to restore with-profits sales? Nick Bamford believes there will always be demand for the security that properly managed with-profits funds can offer. 'There are lots of cautious people for whom with-profits will provide a good return.'

But McPhail is not convinced: 'It's a process that's had its day.'

webTitle: Money writes: Solicitor's slur turned village gossips  against me

fields.headline: Solicitor's slur turned village gossips  against me
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I live in a pretty village where gossip is rife. Imagine my horror when a neighbour delivered a document he had received from a firm of solicitors with whom I have a poor relationship.

They wrote to him at number 20 saying their communications to me at number 21 had gone unanswered, and asking if he had a forwarding address. Strange they should decide they cannot trace me because we exchange hate mail regularly over a debt with a financial institution.

The solicitor has routinely corresponded with me, answering my queries, but for some reason has now decided to spotlight my fiscal plight. The neighbour has succeeded in casting aspersions on my character around the village. Is this how these organisations normally work?
ND, Kent

This is appalling and it is illogical to assume that No 21 is anywhere near No 20 anyway. If you have been in correspondence with the solicitor, there is no reason why he should not continue to contact you at that same address.

The only time a firm might contact neighbours is if a borrower's relationship with a lender has completely broken down, letters have been returned marked, 'gone away', and there is no response by telephone.

Then lenders use tracing agencies to find debtors who appear to be deliberately avoiding paying. But you have been maintaining payments.

You should complain to the Office for the Supervision of Solicitors helpline, on 01926 822007, and tell the lender how its agent is behaving.

Wait for Widows: Double trouble

I had a Scottish Widows endowment policy with my former husband.

When we divorced, I took over the policy. Subsequent letters from the company were still addressed to my ex-husband, and I was told that the Scottish Widows computer system did not allow the principal name to be changed, although the policy was indeed in my (by now different) name.

I was assured that the demutualisation cheque would be in my name. It wasn't and I am still waiting for my money.
SvR, Cambridge

Readers will be familiar with the chaos over Scottish Widows' windfall payouts following its merger with LloydsTSB last August.

Scottish Widows is now blaming 'technical difficulties' for delays in issuing cheques to pay compensation.

Finally your main cheque arrived, followed later by another for £28 net interest. Because of the hassle you have suffered, the company is adding an ex gratia payment of £50.

Missing pension: Widow's mite

My husband was an employee of the Communist Party. He dealt out the wages and, if nothing was left, that week we lived on my earnings. He died in 1965 and had paid into a pension fund.

It occurred to me that I could come off income support and maybe even pay tax if I received the pension due to a widow. The few aged comrades I have spoken to know nothing about it.
AF, Aylsham

Your best chance is to write to the Pensions Registry, PO Box 1NN, Newcastle upon Tyne NE99 1NN which keeps information about private and company pension schemes.

Give them as much information as you can about your husband, his employment and past addresses.

Loan exit fees: Left stranded

In September 1995 we started a five-year fixed-rate mortgage with the Yorkshire building society which involved penalties for early redemption; we borrowed more when we moved house in May 1996.

Last year we wanted to switch our mortgage to the Halifax. I telephoned the Yorkshire to ask if we would incur any penalties and was assured that the penalty period had expired.

On completing the remortgage, we were dismayed to find that the Yorkshire charged us £650.

I now realise that we were still within the penalty period on the second loan, but feel the Yorkshire has a moral responsibility to reimburse these charges, which were incurred as a direct result of their incorrect advice. We could have delayed transferring the mortgage until the penalty period ran out.
RE, Leeds

The Yorkshire is adamant that the penalty is payable, even though it admits its staff might have noticed only your first mortgage and overlooked the second.

It says documents sent to your solicitor clearly showed the charge, and the solicitor should have made sure you knew.

This is where you hit a snag. Halifax offered a free legal service as part of the remortgaging package but, unusually, the solicitor acts for the lender, not the borrower. It had no duty to alert you to the Yorkshire's conditions even though Yorkshire did not send you a copy of the redemption statement.

The Halifax admits it would not expect you to instruct a second solicitor. Both lenders are leaving you stranded, but your experience is a warning of the limitations of a free service.

Adviser's error: £7,000 penalty

I have had a personal pension with Norwich Union for the past 10 years, arranged through an independent financial adviser, and pay £50 a month.

Six years ago, I wanted to pay more and a different adviser persuaded me to take out a new policy with the same company for £320 a month.

Recently, Norwich Union told me that I would be better off financially if I combined the two policies, but doing so would cost me 40 per cent of my premiums for 18 months, which is £360.
SB, London

The amount of correspondence generated by your simple inquiry shows how difficult it is to understand exactly what people pay to buy pensions. The 40 per cent charge reflects Norwich Union's allocation rate, which means that only 60 per cent of your money is invested.

You can transfer the current value built up in the smaller pension - £7,611 - into the other at the single premium allocation rate of 99 per cent, so the charge is a more tolerable £76, although you still pay 40 per cent on ongoing premiums.

This might tempt you to cancel the £50 direct debit, and start a far cheaper Stakeholder Pension in April.

fields.bodyText: I live in a pretty village where gossip is rife. Imagine my horror when a neighbour delivered a document he had received from a firm of solicitors with whom I have a poor relationship. They wrote to him at number 20 saying their communications to me at number 21 had gone unanswered, and asking if he had a forwarding address. Strange they should decide they cannot trace me because we exchange hate mail regularly over a debt with a financial institution. The solicitor has routinely corresponded with me, answering my queries, but for some reason has now decided to spotlight my fiscal plight. The neighbour has succeeded in casting aspersions on my character around the village. Is this how these organisations normally work? ND, Kent This is appalling and it is illogical to assume that No 21 is anywhere near No 20 anyway. If you have been in correspondence with the solicitor, there is no reason why he should not continue to contact you at that same address. The only time a firm might contact neighbours is if a borrower's relationship with a lender has completely broken down, letters have been returned marked, 'gone away', and there is no response by telephone. Then lenders use tracing agencies to find debtors who appear to be deliberately avoiding paying. But you have been maintaining payments. You should complain to the Office for the Supervision of Solicitors helpline, on 01926 822007, and tell the lender how its agent is behaving. Wait for Widows: Double trouble I had a Scottish Widows endowment policy with my former husband. When we divorced, I took over the policy. Subsequent letters from the company were still addressed to my ex-husband, and I was told that the Scottish Widows computer system did not allow the principal name to be changed, although the policy was indeed in my (by now different) name. I was assured that the demutualisation cheque would be in my name. It wasn't and I am still waiting for my money. SvR, Cambridge Readers will be familiar with the chaos over Scottish Widows' windfall payouts following its merger with LloydsTSB last August. Scottish Widows is now blaming 'technical difficulties' for delays in issuing cheques to pay compensation. Finally your main cheque arrived, followed later by another for £28 net interest. Because of the hassle you have suffered, the company is adding an ex gratia payment of £50. Missing pension: Widow's mite My husband was an employee of the Communist Party. He dealt out the wages and, if nothing was left, that week we lived on my earnings. He died in 1965 and had paid into a pension fund. It occurred to me that I could come off income support and maybe even pay tax if I received the pension due to a widow. The few aged comrades I have spoken to know nothing about it. AF, Aylsham Your best chance is to write to the Pensions Registry, PO Box 1NN, Newcastle upon Tyne NE99 1NN which keeps information about private and company pension schemes. Give them as much information as you can about your husband, his employment and past addresses. Loan exit fees: Left stranded In September 1995 we started a five-year fixed-rate mortgage with the Yorkshire building society which involved penalties for early redemption; we borrowed more when we moved house in May 1996. Last year we wanted to switch our mortgage to the Halifax. I telephoned the Yorkshire to ask if we would incur any penalties and was assured that the penalty period had expired. On completing the remortgage, we were dismayed to find that the Yorkshire charged us £650. I now realise that we were still within the penalty period on the second loan, but feel the Yorkshire has a moral responsibility to reimburse these charges, which were incurred as a direct result of their incorrect advice.
