webTitle: Bosnia's corrupt elite grow fat on human cargo smuggled to West

fields.headline: Bosnia's corrupt elite grow fat on human cargo smuggled to West
fields.standfirst:
Should Europe seal its borders, or open them to a quota of economic refugees? An Observer investigation reveals how well-connected people-traffickers working out of Sarajevo are raising the stakes in a £4 billion trade

Asylum myths and reality - Observer special

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Should Europe seal its borders, or open them to a quota of economic refugees? An Observer investigation reveals how well-connected people-traffickers working out of Sarajevo are raising the stakes in a £4 billion trade.
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, foreign affairs editor,  in Sarajevo, Chris Morris and Mahmut Kaya in Istanbul
fields.body:
Bag Wahab was one of the unlucky ones. On Friday the 26-year-old Turk sat in the arrivals area at Sarajevo airport, surrounded by police, his head bowed, close to tears. An agricultural labourer and father of two children, he had sold his land and spent all his savings to enter Europe as an illegal migrant.

Wahab fell at the first hurdle. As dozens of young men with similar ambitions passed through immigration into Bosnia, jumping-off point for the 'Sarajevo Route' into the EU, Wahab's lack of education let him down. He thought he was arriving in a country called Sarajevo, at a capital called Grozny. The State Border Service informed him he would be sent home.

Like dozens of other young men from Tunisia and Turkey who had passed through, their tickets and passports in order, and with sufficient cash to be allowed to stay, Wahab had said he was a tourist. Sitting in a corner of the departures lounge, his journey over, he abandoned the dissimulation. 'I was trying to get to France to work,' he told The Observer. 'I've already spent most of my money paying a commission to come in. Now what I am going to do? What is going to happen to me?'

Wahab is the exception rather than the rule. Half an hour later the others who arrived from Istanbul with him were heading for an unofficial rank of cabs that pull up on a verge just outside the airport compound on the days the Turkish flight comes in, specifically to carry migrants. Where they are taken next is Sarajevo's biggest open secret. Those not taken by van or taxi immediately to the Croatian border will spend a few days in a hotel, among them the Alemko, a low, dilapidated, purple building not far from the city centre. The Orijent and Palas hotels are also favourites with the criminal gangs running the people-smuggling rackets.

Their next step was revealed by a surveillance operation set up by officers of the International Police Task Force in Sarajevo in December, who tracked three groups of migrants to small hotels and safe houses close to the international borders they will cross by foot, in boats across the Sava river, or even in the back of empty fuel tanker lorries specially equipped with benches, all of them en route for Fortress Europe.

Wahab and the other young men who arrived on Friday are the willing victims of the world's fastest-growing crime, a trade that the International Organisation for Migration calculates is worth upwards of £70 million a year in Bosnia alone. Worldwide, the UN estimates, the smugglers earned around £4 billion in the past 12 months alone. Coming to Bosnia is not a crime. But what they will try to do when they are here is definitely illegal. And few have any doubt that the smuggling of migrants is being aided through Bosnia by police and politicians at the highest level.

According to Geoffrey Beaumont, coordinator of the UN's project to set up a functioning Bosnian State Border Service, more than 10 per cent of the half million illegal migrants who reached the EU last year came via the Bosnian route. And although Croatia has been catching up to 5,000 of them a year, few are in any doubt that, deported back to Bosnia, most will try again. By their third attempt officials believe most will have crossed into Europe proper.

It is a route fast becoming one of the biggest headaches for the EU. Last week European Commissioner Chris Patten announced extra aid for training Bosnian and other Balkan police forces in the fight against migrant-smuggling after it was raised by EU Foreign Ministers.

The announcement comes against a background of a rising sense of crisis in the EU over illegal migration which has increased more than tenfold in the past 10 years. Across Europe arrests at borders are rocketing, as are asylum applications across the 15 nations.

In Bosnia the traffic in illegal migrants conceals a second, more venal trade in humans: the trade in sex slaves which lures women and young girls to Bosnia 'mainly from Eastern Europe and former Soviet republics' with the promise of jobs as au pairs or waitresses in the EU.

In one of the most shocking cases, uncovered last summer, 12 women and young girls were found locked in a darkened room in a bar in the town of Prijedor, where they had been held and repeatedly raped.

According to officials who dealt with the case, the horror of the original discovery was quickly overtaken by a sense of impotence as corrupt local officials frustrated their efforts to prosecute those involved. Their persistence paid off. Faced with constant harassment, four of the five women prepared to testify against the slavers withdrew their evidence and the case collapsed. International officials have no question about how the women were so easily found. 'We have very strong indications,' said one official familiar with the case, 'that the authorities collude in both the trafficking of people and smuggling in illegal immigrants at the very highest level.'

The case of the Prijedor women, say officials, is simply the starkest evidence of the difficulties they face in trying to stamp out human trafficking in Bosnia: the large-scale involvement of corrupt politicians and police. Prosecutions have been almost non-existent for both crimes; detection is hampered by those willing to help the people-smugglers.

Among those named to The Observer by international officials as suspected of benefiting from the trade in migrants is the son of one of Bosnia's most respected figures. One senior official said: 'His company was organising special charter flights full of Iranians last year who simply disappeared. Do I think he is involved? I believe at least that he has benefited from it. The truth,' he continued, 'is that this is being encouraged by corruption at the very highest levels.'

Evidence exists too that the smuggling business is part of a sophisticated international network that supplies forged documents as well. In some cases the trail leads to Britain.

Late last year, say international police, a package was intercepted from London addressed to an Iranian woman renting accommodation in Sarajevo. Instead of the CDs it claimed to contain, the package was stuffed with stolen European passports.

The shocking reality of Bosnia today, international officials say, is this. Five years after the Dayton Peace Agreement was signed to bring a genocidal war to an end, a country that has received unprecedented military and economic aid from the international community has turned, not into a model Balkan democracy, but into one of Europe's main hubs for smuggling people.

'It is depressing as hell,' said one official. 'Almost half the people in Sarajevo depend on the international community for their income, but we can't persuade the authorities to stamp it out. It would be easy if the international community was really bothered. We could simply say stop this or we stop the aid.'

It is a threat already levelled against Yugoslavia, blamed for years under the Milosevic regime of being the main conduit of Chinese migrants into Europe. Late last year the EU told President Vojislav Kostunica that aid to his country is contingent on him closing the door to the tens of thousands of Chinese illegal immigrants using Belgrade as a first stop on their route into the EU.

It is a solution many international officials believe should be applied to shock Bosnia's corrupt politicians out of their complacency. But they do not blame Bosnia alone. 'We are very concerned over what Europe is going to do about this problem,' says Geoffrey Beaumont. 'They say they are worried about this, but is their solution to seal off Bosnia from Europe?'

So far, he concedes, there is little danger of that. The State Border Service he is helping to set up is 'so far working at only four of Bosnia's 400-odd border crossings. International funding for the project has been woeful. At present we have a budget of around £6 million to control all of Bosnia's borders. If Europe was serious about controlling this problem all it would cost the individual governments would be around £3m a year. That must be cheaper than the money that they are spending on detecting, arresting, holding and returning illegal refugees. So far the only people who are really trying hard on this issue are the Germans and the Dutch.'

The alternative is a solution that is quickly becoming the EU's most controversial issue: a proposed scheme of managed migration into Europe via quotas and a 'green card' entry scheme similar to that in the US. Floated last December in a European Commission communication, it calls for a Europe-wide asylum and immigration policy that would abandon three decades of a zero migration policy in response to predictions of a declining and ageing European population that will need mass migration to sustain its economic life.

What that would mean, according to the EU justice and home affairs Commissioner, Antonio Vitorino, involved in drawing up the paper, is a policy aimed at trebling legal migration to almost one million by 2004.

But despite evidence collected by the Commission, the idea of a permit system for unskilled labourers like Wahab is unlikely to be smiled on by politicians in Britain or elsewhere. For although Britain's Home Office Minister, Barbara Roche, has been persuaded of the need to attract skilled migrants, no one has been persuaded of the case of those at the bottom of the ladder. It is a contradiction that has been noted by Sarah Spencer, director of the Citizenship and Governance programme of the Institute for Public Policy Research, who has been advising the Home Office on any change to its migration policy.

'One of the questions that has yet to be addressed is that, if we had legal channels into Britain and Europe, would it reduce the pressure to come in and dissuade people from going to the smugglers? That is a very sensitive issue. At the moment we have got a consensus that we need skilled labourers. We need to extend that consensus to a similar need for unskilled labourers of the kind currently coming in illegally.'

webTitle: People trade makes Bosnia rich

fields.headline: People trade makes Bosnia rich
fields.standfirst:
Asylum myths and reality - Observer special

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Politicians and police officers in Bosnia are enriching themselves from the massive smuggling of migrants into the European Union.
fields.body:
Politicians and police officers in Bosnia are enriching themselves from the massive smuggling of migrants into the European Union.

Despite the presence of a 20,000-strong international military mission - including British troops - the illegal trafficking of migrants from the Arab world and Turkey through Bosnia is big business five years after Western intervention ended the civil war. The trade is estimated to be worth £100 million a year.

The accusation of senior government involvement has been made by international officials operating in the capital, Sarajevo. It follows publication this month by the UN Mission in Bosnia-Herzegovina of figures showing the Sarajevo route was taken last year by more than 10 per cent of the 500,000 illegal migrants who reached the West.

Despite the funding by the international community of a new State Border Service, officials claim corruption is hampering international efforts to secure Bosnia's borders and close the route through Croatia into Europe.

Officials familiar with the programme also claim it is underfunded by the international community. Up to a third of the cash generated by the trade in women for prostitution ends up with police and politicians, according to a source - a situation believed to be mirrored in the smuggling of migrants.

The claims against Bosnia came as European Foreign Ministers met in Brussels last week to agree a plan to tackle trafficking through the Balkans. Growing concern about irregular migration into Europe led last week to the announcement by Spain that it plans to deport up to 60,000 illegal immigrants.

The increase in the number of illegal migrants coming into the EU - from 40,000 in 1993 to an estimated 500,000 last year - has been matched by a rise in asylum claims which reached record levels in Britain last year.

Although migrants arriving in Bosnia and intending to travel to the EU commit no crime until they cross the border into Croatia en route for Italy, Austria and Germany, traffickers who take up to $4,000 a time to guide them across the boundaries are breaking the law.

The difficulties facing officers have been highlighted by the collapse of operations against people smugglers and gangs trafficking women for sex, after the traffickers were tipped off.

'We have strong indications of the direct involvement of police and senior political figures in this trade at the very highest levels,' said one official.

webTitle: Paperback round-up

fields.headline: Only the cloning
fields.trailText: Jeremy Worman on a challenge to personal identity The Second Creation, plus the rest of the weeks' paperbacks
fields.body:
The Second Creation
Ian Wilmut, Keith Campbell and Colin Tudge
Headline £7.99, pp374
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In 1996, at the Roslin Institute in Scotland, Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell cloned Dolly the sheep. Their success opened up possibilities of human cloning - of which they do not approve - that could alter our ideas of personal identity and culture.

Colin Tudge, a well-known writer on science, has produced a thought- provoking book about the history of their experiments. He uses the first-person voices of Wilmut and Campbell and then inserts his third-person commentary.

The reader of modest scientific knowledge (like this reviewer) is given in chapter two a crucially helpful section on 'Genes and genetic engineering'; the easy-to-use glossary and index also prove invaluable, as does the diagram of the stages of cloning. In our twenty-first century culture, some understanding of biotechnology is perhaps as crucial as was an understanding of Darwin to the Victorians. The Second Creation brings you up to speed.

Laura Blundy
Julie Myerson
Fourth Estate 6.99, pp263
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Laura Blundy, the strange, eponymous heroine, saturated with a sense of loss, takes the reader on a dark, gripping journey through a low-life world of Victorian London towards a chilling and satisfying conclusion.

Told in the first person, the atmosphere Laura Blundy evokes is that of a compulsive dream crossing into nightmare. The macabre, grisly, bodily imagery that patterns the novel suggests a human condition of inevitable degeneration. For example: 'I believe I blacked out as he severed the muscle and then woke some seconds later to the crunch as the membranes succumbed and separated.'

Claustrophobia is maintained as all characters' speech is denoted without speech marks. Scenes near the Thames seep into the reader's flesh. Laura's reflections move back and forth, with integrated stories running concurrently, as she explores her emotional universe. When you finish this moving, spine-chilling novel, it will stay in your head for days.

A Sweetheart Deal
Ben Richards
Review £6.99, pp274
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This dramatic page-turner of a contemporary London novel follows the progress of Mel Holloway, a regional officer for a large union, as she fights the case of a laboratory technician sacked for giving the wrong blood to a hospital.

The patient concerned subsequently dies and Mel becomes emotionally involved with his wife. Tension created by the developing conspiracies is successful; East End locations add gritty atmosphere.

Ben Richards's dialogue is electric and the range of his characters is outstanding. Mel's private world is convincing, involving an ailing, ex-rock group boyfriend and her sassy, girl-power confidante.

At the end, the thriller element slips into a study of personal growth for Mel, through love and loss, which does not entirely convince.

All in all, though, A Sweetheart Deal is a truly rich novel painted on a large canvas.

Greewich
Charles Jennings
Abacus £7.99, pp242
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Charles Jennings's engaging history explores how 'a draughty bend of the river at Greenwich' became a place of global importance. In 1011, the Archbishop of Canterbury was stoned to death here by Danes who grew tired of holding him captive. A palace was built in the 1420s (Greenwich Park is its only memorial), which led to Greenwich becoming known as 'the royal township'.

The author's tone occasionally feels like a guidebook as he summarily covers a lot of ground too neatly categorised- 'Working', 'Art', 'Consumer' and so on. But two chapters on science at Greenwich are especially enthralling: Charles II appointed an Astronomer Royal and Greenwich Mean Time was internationally agreed in Washington in 1884. Moving to the twentieth century, Jennings writes well on the Millennium Dome. But after such a rich tapestry of history, is the Dome just postmodernist fluff? Greenwich gives you all you need to form your own judgment.

The Abomination
Paul Golding
Picador £6.99, pp515
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Abomination is a first novel, in first-person confessional style, chronicling the stormy life of a homosexual, James Moore, from his upper-class childhood in Spain to Catholic boarding-school in England, then Oxford and the grubby decadence of his current London life.

The novel begins in London, and the writing is needle-sharp and shocking about sex and drugs, with eye-opening details of a gay club. Then the author returns to childhood and adolescent reflections. His tone is often obsessive, and unrelieved by any dialogue in the entire novel. Consequently, vividly related homosexual relationships with a teacher both at prep and public school are only partially successful, the characters lacking vitality.

As the hero reaches mid-adolescence, his story gains momentum, becoming sophisticated with a Dorian Gray tone of contemptuous mockery. The powerful conclusion returns to adult London life and the tragic search for perfect love.

The Abomination is demanding, beautifully written, uneven. As a debut, this is a tour de force.

BBC Radio Collection £9.99 (cassette), £12.99 (CD), running time 2hrs 10mins
Buy the book at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: Observer review: Being born in a northern town, Bennett tells us, is more like a handicap than an inheritance
fields.body:
Being born in a northern town, Bennett tells us, is more like a handicap than an inheritance, with that 'incurable disease of the vowels' always lying in ambush. But only Bennett's intonation could make Aunt Eveline with her 'enormous bust' immediately recognisable as a Bennett aunt - along with the telling detail of the lace-bordered frontal that masks the 'dark and mossy chasm' of the cleavage which so fascinated the young child.

Poignant detail dancing between tragedy and comedy is Bennett's art. In his childhood home above his father's butcher's shop, the young Alan had to edge past the beef heads hanging in the cellar to get the coal. Upstairs, his mother sat by the iron range she had prettified with a flowered cretonne pelmet in a kitchen pervaded by the stench of dripping.

As a child, he was ashamed of his parents, and now he is ashamed of his youthful self but, Bennett muses after a deft pause in a low, tender voice, there is no one left from whom to ask forgiveness.

Where was life for this odd 14-year-old boy who prayed assiduously and took upon himself the nightly cleaning of his parents' false teeth neglected in the cup with no handle? Certainly not in Leeds, it seemed to Bennett at the time, but his Tales show that it was indeed there and its minutiae absorb him, and his listeners, still.

Poignant detail dancing between tragedy and comedy is Bennett's art. In his childhood home above his father's butcher's shop, the young Alan had to edge past the beef heads hanging in the cellar to get the coal. Upstairs, his mother sat by the iron range she had prettified with a flowered cretonne pelmet in a kitchen pervaded by the stench of dripping. As a child, he was ashamed of his parents, and now he is ashamed of his youthful self but, Bennett muses after a deft pause in a low, tender voice, there is no one left from whom to ask forgiveness. Where was life for this odd 14-year-old boy who prayed assiduously and took upon himself the nightly cleaning of his parents' false teeth neglected in the cup with no handle? Certainly not in Leeds, it seemed to Bennett at the time, but his Tales show that it was indeed there and its minutiae absorb him, and his listeners, still.

webTitle: Interview with Anita Brookner

fields.headline: Just don't mention Jane Austen
fields.standfirst: Anita Brookner's latest book - her twentieth - is familiarly bleak. But she's unrepentant. She had a good time writing it
fields.trailText: Anita Brookner's latest book - her twentieth - is familiarly bleak. But she's unrepentant. She had a good time writing it
fields.body:
 Anita Brookner trained as an art historian, taught at the Courtauld until 1988 and won the Booker Prize for Hotel Du Lac. She rarely gives interviews

Observer: First, what is The Bay of Angels about?

Brookner: It is about the sort of misfortune that can come upon you without warning, which finds you totally bereft trying to get yourself out of it.

Obs: Was there a particular moment of inspiration ?

AB: Well, the curious thing is that I didn't intend to write it. I didn't know I was going to write it, so it came upon me quite suddenly and quite easily and I enjoyed writing it. I'm sorry if it's very bleak. I'm sorry if it's mournful. I had a good time, that's all I can say about it.

Obs: It's your twentieth novel in about 20 years. Is that how you like to work - at the rate of a novel a year?

AB: I'd like to be writing all the time, but that's not possible.

Obs: Why not?

AB: Lack of ideas, I suppose.

Obs: Where do you think your ideas come from?

AB: I wish I knew. I'd tap into them straight away. I think it's mostly dreams and memories, isn't it, as with all novelists? And a certain amount of observation, obviously.

Obs: Did you always want to be a novelist?

AB: No.

Obs: What made you switch from teaching ?

AB: Well, I was a teacher most of my life, which I loved. I had a very happy working life and when I retired I thought I must do something and I've always read a lot of fiction, you learn so much from fiction. My sentimental education came mostly from fiction I should say, so I thought I'd try.

Obs: You've been very successful for a late starter.

AB: I wouldn't say that. I'm not very popular, because they're bleak and they're mournful and all the rest of it and I get censorious reviews. But I'm only writing fiction. I'm not making munitions, so I think it's acceptable.

Obs: In this book there are several references to art. How much does your art history influence your fiction, if at all?

AB: Not at all.

Obs: So you keep your art history and your fiction in separate compartments?

AB: Absolutely. Well, they keep themselves in separate compartments. I'm a member of the public these days. I go to the galleries and wander around like everybody else. I love it.

Obs: What did you read as a child?

AB: Ah! Dickens. My father fed me Dickens. Two novels for my birthday, two novels for Christmas until I'd read the lot. And after that I think it was H.G. Wells, for some reason. I've been talked about in the same context as Jane Austen. I didn't stick that label on myself, other people did. Quite inaccurate. I've never got on very well with Jane Austen.

Obs: Where do you see yourself in the tradition of English literature?

AB: I don't know anything like that. I'm a middle-class, middle-brow novelist. And that's it. It amuses me.

Obs: With a middle-class audience?

AB: Yes. Mostly women, but the best letters I've had have been from men. One man said a marvellous thing. He said: 'You write French novels', which pleased me enormously.

Obs: Which foreign country are you most popular in?

AB: America. And France. I do better in America than I do here.

Obs: Who was your father?

AB: My father was a small businessman, extremely virtuous, not very successful. He had a number of enterprises. He had a lending library at one point, I remember, which was, of course, very congenial. My mother had been a professional singer in America. And they were a virtuous couple and very unhappy and that sent mixed messages, as you can imagine.

Obs: Were you close to your father?

AB: I was closer to my mother, but I loved them both. [Let me get you a cup of tea].

Obs: Who are the writers you admire now?

AB: I read a lot in French and I read the Russians. Here's my favourite novel.

Obs: Oblomov.

AB: Yes. It's about a man who fails at everything.

Obs: I confess I've never read it.

AB: It's great. He fails at everything - not through any fault of his own, but through sheer inactivity. I learnt a terrific lesson there.

Obs: Do you think failure is a subject to which you're drawn in your fiction?

AB: Much more interesting than success.

Obs: There's a very powerful passage here. You write: 'As a woman approaching middle age I know that certain changes are inevitable, but I may not always be as adaptable as I have so far proved to be. I feel very tired, cranky, inclined to insist on a life of my own. I miss children, as all middle-aged women do, if they're childless.' Are your books, in some sense, your children?

AB: No. Not at all.

Obs: And do you identify with that passage?

AB: I think so.

Obs: The Bay of Angels is a book that the people who admire your work will recognise immediately.
AB: And denigrate.

Obs: Do you ever think of writing a different kind of book entirely?

AB: I wish I could, I wish I could, maybe it'll come. I don't know. I've no control over these things.

Obs: What would you do if you couldn't write fiction?

AB: Read fiction.

Obs: So your life is really immersed in various kinds of fictional activity?

AB: Well, I live in the world, like everybody has to, and I go out, do the shopping, and do the cleaning - that sort of thing. See friends. I suppose what one wants really is ideal company and books are ideal company.

Obs: And are you working on a new novel now?

AB: No.

Obs: Where will the next idea come from?

AB: I don't know, that's the point. I have no control. I'm a great believer in unconscious processes. They usually work.

Obs: When do you write?

AB: I start work at seven.

Obs: Pencil or pen?

AB: Pen.

Obs: In manuscript?

AB: I haven't got any of these machines.

Obs: And do you type them up later on?

AB: Yes, I do that.

Obs: And how long do you write for?

AB: Two or three hours. I think about it most of the day.

Obs: All your books have this very intense atmosphere.

AB: That comes from the early reading, I think. One has left oneself behind, but it lingers.

Obs: Do you write quickly?

AB: Yes.

Obs: Do you revise a lot?

AB: No, not at all.

Obs: It feels that way, as a reader.

AB: Yes, only one draft.

Obs: So you've now finished the book, and you're a free woman?

AB: Very boring.

Obs: You're bored?

AB: Oh terribly.

 Read a review of The Bay of Angels here.

webTitle: Review: The Other Side of Eden by Hugh Brody

fields.headline: An Inuit on the Underground
fields.standfirst: Ros Coward on how the hunter-gatherer world-view contains important lessons for humanity's future in Hugh Brody's The Other Side of Eden
fields.trailText: Ros Coward on how the hunter-gatherer world-view contains important lessons for humanity's future in Hugh Brody's The Other Side of Eden
fields.body:
The Other Side of Eden: Hunter-Gatherers, Farmers and the Shaping of the World

Hugh Brody

Faber and Faber, £20, pp348

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Anthropologist Hugh Brody describes the visit to London of Anaviapik, an Inuit who had never previously left the Arctic. Anaviapik is disgorged from a British Airways plane on a hot summer's day swathed in a fox-fur- trimmed parka and 'wearing sealskin boots with brown trousers tucked into their patterned tops'. To Brody's relief, Anaviapik survives this visit with equanimity. One thing he never masters, however, is the built environment. Everyday Brody teases him, challenging him to find the short way home from the Tube. Everyday he fails: 'How amazing that the Qallunaat [white people] live in cliffs. I would never be able to find my way here without you.'

Back in the vast, white, apparently indecipherable landscapes of the Arctic Anaviapik has no such problem. On one occasion, Brody travels hundreds of miles with him by dog sledge. En route, Anaviapik diverts to a place he has not visited since 1938. 'How did you remember the way?' asks Brody. 'Inuit cannot get lost in our own land. If we have done a journey once we can always do it again.' This is one of the many instances which brings home to Brody the profound difference between hunter-gatherers' attitude to the land and our own. Theirs is an intimate knowledge of the land's contours, its seasons and creatures. A transformed landscape, dominated by man's activities, is alien and unattractive to them.

Others have noted the differences in attitudes towards the land of hunter-gatherer societies. But all too often racism and prejudice dismiss hunter- gatherers as backward people too ignorant to settle the land. Over the years, Brody has lived with and studied several hunter-gatherer societies. He has become convinced that the hunter-gatherer world-view contains important lessons for humanity's future.

He devotes much space to discussing Inuit language in addressing these issues. It is the language, he claims, that 'reveals different ways of knowing the world'. Anaviapik introduces him to Inuit not as a collection of words but as a culture. When Brody learns about seal hunting, he is shown not only how to hunt but how to talk about the hunt to other community members. He also learns there is no generic word for seal, only 'ringed seal, one-year-old ringed seal, adult male ringed seal, harp seal, bearded seal'.

It is a well-known academic curiosity that Inuit has no generic word for snow either, only a vast array of different snowy conditions. For Brody, these are far from idle academic points. They expose how hunter-gatherer languages 'express and celebrate the importance of detailed knowledge of their natural world'. They demonstrate a complex and profound respect for their land and the creatures they hunt. Far from the miserable subsistence existence imagined by colonists, Brody meets an almost spiritual connection to the land. Many hunter-gatherers feel there's a porous connection between the natural and spirit world.

Its impossible not to sympathise with Brody's indignation at the way the hunter-gatherers' language and culture have been misunderstood, silenced, and even repressed by those who have appropriated their lands. In one case, George, a member of the Nisga'a society in Alaska, recounts how he was forced by the government to leave his valley and attend an 'Indian residential school'. He was taken forcibly from his parents and his familiar coastal forests. He was beaten every time he used his own language. The terror George experienced is still palpable, as is the pain of separation from his culture. Equally distressing are the accounts of Nato's refusal to hear evidence from traditional 'experts' when an air base destroyed their hunting grounds.

Those appropriating hunter-gatherer land pour contempt on their culture, dehumanising them by reference to their lack of discipline towards children, their subsistence existence. Brody sees these as a function of an egalitarian culture which is not interested in subduing children or landscape but in leaving nature intact. Now he is convinced the fundamental division in human history is between this world view and that of the hunter-gatherers' oppressors, the agriculturalists.

Normally, hunter-gatherers are seen as nomads and farmers as settlers. Brody thinks the reverse is true. Farming culture is accompanied by 'a longing to be settled, a defensive holding of ground and a continuing endemic nomadism' caused by the continuous growth of population among such communities. Genesis, says Brody is the ultimate agriculturalist myth, embodying their continuing quest to reshape nature as a lost Eden. Hunter-gatherers, by contrast, do not seek to reshape and dominate their landscape. Their conviction is that their land is 'already Eden and exile must be avoided'.

Brody is also convinced that hunter-gatherers had different cultural origins from the agriculturalists since they do not share the Indo-European languages characteristic of all agricultural people. Brody postulates agriculturalists spread out from one place, a combative and imperialist culture which eventually drove hunter-gatherers to the edge of habitable land. Brody concludes that the fate of the hunter-gatherers is a hugely important part of human history. This is not a primitive culture surpassed by superior forms. Instead, it embodies an equally significant aspect of the human condition.

As well as being an argument for the political rights of hunter-gatherer societies, The Other Side of Eden is also a passionate argument in support of recognising and nurturing the hunter-gatherer world-view. At a time when nature is so under threat from humanity, there are invaluable environmental lessons to be learnt from cultures which seek to survive from the land but also leave it as they find it.

webTitle: Review: The Hitler of History by John Lukacs

fields.headline: No one understands Hitler. Least of all his biographers
fields.standfirst: Jason Cowley looks at The Hitler of History by John Lukacs and asks, will we ever be finished with Adolf?
fields.trailText: Jason Cowley looks at The Hitler of History by John Lukacs and asks, will we ever be finished with Adolf?
fields.body:
The Hitler of History: Hitler's Biographers on Trial

John Lukacs

Weidenfeld and Nicolson, £25, pp279

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Will we ever be finished with Adolf Hitler? Not a month passes, it seems, but a new study emerges announcing its intention to anatomise, deconstruct, unmask or interpret the Führer. In short, to explain him; but not, mercifully, to revive him as George Steiner did in his admirable novella, The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H., in which a group of Nazi hunters discovers an aged but determined Hitler hiding out in the Peruvian wilderness. They capture him but before leading him out of the jungle, they allow the dictator one last long monologue of self-justification.

Where (and when) will it all end? Well, in perpetuating mystery and incompleteness, I suspect, judging from the experience of the American journalist Ron Rosenbaum. In his recent book, Explaining Hitler, Rosenbaum interviewed the world's leading authorities on Nazism, including Steiner and the reviled David Irving, only to conclude after more than 400 pages that, in fact, there is little to conclude: that Hitler remains resolutely inexplicable, a figure whose motives are hidden in impenetrable darkness.

The German historian Joachim Fest understood something of this dangerous emptiness when he spoke of Hitler as being an 'unperson', a nihilist bereft of any coherent sense of self. Perhaps it was this apparent hollowness of the self, which led Karl Kraus to remark that: 'When I think of Adolf Hitler, nothing occurs to me.'

And yet this 'unperson' continues to fascinate more than perhaps any other twentieth-century figure. Steiner, in conversation with Rosenbaum, is still capable of speaking fervidly, as if approvingly, of Hitler's courage as a foot soldier on the Western Front and of his indisputably compelling presence. Albert Speer, as revealed by Gitta Sereny in her biography of the duplicitous architect, clearly loved the Führer and continued to love him long after his death. Goebbels, on meeting the young Hitler for the first time, was so mesmerised that he wrote, comically, in his diary: 'Is he John the Baptist? Is he Jesus?'

Today, there is little more to discover about the Hitler of contemporary notoriety; his public life is oppressively documented (most recently by Professor Ian Kershaw, in his monumental, if flatly written, biography). He is less John the Baptist now than the Devil's own child.

Hitler studies, though, continue to attract in equal measure distinguished scholars, journalistic populists, revisionists, conspiracy theorists and innumerable paranoids and maniacs. And Hitler studies are the subject of this impressive, but perhaps premature, new book by John Lukacs.

It is premature for two reasons. First, as Lukacs acknowledges, our academic interest in Hitler now lies less in what more there is to discover than in understanding. If so, it is too early to offer definitive judgement on Hitler's biographers, for more will inevitably follow. Second, in his eagerness to complete this book before the end of the last century (it was published in the US in 1998), thus offering a timely retrospective on Hitler's posthumous reputation at a moment when we were all haunted by a sense of an ending, he ignored, except for a glancing reference in one of many footnotes, one of the best books on Hitler - Brigitte Hamann's Hitler's Vienna (1998).

Hamann's triumph was to return to the darkest, the most formative and least known part of Hitler's life: that of his adolescence in Linz, the Upper Austrian provincial capital, and of his early adulthood as a restless wanderer in Habsburg Vienna, the imperial metropolis, the cosmopolitan seat of an ancient empire. Artistic-intellectual fin-de-siècle Vienna was a world of radical innovation - of Freud, Mahler, Wittgenstein, Klimt, Schnitzler, Schoenberg and Adolf Loos. But this was not Hitler's Vienna. Rather, his was a city of the disenfranchised little people, insurgent on all fronts, bewildered and frightened by Viennese modernity.

Hamann followed the young vagabond Hitler on his journey into the lower depths of the city - a world of men's hostels, of isolation, threat and, as Hitler wrote in Mein Kampf , of 'constant unappeasable hunger' - and in so doing, through super-sleuthing and fidelity to primary sources, she challenged and overturned many of the popular misconceptions about Hitler: that he had Jewish antecedents; that he was an anti-Semite as soon as he arrived in Vienna; that he abandoned his dying mother; that Jewish academics played a part in his rejection from the Academy for Visual Arts in Vienna. (Kershaw leans heavily on Hamann in his discussion of Hitler's early years.)

Hamann was a diligent re-reader, too, of August 'Gustl' Kubizek's book My Friend Hitler, which many biographers had dismissed as unreliable, the work of a fantasist, and which Lukacs here never mentions. But Kubizek was, in one sense, Hitler's first biographer. After all, they were close friends during his formative years in Linz (they met at the opera), when their heads were clumsily full of yearning and dreams of limitless artistic achievement. He later accompanied Hitler to, and lived with him in, Vienna. They separated in 1908 when, as Kubizek wrote, Hitler disappeared into the 'shadowy depths of the metropolis', from which he emerged, unutterably changed, in 1913.

Where Lukacs excels, however, is in his shrewd analysis of how history and biography have grown closer together, and of how many of the new historians have become adept at exploiting the slippage between exegesis and fact. 'History is not the truth,' he writes, 'but the pursuit of truth through hindsight. The pursuit is inseparable from the purposes of the pursuers.' This is a smart observation; Lukacs understands that in an age when boundaries between fact, fiction and interpretation are collapsing - when more and more novelists, for instance, are appropriating real-life characters and the past for fictional ends - meaning itself has become intrinsically unstable.

The Hitler battles of the future, then, will flourish not in the search for truth but in its interpretation, less in accuracy than in understanding. And it is in the academy, no less than in popular imagination, that Hitler will continue to enjoy a curious afterlife - if not as an iconic presence then as one whose crimes and inexplicability will lend themselves to multiple and conflicting interpretations, certainly enough to keep the professors busy for years. They capture him but before leading him out of the jungle, they allow the dictator one last long monologue of self-justification. Where (and when) will it all end? webTitle: Review: The Greatest Taboo by Delroy Constantine-Simms

fields.headline: Voices from the sexual and racial crossroads
fields.standfirst: Peter Tatchell on the intertwining of racism and homophobia in The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in the Black Communities by Delroy Constantine-Simms
fields.trailText: Peter Tatchell on the intertwining of race and sexuality in The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in the Black Communities by Delroy Constantine-Simms
fields.body:
The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in the Black Communities

Delroy Constantine-Simms

Alyson, £12.99, pp460

President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe decries homosexuality as 'unAfrican'. Sodomy is, he claims, a modern perversion imported by Western colonialists. But 800 years ago, at the time of the Crusades, Europeans were claiming the reverse. They denounced homosexuality as a 'foreign vice' introduced by Muslim infidels.

These twin myths illuminate the often mutually reinforcing nature of racism and homophobia. This intertwining history of racial and sexual intolerance is one of the themes explored in The Greatest Taboo. Eugene J. Patron's essay endorses the idea that Western colonisers of Africa saw homosexuality as a corruption of nature and therefore an immorality exclusive to advanced, decadent civilisations. Viewing Africans as simple, naïve and innocent, they believed homosexuality was alien to Africa culture.

This is an appealing theory, but an unsatisfactory one. While some Europeans may have subscribed to the 'innocence of Africa' thesis in the misguided belief that it was liberal and enlightened, it was not the dominant imperial understanding.

A far more compelling explanation of the historical inter-relationship between race and sexuality can be found in the letters and diaries of nineteenth-century European explorers, missionaries and ethnographers. They suggest that Western anxieties concerning ethnic 'otherness' were fuelled by revulsion at the homosexual practices of indigenous peoples in Africa, Asia and Latin America. Blackness became equated with perversion and perversion with barbarism.

The sodomy of non-whites was seen as evidence of their unbridled depravity. This led to the simultaneous demonisation of racial and sexual difference. This alternative theory is best articulated by Rudi C. Bleys in The Geography of Perversion (Cassell, 1996). He argues that there is a close connection between the rise of imperial, racist and homophobic ideologies. The acceptance, and sometimes veneration, of same-sex behaviour in many non-European cultures horrified the Christian colonisers and was cited as evidence that black people were subhuman. Homosexuality among the heathens, often falsely linked with cannibalism and human sacrifices, became another rationalisation for racist notions of white superiority and the civilising mission of Western conquerors.

It is a perverse twist of history that Mugabe now espouses a homophobic agenda similar to the one imposed on black Zimbabweans by the colonisers he fought a war of liberation to overthrow. Moreover, not only does Mugabe enforce anti-homosexual laws inherited from the era of British rule, he also invokes the support of Christian churches in his crusade to defend 'authentic' African culture against what he denounces as imperialist-imposed homosexuality.

Mugabe's contradictions are abjured by more sophisticated black homophobes, such as Louis Farrakhan and Afro-centric scholars like Dr Molefi Asante. They share his view that homosexuality is alien to the true African experience, but promote this fiction via an Africanised version of an old European racist discourse: the 'noble savage' living in a state of pristine heterosexuality.

The Great Taboo explodes this myth, documenting examples of homosexuality in pre-colonial Africa, including the traditions of male wives in Zaire and Madagascar and female husbands in Benin and South Africa,. This suggests that the real European imposition on Africa was homophobia, not homosexuality.

This book is a brave milestone. Written from a predominantly gay black perspective, it exposes straight supremacist strands in black history, politics, literature, religion and music.

Nevertheless, some of the greatest allies of the queer liberation movement have been black leaders, such as Huey Newton, Desmond Tutu, Jesse Jackson and Thabo Mbeki. In 1987, I challenged the homophobia of the African National Congress. The result was a U-turn. The ANC went on to ensure that South Africa became the first country with a constitution outlawing discrimination based on sexual orientation.

Aside from its critique of black culture, The Great Taboo celebrates the long-marginalised experience of those who are both black and gay, and the conflicts this creates between their dual identities. 'Are you black first or are you queer?' asks Gregory Conerly. It was a dilemma that haunted James Baldwin, Ma Rainey, Langston Hughes and Bessie Smith. Neglected by the black, white and gay communities, these voices from the crossroads of the sexual and racial diaspora speak to people of all races and sexualities.

webTitle: Review: Philosophical Investigations: Ludwig Wittgenstein by Richard Wall

fields.headline: With Wittgenstein at the end of the world
fields.standfirst: George Steiner on a discreet jewel:  the account of Wittgenstein's visits to Ireland   in Philosophical Investigations by Richard Wall
fields.trailText: George Steiner on a discreet jewel: the account of Wittgenstein's visits to Ireland in Philosophical Investigations by Richard Wall
fields.body:
Philosophical Investigations
Richard Wall
Blackwell, £16.99, pp250
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Is it the ever-changing light and the dark seas? Ireland has long been home to solitudes and to the kind of logical and metaphysical play that breeds on solitude. The lineage stretches from Duns Scotus (the name is, in fact, a misnomer) to Bishop Berkeley and Beckett, that virtuoso of aloneness and negativity.

Wittgenstein's visits to Ireland began in 1936 and resumed in 1938. The years 1947 to 1949 found Wittgenstein spending months in Dublin and Co Wicklow. Time and again, he considered establishing himself in Ireland, possibly to practise psychiatric medicine. Much of the work which led to the Philosophical Investigations was done in Ireland.

Together with Norway, the Ahling Hotel in Dublin and almost inaccessible cottages near Galway proved to be Wittgenstein's refuge from what he felt to be the falsehood of his professorial existence in Cambridge. Consciously or not, Wittgenstein strove to recapture the condition of the hermits and visionaries who are recurrent in Irish legend and history. To be thought somewhat mad in western Ireland was to be made welcome.

Yet, as Richard Wall's enchanting and perceptive record makes clear, Wittgenstein's actual visits had a context of intimacies. He was introduced to Irish life by his pupil, Maurice O' Connor Drury, whom he discouraged from studying philosophy, 'a dishonest and pointless occupation', and directed towards medicine. Subsequently, he travelled with Francis Skinner. It is one of the as yet rare victims of Wall's account to be perfectly calm and factual about this crucial, though undoutedly opaque, element in Wittgenstein's tormented private life. When Skinner died young in 1941, Rush Rhees reports Wittgenstein's conduct at the funeral as that of a 'frightened wild animal'. From the time of David Pinsent's death in 1918 onward, Wittgenstein's thirst for monastic isolation and the uttermost stripping bare of human contacts had, at its roots, a sense of tragic loss and of love gone to darkness.

Analogously, it was in deliberate counterpart to the truly immense wealth of his family background, to the opulence of his upbringing in late imperial Vienna, that Wittgenstein embraced asceticism and even destitution in regard to material circumstances. Roast chicken would not do when Drury made his master welcome. Porridge, vegetables and a boiled egg at supper would suffice. Rosroe, in the great shadows of Mweelrea Mountain, was at the time of his stay at the end of the world. Even today, the hamlet cannot be reached by public transport.

Virtually all of the incidents and obiter dicta narrated in this vignette have figured in previous biographies and memoirs. Yet they retain their unnerving strangeness. Unrecapturable to those who did not experience it directly, Wittgenstein's charisma, the sheer spell of his outwardly meagre presence must have been extraordinary. How else can one explain the impact on other men's and women's personal lives and memories of quite banal advocacies for decency, for truthfulness, for absolute scruple in the handling of language, a good many of which closely reflect Wittgenstein's imitation of the later Tolstoy? When, however, it comes to politics, a number of Wittgenstein's pronouncements, emitted in both Cambridge and Ireland, are simply stupid. No other word will do. Not only did Wittgenstein, on a by no means cursory visit to the Soviet Union in 1935, grasp little of the nature of the regime, but the ascent of Nazism left him either indifferent or blind. To the very last moment, he dismissed the possibility of Hitler's Anschluss of Austria or, after the event, that his family might be in any danger! A man capable of saying that to loathe Hitler was as futile as being in a rage with God does seem capable of saying almost anything.

Richard Wall lives in Austria and publishes also in German. He is a designer and a painter as well as a writer. The title of his most recent publication, HerzAsphaltMorder GrubenRhapsod ie, HeartAsphalt MurdererPitsRhapsodie, does suggest an elective affinity not only with the daemonism of Ireland. The black-and-white photographs which illustrate this monograph are near to amateurish. This enhances their persuasion. The gloom of St Patrick's Hospital in Dublin (a vital venue both in Wittgenstein's flirtations with the medical profession and in his own search for peace of mind), the misère of Rosroe, are shown unadorned, but so is the silent wonder of the Wicklow Mountains and of Kylemore Lake.

With Terry Eagleton's witty Wittgenstein novel, Saints and Scholars, and Richard Murphy's poem 'The Philosopher and the Birds', Wall provides an unforgettable understanding of 'Irish Wittgenstein'. It is a discreet jewel.

 George Steiner has just been appointed Commandeur dans l'ordres des Arts et Des Lettres by the French Minister of Culture

webTitle: The world of books: More fascinating than most Tories

fields.headline: More fascinating than most Tories
fields.trailText: Robert McCrum on the potential million-pound world of Peter Mandelson
fields.body:
On the day that Peter Mandelson was toppled from the greasy pole, I happened to be in conversation with a well-known literary agent. The talk turned to the kind of advance the ex-Minister might be able to command for his memoirs. 'You know,' said my friend, speaking on the assumption that such a book proposal would dish the dirt pretty freely, open the Pandora's Box of Millbank and so forth, 'taking into consideration the potential serial rights income, we're looking at a figure close to one million pounds.'

I am certain that Mr Mandelson has no intention of writing his memoirs just yet, and absolutely convinced that if he were to do so at some point in the future he would betray neither the Project in general nor his New Labour colleagues in particular. Even if he were to do so, the sales performances of recent political memoirs do not suggest a reliable return on such a colossal investment.

In the last year or so, we have seen the publication of Norman Lamont's In Office, Paddy Ashdown's diaries and John Major's autobiography. Lamont's self-important volume was remaindered before it was fully reviewed. Ashdown's vainglorious jottings immediately became a House of Commons joke. Only the ex-Prime Minister's Dickensian life disturbed the prevailing torpor at the cash registers of the nation's bookshops.

Yet, perhaps because the late Alan Clark hit the jackpot with the first volume of his political diaries, publishers continue to hope against hope that a disgraced figure like Mandelson will be the goose who lays the golden egg. The odds are against it. Mandelson, of course, is several million times more fascinating than most Tories you care to think of, and there's no doubt that his memoirs would attract a larger and better class of reader. But even then, you'd have to sell an awful lot of books to justify a million-pound advance.

So the puzzle remains. Why do publishers continue to stump up such extraordinary amounts of money for a certain kind of fashionable book when they must know in their secret hearts that pigs will fly, and the Earth found to be flat before they will see even a modest return on their initial outlay?

Actually, in the catalogue of genres in which publishers will cheerfully lose an entire wardrobe of bespoke shirts, political memoirs are a com paratively humdrum item. Consider, for instance, the extraordinary money some publishers will spend on acquiring the British rights to unpublished novels by obscure American novelists. I know of at least one conglomerate that has just celebrated the new year by rustling up a telephone number advance for some unknown New Yorker's unlikely new fiction.

Well, good luck to him and his agent, but, as with political memoirs, the omens for future success are extraordinarily discouraging. Although it's impossible to escape the profound Americanisation of our language and culture, it's an odd feature of both the British and American book trades that transplanted authors sell almost as badly as ex-politicians. In America, you'll find that the exclusive class of British author known by their surnames (Follett, Hornby, le Carré, Harris, Rowling) is well represented on the big-city bestseller lists. The American literary press also pays a disproportionate amount of attention to big names from the English literary world. But go into any regional American bookstore and you'll look in vain for British books. There's no call for them.

In London, similar conditions prevail. Grisham, King and Clancy pop up regularly on our bestseller lists. Important contemporary writers like Updike, Roth, Bellow and Mailer command yards of review space, but they don't really sell.

It's a strange but remarkable fact that in the past 25 years, only three North American writers of consequence have sold in significant quantities in the United Kingdom: Tom Wolfe, Carol Shields and Garrison Keillor.

Last year, The Observer, among others, paid extravagant attention to the young American bestseller, Dave Eggers, author of A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius , one of the most remarkable debut volumes of recent years. Despite the widespread acclaim, Eggers's sales in the UK fell a long way short of 50,000 copies.

None of this is new. Hemingway and Fitzgerald never sold well here in their lifetimes. Books by and about politicians like Reagan, Kennedy and Kissinger rarely achieve the sales that match the attention they receive.

Oddly enough, in the political arena, the only politician whose writing earned him a substantial income out of office on both sides of the Atlantic was Anglo-American: Winston Churchill.

And oddly enough he is, so far as I know, the only politician in the last 100 years to survive two successive Cabinet resignations. Perhaps Mr Mandelson should take up his pen after all.

But go into any regional American bookstore and you'll look in vain for British books. There's no call for them. In London, similar conditions prevail. Grisham, King and Clancy pop up regularly on our bestseller lists. Important contemporary writers like Updike, Roth, Bellow and Mailer command yards of review space, but they don't really sell. It's a strange but remarkable fact that in the past 25 years, only three North American writers of consequence have sold in significant quantities in the United Kingdom: Tom Wolfe, Carol Shields and Garrison Keillor. Last year, The Observer, among others, paid extravagant attention to the young American bestseller, Dave Eggers, author of A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius , one of the most remarkable debut volumes of recent years. Despite the widespread acclaim, Eggers's sales in the UK fell a long way short of 50,000 copies. None of this is new. Hemingway and Fitzgerald never sold well here in their lifetimes. Books by and about politicians like Reagan, Kennedy and Kissinger rarely achieve the sales that match the attention they receive. Oddly enough, in the political arena, the only politician whose writing earned him a substantial income out of office on both sides of the Atlantic was Anglo-American: Winston Churchill. And oddly enough he is, so far as I know, the only politician in the last 100 years to survive two successive Cabinet resignations. Perhaps Mr Mandelson should take up his pen after all. robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Children's choice: Letters from the Inside by John Marsden

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.standfirst: Letters from the Inside by John Marsden
fields.trailText: Letters from the Inside by John Marsden
fields.body:
LETTERS FROM THE INSIDE

John Marsden

Macmillan £3.99, pp146

Buy it at a discount at BOL

The title is an absolute clue to the reality of this extraordinarily sensitive and engaging novel, but you don't realise it until you are well and truly hooked into the story. The wonderful, late Robert Courmier (and if your young teens don't own his books, go and put that right now - and read them yourself) describes this novel as unforgettable and he's right. It lingers in the mind because of the But whats? in its closure and the secrecies and ambivalencies of the text. But don't let that put you off. It is also realistic and down-to-earth.

This is an epistolary novel and the plot is simple. Two teenage girls start writing to each other after one answers an ad in a magazine. They chat about their families, their pets, their boyfriends. But how truthful are they being? One of them, at least, is hiding something. As the letters progress, the shocking truth starts to emerge. This is a story of a meeting of minds, a true friendship and a real mutual dependence. The ending will shock you and, as Courmier said 'strangle your heart'. For 14 ups.

webTitle: Review: Idolising Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art by Anthony Julius

fields.headline: Just idol speculation?
fields.standfirst: Idolising Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art by Anthony Julius  is a  new exploration of Jewish art that celebrates its 'otherness'
fields.trailText: Idolising Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art by Anthony Julius is a new exploration of Jewish art that celebrates its 'otherness'
fields.body:
Idolising Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art

Anthony Julius

Thames and HUdson, £8.95, pp120

Buy it at a discount at BOL

In 1955, the abstract expressionist painter Clyfford Still, notorious for his mistrust of conventional art criticism, wrote of the paintings of Mark Rothko: 'When they are hung in a tight phalanx, as he would have them hung, and flooded with the light he demands that they receive, the tyranny of his ambition to suffocate or crush all who stand in his way becomes fully manifest... it is not without significance, therefore, that the surfaces of these paintings reveal gestures of negation, and that their means are the devices of seduction and assault. Not I, but himself, has made it clear that his work is of frustration, resentment and aggression.'

For Still, who described his own non-representational painting as 'pictorial meditations on life, death, and the persistence of spirit', the absence of any tradition of metaphor, symbol or mythology in Rothko's art means that the gallery-goer is helpless to pursue his or her own voyage of creative discovery, prevented from engaging with a Rothko painting in any other terms than those already laid down by the artist himself. Rothko's 'iconoclasm', in other words, his shattering of the recognisable conventions of imaging, becomes, in execution, unacceptably coercive.

In Idolising Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art, Anthony Julius proposes an identifiably 'Jewish' tradition in art which rejects (as Still maintains Rothko does) the continuous and largely unbroken tradition of Christian figurative representation and classical mythological imagery which has defined Western art since the Renaissance. The observant Jew is bound by the biblical injunction: 'Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of anything that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth.' A distinctively Jewish art, Julius argues, engages with the unease generated by Judaism's fundamental iconoclasm, and the consciously idolatrous nature of the high tradition in Christian art. As a serious alternative to the mainstream, such an art emerges with modernism at the beginning of the twentieth century.

The moment of modernism is, conventionally, the moment at which art scrutinises the traditional ways of conveying meaning, dismantles them and announces that from now on meanings have to be rebuilt, without the benefit of history. When the agreed-on order, stories and images are emptied out, to become simply fragments in a palette of possibilities the artist manipulates at will, then, finally, according to Julius, the Jewish artist can get on with a distinctive artistic agenda.

There are two obvious problems with this argument. One is, as Julius himself readily admits, that the attraction of art for Jewish artists such as Marc Chagall and Mark Rothko is that it is transgressive of all representational 'rules': 'Not only did art defy family expectations for a bourgeois career, it was also contrary to Jewish tradition. Rothko himself wrote, "Without monsters and gods, art cannot enact our drama: art's most profound moments express this frustration."'

There seems no intrinsic reason, then, why an artist designated 'Jewish' should not draw upon the repertoire of canonical Christian artistic symbols (the crucifixion, the Madonna and child) to produce a conscious tension between the 'given' (Christian iconography) and his or her own creative impulse. But Julius's argument for symbolic separateness forces him to the conclusion that because of its imaginative adaptation of Christian iconography, the work of a painter as distinguished and distinctive as Chagall nevertheless fails his test of Jewishness: 'What Chagall's career demonstrates is that the Jewish artist can also contribute to the dominant, non-Jewish artistic repertoire. But for Jewish art, this in itself is not enough.'

The second problem with Julius's argument, though, is one which makes me more uneasy. Idolising Pictures insists on the absolute distinctness of Jewish cultural experience, because of the injunction in Exodus, and on the importance of an equivalently distinctive art for the framing of Jewish identity. This is classic 'allosemitism' - the setting the Jews apart in society, as people radically different from all others, needing separate concepts to describe and comprehend them. According to this view, Jews are unassimilable 'others', permanently available as a reference point for social and cultural unease. As Zymunt Bauman describes it: 'The Jew is ambivalence incarnate. And ambivalence is ambivalence mostly because it cannot be contemplated without ambivalent feeling, it is simultaneously attractive and repelling.'

Such an affirmation of disturbing difference, attributable to a single group on grounds of some fundamental ethnic altereity, does not seem to me a helpful one for an art critic to make at the beginning of the twenty-first century. It leads directly to Julius's privileging art which is hectoring and bullying in the message it seeks to convey. It tempts him into overlooking what in other contexts he himself would be only too ready to recognise - that art is tribal (as Antony Gormley puts it), not because it is sectarian, but because its resonances are inevitably culturally inclusive. The many diasporas which are included in contemporary Britain derive their senses of identity not by rejecting a long indigenous tradition in art and literature, but by productively placing it in tension with the variety of representational alternatives to which they have access.

It is, surely, a vigorous struggle with the culturally local that gives the work of artists like R.B. Kitaj or Anselm Kiefer its lasting power and significance. Not their status as Jews (I had never thought about the 'Jewishness' of either before I read Julius's book), but their engagement with the perennial predicament of humanity. As one critic wrote recently of Kitaj: 'In a world where the centre will not hold, Kitaj turns for succour to those who, faced with the violence that is the world's constant refrain, themselves affirm life in their writing and painting, in their allegiances and convictions. To glimpse homages and icons in Kitaj's paintings, ghosts of others who went before, is to see what may be the only beauty vouchsafed us on our doomed journey through an alien countryside.'

Is such an artistic practice specifically Jewish? Personally, I prefer to think that it is part of a shared project in which each and every one can, and ought to, participate.

webTitle: Review:  The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians

fields.headline: Thank you for the music...
fields.standfirst: ...and the musicians. They're all here in the 29 volumes of The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians that cover everything. Well, almost
fields.trailText: ...and the musicians. They're all here in the 29 volumes of The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians that cover everything. Well, almost
fields.body:
The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians

Edited by Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell

£2,950, pp26,390 approx

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Gnocchi, according to an entry in the second edition of New Grove, was a prodigious seventeenth-century Italian who composed five dozen masses. No couch dumpling, he also travelled extensively and wrote a 25-volume history of ancient Greece before becoming maestro di cappella at Brescia Cathedral at the late age of 85. This information appears under 'Spoof articles', a new entry wisely added to safeguard against any fantasy concoctions slipped in by playful or (given some of the unpublishable accounts of putting this dictionary together) vengeful sub-editors, as occurred in the 1980 New Grove on which this edition is based. The point about Gnocchi is that he was real. Why make up composers, the writer asks, when life throws up such glorious oddities?

With 29 volumes of New Grove II consisting of 25 million words from which to choose, it might seem perverse to alight on Gnocchi. Serendipitous dictionary browsing, however, can reveal more about function and usage than a dogged masterplan of cross-reference. Even the fearless have to prepare themselves gently before negotiating the tougher challenges of Aleatory or Beneventan Chant, Xenakis or Zarzuela, not to mention a few well-known figures in between.

Seduced by Gnocchi, I turned to the individual entry under his name. This states that he became maestro di cappella when he was 34 years old. Of any octogenarian achievements there is no record. Why the discrepancy? Does the lexicographer's left hand know what the right is writing, or was this a double spoof? Comparison with the 1980 version reveals that the writer of the spoof article based his information on the old Gnocchi entry. Since then, the composer's dates have been revised. This exercise, trivial and hair-splitting, reveals worrying haste in this vast enterprise. If a dictionary is not consistent with itself, what hope is there for the reader? For £190 per year, Grove Online (www.grovemusic.com) will remedy errors and keep information up to date, vital for living musicians whose moving on waits for no hard-back. As yet it remains only text-based, a useful adjunct to the book but not a replacement for those who like turning pages.

The real puzzle is why a new printed edition has been issued now? Despite expansion and revision, especially on major composers, it is essentially the same beast with a change of cover from brown to blue. Improved essays on Haydn, Schubert and Schumann, among others, are stimulating but not essential. Twenty years is too soon to revisit the entire history of music. Many of the alterations are simply tinkerings: a few lines excised, a longer (or, often, shorter) bibliography, a different photograph, an inexplicable reordering of words. Thus the stage designer and architect Schinkel has shrunk by a dozen lines; an illustration from his important 1816 design for The Magic Flute has been replaced by a murky line drawing of the Berlin Schauspielhaus. By contrast Schenker, the formidable theorist who gave his name to a crucial form of twentieth-century musical analysis, benefits from a cogent new article and exhaustive bibliography.

The much publicised additions could simply have been added online, or published as a supplement. An assiduous piece on gay and lesbian music struggles to incorporate a mass of disparate ideas, some provocative, some dubious. One sentence in particular is still giv ing pause for thought: 'Threatened masculinity tends to see all musicians and their activities as feminine and to value (or devalue) them accordingly.'

Coverage of world music, though impressively prominent and with generous illustration, is necessarily tentative in tone. The hulking shadow of political correctness lurks. To ask one UK-based area editor, however well informed, to cover all 'non-Western and traditional music' smacks of tokenism. Yet perhaps the balance is correct; whatever anyone says to the contrary, Grove is first and foremost a dictionary of Western art music. Matters of form and technique, overseen by the veteran editor, Stanley Sadie, benefit from this wider outlook. Hemiola, for example, a metrical 'step and a half' found in French Baroque music and Viennese waltzes, now also carries a reference to Andalusian and Central American folkdances and to the song 'America' in Bernstein's West Side Story . Whether this fashionably increased field of vision justifies the epic scale of the undertaking is open to debate.

Grove is often at its best at the margins: a pithy entry on Paul Bowles, whose cult status has grown in the past decade, describes his music as 'witty, aphoristic and tuneful', which is all you need to know. Oscar Wilde makes a lively 34-line appearance and the entry on Frank Zappa is a model of precision and insight. Adelard of Bath and his theories on celestial harmonies are in for the first time, not a moment too soon (he died c.1150). The arcane distinctions between the 'pennywhistle [tin whistle]' and the 'tin whistle [pennywhistle]' are discussed with rare detail and sobriety. If only the contributions on living musicians were not so woefully drab.To characterise a world-famous string player by his 'fine tone', a countertenor by his 'strikingly individual' voice or an organist by his 'powerful intellect' is inadequate. Colour, personality and anecdote seem to have been forbidden. Given the general air of blandness, to find anything quirky or wayward comes as a shock. Did the admirable Lindsay Quartet, still mid-career, deserve quite so caustic an entry, especially when lesser groups are covered in inconclusive, neutral terms?

The quality of material on those composers who have become part of history since 1980 is uneven. An illuminating essay on the American John Adams shines out as an instance of lucid, analytical writing whereas the piece on Thomas Ades, long for a composer still in the foothills of his career, bursts with facts but ducks the difficult task of saying what the music sounds like. If Grove cannot talk plainly about harmonies and chord structures, who can?

One serious omission persists: there is still no entry on wit or humour in music. Alfred Brendel's 1989 essay on the comedy in Beethoven's 'Diabelli Variations' remains one of the best discussions of this elusive topic. Why not ask him to contribute? Alas this dusty, strait-laced Grove of academe is all too often merely a grave for the dead and a groove for their recordings. It grieves me to say that New Grove II at times is greying at its own temples.

webTitle: Review: The Bay of Angels by Anita Brookner

fields.headline: Those happy endings
fields.standfirst: Kate Kellaway on Anita Brookner's beautiful workmanship in The Bay of Angels
fields.trailText: Kate Kellaway on Anita Brookner's beautiful workmanship in The Bay of Angels
fields.body:
The Bay of Angels
Anita Brookner
Viking, £16.99, pp224
Buy it at a discount at BOL

If you had never read Anita Brookner before, you would be unreservedly delighted by this book. Its workmanship is such a treat. It is decorous and as finely made as a Queen Anne - or should that be Queen Anita? - chest of drawers. Brookner is a regal writer whose novels have sometimes seemed to imply that happiness itself is vulgar. But in The Bay of Angels she seems determined to turn over a new leaf. She declares her unusual intention: she is to investigate happy endings.

A widow, Anne, and her daughter, Zoe, live together in hopeful passivity, proficient at mutual solitude, as if confined to a Gwen John painting. But Zoe is confident, rightly, that this state of affairs will not last: 'But I did know, or was convinced, that our story would have a happy ending, not realising that there is no proper ending in human affections until time provides an ending to which we must all submit.' (Observe the formidable way the sentence doesn't draw breath until it catches up with its own death.)

Anne remarries. Simon is kind, elderly and rich. He rescues the two women from their elegant penury but may not be a reliable purveyor of happiness. He does not seem in perfect health, his business affairs are mysterious, he is dismayingly voyeuristic when Zoe's sexy boyfriend Adam comes to stay. What will become of this ménage?

Zoe is expert at attempting to answer questions of this kind. She lives in a subjunctive mood. Much of the book pursues her mournful imaginings of what her future may hold; variations on themes of solitude and disappointment. And when her stepfather dies suddenly and her mother is admitted to a sanatorium, she imagines the future after her mother has been discharged: 'My life would be hedged in by duties, most of them of an unwanted nature.'

But no one can foretell their own future and Zoe's predictions are a waste of time. I found this novel chilling but never dull (even though it often describes chronic stasis). It is a tribute to Brookner's power as a narrator that she manages to make Zoe's situation so engrossing. Yet Zoe's take on life is depressing. It is like being admitted into a sanatorium where everything is beautifully done for one, but there is no way out.

House arrest, the sense of being immured, is a state Anita Brookner writes about better than anyone. Here she tries to give herself the slip but happiness goes against the grain. Zoe finds love with a person who borders on ineligibility. For a start, he has an unmarried sister living with him. Perhaps she might serve as the heroine for Brookner's twenty-first novel.

 Read an Interview with Anita Brookner here.
