A widow, Anne, and her daughter, Zoe, live together in hopeful passivity, proficient at mutual solitude, as if confined to a Gwen John painting. But Zoe is confident, rightly, that this state of affairs will not last: 'But I did know, or was convinced, that our story would have a happy ending, not realising that there is no proper ending in human affections until time provides an ending to which we must all submit.' (Observe the formidable way the sentence doesn't draw breath until it catches up with its own death.) Anne remarries. Simon is kind, elderly and rich. He rescues the two women from their elegant penury but may not be a reliable purveyor of happiness. He does not seem in perfect health, his business affairs are mysterious, he is dismayingly voyeuristic when Zoe's sexy boyfriend Adam comes to stay. What will become of this ménage? Zoe is expert at attempting to answer questions of this kind. She lives in a subjunctive mood. Much of the book pursues her mournful imaginings of what her future may hold; variations on themes of solitude and disappointment. And when her stepfather dies suddenly and her mother is admitted to a sanatorium, she imagines the future after her mother has been discharged: 'My life would be hedged in by duties, most of them of an unwanted nature.' But no one can foretell their own future and Zoe's predictions are a waste of time. I found this novel chilling but never dull (even though it often describes chronic stasis). It is a tribute to Brookner's power as a narrator that she manages to make Zoe's situation so engrossing. Yet Zoe's take on life is depressing. It is like being admitted into a sanatorium where everything is beautifully done for one, but there is no way out. House arrest, the sense of being immured, is a state Anita Brookner writes about better than anyone. Here she tries to give herself the slip but happiness goes against the grain. Zoe finds love with a person who borders on ineligibility. For a start, he has an unmarried sister living with him. Perhaps she might serve as the heroine for Brookner's twenty-first novel.  Read an Interview with Anita Brookner here.

webTitle: Review: Brief Interviews with Hideous Men by David Foster Wallace

fields.headline: The good, the bad...
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Merritt on   the most influential voice of the new generation of US writers  - Brief Interviews with Hideous Men by David Foster Wallace
fields.trailText: Stephanie Merritt on the most influential voice of the new generation of US writers - Brief Interviews with Hideous Men by David Foster Wallace
fields.body:
Brief Interviews with Hideous Men

David Foster Wallace

Abacus £6.99, pp273

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Long before Dave Eggers attracted critical attention for the tongue-in-cheek metafictional self-deconstructing style in A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, David Foster Wallace (who generously gave Eggers a cover quote) had been honing that particular voice to perfection.

These stories are difficult to categorise, roaming wilfully across the boundaries of genres and inventing new ones, a fact that Wallace appears to be self-mockingly acknowledging in 'Octet': 'You are, unfortunately, a fiction writer. You are attempting a cycle of very short belletristic pieces, pieces which as it happens are not contes philosophiques and not vignettes or scenarios or allegories or fables, exactly, though neither are they really qualifiable as "short stories"...'

The brief interviews of the title are interspersed with the other stories and form a series of overheard conversations transcribed as if from tape. One of Wallace's eminent talents is his ability to juxtapose pseudo-academic discourse with unerring recreations of modern American vernacular, and the variety of voices, from the blue-collar to the would-be intellectual, add up to a comically unappealing and disconcertingly vivid portrait of the American male and his view of women.

Some of the stories are dense with footnotes and ironic self-reference to the point where they defeat their own purpose as stories (which is probably the whole point), but the majority are ingeniously funny and conceal surprisingly wise insights into the quirks and self-deceptions of consumer society, and particularly the oddities of the ways in which the sexes view each other.

Wallace remains the most influential voice of the new generation of US writers that includes the likes of George Saunders and Jonathan Lethem, and this collection is stunning.

webTitle: Review: The Carpenter's Pencil by  Manuel Rivas

fields.headline: Lead in his pencil
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Merritt on a beautiful portrait of a brutal, ugly period of Spanish history in The Carpenter's Pencil by  Manuel Rivas
fields.trailText: Stephanie Merritt on a beautiful portrait of a brutal, ugly period of Spanish history in The Carpenter's Pencil by Manuel Rivas
fields.body:
The Carpenter's Pencil

Manuel Rivas

The Harvill Press, £12, pp192

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Choosing to write in a minority language is in itself a political act, asserting a commitment to identity and cultural heritage. Manuel Rivas, a journalist on El País, writes his fiction in his native Galician, and The Carpenter's Pencil, first published in Spain in 1998, has quickly become the most widely-translated work in the history of Galician literature.

It follows the story of Dr Daniel Da Barca, a Galician republican activist imprisoned by Franco's Falangists during the Spanish Civil War. The memories of this time belong to Herbal, a guard who pursued Da Barca throughout his imprisonment and, many years later, recounts these adventures to a young prostitute in the brothel where he now works.

Rivas partially obscures his political sympathies behind a smokescreen of fable, romance and magic realism. 'I'm not interested in politics,' says the journalist who comes to interview Da Barca at the end of his life. 'I'm interested in the person.' But Da Barca's story shows that in true heroes, idealism and a commitment to one's fellows are inseparable. The pencil of the title belonged to an artist imprisoned with Da Barca, whom Herbal shot to save him from a tortuous execution. Herbal keeps the pencil as a trophy, but finds that when he tucks it behind his ear, he becomes involved in a dialogue with the dead artist, who shares with him the secrets of painting in recurring, enigmatic images, and urges him to stay close to Da Barca. The latter, like his namesake, the prophet Daniel, seems to enjoy divine protection; several times, he is taken out for execution but is always granted a reprieve.

Shifting the narrative from Da Barca's perspective to that of Herbal distances and romanticises the doctor and his wife, Marisa, while Herbal himself, viewing the lovers, especially Da Barca, with a mixture of awe, loyalty and hatred, appears as a kind of Bardolph figure. Even in Herbal's unpolished voice, Rivas's language has the sheen of poetry, decorated with peculiarly Spanish imagery - mimosas that 'flowered like candles on a roadside altar' or 'trains that crawled along like penitents with the cross on their shoulder'. The Carpenter's Pencil is a strange and haunting novel, seamlessly translated (by Jonathan Dunne), a sincere and beautiful portrait of a brutal, ugly period of Spanish history.

webTitle: Stressed-out staff driven to brink

fields.headline: Stressed-out staff driven to brink
fields.standfirst:
Pressure in most jobs is spiralling out of control, according to a major new survey. Can we find a way to break out of the anxiety loop
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pressure in most jobs is spiralling out of control, according to a major new survey. Can we find a way to break out of the anxiety loop.
fields.body:
Workplace stress has become so bad that thousands of workers are presenting themselves for treatment with symptoms similar to those of psychiatric outpatients, according to a major new investigation.

'This is not just a minor worry any more, it can be a serious crisis in people's lives,' said Professor John McLeod, who has completed a survey of 10,000 victims of workplace stress. 'The problem is definitely no longer linked only to management occupations. It now includes ordinary office workers and manual workers too.'

In the private sector, employees are suffering from the requirement to deliver higher and higher productivity per person. In the public sector, beleaguered staff are often being asked to bear greater degrees of responsibility with fewer resources.

'Among groups such as teachers, social workers and police officers, 25 per cent are now suffering from serious stress symptoms,' said McLeod. 'In other occupations, we're finding between 10 and 15 per cent of workers with problems.' Undiagnosed anxiety conditions now cause more lost days from work than complaints such as backache, hangovers and stomach upset.

Miriam West, from Swanage, Dorset, said: 'I worked for 15 years and was very successful but two years ago I began to feel almost frozen at work. I didn't know what it was. I hated the idea of going in to the office. I would just sit at weekends and in the evening doing almost nothing.

'When I was at work I constantly chastised myself for not doing enough. In retrospect, I was over-performing. I was setting standards for myself which I couldn't reach. My bosses were staggered when I decided to leave. They hadn't realised that the chaotic atmosphere they created was putting pressure on everyone else.

'But I only made the final decision to re-assess my career after seeing a counsellor. He encouraged me to work out exactly what was creating the pressure and how I could address it.'

Almost 1,000 major British firms already provide free stress counselling services to employees. Staff are referred for three to six sessions in the first instance.

'However much we try to minimise sources of stress in the workplace and however much we work to improve employee resilience to pressure, we have to acknowledge that there'll always be some people who need help,' says Dr Marian Roden, corporate medical director of SmithKline Beecham. 'The provision of counselling services ensures our staff always have somewhere to turn. Whether the primary source of stress lies within or outside the workplace, early resolution facilitates a rapid return to productivity.'

Mike Doig of Chevron Europe, an arm of the US oil company and another provider of workplace support, said: 'The evidence not only demonstrates the positive emotional outcomes of help, but also makes a first-rate business case. For every $1 we spend, we have saved between $6 and $10.'

The report suggests workplace counselling can reduce the incidence of office stress by 50 per cent. Efficiency savings include higher performance and lower levels of sickness and unexplained absence. Substance abuse - from alcohol to serious drugs - also falls among staff who have received help.

Dr Michael Reddy, whose company ICAS provides workplace counselling to businesses in Britain, said: 'It's not just a question of shopfloor versus management, as trade unions have often suggested. In this cost- and corner-cutting culture we are all in the stress firing line. Managers who work 16-hour days are as misguided as lorry drivers who fall asleep at the wheel.'

Miriam West insists that workplace counselling transformed her life. She has left the financial services industry and is setting up a landscape gardening business. 'I won't earn quite so much, but I'm immeasurably happier. One regret I do have is that I didn't take advice earlier. I think if I had seen someone five years ago, I might have found it much easier to change things at work. I might still be there, but happier.'

McLeod, of Abertay University, Dundee, says British reserve might be pre venting us admitting how awful our working lives are. 'American employees tend to be more positive about being counselled for workplace problems. Consequently they tell their mates. In British organisations, that admission is much less likely. If people were more willing to acknowledge that they had seen a workplace stress counsellor it would make it much easier for others to go.'

webTitle: Driving forces that stall cars

fields.headline: Driving forces that stall cars
fields.standfirst:
The industry's problems are compounded by autocracy as well as inbreeding, explains Bob Heller

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The industry's problems are compounded by autocracy as well as inbreeding, explains Bob Heller
fields.body:
The victims of Vauxhall's Luton closure have plenty of candidates for blame, from the high pound and the relative ease of British shutdowns to the hire-and-fire mentality of the American overlords. But the real cause runs deeper through decades of managerial mishaps.

The British managers bear some responsibility for the underlying, persistent weakness of the Vauxhall brand. But that's as nothing compared with the monumental mistakes of parent General Motors, at home and abroad. Entangled in bureaucracy, paralysed by inaction, drowning in excess costs, GM has wasted tens of billions on learning how not to run a mega-corporation.

Very few other car managements are in a position to hurl the first stone. Consider the present scene of devastation. Chrysler, quite recently the most profitable US carmaker by far, is bleeding millions so fast that its purchaser, Daimler-Benz, is buckling at the knees. Daimler not only overpaid ridiculously, but compounded this sin by heavy-handed and typically unsuccessful long-distance interference.

BMW is still licking its wounds from the inept takeover of Rover Group. But there is no comfort for British management in these foreign fiascos. Not only Rover but also its sister Land Rover were found wanting in fundamental management and manufacturing skills by their new owners. So, in spades, was Jaguar. The first American sent to the rescue by Ford declared its plant the worst he had ever seen, with the possible exception of the Gorki factory outside Moscow.

In fact, the list of ineptitudes is as long as the M1. Is there some pattern here? The carmakers have all that managers could desire: huge financial resources, vast expertise, armies of well- versed executives and specialists, global markets and public demand. How could they get so much so wrong?

The first answer is that this industry is highly inbred, dominated by company veterans who, like all their colleagues, adore playing with motors. Infusions of outside talent are rare, and so is jobhopping at the highest level. When jobs are hopped, as when a miffed Lee Iacocca quit Ford for Chrysler, the results can be electrifying. But Chrysler was a basket case then, as now. Others with bigger market shares, larger cash flows and greater conceit, which is endemic among car managers, are unlikely to place their heads on somebody else's block.

The conceit is compounded by a second fault - autocracy. The Western industry was originally created by all-powerful entrepreneurs. Their heirs can't match their genius, but grasp for their power. A bitter boardroom battle at Daimler thus ousted the company's top car man and left total control to Jürgen Schrempp, the mastermind (if that's the word) of the Chrysler fiasco. It's unfair to blame Schrempp for other flops, like the original instability of the A-cars or sluggish sales of the unsmart Smart. But he's certainly responsible for the halved share price and the sadly reduced reputation.

The misfiring of Mercedes is a textbook study in top-down management. Because of autocratic traditions, Western car firms have lagged behind the management trend towards self-managed teams whose leaders have genuine autonomy.

When the new approach has prevailed - as when Ford launched the Taurus in the US - the results have been spectacular. But the industry reverts to past form at the flip of a throttle. Even Ford forgot the Taurus lessons, rediscovering them in the Nineties with renewed success.

That exemplifies a third fault, cyclical mismanagement. Periodically one car firm leaps ahead of the pack. It's hard to believe, but for several years GM Europe was a star performer, clobbering a money-losing Ford. The usual reaction is to rejoice over the success, remove its architects to head office, and complacently watch while the star rapidly loses its lustre. In the process, basic errors are made, like allowing models to run too long before renewal (witness Vauxhall's battered Vectra).

That damages not only the model but the brand. A few years back, a top GM executive announced enthusiastically that his company had neglected its brands, and was now pouring effort into their nurture. That's like a football coach revealing that his club has discovered the importance of scoring goals. All GM's brands have lost power. One, Oldsmobile, has now died as a result. It was suicide. A fourth defect provides apparent excuse for these lapses. Schrempp's defenders would argue that the not-so-little local difficulties are mere blips in a long-term scheme for turning Mercedes into a full-line global manufacturer, competing in every market and segment.

Ford, another long-termer, is in the throes of a second major reshaping, while GM has started yet another. This addiction to upheavals disorients good managers and makes bad ones worse, while unwanted secondary evils often outweigh good results.

The British, like the Vauxhall workers, are injured bystanders. The insularity and narrow-mindedness of the long-gone native manufacturers barred Britain from sharing in the fast-growing markets and laid companies bare to foreign competition. The consolation used to be that modern, well-managed foreigners - first Ford and GM, then the Japanese - kept the UK in car manufacturing, even though on a relatively humble scale. Expanding Japanese presence, led by Nissan's achievements at Sunderland, sparked a genuine recovery in output.

But poor parental performance, in a Japanese industry dominated by Toyota and Honda, is to blame. Now the Luton closure, Dagenham's withdrawal from making Fords, and the darkened prospects for Sunderland are sounding another retreat. It's too late to stop this slide. But managers in other industries - and politicians in government - had best take notice. Without growing customer franchises, indigenous research and product development, autonomous local managers and genuinely world-class management, the automotive debacle will be repeated elsewhere - up to and including the star industries of the New Economy.

webTitle: How to keep your PC free from viruses

fields.headline: How to keep your PC free from viruses
fields.trailText: 1 Recognise the damage they can do - making your computer unusable and infecting your contacts by sending bad emails to everyone in your address book. When Elizabeth's PC was recently attacked, she was unable to use it for a week. 'It was doing things like sending 18 to one person, which was embarrassing.'
fields.body:
1 Recognise the damage they can do - making your computer unusable and infecting your contacts by sending bad emails to everyone in your address book. When Elizabeth's PC was recently attacked, she was unable to use it for a week. 'It was doing things like sending 18 to one person, which was embarrassing.'

2 Be suspicious especially about emails with attachments. Most viruses come as software programs in an attachment. 'The worst thing you can do is to click out of curiosity,' says Eric Doyle of Computer Weekly. Most viruses have a 'subject line', written to intrigue - 'I love you', for instance. As soon as you click on the attachment, the virus is in your system.

3 Look closely at the description of the attachment file. Those that end '.exe' or '.vbs' - and others that suggest they contain software programmes - are the most suspicious. Those that end '.doc' and then after a long gap 'vbs' are particularly worrying as the author is trying to hide the 'vbs' ending. VBS stands for Visual Basic Script, an easy programming language that makes it easier for people to create viruses.

4 Ensure that your system's anti-virus software is working and updated at least once a week. Most PCs come with the software built in, although you may need to turn it on and increase the automatic update. You can get a free health check on www.symantec.com makers of the best-known A-V software, Norton Anti-Virus.

5 Go through an Internet Service Provider that offers checking. None of the customers of ISP Starnet (www.star.net.uk contracted the 'Love Bug' last May because its A-V checking arm, Message Labs, weeds out all emails first that contain suspect software).

webTitle: Internet banking: End the high street bank heist

fields.headline: End the high street bank heist
fields.standfirst: Marianne Curphey  on how to click on to a good deal and get a better deal from your bank
fields.trailText: Marianne Curphey on how to click on to a good thing and get a better deal from your bank.
fields.body:
Believe it or not, your bank has been 'ripping you off' for years. It's nothing personal and it's all perfectly legal. You could be losing out by as much as £400 a year, as a few pounds disap pear here and there in cash machine charges, overdraft fees, poor interest on deposit accounts, low savings rates and hefty charges for small businesses.

Put another way, you could be £1 a day better off if you changed to a more competitive bank account.

According to an investigation ordered by the Government and carried out by Don Cruickshank, the chairman of the London Stock Exchange and former telecoms watchdog, the UK public is paying between £3 billion and £5bn a year too much for banking services. This amounts to between £40 and £400 per household, his report stated.

Here are some of the ways in which your hard-earned money disappears:

 Overdrafts: We've all needed one at some time, but nearly half of us pay about £5 a month for the privilege.

 Low savings rates: Many of the high street banks pay very low rates of interest on savings accounts.

 Obsolete accounts: Banks have also come under fire for failing to tell customers about new savings accounts paying better rates of interest.

 Cash machine charges: If you withdraw money from another bank's machines, your bank may charge you a so-called 'disloyalty fee'. Banks are scrapping these for their own customers, but anomalies remain and you may be charged for using an ATM which is not owned by your bank.

Until recently it was difficult to change bank accounts, and there was little incentive to do so. Why switch to another provider when no one seemed to have a good word to say about any of the banks?

This is where the internet comes in. Until now, most people had a lifelong relationship with their bank, through either apathy or lack of suitable alternatives. The internet, however, has introduced new competition - and lots more choice.

The internet is also a tremendous resource that you can use to shop around for the best deal.

At the click of a mouse you can discover which financial services companies offer the best savings rates, the most competitive personal loans and the best mortgage rates for you.

New companies are arriving on the scene, with more transparent accounts and better interest rates. The old industry players are having to buck up.

But before you take your bank account online there are a number of important questions you should ask yourself:

What are the advantages for me?

Internet banks tend to pay better savings rates than high street banks and many building societies. They are keen to attract new customers, and internet operations are much cheaper to run than a network of branches.

You may find comparatively high rates from postal bank accounts, but these do not give you immediate access to your money; some internet current accounts do.

Online banking offers you greater personal power. You sort out your bills at a time convenient to you. You have more information instantly at your fingertips. You can compare the rates offered by other providers to ensure that your internet bank is continuing to offer a competitive savings rate.

What type of account is suitable for me?

There are two types of internet bank:'Clicks and bricks' banks are the online presence of established banks such as NatWest, Lloyds TSB and Barclays.

The clearing banks and converted building societies, such as Halifax and Woolwich, all have websites and internet banking services. The sites vary in sophistication and ease of navigation, but at the very minimum their online account should allow you to:

 View your balance

 Transfer funds between accounts

 Pay bills online, including setting up payments for when you go away on holiday

 Set up standing orders and direct debits

The drawback is that most of these accounts offer online access as an extra service, and the rates and charges don't tend to be any better than those available for other customers.

'Clicks only' or 'standalone' banks are either new entrants to the UK banking market or are entirely new businesses set up by existing banks specifically for the internet.

They don't have any high street branches, although a number have telephone helplines.

Some of the better known brand names are First-e, Egg, and Smile. Some of the new internet banks concentrate on savings, because savings accounts are much cheaper to administer than current accounts.

Some, such as Egg, offer online credit cards. Others, - IF from Halifax and Virgin One from Virgin Direct, for example - offer a better deal if you bundle your savings and mortgage borrowing together into one account. This is known as a flexible current account and is popular in Australia.

Do you want a pure internet account?

Before you choose an account you need to decide whether you want support from a telephone helpline and the option to transact over the telephone from time to time, or whether you can cope with a pure internet account. The latter may penalise you with charges or loss of interest if you try to do transactions over the telephone.

There's a lot of choice, and no two accounts are the same. This makes it a matter of personal preference, and depends a lot on how comfortable you feel with using the internet and whether you are content to carry out all your transactions online.

What are your priorities?

Do you want convenience, high interest on a current account, combined savings and current account, telephone support?

If you are looking for the best interest rates on current account balances, you are unlikely to find them offered by the 'clicks and bricks' account from your high street bank. Most of these websites assume you are an existing current account customer.

How do I get at my money when I need it?

Some accounts allow you to access your cash via an ATM; others offer the option of transfers to another account.

It is important to find this out before you choose your account, because you may be charged for certain extra services.

E-asy as one, two, three

This is an extract from E-cash, a step by step guide to managing your money online by Marianne Curphey. Find out how to control your own finances, search for a mortgage online, move bank accounts, submit your tax form online, invest in shares and find the best websites for financial information.

E-cash is published by Pearson Education and is available at bookshops or via www.bol.com.

Marianne Curphey is editor of MoneyUnlimited, the personal finance website of the Guardian and part of the GuardianUnlimited website. Find out more about banking, share dealing and homebuying online at www.moneyunlimited.co.uk.

webTitle: Cracking up?

fields.headline: Cracking up?
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: DO YOU....
fields.body:
DO YOU....

1 Have aching shoulders or backache?

2 Suffer from nervous tics, twitches, foot tapping, scratching?

3 Say yes to any extra work?

4 Linger on the phone to have someone to talk to?

5 Give unrealistic deadlines?

6 Miss deadlines?

7 Make an unusual number of mistakes?

8 Tackle work unsystematically?

9 Pick verbal fights?

10 Get pushed around?

11 Refuse to change routines?

12 Agonise over trivial issues?

13 Work longer and longer to achieve the same or less?

14 Suffer from sleep disorders?

HOW DO YOU SCORE?

Up to five symptoms: Try to identify the person or problem making you feel anxious and think of ways in which you can react differently to the pressures - whether to avoid, confront or negotiate.

Five to 10: You need to see a doctor. Definitely time to have a holiday. It may be time to re-think your career.

More than 10: Psychological burnout is a genuine possibility. It's time to stop - change your job, change your hours and get therapy/counselling.

Phillip Hodson, British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy

webTitle: Should we snitch over colleagues' emails?

fields.headline: Should we snitch over colleagues' emails?
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: My employer's new emails policy states that we have to show management any sexually explicit or inappropriate emails we receive at work. We have been told that we face disciplinary proceedings if we do not snitch on our colleagues. Is this legal?
fields.body:
My employer's new emails policy states that we have to show management any sexually explicit or inappropriate emails we receive at work. We have been told that we face disciplinary proceedings if we do not snitch on our colleagues. Is this legal?

This seems extreme. Legally, employers can take a heavy-handed route, but it may not be upheld by an employment tribunal if they sacked someone who then claimed unfair dismissal.

To dismiss fairly, there are two hurdles - a suitable reason, such as lack of capability, or a wrongful act under the employment contract.

The decision must also be reasonable - bosses cannot, for example, fire an employee for being one minute late. A tribunal may find that sacking someone who did not snitch was also unreasonable. After all, if you weren't fired you would still be expected to work with that colleague. Others may make your working life very awkward.

The practical difficulty is that this could take a long time to be tested in the courts - especially if your company disciplined rather than sacked people. The best approach may be a collective one, through a group of you or a union suggesting that the snitching clause be left out for the sake of trust and good personal relations.

webTitle: Jobs for the BAs

fields.headline: Jobs for the BAs
fields.standfirst:
Your choice of degree can affect earning power for a whole lifetime, says Jim Pollard

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Your choice of degree can affect earning power for a whole lifetime, says Jim Pollard
fields.body:
If you're a graduate, can you remember exactly what you studied and why? Might you have made a different decision had you known that £250,000 or more could be riding on it?

According to research by the University of Warwick published last year, a woman studying law could expect to earn on average £10,000 more in every year of her working life than one who chose agriculture. (A male graduate could earn a further £7,400 a year, but that's another story.)

Now the latest edition of What Do Graduates Do?, the annual study published jointly by the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services, the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service and the Higher Education Careers Services Unit, suggests that graduates in design studies are three times more likely to be unemployed than those who studied law. Suddenly, a decision so often taken on a teenage whim assumes a major importance.

In the past, some of the newer vocational degrees, such as media studies, have had a rough ride, but the evidence shows that they do lead to jobs. Indeed, media studies is the fifth most employable discipline, according to What Do Graduates Do? Only graduates in computing, accountancy, business and civil engineering - four more respectable but equally vocational subjects - are more likely to be in jobs.

In the Warwick survey, too, the top earners were all graduates in vocational subjects: law, computing, business and medicine. Maths, in fifth place, was the top-earning academic discipline. But with this summer's graduates likely to enter the job market with debts of £12,000-15,000, according to the National Union of Students, you don't have to be a maths graduate to see that it takes a brave teenager to plump for a non-vocational degree these days.

So in 2001, is the writing on the wall for history and sociology? Lesley Knaggs, president of AGCAS, thinks not. 'There is a close correlation between some of the vocational subjects and good well-paid jobs,' she says. 'But if you look at the unemployment levels among these graduates, they're certainly not the lowest. If you don't make it in a vocational subject, or you change your mind, you could be in trouble because you then have to explain that apparent failure to a future employer.'

A vocational degree can be a big mistake if that subject is not your vocation. 'If you move into the wrong job and leave within six months, how's that going to help pay off your debts?' Knaggs asks.

Tony Higgins, chief executive of Ucas, agrees. 'The hard evidence is that virtually all graduates find jobs relevant to their academic qualification within a relatively short time. Higher education applicants must be encouraged to select courses which best suit their academic and personal strengths and interests, rather than being swayed by short-term inducements which may land them in careers they won't enjoy.'

Graduates of all types are hot property in the job market. Graduate unemployment has fallen every year since 1992. It is now 5.5 per cent six months after graduating, and as low as 2 per cent three years later. This is despite the continuing growth in the numbers of students. About 30 per cent of 18- year-olds now enter higher education - twice the rate of 10 years ago - and the Government has a target of 50 per cent.

This is a trend that could see employers looking for a little more from their graduate recruits than a blinkered vocationalism. 'With degrees becoming more commonplace and job-hunting more competitive, employers are looking for evidence of other "soft" skills,' says Knaggs.

The Employment Satisfaction Survey asked 127 graduate employers what they were looking for in a graduate. Their top 10 were a willingness to learn, commitment, dependability, self-motivation, teamwork, oral communication skills, co-operation, written communication skills, energy and self-management.

These are the sort of transferable skills that students with a broader approach to learning tend to develop - Higgins urges plenty of extracurricular activity, too - rather than those narrowly obsessed with the job market.

However, despite graduates' growing debt burden, more and more of them go on to post-graduate study. 'The rate is up to one in five,' says Lesley Knaggs, 'and at some institutions it's far higher.'

And it is here that academic graduates may be responding to a perceived need for greater vocationalism in their studies. Knaggs says: 'Some of these post-graduates are doing traditional training, such as teaching and law, but others are looking to add something business-related to their qualifications, or to develop their IT skills.'

Rob Aspinall, 38, is a university lecturer in English, a subject he didn't study at university, in Japan, a country he didn't visit until he was in his late twenties. 'I would say that someone who is very good at an obscure subject has a better chance than someone with a middling qualification at a more "suitable" subject,' he says. 'In other words, it is more important to be good at what you do, rather than to choose a subject just because it sounds like it might have more chance of getting you a job.'

Whatever your degree choice, there are signs that it is once again becoming a decision to be made sooner rather than later in life. After several years of growth, the number of mature students was down last year and Knaggs is concerned that it may continue. 'The debt burden may put mature students off more than younger ones,' she says. 'For them there are often other factors like a family or a mortgage that make the debt just too big a risk to take.'

So what should you do? The advice from careers advisers is to follow your heart, not the money. Graduates in less conventional degree subjects agree. Belinda Canham, 34, now a PR consultant, says: 'Look back at anyone's career path and you'll see it is littered with changes of direction, changes of mind, missed opportunities and opportunities taken. I think you should just enjoy your studies and keep an open mind about where they will lead you.'

It's just the sort of measured, historically aware overview you'd expect from someone who graduated in Greek civilisation and philosophy.
